HEADLINE: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: EUROPE; 
AUTONOMY EXPECTS PROFIT SHORTFALL

BYLINE:  By Suzanne Kapner 

 BODY:
 In another sign that the slowdown in the United States economy is spreading to Europe, Autonomy, a British software company, warned that first-quarter profit would fall below analyst estimates. Its shares fell 43 percent, to $:3.25, or $4.67. Autonomy now expects to earn 4 cents a share for the quarter that ended March 31 on revenue of $14 million to $15 million. Earnings will be reported on April 26. Michael Lynch, the chief executive, said the slowdown in orders for software came suddenly. "Almost without exception," he said, "we have been informed that purchasing decisions have been delayed."
 Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

HEADLINE: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; 
CANADA'S JOBLESS RATE IS UP

BYLINE:  By Timothy Pritchard 

 BODY:
 Canada's unemployment rate rose to 7 percent in March from 6.9 percent in February. While employers added almost 30,000 jobs last month, reversing a drop in February, the unemployment rate rose because more Canadians began looking for work. Other indicators show Canada's economy is following the United States into a slowdown, and analysts predict a quarter-point cut in interest rates by the Bank of Canada at its meeting on April 17.
 Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

HEADLINE: World Briefing 

 BODY:
 EUROPE

YUGOSLAVIA: PURSUING MILOSEVIC
A delegation from the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague handed Yugoslav officials an indictment and arrest warrant for former President Slobodan Milosevic, asking that he be transferred swiftly to The Hague for prosecution for war crimes. Mr. Milosevic was arrested Sunday by the Serbian police on charges of embezzlement and abuse of power and is being held in Belgrade's Central Prison. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

RUSSIA: TV TALKS BREAK DOWN
Talks between Russia's independent NTV television network and the state-dominated company Gazprom broke down, leaving both sides locked in conflict after Gazprom's hostile takeover of the network on Tuesday. NTV journalists met with Gazprom officials for less than an hour and asked the company to join them in an appeal to President Vladimir V. Putin. Gazprom said journalists walked out of talks after it refused their request. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

GERMANY: DISPUTE ON HOLOCAUST PAYMENTS
A meeting between Chancellor Gerhard Schroder and Prime Minister Jerzy Buzek of Poland ended with sharp disagreement over German compensation to Polish laborers forced to work by the Nazis. Poland wants immediate payments to former forced laborers, who are dying at the rate of one every 11 minutes according to Mr. Buzek. But Mr. Schroder insisted that legal disputes in New York over an overall compensation agreement must be cleared up before payments begin.
Roger Cohen (NYT)

GERMANY: PRESSURE ON TURKEY
Defense Minister Rudolf Scharping pressed Turkey to drop its objections to a 60,000-member rapid reaction force being readied by the European Union. Turkey, a member of NATO but not of the European Union, is uneasy about a force that would include its old rival, Greece. Mr. Scharping hinted that Turkey's application to the European Union could be adversely affected if its opposition continued. Roger Cohen (NYT)

BULGARIA: THROWING CROWN INTO RING
Bulgaria's former king, Simeon II, said he would lead a new political party -- the National Movement for King Simeon II -- in the June 17 general election. Simeon, 65, was exiled in 1946 and has lived in Madrid. He received a rapturous welcome on his first return to Bulgaria, in 1996, and made his announcement at his residence near the the capital. (Reuters)

AFRICA

MALAWI: THOUSANDS IN MISERY
Thousands of families are still homeless and struggling to recover from torrential rains and flooding that battered the country in February, the World Food Program reported. In early March, the government ran out of money to deal with the emergency. The World Food Program, a United Nations agency, issued an urgent appeal for donations. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

KENYA: ARRESTS IN DEADLY SCHOOL FIRE
Two teenage boys have been arrested in connection with a fire set in a school dormitory last month that killed 67 students, the police said. The youths were students at the Kyanguli Secondary School in Machakos. Survivors have said they believe that the blaze was set by students angry over the annulment of final exam results and demands that they pay school fees. (Associated Press)

MIDDLE EAST

ISRAEL: CRACKING DOWN FOR PASSOVER
Israel has commissioned 15 inspectors to fine any Israeli found eating bread in public during Passover in violation of the Bible, which forbids the consumption of bread and other foods containing yeast during the holiday. "The law regarding leavened foods should be respected by all," Interior Minister Eli Ishai of the ultra-Orthodox Shas Party said on Israeli radio. (Agence France-Presse)

ASIA

INDONESIA: SUHARTO AIDE JAILED
One of the most prominent cabinet ministers and economic managers under former President Suharto has been jailed while prosecutors question him about a major corruption case. The minister, Ginandjar Kartasasmita, led talks with the International Monetary Fund during Indonesia's economic crisis three years ago and helped persuade Mr. Suharto to resign. Seth Mydans (NYT)

AMERICAS

PERU: GENERAL ARRESTED ON DRUG CHARGES
General Nicolas de Bari Hermoza Rios, who led the armed forces through much of the government of former President Alberto K. Fujimori, was arrested on drug trafficking charges. Investigators said General Hermoza, who is retired, protected the operations of drug traffickers in the upper Huallaga Valley, one the world's main coca growing regions, between 1991 and 1993.Clifford Krauss (NYT)

NICARAGUA: UNION LEADERS REGAIN JOBS
A court has ordered the Taiwanese owners of a Managua clothing factory to reinstate with back pay nine union leaders who were fired last year after brief work stoppages to protest low wages and workplace abuses. The court ruled that the Chentex factory had illegally fired the union leaders. Concerns over conditions at the factory, where 150 workers were fired last year, have been voiced by several dozen members of Congress. David Gonzalez (NYT)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
One California Utility Files For Bankruptcy Protection
Pacific Gas and Electric, California's largest utility, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, saying that politicians and regulators had not moved quickly enough to resolve an energy crisis that has caused periodic rolling blackouts and cost the state billions of dollars.
 The filing shifts the decision making about key aspects of the state's energy problem to a federal bankruptcy court in San Francisco, where Pacific Gas has its headquarters. The utility hopes to win relief from $9 billion in wholesale energy debt it says it has incurred since prices began soaring last May. Pacific Gas and Southern California Edison, the No. 2 utility, had complained they were running out of cash and had demanded that energy rates be increased to cover their costs. Page A1. 

March Jobless Rate Climbs to 4.3%
The unemployment rate rose in March to 4.3 percent from 4.2 percent in February and 3.9 percent in October, as the Labor Department's job figures reflected layoffs and hiring freezes since last fall. Employers shed 86,000 jobs in March, the largest loss for a single month in more than nine years and an indication to many economists that the United States may be on the verge of a recession. A1.

Europe Examines Intel's Practices
The European Commission confirmed that it is investigating Intel over accusations that it abused its dominant position in the European computer chip market. Activities under investigation include Intel's licensing agreements with personal computer makers and retailers and the rebates it grants these other companies in return for their loyalty. C2.

Smaller Tax Cut in Senate Budget
With the support of Republicans and votes from nearly a third of the Democrats, the Senate approved a budget measure that would allow a $1.2 trillion tax reduction over the next 10 years and an $85 billion tax cut this year. The tax cut was only three-quarters of the amount President Bush had said was essential, but the White House and its Republican allies in Congress proclaimed victory. A1.

Motorola Denies It Is Short of Cash
Motorola denied a report that it was facing serious liquidity problems after its shares fell to their lowest level in eight years. Its shares fell $3.45, or 23 percent, to close at $11.50. Robert L. Growney, Motorola's president and chief operating officer, said the company was financially sound. C3.

Greenspan Calls for More Education
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said in a speech that more must be done to help Americans understand the changing financial world. "Just as we have recognized how critical it is to demystify technology and to increase workers' comfort and familiarity with the new tools required for their success," he said, "so should we work to educate consumers on evaluating the broad array of products offered by financial service providers and to empower them to make the choices that contribute to their overall well-being." C14.

Earnings Warning From RadioShack
RadioShack warned that poor margins on mobile phones, satellite television and computers will cause its first-quarter earnings to fall below those a year earlier and miss forecasts. Shares of RadioShack fell $10.20, or 26.5 percent, to $28.30. The company expects to earn 31 to 33 cents a share in the first quarter, down from 34 cents a year earlier. Analysts had expected earnings of 38 cents a share. C3.

South Korea Holds Call Rate Steady
South Korea's central bank held interest rates steady as accelerating inflation, stoked by a weakening currency, prevented a rate cut. The Bank of Korea left the benchmark call rate, the interest it charges on overnight loans to commercial banks, at 5 percent at its monthly policy meeting. C2.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Japan's Emergency Relief Plan Is Brought Out to a Cool Reception

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 6 

 BODY:
Two days later than planned, the Japanese government produced its eagerly awaited emergency overhaul package, aimed at relieving longstanding problems in the banking industry and kick-starting the moribund economy. It was met with groans of disappointment from every quarter.
 Both Japanese and foreign economists faulted the plan for lacking cohesion, detail and, most important, political commitment. "There is no clear, comprehensive vision in this package," said Takuro Morinaga, senior analyst at the Sanwa Research Institute. "It is simply a patchwork plan, aimed at appealing to the United States." 
 Using broad language, the package promises to sweep the worst of the banks' soured loans from their balance sheets and to buffer the banks from the gyrations of Japan's wildly volatile stock market by taking some of their cross-holdings of corporate stock off their hands. 
For the debt-ridden corporate sector, the plan promises various tax and financing incentives to curb the alarming rise in bankruptcies.
The package also includes projects to spruce up urban areas, which the government hopes will stop the decade-long slide in land prices, and it includes a pledge to increase unemployment benefits, especially for older workers and those laid off in bankruptcies.
The most concrete plank of the package is a reiteration of a promise Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori made to President Bush that major banks would write off the very worst of their nonperforming loans within two years.
Faced with economic travails of its own, the Bush administration has been trying to cast Japan's long-festering economic and financial malaise as a major global problem and has pressed Japanese officials to act. Still, the package offers no hint of how the government can compel the banks to meet the deadline. 
What little of substance there is in the package is cast into further doubt by the imminent change of leadership in Japan. After stalling for weeks, Mr. Mori said on Thursday that he would heed calls to resign. On April 24, the ruling Liberal Democratic Party will choose a new leader to replace him. In the ensuing cabinet reshuffle, it is unlikely that Hakuo Yanagisawa, the plainly frustrated chief advocate of far-reaching economic overhaul, will remain as financial services minister.
The package is drafted with such broad strokes that it effectively leaves a blank slate for the new cabinet to fill in. That cabinet's paramount concern will be limiting the damage in elections for the upper house of Parliament in July, when analysts predict a drubbing for the ruling party. 
Speaking to foreign journalists, Mr. Yanagisawa said his presence in the cabinet was not critical, and that Japan could not avoid keeping Mr. Mori's promise to President Bush about loan write-offs. But a 1997 promise to the United States by Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto that Japan's telecommunications market would be opened up to competition remains a long way from being fulfilled.
"I think Mr. Mori and Mr. Yanagisawa know that their time as ministers is short," said Takashi Kiuchi, economic adviser to Shinsei Bank. "So how the specifics of this plan will be worked out by the next team is another anxiety for the markets, I'm afraid."
Mr. Yanagisawa himself acknowledged repeatedly that today's package lacked specifics, ticking off each of the many questions analysts and investors have raised about the entity the government plans to establish to buy stocks from the banks. "We do not have any details finalized at this point," he said.
Finalizing those details now is politically impossible, he said. As an example, he noted that politicians and government officials could not agree on forcing shareholders to bear some responsibility for cleaning up corporate Japan, which would require a change in the commercial code. "If we had to include that, we felt we would not get it through at this time," he said.
The biggest sticking point, though, was the proposed fund to buy banks' share portfolios, a legacy of a once-cozy system in which the banks and customers owned stock in one another. Starting in September, the banks' books will have to carry the stocks at their current market value, raising the threat of a deep dent in the banks' capital if the stocks are not sold. The existence of the shareholdings also tends to inhibit the kind of thorough restructuring that Mr. Yanigasawa and others favor.
But the government cannot simply order the banks to sell the stock on the open market, because prices would plummet. The banks' portfolios are immense, valued now at perhaps 40 trillion yen ($332 billion), and include many obscure, illiquid shares in small companies.
The government said that the fund would eventually resell the stocks to pension and mutual funds, but few analysts expect them to be eager takers. "The largest question in my mind is: What's the exit strategy?" said Paul Frost-Smith, head of equity markets in the Asia-Pacific region at J. P. Morgan.
Mr. Yanagisawa acknowledged that there were likely to be losses on the stocks, given Japan's economic straits. "There is a certain price level at which the banks will sell these stocks, and it will be difficult for other investors to buy at that level," he said.
Ultimately, most economists and investors have concluded, public money will be used to cover losses on the stocks and shore up the banks' capital as they write off bad loans.
The government is also known to be considering requiring banks to trim their stock portfolios but not eliminate them. Some economists worry that such a half-measure will shelter the banks from the rigors of the open market without eradicating the cozy relationships between them and their borrowers.
"We have to some extent been outwitted by this plan," said Ronald Bevacqua, senior economist at Commerz Securities in Tokyo. "They've done just enough to make sure the stock market can't force them to do something they don't want to do. The last lever on the government to act has been neutralized."
Mr. Yanagisawa made plain that he had concerns about the stock purchase plan, one of the most divisive issues the ruling party has faced in years. He and like-minded colleagues are loath to use any more public money to shore up the banks without guarantees that fundamental changes will be made. The fact that top echelons of the party are taking positions on the plan and arguing them forcefully offers perhaps the one real glimmer of hope in today's package.
Departing strikingly from accepted protocol, Mr. Yanagisawa confirmed that he had clashed with Shizuka Kamei, the party's policy chief. Identifying Mr. Kamei by name, Mr. Yanagisawa said that nemawashi, the time-honored practice of painstaking consensus building that so often congeals politics in Japan, had broken down. "There was direct confrontation on some of these issues," he said.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Urges Better Money Sense 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 6 

 BODY:
More must be done to help Americans understand the changing financial world, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today.
 Just as job training helps workers adapt to the spread of computers and technology throughout the economy, so does financial literacy help improve standards of living for consumers, Mr. Greenspan said in an address to a Fed community affairs research conference. 
 Mr. Greenspan did not discuss the state of the United States economy or interest rate policy.
Advances in computer technology have led to the creation of a wide range of financial products, Mr. Greenspan said, while at the same time lowering the cost and broadening the scope of financial services.
As a result, however, Americans "need to accumulate the appropriate knowledge on how to use new technologies and on how to make financial decisions in an informed manner," he said.
"Just as we have recognized how critical it is to demystify technology and to increase workers' comfort and familiarity with the new tools required for their success, so should we work to educate consumers on evaluating the broad array of products offered by financial service providers and to empower them to make the choices that contribute to their overall well-being," Mr. Greenspan said.
He suggested that the education process start as early as possible. "Improving basic financial education at the elementary and secondary school level is essential" to help young people avoid poor financial decisions "that can take years to overcome," Mr. Greenspan said.
Poor financial education has kept some lower-income people and minorities from fully benefiting from the record economic expansion, he said.
From 1995 to 1998, the median real net worth for all families increased 17.5 percent, according to the Fed's most recent survey of consumer finances.
But in contrast, median net worth declined for families with incomes below $25,000, while the median income for nonwhites and Hispanics was little changed. "This performance leaves much to be desired," Mr. Greenspan said.
Job training also remains critical, he said. "Significant segments of our population have exhibited fears that their skills will not be adequate to deal with a rapidly changing work environment," he said. "The day when a high school or college education would serve a graduate for a lifetime is gone."
Helping individuals overcome their fear of technology "can be a means of increasing economic opportunity," Mr. Greenspan said.

HEADLINE: An Instructive Vote 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 6 

 BODY:
On tax cuts, President Bush has had a single, relentless message for months: It is my way or the highway, and my way is $1.6 trillion in reductions over the next decade, not a penny more or less.
 By that standard, Mr. Bush lost today. 
 In voting to adopt a budget blueprint calling for $1.2 trillion in tax cuts, the Senate resisted intense pressure from the White House and the Republican leadership on Capitol Hill to stick with Mr. Bush's figure. And in paring the president's plan, Democrats in the evenly divided Senate showed they can be an effective check on Mr. Bush and his agenda. 
Yet as much as today's vote was a blow to Mr. Bush that could have lasting effects on his political authority, it arguably left him better positioned than ever to enact the biggest tax cut in two decades.
By sticking doggedly to his $1.6 trillion package, the president forced Democrats to move much closer to his position, and he put a floor under the size of the tax cut that was well above anything that Democrats would have gone along with even a few weeks ago. 
At the start of the presidential campaign last year, Democrats were backing a $250 billion tax cut. By election day they were at $500 billion. Earlier this year, with projections of the federal budget surplus increasing, Congressional Democrats said they would support $750 billion. 
This week, when a bipartisan group of moderates pushed for a compromise of around $1.2 trillion, Democratic leaders withheld their support but left open the possibility that they could ultimately accept a tax cut of that level.
On the final vote today, 15 Democrats supported the $1.2 trillion figure, enough for the White House to claim true bipartisan support for the largest tax reduction since 1981. The House, where Republicans have a slim but solid majority, has already approved a budget blueprint calling for a $1.6 trillion tax cut.
"Getting substantial Democratic support for $1.3 trillion in tax relief is a remarkable accomplishment, and shows how effective the president's been in moving the debate," said Senator Rick Santorum, Republican of Pennsylvania.
But even as Republicans looked on the bright side, they acknowledged that Mr. Bush had come up short on his first big legislative test. Despite an aggressive effort to rally public opinion to his side, including campaign-style trips to 22 states in the last two months, the president was unable to persuade or threaten 51 senators to stand by him on his signature issue. 
Even considerable arm twisting in the last 24 hours by Vice President Dick Cheney, among other administration officials, could not put Mr. Bush over the top. "Frankly, the administration tried to secure additional votes for a higher figure," said Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the assistant Republican leader. "We didn't have the votes."
Democrats in the Senate now know they can buck the president, and will no doubt be emboldened to do so regularly, whether in search of true compromise or political advantage.
"Neither end of Pennsylvania Avenue is going to dictate the result," said Senator Max Baucus of Montana, the senior Democrat on the Finance Committee.
After losing the White House and failing to win back either the House or the Senate, Democrats had spent the first few months of this year struggling to hold back what at times seemed to be unstoppable momentum behind Mr. Bush's tax cut.
The federal budget surplus forecast was revised upward, making it harder for Democrats to argue that Mr. Bush's plan was unaffordable. Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, endorsed the idea of a substantial tax cut. The threat of a recession gave new urgency to providing the economy with a dose of fiscal stimulus through tax cuts.
In the end, only one Democrat in the Senate, Zell Miller of Georgia, came out squarely for Mr. Bush's plan, and several moderate Republicans, notably Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island and James M. Jeffords of Vermont, edged away from it.
Rather than compromising on his own terms, Mr. Bush elected to fight for his plan to the end. And although the measure voted on today was largely the work of centrists from both parties -- and was opposed by Democratic leaders -- it was far enough removed from Mr. Bush's wishes to allow Democrats to claim victory.
"It's like a quarterback beginning the game by announcing his own point spread," said Senator Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey. "If he doesn't achieve it, he's a failure."
From now on, Democrats said, Mr. Bush will have to come to the negotiating table, on taxes and on all issues dividing the parties, if he wants progress.
"We have said from the beginning, if he'd work with us, we could reach bipartisan compromise," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader. "He chose not to do that and he got beat. I don't think that's something that I would expect him to do in the future."
Republicans still have a chance to enlarge the tax cut somewhat when the House and Senate meet to work out differences between their budget resolutions. But the real focus will shift to the Finance Committee, which will draw up legislation next month apportioning whatever figure is available for tax cuts among a host of competing provisions.
The measure adopted by the Senate today called for up to $85 billion in immediate tax cuts that would take effect this year, perhaps retroactive to Jan. 1. But there is no consensus on how to do it.
The measure then provides about $1.18 trillion over the next decade that will have to be divided among components backed by the president and others supported by either or both parties in Congress. 
That is not enough money to do everything, at least not to do it the way Mr. Bush has proposed. The resulting fight is all but sure to force the president to make difficult compromises about central elements of his tax agenda, including his call to repeal the federal estate tax and to reduce all income tax rates.

HEADLINE: Autonomous Television in Russia 

 BODY:
It is not easy to keep track of the cast of characters wrestling to gain financial control of NTV, Russia's only independent television network. But the outcome of the struggle is important to sustaining democracy in Russia. If NTV falls under government control, which remains a distinct possibility, Russians will lose an invaluable source of information about their country and the world outside. 
 Earlier this week the government-dominated natural gas monopoly, Gazprom, used its control of a majority of NTV's shares to install a new management team under Boris Jordan, a Russian-American investor. But many of NTV's leading journalists continue to resist the takeover, and its former owner, Vladimir Gusinsky, has been trying to interest the American media entrepreneur Ted Turner in buying a large minority interest to discourage Kremlin bullying. 
 The importance of NTV's independent broadcasting has grown in direct relation to President Vladimir Putin's effort to gather power into his own hands and silence critics of his government. Russian democracy depends in part on maintaining widely accessible sources of public information that the Kremlin cannot easily manipulate or silence. 
Mr. Gusinsky is neither an altruist nor a political innocent. He became a multimillionaire in the gold-rush culture of Russia's transition to a market economy. At one point he was a loyal ally of Boris Yeltsin's Kremlin. But along the way his holding company, Media-MOST, became a vital redoubt of news professionalism and press freedom. In recent years, NTV has fearlessly chronicled Russia's brutal military campaign in Chechnya and has exposed incompetence and criminal conduct by government officials in Moscow. 
NTV's new boss, Mr. Jordan, comes from the same kind of business background as Mr. Gusinsky. If he prevails in the current management struggle, he must not do Mr. Putin's bidding. Encouragingly, he has publicly pledged to maintain NTV's political independence. Mr. Jordan, or anyone else who ends up managing NTV, should retain its talented staff and insist on unfettered coverage of Russia and its leaders.

HEADLINE: SENATE PASSES BUDGET PLAN WITH A $1.2 TRILLION TAX CUT 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 6 

 BODY:
With the solid support of Republicans and votes from nearly a third of the Democrats, the Senate approved a budget measure today that would allow a $1.2 trillion tax reduction over the next 10 years and an $85 billion tax cut this year.
 The 10-year tax cut was only three-quarters of the amount President Bush had said was essential, but the White House and its Republican allies in Congress proclaimed victory. 
 "It's a good number, fairly close to what the president wanted," said Vice President Dick Cheney, who spent the week in the Capitol twisting arms, cutting deals and, in his position as president of the Senate, breaking three tie votes.
No president ever gets everything he wants, Mr. Cheney said, adding: "It's a give-and-take process. That's what I've been doing this week." 
At the White House, Mr. Bush told guests at a ceremony in the East Room that $1.2 trillion was "meaningful tax relief for the American people" and that it would be "good for the economy."
But Democratic leaders, all of whom voted against the measure, said they had succeeded in sharply paring the size of the tax plan, even though it is far higher than the $500 billion they were seeking as recently as Election Day. And they challenged the notion of a presidential victory. 
"If this is a victory for them," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, "then we want more victories just like it."
The measure, approved 65 to 35, now goes to a conference with the House of Representatives, which approved a budget plan last month that would allow $1.6 trillion for tax cuts. Roll call, Page A11. 
The final figure will probably be between what the House and Senate passed -- and thus closer to what Mr. Bush had wanted from the start. 
The catalyst for the compromise tax cut was Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, who has tried throughout his career, usually unsuccessfully, to assemble coalitions of moderate Democrats and Republicans. 
Today, after a week of partisan squabbling and votes that broke almost entirely along party lines, Mr. Breaux brought into the fold two Republicans who had defected from their party's position and 14 other Democrats who favored a larger tax cut than their party's leaders were supporting but thought the president's proposal was too high.
His success showed that "it is in fact possible to change the political culture in Washington," Mr. Breaux said after the vote. "While the numbers will change" as debate over taxes continues over the next few months, he added, "the coalition will not." 
Republican leaders, despite claims of victory, acknowledged that they would have preferred a larger tax cut. "We didn't have the votes to pass 1.6," said Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the assistant majority leader. 
They did not have the votes because only one Democratic senator, Zell Miller of Georgia, voted for the president's plan, while two Republicans, James M. Jeffords of Vermont and Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island, broke ranks. With the Senate divided 50-50 between the parties, that was enough to thwart the Republicans.
Mr. Jeffords, a maverick throughout his career who insisted on more spending for special education than the Bush administration was willing to accept, called the outcome a "great victory for the young kids of America."
Mr. Chafee was appointed to the Senate in 1999 after the death of his father, Senator John H. Chafee, who was a committed moderate in his long career in the Senate and often an ally of Mr. Breaux. Lincoln Chafee was elected to a full term last year.
"It is a long path we have trod to get here -- centrists working together," Mr. Chafee said after today's vote.
Democratic leaders said they had voted against the budget measure because the tax cuts were still too high, the debt reduction insufficient and the protection of Social Security and Medicare inadequate.
"I don't think it still strikes the right balance," said Senator Kent Conrad of North Dakota, the top Democrat on the Budget Committee.
The measure that was adopted today is called a budget resolution. It is a planning device for Congress, often called a blueprint, that establishes the broad outlines that tax and spending bills are supposed to follow. In addition to the tax cuts, the measure would allow about $2 trillion in government spending in the 2002 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1.
Often, the guidelines established in budget resolutions are ignored. So the action today was not decisive. But the budget resolution this year was more important than usual for two reasons.
First, it established that President Bush did not have enough support in the Senate to win passage of his full $1.6 trillion tax plan.
"That issue is dead," Senator Daschle said. "I don't think it will be revived."
Second, it was the first test of how the evenly divided Senate would operate on a highly partisan matter. The answer, as Mr. Jeffords showed, seems to be that every senator is potentially the king and, as Mr. Breaux proved, that winning margins can depend on a small coalition of senators willing to cross party lines.
After the vote, the Senate broke for a two-week recess. When the lawmakers return, two critical decisions will face them. 
The first is the tax cut for this year, which is to be taken from the budget surplus for the current fiscal year and is designed to stimulate the economy. The Senate's figure, $85 billion, is significantly above the $60 billion that has been discussed but not acted on in the House.
Democrats want part of the money to be returned to taxpayers in rebate checks and part to result from lowering the income tax rate to 10 percent from 15 percent on the first $6,000 of each individual's income. Republicans favor some kind of a reduction in all the tax brackets.
The other decision will be the nature of the tax cuts covering the 2002 fiscal year through the 2011 fiscal year. 
The House has approved three bills along the lines President Bush proposed. One would lower income tax rates across the board. Another would lower taxes on married couples and increase the tax credit for families with children. The third would slowly reduce the estate tax rate and repeal the tax entirely in 2011.
The Senate Finance Committee plans to draft tax legislation next month, and a battle royal every bit as intense as the one this week is likely when that bill reaches the Senate floor.
On Tuesday night, President Bush and the Republicans in the Senate seemed likely to prevail on the full $1.6 trillion tax reduction. Democrats lost what seemed to be a test vote on a proposal to reduce the tax cut by $158 billion and use the money to provide prescription drug coverage under Medicare.
Only Senator Chafee and Senator Miller crossed party lines. The result was a 50-to-50 tie. And Mr. Cheney cast his first tie-breaking vote against the proposal.
But on Wednesday night, Senator Jeffords defected. That led to approval of a Democratic proposal to reduce the tax cut by about $450 billion and apply the money to education programs. At the time, Republican leaders thought they would be able to reverse the vote as the week wore on, but they were never able to do so.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 9, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on Saturday about Senate passage of a budget resolution misstated the measure's allocation of a saving of some $450 billion. The sum, obtained by reducing President Bush's proposed 10-year, $1.6 trillion tax cut, would be divided between spending on education and reductions in the national debt. It would not all be spent on education.

HEADLINE: Well Off but Still Pressed, Doctor Could Use Tax Cut 

BYLINE:  By JIM YARDLEY 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., April 4 

 BODY:
Dr. Robert Cline lives in a graceful four-bedroom house with a pool in a tree-shrouded neighborhood considered one of the more desirable in town. His income approached $300,000 last year, ranking him among the wealthiest 2 percent of all Americans.
 And yet Dr. Cline, 39, a surgeon, says he does not feel rich. He worries about his retirement. He worries about paying for college for his six young children, not to mention weddings for his five daughters. And he worries that his earning power is fairly stagnant in a medical profession squeezed by insurance companies and tightening Medicare reimbursement rates. 
 So in February, when Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic leader, rolled out a shiny Lexus sedan to dramatize his argument that President Bush's $1.6 trillion tax cut plan favors the rich, Dr. Cline was not amused. He understands that his income will not win him outpourings of sympathy, but he resents the argument that people in higher tax brackets are less deserving of a tax cut. 
"The perception is that someone like me doesn't have any concerns other than getting a new car," said Dr. Cline, who drives a 10-year-old Acura.
"I'm not looking for a tax cut to buy a Lexus," he said. "I've got kids to put through school and a retirement to plan. Certainly, I could use the tax money for my family." 
In the hierarchy of wealth in America, a scale that ballooned drastically upward during the booming 1990's, Dr. Cline is at the low end of the high end. His annual income far surpasses what most Americans will ever earn, yet it is dwarfed by the fortunes of the super-rich who have built limestone mansions on the western hills of this city.
When Dr. Cline and his wife, Tasha, offered a visitor a ride-around tour, they drove through a mansion-filled compound called Stratford Hills. The message was clear: They are rich, not us.
For Dr. Cline, a Republican who voted for Mr. Bush, the philosophical basis for a tax cut echoes the president's own points that everyone, regardless of income, should get a tax cut and that since the wealthy pay more, their tax savings should be larger. Dr. Cline said he did not mind that the people in the mansions would get bigger tax savings than he would. He just wants what he considers his fair share and does not believe that only people in lower brackets should get help.
"You know, I think I pay too much in taxes," he said. "I'm sure everybody feels the same way, but I do, too. Should you pay more than a third of what you make to the government? I don't think so."
Practicality, though, as much as philosophy explains why Dr. Cline wants a tax cut. 
Because of the economics of medicine, which saw insurers and Medicare tighten reimbursement rates, Dr. Cline's gross income fell to $289,678 last year from $293,505 in 1999, even though he worked more hours. He said his elite education -- four years of college, four years of medical school, seven years of medical residency and training in his specialty of colo-rectal surgery -- has put him in a profession that is "isolated from capitalism, particularly in the managed care environment." 
"People don't go into medicine for the money, and that's pretty obvious in this economy," he said. "But I'd also like to have some control over what I make. And since I don't, a tax cut is the next best thing."
In fact, Dr. Cline stands to see a significant tax cut under the plans moving through Congress. If Mr. Bush ultimately succeeds in achieving the $1.6 trillion cut, the family could save nearly $12,000 a year, according to an analysis by the Deloitte & Touche accounting firm. 
In 1995, the Clines moved to Austin, where Robert had spent his teenage years as his father worked as business manager for The Austin American-Statesman newspaper. In those days -- the mid-1970's -- the city was a mellow state capital best known for its live music scene. "All most people wanted was a Frisbee and a good dog to catch it," he said a bit wistfully. 
But the Austin that greeted the Clines in 1995 was a high-tech boomtown where public offerings and stock options dominated the cocktail chatter of a new millionaire class.
"It was a little frustrating," Dr. Cline said. "Here I was building a practice and already starting to see there is a top end on what I can provide. And everybody is quitting their jobs and going into dot-com.
"It was insanity. You would see all these young guys driving around in Porsches. I was going, 'Wow, I should have been a computer nerd.' "
When he began his practice, Dr. Cline took out a $100,000 loan to start his business and feed his family. Slowly, his practice grew. 
His family grew much faster. When they moved to Austin, they had just one child; by 1998 they had three children under the age of 4. 
When he and Tasha decided to have a fourth and final child, they instead had twin girls, Monroe and Eva, now both nearly 3. There were complications, and Eva has required extensive medical attention; her annual medical expenses -- the amount paid out of pocket to meet the insurance deductible -- exceed $10,000. 
In 1998, the family moved into their current four-bedroom house in the fashionable Tarrytown neighborhood. The house cost $667,000 -- a stretch for them -- but it was only five minutes from Dr. Cline's office and the overheated real estate market offered few bargains.
But when Mrs. Cline unexpectedly became pregnant with their sixth child and only son, Saylor, now 9 months old, they found they had already outgrown a house they could barely afford. Saylor sleeps in a walk-in closet converted to a nursery.
Mrs. Cline, 35, a former actress, said she does not want to be perceived "as the whining rich." Her days are spent chasing children and ferrying them to schools, doctors and soccer games. With six children under the age of 7, the family spends about $26,000 annually for a 40-hour-a-week nanny, though her hours will be cut in half when the three oldest girls enroll in school this fall. 
Mrs. Cline said she shops at the cheaper grocery stores -- her mother-in-law clips coupons for her -- and that new clothes for the children are a rarity. She said that the family rake their own leaves, paint their own bedrooms, clean their own pool. 
"We don't have the luxuries that you would think in this tax bracket," she said. "Of course, I'm sure that having six kids doesn't help."
Dr. Cline added: "I can only imagine what someone who makes $40,000 or $50,000 a year needs with a family my size." 
Last year, Dr. Cline became concerned enough about his family finances that he asked his office manager to look for ways to save money. The manager had Mrs. Cline document her weekly medical and household expenses, down to coffee at Starbucks. Now, the family budget runs through the office manager, who doles out an allowance to Mrs. Cline every other week. 
When Texas public schools closed for spring break last month, Mrs. Cline said, "everybody I know went to Colorado and Utah. We drove to San Antonio for the day and took the baby to the zoo."
"We have a good life," she added. "And yet we still have the same struggles as other people. I feel like a lot of the time we're treading water. America should be a place where you can get ahead, not get dragged down."
For Dr. Cline, money is not a consuming issue, not something he covets. Yet, he said, "with what I do, I guess my expectation was that I was not going to worry about money. And here I am worrying about money." 
His job often allows him to spend weekends with his wife and children and even make early evening soccer games of his second-oldest daughter, Tess. But he worries about paying for his children's college education the way his father did for him.
His in-state tuition at the University of Texas had been roughly $250 a semester back in the mid-1980s, and medical school at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center at Dallas cost around $650 a semester. His own children's educations, he realizes, will likely cost tens of thousands of dollars each.
"Even if they stay in town and go to U.T., it's not going to be cheap," he said.
Once again, the family is house-hunting. The real estate boom has tacked another $200,000 in appraised value onto their house. But they are having a hard time finding a five-bedroom house in a neighborhood they like for less than $1 million. One option would be to move further out to the suburbs, where houses are cheaper but the commute is longer. Dr. Cline said he was a city guy and hated the thought of moving.
"I don't think I'm unique, especially in the medical community," he said. "We know other families that are moving into smaller houses for the same reasons."
From the tone of the debate in Washington, Dr. Cline said, it was obvious that a tax cut is coming, but not yet clear for whom and how much.
"My point to you is that I need one, too," he said.

Judging the Tax Cut
This is the third article in a series about how taxpayers at varying income levels would be affected by the Bush tax cut proposal. The final installment will focus on a carpenter in Maine.

HEADLINE: COLLEGE PREP; 
La Dolce Semester

BYLINE:  By Glenn C. Altschuler; Glenn C. Altschuler is dean of the School of Continuing Education and Summer Sessions and the Thomas and Dorothy Litwin Professor of American Studies at Cornell University.

 BODY:
Even before attending freshman orientation, many students have already decided to study abroad. The programs, featured prominently in college admissions literature, have become nothing less than an expectation among upper-middle-class teenagers, like braces and a car. Students may not know where they want to go, or what they want to study, but they know they don't want to miss "the experience of a lifetime."
 Especially during the 1990's, amid dire predictions for anyone not trained for the new global economy, enrollments in study-abroad programs soared, from about 70,000 to almost 130,000 at the end of the decade, according to the Institute of International Education. Since students also have to pay for travel and can't get work-study jobs overseas, most participants come from elite, expensive private institutions. Between a quarter and a third of undergraduates at Brown, Cornell, Duke, Notre Dame, Brigham Young and Yeshiva University get credit for academic work in another country. At small colleges, including Bates, Colby, Middlebury and Wesleyan, the percentages are even higher. 
 Still, the numbers are small compared with the total undergraduate population. Study abroad missionaries, who point out that 99 percent of students remain home, are pressing to pick up the pace. If students are adequately prepared, "I don't think there are any cons to study abroad," Jon Ramsey, dean of studies at Skidmore College, said in a refrain repeated by administrators at a dozen institutions. 
Even Bill Clinton, who as president signed legislation that appropriated $150 million for study-abroad scholarships, endorsed an increase in the number and diversity of students who participate. Last year, Richard W. Riley, as secretary of education, set a 10-year goal of doubling the study-abroad population. President Bush and Secretary of Education Rod Paige have yet to weigh in on the subject. 
When it builds on language study or work in an academic major, studying overseas can be a stimulating, even transformative intellectual experience. For Jill Schondebare, who is majoring in animal science, researching wildlife management in Kenya was "my best semester at Cornell." So was reading classics at Queens College at Oxford for Justin Schwab.
More often than the enthusiasts would like to admit, however, the good reasons for study abroad are not always the reasons motivating undergraduates. Another Cornell undergraduate, Alejandro Varela, acknowledges that he was attracted to Seville, Spain, because of the lower drinking age and "vacation aspect."
"No matter how I did in school, it would not be calculated into my G.P.A.," he said. He and his buddies "relaxed five or six days a week -- and that was when we were not traveling." They spent time with other Americans, rarely socializing or studying with Spaniards. The five months in Seville, Alejandro maintains, "was my favorite college semester."
It is difficult to know whether Alejandro's experience is more typical than Jill's or Justin's. In a recent doctoral dissertation, Lisa Chieffo, the study-abroad coordinator at the University of Delaware, wrote that studies measuring the benefits of an academic sojourn yielded mixed, inconclusive and sometimes surprising results. Because study abroad "seems intuitively to be a good thing to do," she wrote, "it is tempting for administrators to assume that such an experience must have positive benefits." 
But alongside favorable documentation, she cites studies -- published in academic journals over the last 20 years -- that are less sanguine. Advanced language learners, for example, do not necessarily become more fluent abroad than those who stay at home. Dr. Chieffo speculates that the students put a greater premium on communicating quickly than on grammatical accuracy, while the reverse is true in language classes in the United States.
In one study, undergraduates with fair or poor language ability, who had little interaction and tended to be ethnocentric, often returned home with their attitudes reinforced rather than challenged or changed. Finally, because experiences in an unfamiliar country -- navigating the buses of Rome or negotiating access to the refrigerator or bathroom with a host family -- can lead to frustration and failure, some students' self-esteem suffered. 
It seems clear, then, that preparation should involve more than just saying "I want to go." And benefits should be weighed against lost opportunities. Are advanced courses in your major available in the study-abroad curriculum? (American studies majors may not, for example, find much in a German university.) Are classes as rigorous as those offered on campus? Will you have difficulty getting started on an honors thesis if you're away your junior year? Will a summer job or internship be harder to get if you're overseas during spring semester? How much does it matter that you will not participate in intercollegiate sports, the school newspaper or the student assembly while away? And are you headed for England or Australia, the destination of more than 27 percent of all study-abroad students, out of genuine interest or because you want to be a tourist and don't have the foreign language proficiency to go elsewhere?
Colleges offer a number of options. Some programs are held over a winter or a summer session, or even spring break -- the shorter the program, of course, the more ephemeral the impact. Some institutions, however, will grant academic credit only for programs taken over a full semester or year. Policies on transferring credits completed while abroad also vary from institution to institution. Credit is not automatically granted, nor are courses always applied to requirements in a major. (In case a question arises, save all syllabuses, exams and research papers.)
In one popular option, called an island program, Americans live together and take courses in English, often taught by professors from the home university, instead of mixing with the local culture residentially and academically. If an institution requires attendance at an island program in, say, Britain, France, Spain, Italy or Australia, think twice about enrolling.
Sometimes, however, only an island program is feasible. Because few colleges and universities offer advance courses in Arabic, Thai, Danish or Russian, students may be unable to survive in courses taught in those languages. In Japan, where the academic year begins in April, study-abroad advisers consider the best option to be the island program at the Kyoto Center for Japanese Studies, which operates on the Western calendar.
Advisers also recommend that students begin preparing freshman year. At Cornell, students are not permitted to study in another country until they've completed pertinent courses in language, history, politics and culture. If nothing is available -- there are no courses on Australia, for instance -- they must arrange a reading tutorial with a faculty member. Participating in a "language table" at the dormitory dining hall or living in a language house is just as valuable in the semester before studying abroad as it is on return.
This may all seem like so many hoops to jump through to get a go-ahead from parents and administrators, but students who reflect on the role of international study in their academic, personal and professional development are likely to have more than just their favorite semester in college. They may have the experience of a lifetime. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lolling about near the Eiffel Tower, Brittany Carroll of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., and Beatrice Imbert of Akron, Ohio, take a break from classes. (Jeh Song Baak for The New York Times)

SUBJECT: STUDY ABROAD PROGRAMS (91%); ADOLESCENTS (90%); STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE (90%); COLLEGES & UNIVERSITIES (90%); COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY ADMISSIONS (90%); FOREIGN STUDENTS (90%); ACADEMIC ADMISSIONS (89%); COLLEGE STUDENTS (78%); UNIVERSITY ADMINISTRATION (78%); PRIVATE SCHOOLS (78%); STUDENT DEMOGRAPHICS (78%); STUDENT FINANCIAL AID (78%); EDUCATION DEPARTMENTS (78%); GLOBALIZATION (70%); LEGISLATION (69%); US PRESIDENTS (64%); WILDLIFE (61%); WILDLIFE CONSERVATION (61%); ANIMALS (61%) Terms not available from NYTimes. 

ORGANIZATION: INSTITUTE OF INTERNATIONAL EDUCATION (56%)

PERSON: BILL CLINTON (54%); GEORGE W BUSH (50%)

GEOGRAPHIC: AKRON, OH, USA (55%) OHIO, USA (79%); ANDALUSIA, SPAIN (66%) SPAIN (90%); UNITED STATES (79%); KENYA (79%)
