HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 4-08-01; 
How to E-Mail Like a C.E.O.

BYLINE:  By Bruce Headlam; Bruce Headlam is an editor for the Circuits section of The Times.

 BODY:
Microsoft may be broken up, Nasdaq may never get off the mat, but one artifact of the digital revolution is healthier than ever: e-mail remains the most popular online application, with more than 6.1 billion messages sent daily. Not only has e-mail opened up a whole new medium for personal correspondence, it has also launched the modern corporation into the Internet age with the promise to free workers from the tyranny of too much paper and too little time. It succeeded so spectacularly, however, that what was once blissfully asynchronous is now woefully chronic. For even moderately busy e-mailers, a hundred new messages a day is nothing out of the ordinary. Just as the answering machine gave us a reason to avoid the phone, e-mail has given us a new incentive to delay work in the morning: in-box dread. 
 The e-mail glut doesn't affect only individuals. AOL, Computer Associates, Intel -- a murderers' row of Internet companies -- have all tried various methods of restricting the volume of e-mail within their companies. Perversely, the few workable solutions to the surfeit of e-mail seem to involve even more e-mail. Multiple addresses, which many time-management experts recommend, make for fewer messages in each account but more accounts, and more time spent checking them all. Wireless e-mail lessens the scramble to wrap up correspondence before heading home for the night, but thereby leaves leisure hours vulnerable to e-mail's taint. If New York's subway authority makes good on its promise to provide wireless access in the tunnels, not even the morning commute will be safe. 
 Perhaps the only good thing about e-mail overload is the comforting thought that it is status-blind, that it strikes the highest executive and the lowliest supply clerk alike. After all, that was the promise from the very beginning: e-mail was going to be the great democratizing agent of corporate America, allowing an instant exchange of ideas unimpeded by gatekeepers and protocols. You were either in or you were out in the new corporation and, thanks to e-mail, you could be in anywhere -- all distances, whether geographic or hierarchical, would vanish into electronic ether.
Sadly, it hasn't worked out that way. Consider the research of David Owens, an associate professor of management at Vanderbilt University. Owens spent a year at a research firm in California, attending meetings and interviewing employees. The company (which he can't name as a condition of his research) was a model of New Economy egalitarianism. Aside from a small management team, everyone had the same job title; projects were voluntary, teams were self-forming and a good deal of internal communication took place electronically. Owens's initial interest was how people who work in a "flat" organizational structure distinguish themselves by using behavioral strategies, what sociologists like to call status signifiers. High-status employees, for example, sat near the head of the table during meetings. Those in the midstatus rung spoke the most. Low-status workers told jokes and made coffee. 
Owens then looked at a sample of some 30,000 e-mail messages sent within the company over four years. What he found was that the messages had status signifiers that divided the senders into the same categories he observed in face-to-face meetings. "You can't interrupt someone in an e-mail or use body language," Owens said in an interview. "But people are finding other ways of getting social distinctions in there."
High-status employees, for example, tended to send short, curt messages, in part to minimize contact with lower-status workers but also to convey comfort with their own authority. (A typical example from Owens's study: "Agenda items: Update on people, equipment, collab space, etc.") Midstatus employees, by contrast, tend to produce long, argumentative messages laden with jargon or overexplicated answers to simple questions. ("I vote for the March date, since it seems to me that a smaller, earlier, more focused meeting is better at this preliminary stage.") Surprisingly, senior managers -- who take the longest to reply to e-mail messages -- are the least likely to use the carbon-copy function ("cc") because, Owens suggested, they want to appear to be managing other people individually. Perhaps less surprisingly, bosses tend to have the poorest spelling and worst grammar, conveying the sense that they have better things to do with their time. 
Owens's findings are so striking, and so consistent, that they could serve as an unintended primer for those who want to be a boss, or at least want to be mistaken for one. If your e-mail messages are late, unevenly capitalized and sloppy, you could be C.E.O. material. If your e-mail messages are earnest and combative, or if you run them through spell-check before hitting send, then you may be destined for middle management. And if you ever use e-mail to forward jokes, send greeting cards or use happy-face "emoticons" -- well, you're giving yourself away. These are all strategies used to build social relationships within a company, to provide a kind of social lubrication. ("Gee, what a neat tie!") Owens acknowledges that those who do so play "an important role that tends to be greatly underestimated." But they are almost always low-status workers.
What Owens's findings suggest is that, while communication may move at close to the speed of light, the mechanics of office politics grind on at their own predigital pace. The transmission of e-mail was so captivating that we neglected to look at what those transmissions were saying. Senior executives appeared to be immediately accessible, but beneath their artfully casual missives was a case study straight out of "Up the Organization." (Owens also found that, within the company's message boards, high-status employees had their own secure mailing lists, the electronic equivalent of the key to the executive washroom.)
In some respects, the presence of e-mail has cheapened the very idea of access. Forty years ago, William Hewlett routinely walked through the offices of Hewlett-Packard, often sitting down with his own engineers to work on a problem. Today, all a C.E.O. has to do is make his e-mail account available to his employees, and he's considered cutting edge. This is not to say that e-mail hasn't succeeded in other areas where the questions of social status remain central -- which is why it's the perfect medium for flirting. But it failed to move the corner office any closer to the water cooler. Meet the new boss; sme az the olde boss. :( 

GRAPHIC: Photo (Stone) Chart: "E-mail etiquette the view from below"Get out the dictionary and use that spell checker! Sloppy spelling in a purely written forum sends out the same silent messages that soiled clothing would when addressing an audience. . . .Communicating by e-mail is no different from writing on your company letterhead.A business communication is business, period. As a result, a certain degree of formality is required. Just because e-mail tends to be more immediate and personable, it can't be casual. Business e-mail must be businesslike. You'll be judged by the quality of your writing, so spelling and grammar do count. All forms of business communication you send reflect on you, affecting your chances for advancement. Sending e-mail riddled with misspellings is the same as wearing a shirt spattered with catsup. Sloppy e-mail gets tongues wagging about the writer's literal failings. -- from "The Complete Idiot's Guide to Office Politics"

HEADLINE: HOW TO; 
A User's Manual for Modern Living

BYLINE:  By Charles McGrath; Charles McGrath is the editor of The New York Time Book Review

 BODY:
The only thing you really have to know how to do these days is turn on your computer, and strictly speaking, even that is not essential. You could always call the tech guy and get him to do it. One of the wonders of the service economy is that so many of the things we used to do for ourselves are now done by others. We turn gratefully to the experts and the professionals because it is easier and because so many of life's essential tasks -- automobile maintenance, for example, and income-tax preparation -- are now bewilderingly complicated, far beyond the ken of ordinary mortals. The tax code is incomprehensible even to those who wrote it, and you couldn't tune you own car engine if you tried -- not unless you hacked into the on-board electronic ignition system. Even such formerly simple-seeming activities as exercising and eating have turned out to be far too risky to be undertaken by the novice, which is why we now have personal trainers and nutritionists. 
 The abundance of expertise and the ready availability of services ought to have made us happier and freer, but the evidence suggests the opposite. We are a people desperate to learn how to do something -- almost anything, it scarcely matters what. Look at the prospectus for your local community school or at those glossy catalogs for the evening and weekend adult-learning mills that periodically fall out of The Village Voice and The New York Observer. Almost any night you like, you can take a class in calligraphy, in flower arrangement, in tae kwon do, in macram 1/8, in taxidermy, in ballroom dancing or in becoming a Wiccan. In conflict resolution and in assertiveness, in self-help and in counseling others, in learning how to learn and in learning how to forget (or at least to forgive), in discovering the inner child and in finding the new maturity. No doubt there are classes in how to wean yourself from going to classes and in empowering you to go in the first place if you're shy and insecure. 
 A Darwinist would say that the urge to acquire practical knowledge -- to learn how to do things -- is what defines us as human and is what enabled us to prevail over our simian relatives. You could also make a case that a reverence for know-how is a peculiarly American trait. For the American male, in fact, it may be the defining trait. Most men of a certain age measure themselves, in whole or in part, by their mastery of the essential manly skills: by knowing (or pretending to know) how to throw a curveball, blow a smoke ring, fudge an expense account, jump-start a dead battery and navigate so well that they can drive anywhere without asking for directions. American women are a little less anxious in this regard, but they are nevertheless relentless amassers of information. Amazingly, there are significant numbers of 30-something women now who want to learn how to box -- something that most sensible American men gave up years ago.
How we got to be this way is not hard to explain. Our country was founded by people who had to do for themselves. They had to know how to build, to farm, to fish and hunt, and eventually they had to figure out how to write a constitution and organize a government. Our heroes in the early days were men like Washington and Jefferson, who were admired because their statesmanship and political genius were just part of a whole range of skills and attainments. Not the least of their appeal was that they came off the farm, literally, and then went back to it. Our other heroes, a little later on, were not the scientists and the scholars but those other all-around guys, the tinkerers, the people who invented stuff out in the garage: Edison, Ford, the Wright brothers.
We still admire this practical, enterprising trait, which is why we admire, or used to, people like Bill Gates and Steve Jobs. Many of us now also greatly admire craftspeople: furniture makers and glass blowers and wooden-boat builders -- people who are good with their hands. That's because most of the rest of us are not good at anything anymore, and with minor variations, we all do the same thing. We go to the office, we talk on the phone, we answer e-mail. We could be replaced in an instant. Our need for know-how is partly nostalgic -- a wish to get back in touch with the hands-on skills of our forefathers -- and partly it is a yearning for self-definition. If you're a faceless paper pusher, you feel a lot better about yourself if you're a paper pusher who also knows how to do the merengue and smoke your own meat. 
We also tend to worry, idly and guiltily, about how we would measure up in a crisis. What if we had to deliver a baby? Land a plane? Such anxieties must be what's behind the unlikely success of "The Worst-Case Scenario Survival Handbook," by Joshua Piven and David Borgenicht, a little yellow-bound paperback that in a series of easy, step-by-step lessons teaches you how to jump from a moving car, what to do if your parachute fails to open and the best way to win a sword fight. Chances are you would never have to do any of this stuff -- and if you did, you probably would have forgotten it anyway -- but all the same, tips like this are extremely satisfying to file away in your brain. 
This issue of The Times Magazine is a handbook of another sort. It actually contains some information you can use, along with some that may seem irrelevant but is pleasing and comforting to have on hand just the same. You never know. . . . There is also an important meta-lesson embedded here: namely, that the key to a lot of skills (like being popular or getting into college) is simply to fake them, and that the illusion of knowledge is often more important (and certainly easier to acquire) than knowledge itself. If you really believe you can do something, chances are you can. As some of the following articles suggest, it is not the not knowing that so often holds us back; it is knowing too much. If you're going up to bat against Pedro Martinez, don't worry about it -- dig in, take your rips and light him up! Are you really sure you want to try a motorcycle backflip -- well, then, strap on your helmet, rev the engine and pop the clutch. Go for it! Learning is all well and good, but the secret of success, it turns out, is not to fill your head but to empty it.

HEADLINE: DANCE; 
Russians Ask the World, 'Shall We Dance?'

BYLINE:  By JOEL LOBENTHAL; Joel Lobenthal writes frequently for Ballet Review and is the author of a biography of Tallulah Bankhead to be published next year by ReganBooks.

DATELINE: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia 

 BODY:
THE depths of a Russian winter may not seem the most congenial time to inaugurate an annual international dance festival. But when the Maryinsky Theater here held its first International Ballet Festival in February, the damp and cold were the perfect foil for the heat and light of ballet at its best.
 During the eight-day, nine-performance festival, guest stars from Europe and the United States danced with stars of the Maryinsky Ballet (which tours abroad as the Kirov Ballet, its former name). The festival also presented the premiere of a new production of "The Nutcracker," conducted by the Maryinsky's artistic and general director, Valery Gergiev, with sets and costumes by the emigre artist Mikhail Shemyakin. 
 Under Communism, the Kirov toured little in the United States, in part because of the fear of defections. Since perestroika, however, cutbacks in government support have forced the Maryinsky to remake itself. European appearances are frequent, and American ones will increase in the future, supplying needed hard currency; policy and programming have been jolted out of complacency. 
"To only play safe is not what we ever intend to do," Mr. Gergiev said in a recent interview. Balletomanes have sometimes accused him of favoring the opera, but this festival might serve to counter those claims. Mr. Gergiev intends it to be an annual event at the close of the Maryinsky's winter season, a companion to the White Nights Festival of opera and ballet, which he reinvigorated in 1993.
The guest performers at the festival were almost entirely male, reflecting the prevailing belief that while the Maryinsky is surfeited with talented young ballerinas, its men are less commanding. Carlos Acosta, from the Royal Ballet and the Houston Ballet, partnered the Maryinsky ballerina Irma Nioradze in "Don Quixote." From the Bolshoi, the Maryinsky's longtime rival in Moscow, came Nikolai Tsiskaridze, who danced Act II of Yuri Grigorovich's "Legend of Love" opposite the Maryinsky's Maya Dumchenko and Yuliya Makhalina. 
But the Maryinsky also showcased some of its own men, among them the internationally popular Igor Zelensky, as well as Andrei Batalov, Andrian Fadeyev, Anton Korsakov, Ilya Kuznetsov, Vyacheslav Samodurov and Vasily Sherbakov. Indeed, some nights the casts were entirely Maryinsky. Yet the festival's raison d'etre was new casting combinations. "It allows us to look at roles danced in our theater from another point of view," said Makhar Vaziyev, the Maryinsky Ballet's director. "When two dancers from another company are dancing here, it's one thing. But when one is Maryinsky and her partner is not, it brings a completely different unpredictability."
The guests seized the chance to express themselves on one of the world's most hallowed stages. "I didn't go to give them a Kirovified presentation of 'Apollo,' " said the American Ballet Theater principal Ethan Stiefel, who danced the lead in that Balanchine ballet. "I wanted to show them something new." In "Giselle," Diana Vishneva of the Maryinsky was paired with the Ballet Theater star Vladimir Malakhov, who was trained at the Bolshoi Ballet School. Ms. Vishneva told Mr. Malakhov that she would be happy to make changes to accommodate his slightly different interpretation. They received 10 curtain calls.
On toe, the Maryinsky's ballerinas proved generally taller than their new cavaliers, yet their pas de deux went without a flub. The Maryinsky's Svetlana Zakharova said that Ballet Theater's Jose Manuel Carreno, who danced opposite her in "La Bayadere," was a "wonderful dancer and a very caring partner." Mr. Vaziyev insisted that the guests spend several days rehearsing the full-length ballets in the festival. "I don't like it when a dancer, no matter how brilliant, arrives the night before," he said. "It's always apparent onstage whether they've rehearsed enough or not." 
Mr. Vaziyev also told the dancers that they would not be granted the sometime prerogative of guest artists to bring their own costumes. "Usually a production is designed in one style," he said. "I don't like when a production suddenly turns very eclectic." 
Two years ago, the Maryinsky made headlines by attempting a restoration of "Sleeping Beauty" as it might have looked shortly after its premiere on the Maryinsky stage in 1890. By contrast, this year's "Nutcracker" offered a radical revision of the 1934 version by Vasily Vainonen, a company chestnut. Mr. Gergiev's passion for Tchaikovsky's score was the catalyst. He said that earlier productions of the ballet could be forgotten, for the moment.
" 'Nutcracker' is one of the best balletic musical achievements," he said. "Then you can talk about maybe 10 or 20 or even 100 choreographers doing their own versions." 
In this, his first balletic work, Mr. Shemyakin not only designed sets and costumes but also reshaped the concept and narrative. The new production is a fantasia on E. T .A. Hoffmann's themes, and it turns on its ear the cozy bourgeois world seen in most other "Nutcrackers." The Christmas feast becomes a parody of conspicuous consumption. For the dance of the snowflakes, Mr. Shemyakin supplies a desolate landscape worthy of a witches' Sabbath. 
AT the premiere of "The Nutcracker," Mr. Shemyakin was given an ovation when he entered the czar's box wearing a Rococo-style jacket that made him resemble Hoffmann himself. Mr. Gergiev conducted the orchestra at an infernally fast pace to which the dancers miraculously conformed. While this "Nutcracker" was clearly Mr. Gergiev and Mr. Shemyakin's show, new choreography was provided by the young Maryinsky dancer Kirill Simonov. During the second act's Waltz of the Flowers and Grand pas de deux, the tempo calmed and the scenic effects retreated, allowing Mr. Simonov more room for choreographic invention. 
Despite Russia's severely straitened economy, a small government stipend continues for the ballet, and a support infrastructure remains. For example, the Maryinsky commands its own warehouse of scenery and costumes. Union minimums are unknown, and the Maryinsky, one of Russia's most prestigious institutions, pays its performers and staff a pittance. Yet many dancers consider themselves privileged. Mr. Stiefel said he was impressed by "how much they pride themselves on what they do" and surprised to see dancers still rehearsing a half hour before the performance.
Mr. Gergiev has attracted support from corporations and private patrons, the most generous of whom is the Cuban-American billionaire arts benefactor Alberto Vilar. Over the last year Mr. Vilar has given the Maryinsky Theater $14 million toward new productions of opera and ballet as well as $15 million for annual seasons at the Kennedy Center in Washington, to begin next February. The ballet will also return to the Metropolitan Opera next year in the summer.
The festival demonstrated just how loyal a tribe of admirers and donors the Maryinsky has attracted. The demand for tickets was so frenzied that on some nights extra chairs were placed in the aisles, while scalpers on the street commanded up to $100 a ticket. With prices no longer regulated by the government, a Maryinsky ticket is not nearly as accessible for many Russians as it was during the old regime. Yet no matter how many Westerners were present, it was still a Russian audience with its own tastes.
The climax of the festival was an international gala on Feb. 17, which opened with "Apollo." Memorably danced by Mr. Stiefel and his Russian partners, the performance was praised in the press and by Maryinsky dancers, but the audience response was muted. Though Balanchine himself was reared in this theater, his comparatively cool ballets have yet to ignite the acclaim granted to more pyrotechnic items on the five-hour gala program. 
"Naturally it was an enormous amount of work," Mr. Vaziyev said after the festival's closing performance, "Swan Lake," danced by the Maryinsky's Sofiya Gumerova and Daniil Korsuntsev. But plans for the future are still more ambitious. Mr. Gergiev says, "I want to see 10 leading choreographers of our time come here to demonstrate what they have achieved." Ballet Theater's artistic director, Kevin McKenzie, attended two nights of festival performances, and he and Mr. Vaziyev discussed the possibility of cooperation between the two companies.
"We go to the world," Mr. Gergiev has said of the Maryinsky's relentless touring over the last decade. Now he believes it is time to bring the world to St. Petersburg, to make the city one of the world's artistic hubs.
"We have this feeling that there's a lack of communication, not only from our side," he said. "Now maybe Petersburg will become one of the most important destinations."

HEADLINE: FILM; 
Imagine Pitching This In Hollywood

BYLINE:  By ELMORE LEONARD

 BODY:
The novelist Elmore Leonard, who has seen 17 of his books turned into movies, thought he'd seen it all until he came across "Chopper," an Australian crime film based on a book by the real-life criminal Mark Read, which opens on Wednesday at Film Forum in Manhattan. What follows are his thoughts on how such a movie might be sold to Hollywood.
 THERE was an Australian picture shown at the Telluride Film Festival last year that I thought was great, not like anything I'd ever seen before. 
 The central character is a vicious criminal, a man whose acts of violence are shocking, so unexpected you can't believe your eyes. Still, without slipping out of character, he can appear to be a reasonable man with a sense of humor. 
I've wondered how "Chopper" would do in the United States, and imagined what it would be like to pitch the story idea to a Hollywood studio executive in charge of distribution.
If given enough time -- say, an afternoon -- I could probably pitch an idea, though not one of mine. I'm never that sure what my books are about. I wait for Scott Frank, an A-list Hollywood screenwriter, to tell me what the themes of my books are. He tells me and I say, "No kidding, really?"
In "Get Shorty" there's a pitch made by a producer that goes: "It's about life, about universal feelings of sorrow and hope. It's about redemption and retribution . . ." But it didn't find its way into Scott Frank's screenplay.
Think of the pitches made in the opening sequence of "The Player," directed by Robert Altman, written by Michael Tolkin from his novel:
"A TV star" -- it's made clear that a movie star plays the part -- "goes to Africa and gets worshiped. It's 'Out of Africa' meets 'Pretty Woman.' "
Another: "It's a psychic political thriller with a heart, and it's funny. 'Ghost' meets 'The Manchurian Candidate.' "
I can't think of what two pictures meeting would come even close to describing "Chopper." It might bring to mind Tarantino's work, or possibly Guy Ritchie's; but I don't want to mislead you. "Chopper" is genuinely original.
This makes pitching the story difficult, because normally you have to get in and get out fast. The studio exec has 150 phone calls to take or make in a day. He would prefer the story idea presented in 25 words or less. Exceed that number, his intercom could be fixed to begin buzzing, or you risk having reached the end of his attention span.
But let's say the exec, noticing that I'm old enough to be his grandfather, graciously allows me 10 minutes.
He goes: " 'Chopper.' But you say it's not about a helicopter."
"No, it focuses on episodes in the life of an extremely violent criminal, and it's funny. Critics in Australia called it hilarious."
"It's a comedy."
"Not really. But when we hear 'Don't Fence Me In' played over grim prison exteriors as the titles roll, we get an idea of the picture's attitude."
"Cynical."
"Well----"
"Crime with a light touch."
"Except that we've already caught glimpses of Chopper describing himself as 'just a bloody normal bloke who likes a bit of torture.' He says it lightly, but he isn't kidding."
"It's a prison movie."
"Part of it."
"What's he in for?"
"Kidnapping a judge. But that's not important."
"What's his motivation?"
"He's a criminal."
"But why? He was poor? Got a bad rap? What's the backstory?"
The temptation is to quote David Mamet on backstory, which he calls "a very useful idea because it allows a lot of unemployable people to earn their living saying things to writers." But that would not serve here: to tell the exec there are no obligatory scenes, in the usual scheme of filmmaking, weighing the picture down. I'll assure him that what you get is on the screen, and it's all that's needed to bring a ferocious character to life.
"You know it's based on a real person. Mark 'Chopper' Read, a living legend, considered part of Australia's criminal folklore, right up there with Ned Kelly."
The exec looks off, squinting. "Ned Kelly . . ."
"And Squizzy Taylor. The real Mark Read has even written nine best-sellers about his life in crime, puff pieces that defend his acts of murder and mayhem on the grounds that the victims are drug dealers and deserve what they got. Chopper, in the movie, tells us that 'drugs have completely ruined the criminal world.' "
"Wait a minute. He's portrayed as a good guy?"
"No. He's vicious, he's a brute."
"Then what's funny about him?"
"The way he rationalizes his actions, blames his victims for what he does to them. In prison he attacks a fellow inmate, punches him in the face with a pair of pliers. Immediately then he's full of remorse, offers the guy a cigarette and says, 'You don't like me much, do you?' "
The exec isn't laughing.
"Another time, he punches out his prostitute girlfriend, Tanya, head-butts her mother as she tries to interfere, and says to Tanya: 'Now look what you've gone and done. Your mum's upset.' "
The exec isn't even smiling and this scene works.
"You have to see the way Eric Bana, a stand-up comic, plays the part."
"He does his shtick?"
"He's funny without meaning to be, the character is. The movie guy at The Sun Herald called Bana's performance 'the most stunning film lead debut witnessed by this critic in 14 years of reviewing.' The critics in Australia went nuts over the picture. Used all the words. Brilliant. Extraordinary. Remarkable. Hilarious, I already mentioned. Superb. Frightening and Funny. Spellbinding. 'Some of the most devastating black humour you're likely to witness.' "
"Who made it?"
"Michele Bennett produced, Andrew Dominik wrote and directed."
"What's Michele look like?"
"Cute as a bug. And knows what she's doing."
"Yeah . . .?"
"It's Dominik's first feature and it's an original all the way. His dialogue isspare and gritty. His visuals hit you in the eye: from the immaculate white walls of prison interiors to the harsh colors of Chopper's old haunts outside. It's Dominik's movie."
"How did it open?"
The exec has been waiting to ask that one.
"Big. Did terrific business all over Australia."
"Will our audience understand it?"
"It's in English."
"Yeah, but with that weird accent."
"You pick up on it or it doesn't matter. Chopper calls a guy a 'bloody sook.' What does it mean? Who cares? It has a ring to it, it's a good word. A witness to a shooting is asked if the victim had threatened Chopper. She says no, 'He was copping it sweet.' It's the kind of line that could catch on."
The exec is nodding, his expression thoughtful, then asks, "Why is he called Chopper?"
"It's not in the movie."
"But how did he get it?"
"From snipping off the toes of guys Chopper claimed owed him money."
"Oh."

HEADLINE: IN PERSON; 
This Marriage Takes A Bit of Explication

BYLINE:  By LYNNE WEIL 

DATELINE: PRINCETON 

 BODY:
A RENOWNED scholar and an accomplished poet, married for 36 years, have just gone through hell together -- line by line. They are in the midst of purgatory at the moment, and will soon start on paradise.
 The journey has not always been a pleasure cruise, as both can attest. 
 Robert Hollander, a professor of literature at Princeton University who is a specialist on the medieval Italian authors Giovanni Boccaccio and Dante Alighieri, is collaborating with his wife, Jean, who teaches poetry and literature at the College of New Jersey, to translate the three books of Dante's "Commedia," or "The Divine Comedy," the epic poem about the afterlife.
Rendering a nearly 700-year-old text into the vernacular of another tongue is time-consuming, painstaking and fascinating, Mr. and Mrs. Hollander said. As Mr. Hollander wrote in their new edition of the "Inferno" (Doubleday, $35), Dante "can be as simple and straightforward as one's country neighbor, or as convoluted as the most arcane professor." 
Now they are pressing ahead with an edition of "Purgatorio," which they hope to have published next year. A new "Paradiso" is planned for 2003.
Mr. Hollander -- who has taught Dante at Princeton for nearly 40 years -- said that over the course of his work he had been delighted to discover aspects of the masterpiece that experts have long overlooked.
"I'm getting really excited about scenes that people pay hardly any attention to, that seem to pass by with small attention and little payoff," he said. "And I'm finding some of them absolutely remarkable."
Mr. Hollander had tried to translate "The Divine Comedy" once before, but he and his collaborator gave up because "it was just driving everybody crazy."
Then one day in February 1997, Jean Hollander looked over her husband's shoulder as he worked with the comparatively unwieldy text of a 1939 translation by John Sinclair, one of the most authoritative Dante scholars. "It was awful," she said with a grimace, "not poetic . . . and it really read very badly. So my husband challenged me. He said, 'Well, can you do better?' And I said, 'Well, let me see.' "
When she returned with a free-verse, contemporary version of the text, the couple recalled, Robert Hollander said, "Hey, that's not bad." And so they began. 
The couple said the project's intricacies highlighted a natural tension between his scholarly instincts and her poet's ear.
Jean Hollander noted that they had disagreed "plenty" over distinctions as fine to the untrained eye as whether sinners are hurled "down" or "below."
To preserve their sanity -- and the peace -- the couple agreed that whoever lived longest would be free to revise the books. Mr. Hollander, 67, joked that the accord gave them both "tremendous incentive to stay alive."
The couple met as graduate students at Columbia University, and married on April 23, 1964 -- the fourth centennial of Shakespeare's birth ("so that we'd never forget our anniversary," Mrs. Hollander explained). He was born and raised in New York; she was born in Vienna, but came to New York in 1940.
Hundreds of her poems have appeared in anthologies and magazines, including the Quarterly Review of Literature and The American Scholar. She has published two prize-winning collections of poetry, "Crushed into Honey" and "Moondog." Since 1982 Mrs. Hollander has directed a writers' conference at the College of New Jersey; this year's gathering, on April 18, will feature the filmmaker Spike Lee.
The Hollanders, who have lived in Hopewell Township since 1965, have two children: Cornelia Vanness Hollander, 33, an environmental reporter in Idaho, and Robert B. Hollander III, 31, who attends medical school at the University of North Carolina.
Gregarious and articulate, Robert Hollander tends to digress; rather than interrupt, his children have developed a helicopterlike hand signal to let him know when he wanders too far off track. 
But readers will appreciate his extensive remarks on the margins of Dante's work, which offer a deeper understanding of the "Inferno" than the translation alone might provide. Page after page of notes in this new edition illuminate complexities of meaning and context. For instance, Mr. Hollander quotes more than 60 authors, ranging from early-14th-century Dante scholars to students in his seminars at Princeton.
Such august figures as Henry W. Longfellow, John Ruskin and the country's ninth poet laureate, Robert Pinsky, have translated parts of "The Divine Comedy" into English. And some, like Mr. Hollander, have added commentary. But reviewers say no one has combined helpful comments and a sensitive, modern translation -- until now.
Publishers Weekly said the Hollanders' "Inferno" "will satisfy both the poetry lover and scholar," and called it "accessible and possessed of the seeming transparence that often characterizes great translations."
Even the rather staid British weekly The Economist wrote, "Although there have been more exciting versions that give us something of Dante's music and magic, there has rarely been such a useful one."
As Mr. Hollander put it, "We wouldn't have done it if we didn't think we could do better than what there was."
Mrs. Hollander has devoted much of her energy in the last four years to "The Divine Comedy" -- though she said that she occasionally needed to "take a holiday from translation" to let herself write.
For his part, at one time Mr. Hollander had no patience for Dante. While teaching at Columbia, he was compelled to include some of "The Divine Comedy" in the curriculum. "I didn't like it very much," he remembered. "I kept saying, 'This is the greatest work of the Middle Ages?' "
Then one day, while reading an article on Dante, he said he was stunned by a revelation. "I came to myself several hours later, holding the periodical in my hand." he said. "I can remember that my first thought was, 'So that's how it works.' And I walked out of the library having decided that I was going to be a Dante scholar."
In the opinion of Mr. Hollander's former students, his efforts have paid off.
Charlene Cosman, who graduated from Princeton in 1976 with a degree in medieval studies, said Mr. Hollander "loves unravelling the mysteries of that author and sharing it with lowly peons such as us."
Ms. Cosman added that "one of his strengths is that he manages to maintain contacts with his former students. He's interested in them as people."
Last year, Mr. Hollander arranged a weeklong reunion in an 11th-century castle in the Tuscan countryside south of Florence. Every morning, the 35 people who took part would recite the first 27 lines of "The Inferno" in Italian, then he would teach for about two hours. Each afternoon, six or seven students led seminars, some of them at the poolside.
Susan Saltrick, a 1978 Princeton graduate in comparative literature, said she felt "a little hesitant" about taking part in the gathering.
"I remember thinking, all I will want to do is eat good food, drink wine and soak up the Tuscan sun," she later said. "But as we got into the material, it was so intellectually stimulating, we all found it a wonderful and worthwhile experience."
Ms. Saltrick called the Hollanders "the dream translation team."
"Bob brings the scholarly, rigorous approach to the text," she said. "Jean brings the music of the lines."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert Hollander and his wife, Jean, are immersed in Dante's 700-year-old epic poem "The Divine Comedy" about the afterlife. (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: L.I.@WORK 

BYLINE:  Compiled by Warren Strugatch; E-mail: libiz@nytimes.com

 BODY:
After $51 Million Loss, Twinlab Secures Credit
 After reporting a $51 million loss for the prior fiscal year, the chairman of the Twinlab Corporation (Nasdaq: TWLB) in Hauppauge said Tuesday that the company had secured a $60 million revolving line of credit based on a $15 million guarantee from senior management. 
 Ross Blechman, Twinlab's chairman, president and chief executive, said, "Fiscal 2000 was very difficult for Twinlab as it was for many others in our industry." He promised an "aggressive review" to "streamline operations" to improve the company's "structure, process and systems" and increase customer satisfaction. 
The company, which manufactures vitamins and nutritional supplements, also announced that sales for the fourth quarter of 2000 were $65.4 million, down 26 percent from the $88 million reported in the fourth quarter of 1999. Total sales for 2000 were $280.4 million, down from $315.6 million for the prior year.
Scott Van Winkle, a research analyst at Adams, Harkness & Hill in Boston, said the company was still "an industry leader" and was likely to regain its profitability.

Around the Island
The Cablevision Systems Corporation (NYSE: CVC) of Bethpage announced on Wednesday that it had completed the sale of a 20 percent stake in four networks to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. The four national networks are AMC, Bravo, the Independent Film Channel and WE: Women's Entertainment. The deal was worth $825 million. . . . Technology Flavors & Fragrances Inc. (Amex: TFF) of Amityville reported on March 29 that last year's net income dropped to $271,000 from $657,000 the prior year. In the fourth quarter, sales declined to $2.6 million from the prior year's fourth-quarter sales of $3.4 million. Philip Rosner, the company's chairman and chief executive, said the drop reflected "general economic conditions." . . . Aeroflex Inc. (Nasdaq: ARXX) of Plainview has acquired the TriLink Communications Corporation, a fiber-optics company in Los Angeles. The deal was valued at about $12 million. . . . Vizacom Inc., an Internet and e-commerce company, has closed its executive office in Teaneck, N.J., and moved operations into its PWR Systems subsidiary in Bohemia in an effort to cut costs. The company lost $9 million last year.

HEADLINE: Island's Hospitals: Corporate vs. Community 

BYLINE:  By STEWART AIN 

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH more and more community hospitals are joining large networks like the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System and the Long Island Health Network, they insist they are not sacrificing their community roots. But some of the doctors who work for competing local hospitals say that's not the case. 
 One administrator who takes the positive view is J. Ronald Gaud reault, the president and chief executive of Huntington Hospital. "The core of what we do is still what you would normally think of as a community hospital -- providing for most of the health-care needs of the people in our service area," he said. 
 Five years ago, his hospital joined the North Shore Health System, the predecessor of North Shore-L.I.J. Unlike other community hospitals bought by the system, Huntington became a sponsored hospital, allowing it to keep its own board and its own budget. And Mr. Gaudreault said the system had made the hospital "stronger as a result of the resources available." 
"We're now able to provide a level of sophisticated services like a neo natologist 24 hours a day that makes us stronger and does not diminish our legal authority and community accountability," he explained. North Shore also represents the hospital in reimbursement negotiations with insurers and in purchasing large stocks of supplies and equipment. 
The need to negotiate the best rates with insurers has been a prime motivation for community hospitals to join health-care systems, said Daniel Sisto, the president of the Healthcare Association of New York State, which represents 500 nonprofit hospitals and health-care agencies.
"As government reduced Medicare and Medicaid funding, and as managed care reduced payments, hospitals that were in business to make a profit soon found that that goal was not achievable in New York," Mr. Sisto said. "Community hospitals then banded together to create systems for greater efficiencies, for sharing of services and negotiating with managed-care plans."
The challenge for community hospitals now, Mr. Sisto said, is being able to participate in health-care systems and at the same time to "maintain their identity with the local community and not the needs of a distant system's headquarters."
"They are saying they want to save money by doing administrative things together and buying together, but if they do not appear responsive to the local community, they're dead," he added. "And how formal you make the system requirements for affiliation will vary as each group of hospitals struggles with this tension -- centralization versus local responsiveness."
But in too many instances that effort has failed, said Dr. Amar Jit Singh, the director of clinical services at Brunswick Hospital Center in Amityville.
"Physicians are very unhappy about big corporations taking over the hospitals," said Dr. Singh, who is in the process of buying Brunswick with Harry Fruhman, the hospital's chief financial manager. With 428 beds, it will be the largest hospital owned by individuals in the state.
"We believe that communities must be served the same way as in olden times," Dr. Singh said. "The physicians feel much happier this way because they are dealing with an administration that makes the decisions and not one in which decisions are made by remote control somewhere else. What does the central board know about what is happening in the small communities?"
In February, a group of seven doctors, including the presidents of the medical staffs of five of North Shore-L.I.J.'s hospitals, sent a letter to North Shore-L.I.J. trustees expressing concern about their individual hospitals' ability to provide quality care. In particular, they cited a five-year contract North Shore-L.I.J. Health System negotiated in 1998 with Oxford Medicare that has ended up costing the system money.
"The physician community is concerned that the projected losses from this agreement will impinge on each hospital's ability to dedicate scarce resources to the care of patients," the doctors wrote.
Richard Klarberg, North Shore-L.I.J.'s senior vice president for external affairs, said the system lost $8 million from that contract in 1999 and that the contract was expected to lose even more in 2000. He said that although the contract runs through September 2003, the health system is now negotiating with Oxford in an effort to minimize its future losses. He said 26,000 people are enrolled in Oxford Medicare in Nassau and Queens.
Despite the financial squeeze, Mr. Klarberg said the health system was "committed to maintaining the same quality of care for all patients and to ensuring that all necessary and proper medical charges are paid."
Harry Kassel, the chairman of the South Nassau Communities Hospital in Oceanside, said the drive for consolidation stemmed in part from the fact that "hospitals found themselves in terrible financial condition." Although South Nassau did not have financial problems, he said, it decided four years ago to join a health system because "it seemed that to negotiate, you needed critical mass."
So together with Winthrop-University Hospital in Mineola, it formed the Winthrop South Nassau Health System. Subsequently, that system joined Catholic Health Services, an Island-wide network of four hospitals; Brookhaven Memorial Hospital in Patchogue; and the John T. Mather Memorial Hospital in Port Jefferson to form the 11-hospital Long Island Health Network.
"They were brought together for negotiating purposes and to create clinical resource management -- a body of doctors and specialists who set high standards for all of the hospitals," Mr. Kassel said. 
The rush for community hospitals to join health-care systems is so frenetic that "you need a scorecard to keep up," said Peter M. Sullivan, the chief executive of the Nassau-Suffolk Hospital Council, an organization of nonprofit hospitals. 
"Everybody has some kind of affiliation," he said.
Some of the ties are no more than a clinical relationship, he explained. "For instance, Long Beach Hospital has a clinical affiliation with Mount Sinai so that if they need backup for a clinical problem, they have a relationship," he said. Everybody has some kind of affiliation."
Dr. Richard Falivena, the chairman of surgical services at the Brunswick Hospital Center, said "the stampede of community hospitals rushing to join" health-care alliances has forced some patients to drive to distant hospitals for care.
"They are being told that their insurance company has a better rate at North Shore and that they will have to go there, even if it means driving past two or three other hospitals to get there," he said. "And if the doctor doesn't have privileges at North Shore, the patient may have to find a new doctor. That is destructive to the relationship that people develop with their physician. Patients should have the choice of selecting their own doctor and going to their community hospital." 
Dr. Harvey F. Wachsman, a neurosurgeon who now practices law in Great Neck, said he was opposed to consolidation. "I think it's terrible," he said. "They're doing it out of desperation, out of fear of not being able to survive. The H.M.O.'s have forced many hospitals in the country to consolidate and be on a stringent diet of little money."
As a result, Dr. Wachsman said, "hospitals don't have enough nurses or enough medical programs and have reduced their number of laboratory people and residents because they can no longer afford to pay them."
And he added that "medical research in this country has really become a disaster because hospitals don't have the money to devote to it."
Dr. Wachsman is also a trustee of the State University of New York and chairman of its health and hospital committee that oversees three state medical centers, including the Stony Brook Medical Center. Several years ago, he said, when some administrators at Stony Brook pushed to become part of the North Shore Health System, he expressed his opposition. 
"I think it should remain separate because it promotes competition, and people work harder and are more creative," he said. 
But Joseph Quagliata, the president of South Nassau Communities Hospital, insisted that despite his institution's affiliation with the Winthrop South Nassau Health System, it retains its "community hospital" ambience. To remain competitive, and to make more specialized services available, the hospital has opened 10 outpatient clinics, among them a wound-care center and a center for physical rehabilitation and sports medicine. A comprehensive cancer-care center is to open later this year.
"We have significant expansion now," Mr. Quagliata said. "We borrowed about $40 million, and we're looking for another $15 million in coming months."
Another type of health-system arrangement was created by Southampton Hospital in Hampton Bays. In April 1995, Southampton and two other East End hospitals, Central Suffolk in Riverhead and Eastern Long Island in Greenport, created the Peconic Health Corporation to negotiate with insurers and to pool resources for a central laboratory and a central warehouse. 
Even with these economies of scale, in 1997 Southampton Hospital found itself $50 million in debt because of what its current president, W. Peter Daniels, described as overspending. The hospital borrowed $40 million in 1999 and after receiving substantial community support, he said, it "did better than break even" last year.
One of the principal roles of a community hospital, Mr. Daniels said, is to "provide access for the physician and patient to make an appropriate assessment at the local level and if required, to tap into specialized care."
He said his hospital was also involved in an outreach project with the East Hampton Healthcare Foundation to meet the demand for services, particularly in the crowded summer months. The foundation is erecting a satellite hospital just east of the Village of East Hampton that is expected to open in July or August. It will offer emergency triage services, along with a pharmacy and X-ray equipment. 
Paul Connor, the chief executive at Eastern Long Island, said that Peconic had negotiated better reimbursement rates for him. But he said Peconic could not provide better patient care, so last year the three hospitals decided to become affiliates of North Shore-L.I.J. 
But unlike the full-fledged members of North Shore-L.I.J., the three East End hospitals cannot ask the health system to conduct reimbursement rate negotiations for them -- those are still handled by Peconic.
"We have the best of both worlds," Mr. Daniels said. "We have the ability to be locally responsive to our communities and to participate in programs at North Shore-Long Island Jewish that I cannot do on my own."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Networks like the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System provide economies of scale, but consolidation has its critics. (Steve Berman/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Web-Based Products; 
For Realty Concerns, Internet Is a Disappointment

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
ANDREW FARKAS insists that he is still the "mean, wicked geek" he proclaimed himself to be about a year ago as he prepared to inaugurate the Edi ficeRex Internet residential service portal and other Internet-based products.
 But with EdificeRex continuing to lose money and with other initiatives folded or fading, he said his company, Insignia Financial Services, was focusing less on the possibilities offered by technology and more on real estate. The Internet term B2B, he said, now stands for "back to business." 
 The computer savvy Mr. Farkus, chairman of the company that owns the Douglas Elliman and Insignia/ESG retail and commercial brokerages in New York, said he is now painfully aware that people do not change as quickly as technology. 
The Internet ventures have cost the company about $35 million over the last 18 months, Mr. Farkas says, and produced a change in corporate attitude. "We will look skeptically upon any new technology-related investment opportunities," the company said in its year-end earnings statement.
Insignia is not the only New York area real estate company to have stubbed its toe in the New Economy last year. Companies associated with Vornado Realty Trust and the Reckson Associates Realty Corporation, two of the largest owners of commercial property in the area, backed Internet start-ups that either failed outright or never came close to meeting expectations. Although the companies that actually backed the start-ups are legally separate from the two real estate investment trusts, both are closely linked to their former parents.
In all three instances, the financial losses were not large enough to endanger the health of the overall companies. But they appear to indicate how important it seemed, even for seasoned executives, to hop on to the Internet bandwagon and its promise of limitless growth.
Through a spokesman, Vornado executives declined to comment on their Internet activities. But a search of public statements and documents on file at the Securities and Exchange Commission found that Vornado Operating Company, its Internet unit, lost a bit less than $5 million last year attempting establish something called Transportal Network.
According to an S.E.C. document, the Transportal Network was intended to "provide routing and load management services and facilitate related purchases over the Internet to independent truckers, shippers and receivers to enable them to increase efficiency."
Although improving the efficiency of trucking operations seems well removed from the real estate business, the effort was tied to the operation of AmeriCold Logistics, a chain of 104 refrigerated warehouses that is 60 percent owned by Vornado and 40 percent by Crescent Real Estate Equities, another publicly traded real estate investment trust.
The Vornado and Crescent subsidiaries decided to invest in the same ratio in developing Transportal "to pursue a business-to-business Internet opportunity relating to the temperature controlled logistics business," according to an S.E.C. filing.
A Transportal executive interviewed last year in the industry trade journal Trucking Technology said that the objective of the network was to help individual shipping companies, many of them small operations, offset the growing power of industry purchasing groups, which had been reinforced by the Internet. One aim was to cut costs by reducing the number of return trips trucks were forced to make with empty trucks.
Vornado warned in its S.E.C. filings that Transportal would actively seek additional capital from "third parties, including venture capital firms." But by the middle of last year, the venture capitalists were running away from Internet start-ups as fast as they once ran toward them.
In October, Vornado announced it was folding Transportal because of its inability to persuade outside investors to put up additional cash. For the year, Vornado Operating reported a net loss of almost $17.7 million.
Reckson formed Frontline Capital Group for much the same reason that Vornado formed Vornado Operating: to engage in businesses outside the narrow range permitted tax-exempt REIT's. Scott H. Rechler, the president and co-chief executive of Reckson, is also president and chief executive of Frontline.
Frontline invested in a number of Internet or communications companies, including OnSite Access, which was formed to wire office buildings for high speed telecommunications, and RealtyIQ, a real estate transactions reporting company, and 11 others, many of them dot-coms.
Mr. Rechler said many of those companies had expansion plans that in retrospect at least were overly ambitious. "Instead of staying small and proving their business plans and then growing by steps, they wanted to get there in a leap," he said.
But when the capital markets developed dot-com phobia last year, he said, "there was no floor under them." As the value of these companies fell, so did the value of Frontline's investments in them. Although the company stopped investing about midyear, the damage had been done.
BUT the company did have a big winner in HQ Global Workplaces, a provider of temporary office space, which has grown from 44 office centers in 1998 to 462 by the end of last year. So Frontline's managers divided the company into two units, one for HQ and one for the others, which were written off to the point that they were less than 1 percent of the company's assets by year-end.
Frontline reported that the non-HQ part of the company posted a loss of $204.3 million for 2000, compared with a loss of $37.1 million the year earlier. Including HQ, Frontline had a loss of $234.9 million for 2000, compared with $39.8 million in 1999.
Meanwhile, Frontline's stock, which traded as high as $45 a share as recently as last May, is currently trading about $10 a share.
Mr. Rechler said Frontline was spun off to Reckson shareholders as a separate company to avoid any dilution of the value of the REIT's shares because of speculative investments in start-up companies.
But Reckson did provide Frontline with a credit line of $100 million, of which $92 million has been drawn down. Analysts have speculated that Frontline may try to take the HQ business public or sell it to get the cash to repay Reckson.
Mr. Rechler said the shareholders in Frontline have done well despite the collapse of the high technology sector. He said the company was spun off in 1998 at $1 a share. Even at today's stock price, the shareholders have enjoyed a tenfold increase in the value of their holdings over two years, he said.
Mr. Farkas, whose company invested in 17 Web companies in addition to Insignia's internal Internet developments, said the most important lesson he had learned over the last 18 months is that "the willingness of people to change their behavior over a short time is extremely limited."
He said despite the efficiencies that are a least theoretically possible in buying and selling over the Internet, even business people were not willing to break with existing procedures. "The world was not quite ready," he said. "People want to do business with other people; they are reluctant to do business with a box."
Even where consumers have shown themselves willing to make modest purchases, like books or CD's, online, the companies involved have not been able to post profits. "If they can't make a profit, they will go away," he said.
Another problem, he said, is the notion that has taken hold in many quarters that information delivered over the Internet is free. And advertising is not likely to be able to support Web sites with the services provided by EdificeRex, which include restaurant reviews, commuting tips and commentary on the social scene. RexOffice, a separate building management and purchasing site, was merged into a larger group last year. 
"Advertising pays for about 50 percent of the burn rate," or cost, of the site, he said, adding that the costs of the site had been scaled back to less than $1 million a year.
"It would only take a couple of dollars a month per user to make it prosper," he said. "Twenty-five dollars a year and it would pay its own way. But people do not want to pay for a service that had been free."
One solution, he said, might be to turn off the site for a year or two and reintroduce it with a modest fee attached. He did not say if the company actually planned to take that action.
In the meantime, he said, the company is seeking to bring in partners who can add to the mix of information available at the site. In particular, he said he is looking for content that can be sold.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
Long-Delayed Offices Are Rising in Elmwood Park

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
AFTER a decade of delays and false starts, the third building in an office complex is rising on the east side of River Drive in Elmwood Park, and new plans are advancing to continue the development on the west side of the road with three more office structures and a hotel.
 The 86,000-square-foot structure is being built on speculation, an anomaly in Bergen County. When finished in July, it will complete the 12-acre River Drive Center, containing 240,000 square feet in three four-story buildings. 
 The plan for the west side, a proposed $100 million project that still must be approved by the borough's zoning board, calls for a seven-story 168-room hotel and 500,000 square feet of offices in buildings of 4, 6 and 12 stories as well as retail space. That five-year project would be built in phases on 20 acres overlooking the Passaic River. The first phase would consist of the hotel, a 98,000-square-foot office building and the retail space -- a bank branch and a restaurant, said Joseph P. Langan. He is president of the River Drive Construction Company of Elmwood Park, the managing partner for the investment groups developing the parcels. 
An investor in both groups is Mr. Langan's father, Bernard, who also runs an engineering firm bearing his name. The firms of both father and son occupy space in one of the existing buildings at River Drive Center. 
The projects are a departure from the norm in Elmwood Park, a mostly residential borough of 20,000. The western site is among the last sizable tracts open to development in the 2.5 square mile community. For that parcel, the developers are seeking a height variance from the borough's four-story limit for offices and six-story limit for hotels.
Ralph Alvarez, chairman of the borough's zoning board, said there are concerns about the proposed tall buildings and their demands on the borough's water and sewer systems. For residents who live near the site, the greatest worry is the increased traffic on River Drive, which is already heavily traveled, he said. 
Elmwood Park's mayor, Richard A. Mola, noted, "It is a choice parcel; something will be developed there." So the question is how to improve the borough's economic base without congesting the area, he said.
Joseph Langan said that despite setbacks the partners never gave up on developing the sites because they "had invested several millions of dollars into them" and wanted to capitalize on an attractive location. The parcels are near Exit 61 of Interstate 80, Exits 156 and 157 of the Garden State Parkway and Route 46.
Mr. Langan said the partners were proceeding now despite the uncertainties over the national economy because, among other reasons, highway access was enhanced with the completion in December of the final 1.8 miles of Route 21.
With the road completed, there is now a direct link from Newark to Route 46 in Clifton and to Route 20 in Paterson, Fair Lawn and Elmwood Park, and, in turn, the commute from the River Drive site to Newark has been cut in half to 15 minutes.
He said the end of the road work had also enabled him to buy eight state-owned acres on the west side of River Drive, which in an earlier plan had been set aside for the last leg of Route 21. When the route was changed, however, the land became surplus. 
The eight acres, which Mr. Langan said he bought in January, were added to the 10 acres the partners already owned. They are also under contract to buy two more acres, he said.
The partners have been on a bumpy ride in the last decade in their drive to develop their property on River Drive. After the second building on the east side was built in 1991, the recession caused plans for the third to be put on hold. Also postponed was the project across the street, which then included a 14-story hotel and a 12-story office building on a 10 acres.
By the mid-90's the developers dropped those plans and proposed a retail-entertainment complex on the west-side parcel. But that project, too, was abandoned because of objections, mainly over traffic, from nearby residents.
Meanwhile, the partners spent years debating or negotiating with the state about the fate of its eight-acre road-project site. Once the land was declared surplus, it was proposed as, among other things, the site for a salt dome, used for storing road salt. 
Last year the partners acquired the eight acres for $2.3 million at a state-run auction. Since then they have been advancing their current plan for the west-side parcel and started constructing the final building at River Drive Center. 
AS of the first quarter of this year the vacancy rate for Class A buildings in Bergen County had risen to 11.5 percent, from 7.7 percent in the fourth quarter of 2000 and from 9 percent in the first quarter last year, according to Cushman & Wakefield, the national real estate firm. Among the reasons for the increase is the return of blocks of space to the market, mainly through subleases, because of corporate consolidations and mergers. At the same time the average annual asking rent for prime space was $29.94 a square foot, up from $29.41 in the fourth quarter of 2000 and from $28.22 in the first quarter of 2000. 
Compared with the pace of price increases in recent years, "there has been some easing on pricing, and more space is available," said William C. Hansen, president of NAI/James E. Hansen, a commercial brokerage company in Hackensack. But, he added, Bergen County "is still strong and that there is little room for new development will keep the market in check." 
James D. Hersh, a vice president at the Paramus office of CB Richard Ellis, which is handling the leasing for the latest River Drive building, added, "Leases are expiring and companies continue to grow and shrink." 
One of the few other new developments in the area is the renovation of a 100,000-square-foot building at 395 West Passaic Street in Rochelle Park. The M. Alfieri Company, a development company based in Metro Park that owns the building, stripped it to its steel skeleton after its sole tenant, Toys "R" Us, moved out two years ago and invested $5 million to refurbish it. 
Since the renovation was completed last June, 90 percent of the space has been leased at annual rents of $27 a square foot, Michael Alfieri, president of the development company, said.
As for the River Drive building, Mr. Hersh said, "There are still few large blocks of new space for tenants to choose from, and with asking rents of $27 a square foot we are still below other Class A buildings in the area." 
Mr. Hersh said he expected to draw tenants from older buildings elsewhere in the county that are looking for new space with functional layouts and amenities, as well as those relocating from Manhattan to cut costs. 
Mr. Hansen said that though the county could absorb some additional space, he is unsure if it could accommodate the 500,000 square feet of space proposed on the west side of River Drive. 
Mr. Langan said the scale of the current proposal is necessary "to compete" and make the economics work, and he is confident of his ability to market it. As part of the approval process for the final building at River Drive Center, the developers will widen the last section of River Drive from two to four lanes as they had done to earlier sections. They will also install a traffic light at Slater Drive, which leads into the east and west components of the project.
Mr. Langan said the partners know additional road improvements are needed to support the entire project and will explore with the state's Department of Transportation the possibility of rebuilding the ramps at Interchange 61 of I-80. He said he was optimistic that work on the project's first phase could begin by this summer. 
The borough is cautious. "We've been down this road before," said Mr. Alvarez, the zoning board official. "But assuming everything can be worked out, the project would be a benefit to everyone concerned -- and that is the bottom line"

GRAPHIC: Photo: The third building, bottom, at River Drive Center is to be ready in July. (Sean O'Brian) Map of New Jersey.
