HEADLINE: Holding Back a Human Tide 

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
IT is springtime in Southampton, when diehard farmers plow, city people sign summer leases and builders churn out new McMansions row upon row in what were once farms and open spaces.
 In the building-crazed town, all the studies, comprehensive plans and building moratoriums undertaken by local officials in recent years seem barely to have slowed the spread of these large-lot, jarringly expensive second homes of mock-heroic proportions, now as much a visual mainstay as the open land they overran. 
 But in Southampton and the neighboring towns of East Hampton, Riverhead and Southold, powerful forces and public money are at work, perhaps in a more coordinated way than ever before, to finally and forever save the less than 36,000 acres of surviving farmland and permanently preserve thousands more acres of open space and watersheds on the North and South Forks, the most rural and agricultural areas remaining on Long Island.
Experts and public officials familiar with land-use patterns on the East End say the next four years will see the final set-to between preservation and development in the only part of Long Island yet to succumb to an eastward-spreading suburbanization on a 50-year winning streak. 
Spending for preservation has hit historic highs since 1998, when the four towns' voters approved 2 percent real estate transfer taxes to finance preservation and Suffolk voters -- with large pluralities on the East End -- approved a $60 million parks, farms and open space program. During the three-year period, governments have spent more than $100 million and committed tens of millions more.
With climbing land prices and East End development pressure so far hardly pausing as the economy cools, some local officials -- and all of the region's influential conservation groups -- say that even more must be done, and soon. 
"We have risen to a crescendo of land purchasing activity," said Stuart Lowrie, the director of government relations for the Nature Conservancy on Long Island, a group that preserves plant and wildlife habitat. "I wish I could say with confidence that we have been able to keep up."
But many farmers, developers and workers in the building trades are skeptical of the process, and land owners worry about preservation they say will be at their expense.
In all four towns the wheels are rolling, but on different paths.
In conservative Southold, in a bolt from the blue, the town board has devised a zoning change in agricultural areas that would allow just one house on every five acres. The town supervisor, Jean W. Cochran, said development in neighboring Riverhead spurred the town to action.
"We've spent $13 million in grants and we buy farm development rights, do clustering and it goes on and on and on," Mrs. Cochran said. "But when you look at what's happening in Riverhead and other places, it's not enough."
Mrs. Cochran grew up in Riverhead when it was still very rural, but now looks at commercial and residential development in her old hometown with regret. "It does make me sad what's happened," she said. "It's headed our way, but we are going to fight it like hell." 
Mrs. Cochran said the five-acre zoning, the most restrictive ever proposed on Long Island for an entire agricultural area, was "the quickest way to assure Southold preserves as much of its farmland as possible."
The proposal appears to have the support of a majority of the Southold town board, which is scheduled to vote on it as early as June.
In Riverhead, where nearly 40 percent of the remaining East End farmland is located, Supervisor Robert Kozakiewicz, a lawyer and farm boy who heads a town board often criticized for accommodating developers, was also feeling some pangs about development.
"It seems to be reaching a critical mass," Mr. Kozakiewicz said. "Southold has moved to a five-acre push, Southampton has their master plan and Riverhead is kind of squeezed between them and we've done nothing."
But that may change. Riverhead, one of the last places in New York to adopt zoning, is considering updating its master plan with a consultant's recommendation that future development in the town's more than 17,000 acres of farmland be clustered on 15 percent of farm parcels.
Such a requirement, which the town is still weeks if not months from deciding upon, would preserve 85 percent of the farmland with no direct public expense. But some critics said it could result in unattractive, highly concentrated housing on the remaining portion.
Other criticism was more sweeping. The Riverhead-based Long Island Farm Bureau said the Riverhead proposal was "unrealistic, unworkable and overly restrictive" and would reduce farm owners' equity. 
The bureau's executive director, Joseph Gergela, also sent an angry letter to Southold protesting that it had not been consulted about that town's agricultural rezoning proposal, which it opposes.
Joseph F. Gazza, a lawyer and developer from Quogue, voiced the misgivings of many developers when he said, "Whenever I see some kind of plan that talks about preserving something without buying it all, I always have skepticism." 
Warning signals have also come from the Long Island Association, the regional chambr of commerce, which has identified the islandwide shortage of affordable housing as the leading threat to its economy. Upzoning or generous set-aside provisions could make it more difficult to turn farmland into anything but the most expensive homes.
"The need for affordable housing is at least as acute on the East End of Long Island as it is elsewhere, and any land use plan out there should take that into account," said Matthew T. Crosson, president of the Long Island Association. 
East Hampton has made affordable housing a top priority because of evidence that local residents continue to be forced away by high prices. A comprehensive plan update, for which the town hired the Long Island Regional Planning Board executive director, Lee E. Koppelman, may lead to new steps for affordable units as well as for preservation.
With so much at stake, the struggle over land has increasingly become ammunition for East End politics. An environmental political action group, the New York League of Conservation Voters, has announced that it was planning a first-ever effort to recruit environmental candidates for East End town offices.
"This is a real critical time on the East End, and a lot of these decisions will be made on a local level," said Marcia Bystryn, the league's executive director. "Voters have said over and over that they want preservation, so now it's time to do it."
Another group, the Long Island Pine Barrens Society, said it would begin a lobbying campaign later this month to increase and expedite town and county spending for preservation programs approved by voters.
Richard Amper, the group's executive director, said the governments were moving too slowly. "It's like a roach motel," he said. "The money goes in but it doesn't come out. Now we have to make sure the politicians spend our money as we have directed."
Mr. Amper's group and others want the county to borrow against future sales tax revenues designated for land and water preservation in order to maximize purchasing now. But key officials remain opposed to the borrowing. Paul Sabatino, the counsel to the Legislature, has said that too much borrowing now would increase debt service.
A bill pending in the state Legislature assures the county that it has authority to borrow against the revenues and encourages it to do so, but the effect of passage on the county officials remained unclear. The county executive, Robert J. Gaffney, who increased his support of farm and land preservation beginning in 1997, said he supported the bill.
Much attention now centers on Riverhead, which appears to be eclipsing Southampton as the East End development hot spot.
Among environmental groups, the town is viewed as an easy target for developers because of accommodating zoning and what many see as a lack of commitment to preservation or even a pro-development bias among some officials.
The county's director of real estate, Allan D. Grecco, said the town had been helpful in advancing Suffolk's now 25-year-old farmland preservation program, which involves the purchase of farm development rights. More purchases have occurred in Riverhead than in any other town. But the county-financed program has protected less than 4,000 farm acres to date.
Riverhead's land-use consultant, Land Ethics Inc., said its proposal to limit building to 15 percent of farm parcels was designed to make conversion of farmland into residential developments "less appealing for landowners and developers."
In recent years, several farm owners in Riverhead have converted fields and in least one case surrounding woods into golf courses. The Riverhead consultant urged that golf courses and so-called golf communities be prohibited in agricultural areas and no longer counted as open space. 
Mr. Kozakiewicz, like Mrs. Cochran a Republican, said it was too soon to comment on the proposals. He said he opposed a rezoning plan such as the one proposed in Southold or a building moratorium and preferred to await the revised comprehensive plan.
"Something has to be done," he said. "The question is what. We can't sit back and simply ignore."
In Southampton, the town, on its own and in partnership with the county and the state, has set a record pace for land protection over the past five years yet still seems in the throes of a land-to-houses transformation that is locally abhorred and blamed for worsening traffic. The $28 million spent by the town to acquire 800 acres since 1996 has not satisfied environmental groups and other critics who say the town studies too much and acts too little.
When the town supervisor, Vincent J. Cannuscio, announced early this month that he would not run for a fourth term, he listed among his accomplishments that no other administration had done more to preserve farms and open space.
But his critics said they would remember Mr. Cannuscio, a builder, as the obstructionist at the helm during a time when the town seemed to drag its heels on preservation despite overwhelming local support for a more active town role.
Typical of the slow action, they said, was the town's failure to put in place new laws to limit development in agricultural areas during a 10-month moratorium on large subdivisions in farm areas that expired in early February.
"The problem in Southampton is that after all the comprehensive planning there still isn't that much coming over the hill," said Robert DeLuca, president of the Group for the South Fork in Bridgehampton. He described the town planning board as "the building approval arm of the development industry."
Mr. DeLuca's group sued the planning board after it approved a 28-lot subdivision on a 102-acre property at West Neck Hills, saying it shortcut required environmental reviews the land's primeval woods, swamps and wetlands required. But in a twist, the town board heartily agreed on the importance of the preserving the West Neck Hills land. Last week, despite the planning board approval, it was in negotiations with the owner to set a purchase price. 
The town's failure to produce regulations also frustrated builders prevented from commencing major projects during the moratorium and still without a resolution to questions of what would and would not be permitted.
The town board is now considering a new 60-day moratorium on residential subdivisions on farmlands to allow mre time for approval of new regulations recommended in the town's updated comprehensive plan. Those regulations may include clustering, increases in open space set-asides and financial incentives for farmers and farm owners not to sell their land to developers for set periods of time to allow for future public purchase.
On April 24, the Southampton board will hold a public hearings on 10 proposed town laws to preserve farmland to accomplish these goals and others.
East Hampton has the smallest acreage of farmland of the four larger East End towns (Shelter Island has no farmland at all) but a longer tradition for preservation, dating to building moratoriums in the 1980's. Many key parcels have since been preserved.
The East Hampton supervisor, Jay Schneiderman, said that within the past two years 24 properties on 800 acres were preserved at a cost of $41 million, of which the town provided more than $20 million. The remainder came from the state, Suffolk County and private groups including the Nature Conservancy.
Mr. Schneiderman, a Republican, said the town was in contract to buy a 40-acre ocean parcel in Napeague for $8.4 million. In February, the town and Suffolk County split the $9 million cost to buy the 165-acre Jacob's Farm in Springs as a nature preserve. Last year, in a purchase that ended years of failed attempts, the town, county and state and the Nature Conservancy joined in a $17.7 million purchase of the nearly 100-acre oceanfront Shadmoor property in Montauk. It is now a state park.
The town has identified some 5,300 acres of watershed and open space that would cost an estimated $145 million to preserve. Mr. Schneiderman said such a cost could never be borne by the town alone and would require assistance from other governments.
To speed the pace of purchases, East Hampton borrowed against future revenues from the 2 percent real estate transfer tax, an approach also used in Southampton but rejected in Riverhead and Southold, where the transfer tax has resulted in far lower revenues.
Mr. Schneiderman said that East Hampton was now "pretty well tapped out" and was finding it difficult to wrest more money from the county. He said county legislators from western Suffolk towns wanted preservation money spent in their districts. "It's becoming harder and harder to get the funds," he said.
Mr. Grecco, the county real estate director, said Suffolk spent a record $47 million last year for open land and watershed purchase and protection, a portion of it on the East End, and would spend a similar amount this year.
Though hundreds of farm acres continue to disappear each year, Suffolk remains the biggest agricultural county in New York based on produce value. That is because agriculture on the East Ed has morphed into an intensive greenhouse, vineyard, farm stand and agro-tourism industry far different from the potato realm that ruled until the 1970's.
A recent farm equipment auction at the Cichanowicz farm on Sound Avenue in Riverhead underscored the changes. The Entenmann family of bakery fame, operators of the adjacent Martha Clara Vineyards, is buying the 68-acre farm and will plant 25 acres in vines this spring. The Cichanowicz farm stand will become a wine tasting room.
Though neither buyer nor seller would confirm it, the word in the tight-knit agricultural community was that the Entenmanns paid up to $50,000 an acre for the farm, or roughly twice what farmland had typically sold for in the area.
Charles Cichanowicz Sr., who bought the farm in the 1940's and grew potatoes and other field crops there, took a dim view of government steps to preserve farmland. "They took the land from the Indians," he said. "Is that what they are trying to do now to the farmers?"

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester; 
A Rye Brook Project Invokes New Urbanism's Ideas

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
TWO years after the first homes at BelleFair at Rye Brook went on the market, a meeting house and country-style store have opened at the development, fulfilling what its developer, Mitchell C. Hochberg, describes as his long-held dream of introducing concepts of New Urbanism to Westchester.
 "I wanted to tie a lifestyle to a way of life -- to build a neighborhood, not just houses," said Mr. Hochberg, president of Spectrum Skanska, the home-building and development division of Skanska A.B., based in Stockholm, the fifth-largest construction company in the world. 
 The meeting house, the village green, houses with front porches and the sidewalks where children can ride their bikes remind Mr. Hochberg of a more neighborly way of life. "When I was growing up, everyone was out on the streets," he said. "You met people at the local candy store. I want to bring that feeling back with my projects." 
Watching the children at BelleFair debark from a school bus one recent afternoon and make a dash for the candy section of the Corner Stone Market, a nostalgic Mr. Hochberg said, "This all hits a nerve in me."
But sentimentality aside, eschewing the cookie-cutter model of suburban tract housing has also been good for business. Among other things, the New Urbanism concept with its features of the old-fashioned hometown is a stong selling device.
"Yes, we're in this to make money -- not just out of the graciousness of our hearts," the builder said, explaining that many of the life-style extras at BelleFair -- like the 20,000-square-foot meeting house and the store stocked with licorice and "sweet and sours" -- also help offset the harsh reality of the development's noisy next-door neighbor: the Westchester County Airiport.
Without the extras that allow BelleFair to stand out among other developments, buyers leery of planes flying low over their homes may have passed it up, he conceded.
His strategy appears to have worked. Almost all 261 units at the former site of High Point Psychiatric Hospital on King Street have been sold, and the few resales that have come on the market are being snapped up fast, said Peter Raider, an associate broker for Houlihan/Lawrence in Rye.
On BelleFair's oval-shaped village green, about the size of a football field, the 20,000-square-foot meeting house -- complete with a New England-style clock tower -- was designed to foster interaction among residents. It offers three floors of recreational options in a structure built into a hillside.
Leila Namin, the mother of two small children, said the concept has clearly worked for her. "I've met more people and made more friends in the last two weeks since the pool opened than in the first nine months after I moved here," she said.
The main level of the meeting house, actually the third floor, features a lounge with a fireplace, a 60-inch television, a study, pool table, kitchen, children's playroom and library with computer stations. The lounge overlooks a gymnasium and basketball court, which is next to a large fitness area. On the lowest level, residents can use either a heated indoor pool and a whirlpool spa during the colder months, or an outdoor pool. This level also leads out to a plaza with an old-fashioned bandstand for special events.
Wendy Bosalavage, president of American Leisure, a recreation and real estate management firm in New City, N.Y., that is overseeing the operation of the meeting house, said the concepts at BelleFair reflect a larger sociological trend: the need in a technology-driven world "to touch and feel each other again."
American Leisure is under contract to the homeowners association, which pays it out of the members' monthly maintenance fees.
Next door to the meeting house, the Corner Stone Market has become another place where BelleFair residents congregate. It features a bakery, a deli and a small coffee "bistro." The market also sells basic groceries as well as precooked meals and pizza to take out, and it provides catering service. 
BelleFair is Westchester's first New Urbanism-type development, which is "the coming thing for land use, the cutting edge," said Brit Perkins, a local architect who is a principal of EDI Architecture P.C., which designs housing developments and has offices in Manhattan, San Francisco and Houston. "Lots of their ideas are finally making their way into the mainstream."
NEW URBANISM, a 10-year-old architectural and planning movement features self-contained communities that are somewhat independent of automobiles and offer links to mass transit. BelleFair, for example, operates a daily shuttle bus service to the nearby Metro-North train station in Port Chester. Also, instead of single-family homes on large lots, the development clusters the housing to leave tracts of open land.
In contrast with the backyard-oriented developments built during the 1970's, New Urbanism houses often feature porches that face the street to foster more interaction between neighbors. 
The movement also espouses a mix of housing types to draw all age groups and family types. BelleFair includes detached homes from 2,000 to 3,300 square feet and attached houses from 1,640 to 2,200 square feet. The homes now sell for about $550,000 for attached units to as much as about $900,000. Twelve attached town houses have been set aside for sale to buyers with moderate incomes. Priority will be given to Rye Brook village employees and local teachers, police auxiliary members, firefighters and volunteer ambulance corps workers.
The demographic mix is one factor that led John and Louise Viaggio, who are both in their mid-70's, to purchase a home at BelleFair two years ago. Mr. Viaggio, a retired lawyer, said the couple was not ready "to be living in a community of old people."
"Not only that," he said, "but this place also has an ethnic mix -- blacks, whites, Jewish, Christian. We prefer that."
Twenty percent of the adults at BelleFair are 55 or older. Another 16 percent are 45 to 54. Thirty-one percent are 35 to 44, and 31 percent are 25 to 34. Two percent of the residents did not give their age. BelleFair does not keep data on the ethnic or religious mix in the development. 
Construction is about to begin on a 166-unit senior rental housing community built by Forest City Daly of New York City. Scheduled to open in about 18 months, it will the first independent-living building for the elderly in the area to be constructed as part of a larger residential community. The units will be studios, one-bedrooms and two-bedrooms with kitchens in a three- or four- story building with a clapboard exterior.
For its younger residents, Spectrum Skanska recently broke ground on a new 5,000-square-foot, stand-alone child day-care center to be next to the meeting house and the Corner Stone Market.
One question that has yet to be answered is just how self-sustaining economically some of the enterprises at New Urbanism communities can be. "It's the chicken and egg thing," Mr. Perkins, the architect, said. "Which comes first? Often such developments are not large enough to support a retail establishment, for example."
The country store at BelleFair, managed by Corner Stone Caterers of Rye, will try to draw from a wider audience than just the residents of BelleFair, said Gary Stone, who runs the business with his wife, Liz. "We going to have to draw from surrounding communities as well," he said.
In addition to BelleFair, Spectrum Skanska's other active residential neighborhoods include Legend Yacht and Beach Club in Glen Cove on Long Island, Valimar in White Plains and the Legends at Purchase. Spectrum Skanska, which has its headquarters in Valhalla, is the construction and development manager for Trump National Golf Club in Briarcliff Manor. 
Later this year, Spectrum Skanska is planning to open sales for two new residential communities: Mansion Ridge in Monroe in Orange County and the Legends at Half Hollow in Dix Hills on Long Island.

GRAPHIC: Photo: BelleFair consists of 261 housing units, including both town houses and single-family homes with porches. (Richard L. Harbus for The New York Times) Map of Westchester highlights BelleFair.

HEADLINE: Condos in Washington: $1,000 a Square Foot and Up 

BYLINE:  By JAMES R. HARDCASTLE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
A NEW YORK CITY developer is demonstrating that people will pay Manhattan prices for condominium apartments in Washington if they get the right blend of prestige, convenience and luxury.
 Millennium Partners has sold two-thirds of the 161 units in the two 11-story Residences at Ritz-Carlton apartment buildings that it opened last fall, said Christopher M. Jeffries, one of the concern's founding partners. 
Prices range from $765,000 to $5.6 million for the units, which vary in size from 1,100-square-foot one-bedroom-plus-den apartments to 5,600-square-foot penthouse suites with rooftop terraces. The prices have increased five times since preopening sales began in April 1999.
Owners of the condominiums have access to such Ritz-Carlton amenities as room, maid and valet service as well as their own concierge desk. The condominiums, a 300-room Ritz-Carlton hotel and a vast 100,000-square-foot sports and fitness center are all part of a $260 million mixed-use project developed by Millennium. It takes up an entire block seven blocks northwest of the White House in the city's West End area. 
The site, bounded by 22nd and 23rd Streets Northwest between L and M Streets, is among the largest vacant properties developed in downtown Washington in recent years. It is convenient to both the exclusive Georgetown neighborhood and Washington's principal office districts.
Mr. Jeffries said the average price for the condominiums it sells at the Residences at Ritz-Carlton was about $750 a square foot. This is well over twice the most expensive new units built in the Washington metropolitan area in the last decade, said Anthony Lanier, president of Eastbanc Inc., Millennium's local development partner.
A Millennium spokesman, Matthew Hall, said his company was selling condos atop a Ritz-Carlton Hotel on the southernmost tip of Manhattan for $654,000 to $6.25 million. The price works out to about $900 per square foot, he said. 
The prices for Millennium's Battery Park City apartments will soon be challenged by a second Residences at Ritz-Carlton development in Washington, which the company has under way in Georgetown eight blocks west of its recently opened project. 
Next to an elevated freeway that separates Georgetown from the Potomac River, the company is constructing five buildings that will contain another Ritz-Carlton hotel, apartments and movie theaters. As its central lobby, the complex will use a turn-of-the-last-century brick structure that once served as a municipal incinerator.
A 13-screen, 2,800-seat movie theater will be on the lowest level of the 500,000-square-foot complex, less than half the area of the first project. A 93-room Ritz-Carlton hotel will sit on the floors immediately above the theater. 
On the uppermost five levels of the six-story complex, Millennium will build 25 to 30 large condominium apartments 3,000 to 6,000 square feet in size, each with a view of the Potomac, Mr. Lanier said. The units are expected to sell for between $3 million and $7 million, he said, an average of $1,000 to $1,200 a square foot. Projected completion date is the last quarter of this year.
Millennium is building similar luxury condominiums on Central Park South in New York and on Boston Common, as well as in San Francisco's South of Market area. 
Its strategy, pioneered in its buildings in the Lincoln Center area of Manhattan, is to acquire large sites -- offering dramatic views if possible -- at signature locations in major cities and then to develop mixed-use projects, often anchored by a Ritz-Carlton or Four Seasons hotel.
Millennium's projects typically incorporate vast multiscreen stadium-style theaters and sports clubs to generate energy and excitement, Mr. Jeffries said. 
As part of its strategy, Millennium develops and sells luxury condominiums to recover development costs for the overall project. The company retains an ownership interest in the hotels, retail properties and sports and entertainment centers it develops, Mr. Jeffries said. 
Demand generated by the for-sale apartments improves the economies of operations for the hotels and the sports and entertainment facilities.
MILLENNIUM'S equity partners for current and future projects include five German financial firms; Goldman Sachs & Company's Whitehall Street real estate limited partnerships; the billionaire George Soros and the Quantum Realty Fund, which Mr. Soros's firm manages; and Citicorp Real Estate. The total capital commitment for the projects recently completed or under construction is $3 billion. Partners' equity in the ventures totals about $1 billion. 
The 11-story West End project was the first to open because it is not a high-rise project and could therefore be designed and built more quickly. High-rise projects cannot be built in Washington because of federal limitations on building height.
One reason Millennium is moving so fast to get Residences at Ritz-Carlton projects up in major cities across the country is that it has no corner on the condominium-premium hotel concept, Mr. Jeffries said. And at least two fellow developers are well along with plans for competing projects.
Across the Potomac River from Millennium's Georgetown project, where height regulations are far less restrictive, the developers JBG of Washington and TrizecHahn of Toronto have secured land-use approval in Arlington County, Va., for Waterview, a mixed-use project that includes a 28-story tower containing a 220-room hotel with 65 condominium units on its top 11 floors. The building will be twice as high as the tallest building in Washington.
The site offers unobstructed views of the Potomac River, Georgetown and Washington's major monuments. The architectural firm of Pei Cobb Freed & Partners is designing the office building and the exterior of the hotel. 
A JBG partner, Brian Coulter, said the JBG-TrizecHahn venture would soon select one of two premium hotel operators to manage the hotel and provide service to the condominium units. Construction is expected to begin this fall. Prices for the units have not been set, but 2,500-square-foot apartments there will probably begin at $1.5 million to $1.75 million.
Mr. Jeffries of Millennium said nearly all the buyers moving into the West End project are married couples between 40 and 60 years old.
"There is plenty of wealth in the Washington, D.C., area," he said. "There are a lot of single family houses selling for $3 million, $4 million or $5 million." Now that their children aren't home, Mr. Jeffries said, buyers "are trading cutting the grass for wonderful apartments selling for a couple of million dollars."
Barbara McLeod and her husband, Bruce, were among the first owners to move into Millennium's West End condominiums last November. And they fit the buyer's profile spelled out by Millennium's Mr. Jeffries well.
Ms. McLeod, 55, said she and her husband wanted to live in the city when they first moved to the area from Florida in 1986, but "we didn't feel it was that safe." Instead, they moved to a series of homes in suburban Virginia and Maryland.
Although she must drive to her public relations job at Cable and Wireless in Tysons Corner, Va., she said she rarely drives after returning from work. Her husband walks two blocks and takes the subway two stops to commute to his job in software sales in the Ronald Reagan Building on Pennsylvania Avenue.
She said morning workouts at the Sports Club/L.A. gym have become part of her daily routine. Because the club is only an elevator ride away, she said, she now has time to try new activities like boxing, basketball and jumping rope that she probably would not have time to attempt if she had to drive to a gym.
She said two of her favorite services at the Residences at the Ritz-Carlton were valet parking and the availability of bellmen upon returning from shopping trips.

HEADLINE: Another University, Another Turnaround 

BYLINE:  By PAUL ZIELBAUER 

 BODY:
EVAN S. DOBELLE does not surf. He is not leaving the helm of Trinity College, on this city's south side, for the University of Hawaii because of the weather, but, as he will tell anyone who asks, to help another struggling university save itself.
 "That's what I do best," Mr. Dobelle said. "Turn things around." 
 Mr. Dobelle, 55, surprised many of his East Coast peers and his own board of trustees by announcing that he would leave Trinity's wrought-iron confines in June for Honolulu, where, he said, he expected to face the greatest challenge of his career. The University of Hawaii, which comprises 10 campuses on 6 islands, is beset by administrative and financial problems.
Ronald Thomas, Mr. Dobelle's chief of staff, was appointed by the board to act as interim president for up to one year. A national search for Mr. Dobelle's successor will begin later this year. 
Since his arrival in 1995, Mr. Dobelle has been widely credited with turning things around at Trinity, where annual tuition is more than $32,000. Average SAT scores of incoming freshmen are up 31 points, to 1271; more than half of Trinity's alumni now donate money to the school, an usually high percentage, and instead of fencing itself off from Frog Hollow, the black and Hispanic neighborhood surrounding its 100-acre campus, the college has built a bridge to it. 
Mr. Dobelle recruited Janice Perlman, the founder of the nonprofit Mega-Cities Project, an effort to share innovative public policies among cities around the globe, to teach an innovative urban studies class. He hired 20 faculty members and arranged to build another dormitory, which opened in September, and a new admissions building set to open in May.
But Mr. Dobelle's signal achievement, state and city officials said, was the Learning Corridor, a $175 million urban renewal and education project to connect the private college's students with the hardscrabble neighborhood that surrounds the campus. Over five years, the project razed and rebuilt several downtrodden city blocks into a modern campus for a Montessori elementary school, a public middle school, and two arts and sciences academies for local public school students. Trinity donated $6 million toward the project, which took five years to build and opened in September.
"He kind of filled a vacuum," said Harry J. Hartley, who was the president of the University of Connecticut from 1990 to 1996. "He decided to take the lead with this Learning Corridor in a very imaginative and creative way."
Reflecting on Mr. Dobelle's departure, Mr. Hartley said, "I view it as a huge loss for the state of Connecticut."
Thomas S. Johnson, the chairman of the college's trustees and of the Greenpoint Financial Corporation in New York City, called Mr. Dobelle "almost unique in American education, in being effective at linking the interests of Trinity to the interests of the community around Trinity."
The college's board, he added, was at first surprised to hear their president was leaving for, of all places, Hawaii. But the more they learned of the university's problems, he said, the more it made sense. 
Starting July 1, Mr. Dobelle will succeed Kenneth P. Mortimer, who is retiring after eight years as president, and begin a seven-year contract that will pay him $442,000 a year, compared with the $275,000 plus deferred compensation he earned at Trinity, he said.
There will be no honeymoon. Hawaii's 3,000-member faculty, without a contract since 1998, is scheduled to begin a strike for higher wages on April 5. Persistent student protests outside Mr. Dobelle's future offices have started a public debate over a plan to increase tuition. Cuts to the university's $700 million budget have prompted some faculty defections and held up plans to build a new branch..
"They've got complicated times," Mr. Dobelle said in a telephone interview from Honolulu. "To me that's a real opportunity. I don't know how many universities are about to go on strike."

HEADLINE: Where Westchester Goes to College 

BYLINE:  By MERRI ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
WITH its storied wealth and excellent schools, it's no surprise that Westchester County sends dozens of high school graduates to prestigious and expensive universities like Columbia and Wesleyan.
 But by a startling margin, the No. 1 destination of the county's public school graduates is Westchester Community College, where the tuition is a mere $2,350 a year. 
 A survey of 27 high schools by the Westchester section found that last year, 610 seniors went to Westchester Community College, almost five times the number who went to the second most popular choice, the State University of New York in Albany, which drew 129.
Next on the list was Pace University, with 113; Iona College, with 92; and SUNY Oneonta, with 72. In fact, of the top 19 colleges on the list, only one -- Boston University -- is not in New York State. 
Among Ivy League schools, Cornell was by far the most popular, with 55, followed by the University of Pennsylvania, with 33.
At first glance, these figures might seem unexpected, given the county's reputation for affluence and the ambitions of its high-achieving parents. But to those who advise high school students on the college application process, the results were predictable.
"Not everybody here goes far away and spends oodles of money," said Susan Dickson, assistant director of guidance at Rye High School. "Within Westchester, there is a huge diversity factor. You've got families in million-dollar homes, and people who are renting, so you're going to have a wide disparity in colleges."
Even at Horace Greeley High School in affluent Chappaqua, which sent 26 seniors to Ivy League colleges -- more than any other school that participated in the survey -- cost is important.
"We forget how expensive education is, and if you're earning $60,000 a year, you don't have $35,000 to spend on college," said Penny Oberg, chairwoman of the counseling department at Horace Greeley. "The SUNY's and W.C.C. are the best value. We will frequently meet parents who say, 'I'll pay for Harvard, not Hamilton.' So it's not surprising that the SUNY's are popular."
To get a picture of where Westchester students go to college, the Westchester section asked the guidance departments at all 43 public high schools in the county to provide data about the class of 2000. Most schools responded. Some, like Scarsdale and Dobbs Ferry, declined to participate. Others, like Pleasantville, Ossining and Mount Vernon, sent lists describing where their students were accepted, but not where they actually enrolled.
The survey did provide some surprises.
For example, six students from the county went to Palm Beach Community College in Florida, the same number that went to Rockland Community College and Hudson Valley Community College, much closer to home; to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and to McGill, the prestigious university in Montreal. Guidance counselors said Palm Beach attracts students who want a sunny climate and who have relatives in Florida.
As Scott MacLachlan, dean of enrollment management for Palm Beach Community College, explained: "We find that most students from the North have relatives in Palm Beach County -- typically, grandparents or the noncustodial parent of a divorce. Some students are intrigued by the thought of going to college in sunny south Florida." He said the college also has student housing.
By and large, however, the survey found that Westchester students like to stay close to home.
"Juniors will say, 'I'm going to go to California,' " Ms. Oberg said, "and seniors will say, 'I'd like to be on the East Coast.' " 
Added Carol Gill, president of Carol Gill Associates, an educational consulting firm with offices in Dobbs Ferry and Boston: "It's true that kids are staying in the mid-Atlantic region. I have more and more parents and students telling me that they want to be within a three- to four-hour drive."
In keeping with national trends that indicate that more students are seeking urban schools, Boston University, New York University and Syracuse University were popular with Westchester students, as was George Washington University. 
Some students also ventured farther afield, to places like the University of Colorado, the University of Miami and Arizona State University. 
Highly selective colleges like Duke, Brandeis and Georgetown each enrolled more than a dozen students from the county.
In total, Ivy League universities enrolled 165 Westchester students, including 25 at Columbia, 14 at Harvard, 13 at Brown, 10 at Dartmouth, 10 at Yale and 5 at Princeton.
Few guidance counselor were surprised that among the Ivies, Cornell and the University of Pennsylvania attract so many Westchester graduates. Cornell has 14,000 undergraduates in its various divisions, compared with Yale's 5,200. And Penn's freshman class of 2,385 means that there are potentially many more slots than at some of the smaller universities.
In addition, Cornell has significant cost advantages for New York State residents because it is a "land grant" institution and some of its units, like the College of Agriculture and Life Sciences and the School of Industrial and Labor Relations, receive state financing. In those schools. annual tuition and fees for a state resident is $12,062 (excluding room and board), compared with $26,062 at other schools, like the College of Arts and Sciences.
"Cornell offers a bargain," said Anne Keary, a guidance counselor at Irvington High School. "It's an Ivy League education, but depending on the school at Cornell, families can be paying substantially less."
Other factors contribute to these schools' appeal. 
"Cornell and Penn have always been popular Ivy schools in this area," Ms. Gill said. "Cornell is fairly close and offers a great deal. It's a multi-university, where you can buy a small school within a large university. 
"And Penn has become hot. It seems to have the essential ingredients. It's located in a city, and there's a lively campus life, with excellent academics and social opportunities outside."
Cornell representatives regularly attend college fairs and parent information sessions sponsored by local high schools, and Cornell even runs a bus trip to the campus in Ithaca for prospective students.
Lloyd Hall, an associate director of admissions at Cornell, added that Cornell's large alumni presence in Westchester helps maintain the university's strong relationship with county high schools.
Similarly, the University of Pennsylvania has long enjoyed a positive relationship with many of the county's high schools.
"We treasure our relationship with the county," said Dr. Lee Stetson, the dean of admissions. "There are excellent schools, the students are well-prepared, they look competitive during the application process, and they thrive when they come to Penn. 
"We've always had many students from Chappaqua, Scarsdale, Ardsley, Rye and Mamaroneck -- now we're seeing increasing numbers from Byram Hills, Yorktown and Dobbs Ferry. There's also a very strong alumni base in the county. And now that students consider a city environment to be the environment of choice, and Philadelphia is perceived as a manageable city, it helps makes the university more attractive."
As for which high schools are most successful at sending students to the Ivy League, the top two among those that responded to the survey -- Horace Greeley in Chappaqua, and Mamaroneck High School -- are also no surprise, given the schools' academic reputations and the communities' economic profile. 
What was less predictable, however, was the record of one of the county's smaller high schools, Ardsley, which sent 13 studebts to the Ivies, and one of the county's more diverse schools, New Rochelle, which sent 14. 
"New Rochelle has always been extremely competitive for the Ivy League and highly selective colleges," said Dr. Diane Massimo, district coordinator of guidance counseling for the New Rochelle School District.
Other high schools that provided data only on where students were accepted, rather than where they enrolled, also did well.
Students from Mount Vernon High School, for example, were accepted at Brown, Columbia, Dartmouth, Harvard and Yale, as well as universities like Brandeis and Georgetown.
Pleasantville students were accepted at Colby, the College of William and Mary, Harvard, Yale, Columbia and Cornell, among others, while Edgemont students were accepted at Brown, Columbia, Dartmouth, Duke, Georgetown, Harvard, the University of Pennsylvania and Yale.
Cost is not the only reason for the popularity of Westchester Community College, guidance counselors say.
"It serves a lot of purposes," said Dr. Massimo of New Rochelle. "A lot of our students are seeking a two-year career degree. It's also a steppingstone for many students that opens a lot of doors. It's very positive, in giving students the maximum opportunities. We even have a registration process for W.C.C. here on campus."
For Stephanie Annunziata, who graduated from Westlake High School last year, W.C.C. was just what she was looking for. 
"My guidance counselor recommended it," she said. "I looked into it, heard it had great academics and gave students many opportunities. I live at home -- my parents wanted me at home -- and I love it." Ms. Annunziata intends to earn an associate's degree in communications and then transfer to a four-year college.
Teresita Wisell, director of admissions for Westchester Community College, said there were several reasons for its popularity. 
"We've been working to dispel the myth that community college is less than other institutions, especially in Westchester," she said. "There's also the myth that it's only for students who can't go elsewhere. We are a SUNY school, and students who start here can end up at Dartmouth, Harvard and Columbia, as well as N.Y.U., Manhattanville, Iona and the four-year state colleges."
For certain students, W.C.C. can be a choice, not a fallback. 
"Some recognize that they're not ready, emotionally or academically, to go away," Ms. Wisell said. "And for some, it's a second chance to build up their grades so they'll be more attractive to a selective college."
Ms. Dickson of Rye High School said: "Students know that if they attend a community college and do well, they're automatically accepted at a four-year New York State college. Kids who have to pay for their own college find that appealing."
But SUNY showed enormous appeal to incoming freshmen as well. Taken together, the various units of the State University of New York (excluding Westchester Community College, which is affiliated with the SUNY system) drew 647 students.
"SUNY schools are really coming into their own and getting national recognition," Ms. Gill said, "especially Binghamton, which is one of the best in the country."
Dr. Lois Guberman, director of guidance at Pelham Memorial High School, said she was not surprised by the popularity of SUNY Albany. "A lot of kids stay close to home, and SUNY is a great education," she said, adding, "Albany is one of the four university centers in the system, and it's in a city."
While Albany was No. 1, it was followed closely by Oneonta, with 72; New Paltz, with 66; Purchase, with 58, and Binghamton, with 48. SUNY Buffalo drew 41 students.
For an in-state undergraduate, tuition at SUNY Albany is $3,400 a year.
State universities elsewhere also showed strong appeal in Westchester. Confirming Ms. Gill's comments about the lure of the Middle Atlantic states, the University of Delaware drew 37 students, while the University of Maryland drew 32.
"One of the reasons we like your students is that we know they're well prepared," said Ronne Patrick, associate director of undergraduate admissions at the University of Maryland, which has about 24,000 undergraduates, and accepts about 4,000 students for its freshman class. "Maryland is a public research university that offers a real campus life and wonderful programs. I think students are attracted to the opportunities we have as a large campus. We've also got a Metro stop here that goes to Washington, D.C., and we're 45 minutes from Baltimore."
In New England, the University of Massachusetts attracted 32 students, while the University of Rhode Island drew 25.
Even farther afield, the University of Michigan attracted 34 students, while the University of California campuses drew 7.
Closer to home, Pace University, with campuses in White Plains, Pleasantville-Briarcliff Manor and New York City, has made a concerted effort to attract students from Westchester, and draws 30 percent of its freshman class from the county.
"We consider ourselves the university of Westchester County," said Desiree Cilmi, executive director of enrollment services for Pace. "We are the only comprehensive university in the county, with undergraduate, graduate and professional schools. Our name recognition in the county is extremely high."
Regine Bruny, a 2000 graduate of New Rochelle High School, chose Pace over SUNY Binghamton and SUNY Farmingdale, where she was also accepted.
"My guidance counselor told me that Pace University was on top for nursing, and that's what I want to do," Ms. Bruny said. "I think it's important for a freshman to be close to home. Pace was close, but not too close, so I can feel independent. My mom wanted me to stay close. And I'm happy with Pace."
Ms. Cilmi said Pace made a special effort to reach students like Ms. Bruny.
"We do a lot of outreach to the community, like running workshops on how to complete the college application and how to complete the financial aid application," she said. "We also have an aggressive academic scholarship program, with a minimum of $5,000 up to full tuition, which is about $16,000 a year." 
Ms. Keary, the Irvington guidance counselor, confirmed Pace's aggressive use of scholarships. "Pace has been offering nice financial packages to students in the middle of the class," she said, "and attracting good students."
Pace also offers full scholarships each year to the top two graduates of Westchester Community College. 
Whatever the choice, guidance counselors said, the college selection process generally ends well. As Ms. Oberg put it, "Most kids, no matter where they go, make peace with it and are happy."

How the Survey Was Done
OVER the last few months, the Westchester section asked the county's public high schools to provide lists of where students from the class of 2000 enrolled in college. Parochial and independent schools were not part of the survey. 
Some schools, like Scarsdale and Dobbs Ferry, declined to participate. Others, like Pleasantville, Ossining and Mount Vernon, sent lists describing where students were accepted, but not where they enrolled. And some schools, like Bronxville, provided lists of the colleges their students were attending, but without specifying how many students were enrolled at each college.
As a result, the survey is incomplete and is based on the cooperating high schools' self-reported data. It is likely that, in some cases, students might have changed their minds between the time they told the guidance office where they intended to enroll and when they actually enrolled in September.
Experts warn that the survey should not be seen as a report card for the county's high schools. The college admissions process, they point out, is capricious; high school classes differ from year to year even within a community (one year, for example, a school can send four students to Harvard, and the next year there can be none), and students themselves can be fickle about which colleges appeal to them. There are years when Duke and Brown look most alluring, and others when Yale and Stanford are most attractive. At best, these results reflect a snapshot of specific classes for a given year; the classes of 1999 or 2001 might yield different results. 
As Dr. Lois Guberman, director of guidance at Pelham Memorial High School, said, "I consider that Pelham has had a good year if they're all going someplace that's right for them and they're happy."

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME; 
City Bills Back Fees On Units

BYLINE:  By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
AN effort by the New York City Department of Finance to collect unpaid annual registration fees due on rent-stabilized apartments -- along with compounded interest on past due amounts -- has generated anger among representatives of property owners and concern and confusion among co-op boards, lawyers and managing agents.
 The fees, which have been added to the property-tax bills for thousands of buildings in the city, are the result of a state law that since 1984 has required owners of rent-stabilized apartments to pay an annual $10 registration fee for each apartment. And while the registration fees themselves generally do not amount to a significant amount, the charges being added to the tax bills can amount to tens of thousands of dollars when compound interest is added to the unpaid amounts. 
 "This is insanity," said Joseph Strasburg, president of the Rent Stabilization Association, a Manhattan organization that represents owners of multifamily buildings. "Some owners are getting hit with bills that are four times the amount of the original registration fees. And if that isn't bad enough, some owners are saying they're getting billed for fees they've already paid." 
Mr. Strasburg explained that while property owners do not dispute the legality of the $10 annual registration fee, many of them are infuriated because the city is only now trying to collect fees dating as far back as 1984. "At this point in time it's the city's position that the money is due and owing and the burden is on the property owner to prove that they have paid the required amount," he said. "Some owners don't even have records going back to 1984."
Paul Korngold, a Manhattan tax lawyer, said that the charges are being added to the property-tax bills of residential buildings for which city records indicate that charges have not been paid. The problem with that, however, is that among those buildings receiving bills are co-ops in which the registration fees are typically the responsibility of the original sponsor or the investors who subsequently bought rent-stabilized apartments. 
And while Mr. Korngold said that city officials have indicated to him that they do not intend to hold property owners -- including co-op corporations -- responsible for fees that should have been paid by others, the officials have not yet indicated how or when charges will be removed from the tax bills. Curt Ritter, a spokesman for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, said that Mr. Korngold is correct. Mr. Ritter added that the Department of Finance has a customer service department that will assist anyone who has concerns regarding the charges. The number to call is (718) 935-9500.
Gregory Carlson, executive director of the Federation of New York Housing Cooperatives, said that even though co-ops will not be held responsible for fees that should have been paid by sponsors or investors, the inclusion of the amounts due on the building's property tax bill can result in a number of problems.
"My greatest fear is that some escrow agent out in Ohio gets a tax bill from the city and just goes ahead and pays it," Mr. Carlson said, explaining that in many cases, lenders who hold underlying mortgages on co-op buildings often require that the lender itself or its agent pay the taxes, rather than allowing the co-op board to pay directly. In such a case, he said, if the escrow agent pays the amount demanded by the city before the co-op has an opportunity to contest it, the co-op would be faced with the daunting challenge of getting a refund from the city or chasing the responsible party -- in many cases, a sponsor long gone from the building -- for the money that was paid.
"Unless it's a large amount of money, it could easily cost the co-op more in legal expenses to sue the responsible party than the amount that's in dispute," Mr. Carlson said. "That means that even if the co-op wins, it loses."
In some cases, however, the amount being added to a building's tax bill is large. "One 275-unit co-op I know of in Bayside, Queens, just got hit with a bill for more than $35,000," Mr. Carlson said. "Another building in Woodside got a bill for about $25,000, only about $9,000 of which was for the actual fees and about $16,000 being for interest."
Mitch Unger, the controller for John B. Lovett & Associates, a managing agent in College Point, Queens, said that he represents several buildings that have been billed for substantial amounts by the city, including the first one referred to by Mr. Carlson.
"It's fine and dandy for the city to say that co-ops won't have to pay for charges that were the responsibility of sponsors and investors," Mr. Unger said. "But when you're dealing with the city, you usually have to prove you don't owe something rather than the other way around."
To complicate matters even further, there is always the possibility that the co-op corporation may legitimately owe some or even all of the amounts assessed by the city. Errol A. Brett, a Manhattan co-op lawyer, said that could happen in situations where the co-op owns rent-stabilized apartments -- usually as a result of a sponsor default -- and has failed to pay the required registration fees.
"In that case, the co-op would have to pay what it owes," Mr. Brett said, adding that shareholders selling their apartments could encounter problems if any unpaid charges are reflected on the building's tax records -- regardless of who is ultimately responsible for them.
"If the lender for the buyer sees an amount due for the building's real estate taxes, he's going to want to know who's responsible for paying it," he said. "And I don't know how many lawyers or managing agents will be willing to guarantee that the city will eventually remove the charge."
He said that co-ops that receive bills for unpaid registration fees that are not their responsibility should immediately contact the Department of Finance, contest the charges and ask that they be removed. 
And since some less-efficient managing agents might simply pay the charges when they receive a bill from the city without determining whether the charges are appropriate, he said, co-op boards should advise their agents not to pay the charges without getting explicit board approval.
Mr. Brett said boards or their agents should contact the building's mortgage holder and advise the lender not to pay any charges that are not part of the building's normal tax bill.
Finally, Mr. Brett said, boards should resist the temptation to pay the charges and then hope to get reimbursed by the sponsor or investor ultimately responsible for them.
"The last thing a board should do," he said, "is end up being a collection agency for the city."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
InMoney Funds, Awaiting Dawn

BYLINE:  By VIVIAN MARINO 

 BODY:
NERVOUS mutual fund investors are not quite charging for the exits, but many of them have been heading for the sidelines, waiting for the volatile stock market to hit bottom. As they wait, they are piling up cash in money market funds, long a haven in troubled times.
 An unprecedented $2 trillion sat in money funds at the end of the quarter, up from $1.7 trillion a year ago and double the amount of just four years ago. In fact, the new total is about half of what is currently in stocks. Much of the newer money has come from institutional investors who include managers of pensions, 401(k) plans or mutual funds, as well as corporations and foundations. But individual investors, concerned about the impact of a slowing economy are also a big factor, as many rethink their investments with more emphasis on cash. 
 Ronald and Judy Peace of Jacksonville, Fla., are among the wary. They are in the process of reallocating their $4.5 million investment portfolio. The plan, they say, is to put 10 percent of their assets in tax-free money funds and 15 percent in bond funds, instead of having nearly all of it in stocks and stock funds.
"We haven't changed our strategy in the last year," said Mr. Peace, 57, a retired mortgage financier. But now, he added, "the stock market is making us a little nervous."
Fund companies say the cash pileup began in earnest at the start of the year, as stock losses began to accelerate, with the broad market averages joining in the slide that Nasdaq began a year ago.
Money funds today account for 29 percent of all mutual fund assets, a six-year high, data from the Investment Company Institute show. In January alone, a record $116 billion poured into them, almost double the previous monthly record inflow of $62.4 billion, reached in November 2000, according to iMoneyNet Inc., which collects money fund data.
"The numbers are quite impressive," said Peter Crane, a vice president of iMoneyNet and the publisher of its Money Fund monthly newsletter. "There is normally a huge buildup in money market funds at the first part of the year, primarily due to year-end bonuses, but there's a lot more cash than usual."
Steve Traum, who manages the retail money market funds at T.I.A.A.-C.R.E.F., the giant university-oriented investment group, said assets had risen by more than $100 million since the start of the year, to nearly $720 million. However, he added, "we have not seen any drastic movement out of our equity funds." 
There was no mass exodus from stock funds reported at Janus, either. "We have done a good job of educating our investors that there are going to be ups and downs," said Sharon Pichler, the portfolio manager for Janus money market funds, which have grown to $13.96 billion from $10.87 billion at the start of the year. 
MONEY funds, which invest in short-term debt like commercial paper, Treasury bills and certificates of deposit, are considered safe and liquid. Even though they are not federally insured, no individual investor has ever lost a dime in them, Mr. Crane said, and money can be withdrawn immediately -- if, say, the stock market is suddenly attractive again. Yields, averaging 4.8 percent for a taxable fund, are generally higher than those offered on similar accounts available from banks, around 3.8 percent, and on six-month C.D.'s, around 4.7 percent.
"I think many investors will come to conclude right now that 5 percent 'sure' is a lot better than 25 percent 'maybe,' " said Jonathan Pond, president of Financial Planning Information in Boston, referring to sharp stock gains in the late 1990's. 
Mr. Pond said he recently modified his suggested asset allocation mix for the majority of his clients to 60 percent stocks, 25 percent bonds and 15 percent money market funds. That reflects a 10-point increase in cash exposure at stocks' expense. 
"The lasting lesson from this debacle in the market is the value of diversification," he added, "because a year ago there were people out there saying diversification is dead."
But investors seeking to stay liquid should know that not all money funds are equal. Some 1,591 taxable and tax-exempt funds, with varying yields and fees, are offered by fund companies or brokerage firms. 
When choosing a fund, you should first consider how you plan to use it. If you intend to hold chunks of cash for significant periods while deciding, say, what to do with a year-end bonus or monthly commissions that are piling up, yield should be a priority, Mr. Crane said. If you expect to use the fund more as a checking account, withdrawing and replenishing cash from time to time, then yield would be secondary to other features like unlimited check-writing, he said. 
(Many firms, like Charles Schwab and Fidelity Investments, offer unlimited check-writing for their larger customers, typically with minimum investments starting at $50,000.)
Fees are another consideration. The average money-market fund costs half a percentage point annually, according to iMoneyNet. Among the low-cost leaders are the T.I.A.A.-C.R.E.F. Money fund, which charges 0.29 percent, and Vanguard Prime Retail, 0.33 percent.
Investors also need to weigh risk. Although many money funds hold similar debt instruments, some funds may be considered a bit riskier because they invest in some less-conservative securities. The Securities and Exchange Commission requires that 95 percent of a money fund's assets be in so-called Tier 1 investments, which have the highest credit ratings, and many organizations like T.I.A.A.-C.R.E.F. and Janus invest exclusively in them. But up to 5 percent of a fund's assets can go into lower-grade, though higher-yielding, Tier 2 investments; some funds do include them in their mix. 
Debt instruments can default. In 1994, for example, several money market funds had to be bailed out by their sponsors because of bad investments in money market derivatives, and parent companies also had to buy impaired securities from fund portfolios after Orange County, Calif., declared bankruptcy.
Mr. Crane suggests reading a fund's prospectus to learn about its investment philosophy. If you are looking for the safest fund, you may want to consider one that invests only in United States government obligations, like Treasury bills, or those with some kind of government backing. Of course, yields will be comparatively lower, and short-term rates in general may move down more as the Federal Reserve moves to revive the sluggish economy.
"Still, in relationship to inflation, which remains pretty low, the yields on all money market funds remain attractive," said Hank Madden, a Jacksonville money manager who is working with the Peace household and many other clients to rebalance their investment portfolios. 
"Any new money that comes in right now we're putting into cash until I can get a better feel for the market," he said. "But when the money starts moving back into the market, watch out."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
Taking On the Saint of Indexing

BYLINE:  By DANIEL J. WAKIN 

 BODY:
JOHN C. BOGLE'S critics like to call him a St. Paul (though he prefers St. Jack) who preaches his vision of the true path, a pontificator with the zeal of the righteous. 
 Mr. Bogle, the founder and former chief executive of the Vanguard Group of mutual funds, has cast himself as the conscience of the industry. In speeches, articles and books, he rails against what he sees as its sins: excessive portfolio turnover, wasteful marketing, neglect of the shareholder in favor of enriching managers and, most apparent to the consumer, needlessly high costs. 
 His terrain, of course, is the market-mimicking index fund, which he pioneered at Vanguard. That gives Mr. Bogle a point of view, which he does not hide. "Mutual funds can make no claim to superiority over the market averages," he writes in his latest book, "John Bogle on Investing: The First 50 Years" (McGraw-Hill). Most active managers cannot beat the indexes, he argues. 
Mr. Bogle is careful to stress that not all funds are guilty. But in the vast arena out there, he finds nary a worthy opponent.
"I've yet to hear a single serious rebuttal to my criticisms of the fund industry," he writes. "So I conclude that, because their veracity is self-evident, my words are accepted as truths."
Why not give the other guys a chance? Here are the edited comments of four mutual fund executives on St. Jack. Though not singled out by Mr. Bogle, they all preside over families of funds that include equity funds with more than $100 million in assets and with expense ratios of more than 2 percent, well above the average of 1.19 percent for the category and far beyond the 0.18 percent expense ratio of the Vanguard 500 Index Trust.

MATTHEW KELMON -- President and portfolio manager of Kelmoore Strategy Funds of Palo Alto, Calif., which has just over $500 million in managed assets:
Our funds are sold only through brokers. The adviser fee is 1 percent; the 12b-1 fee is 1 percent. That's all expenses to market the fund. We probably have the most actively managed fund out of any fund on the Street. We have a very complex strategy. We write covered options against a portfolio of 40 to 45 blue-chip equities, on a monthly basis, and pay out a monthly dividend. People who invest in our fund are cash-flow oriented.
How have the indexers done over the last nine months? They have done what the index has done, which has gone straight down. An index fund is just praying it comes back. I'm using the equity as a vehicle to create a cash flow, a monthly cash flow for our investors. We've paid out about 4 1/2 percent on earned profits in 2001, and that's a hard return. I've already made up the expense ratio for the entire year in the first three months.
If the market does not come screaming back, we will earn it multiple times over in 2001. 
I don't see why anyone would pay for an index. If you're in active management and it works, it's worth a fee. Some of the funds with lower expense ratios have absolutely no management and run on cruise control -- I don't see why anybody would pay for those.

SAMUEL S. STEWART JR. -- Chairman of Wasatch Advisors Inc. of Salt Lake City, which has $2 billion under management:
Our basic approach is to say, "You get what you pay for." We're more than happy to compare our Micro Cap fund net of fees against whatever index you deem appropriate. In my mind you can pay Jack's fee of two-tenths of a percent and get a net return of 10, and pay the Micro Cap fee of 2.4 and get a net return of 15 percent.
I would never make an across-the-board argument against index funds. In general, Jack is right, but in particular cases he can be wrong. What you want to do if you're going to get into the higher-fee world is make sure the firm has the talent. For the casual person that just wants to take advantage of the stock market and the higher rates of return over the long course of time, then index funds are the best vehicle.

ROBERT H. GRAHAM -- President and chief executive of the AIM Management Group of Houston, which manages 60 retail funds and $170 billion in assets:
First of all, Jack Bogle comes from the position that people don't need a financial adviser. Well, we come from a different philosophy. We think a financial adviser is extremely important to help the individual. We don't think individuals have the time or the expertise to make their financial decisions. Now, that financial adviser obviously wants to be paid.
If you just look at operating expenses and take all that out, I'm sure we do run higher expense ratios than Vanguard and probably most funds, too, but like anything else, our product costs a little more to produce, and we think it's a better product. We're not sure the lowest-cost product is the best product. 
A lot of his ideas are competitive issues for Vanguard. He promotes ideas that make Vanguard look good. It has to be taken with a grain of salt, his ideas. If I came out with a bunch of propositions that made AIM look great, you might want to question whether I'm really sincere, or trying to make us look good.
Part of the problem I have with indexing is, it's O.K. if perhaps a small amount of money goes into indexing. But we would be in a bad state if all of our money was passively managed. There would be no system for weeding out the bad companies and rewarding the good companies. I think it would be dangerous for our economy if we got to the point where the majority of our money was passively invested.
We certainly have a strong marketing group. Part of our business, we feel, is to bring new money into the funds. AIM as a firm is in the business to make a profit, and see our assets grow and our revenues grow. We're not ashamed to say that's our business, but we don't think that's inconsistent with the interests of the shareholder.

RICHARD E. STIERWALT -- Chief executive of the Orbitex Financial Services Group, with $2 billion under management:
We have very specialized sector funds, and we hire experts in the field who really understand, for example, what the development of new drugs in biotech is. These people are very, very expensive. As a result, we are able to create a better performance.
If you want to be in an index-type product, then you have to expect an index-type return. And if you are in a product that has specialized management, then for the most part you should outperform the market. If you look at Orbitex Information Communications, which rose 150 percent in 1999 and 2000, and compare that to a technology fund that was less expensive and tied more to an index, the client would be better served in Information Communications .
These are brand-new funds. As the assets grow, the expense ratio goes down. That's inconsequential to the return pattern. If you give me $3 and I give you $150 back, how many times would you like to do that?
