HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
How to Salvage Two Companies Buried in Debt

BYLINE:  By BARNABY FEDER and GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
Most of the headlines concerning the business ventures of the billionaire Craig O. McCaw in the last year have focused on his high-stakes maneuvering to pursue his dream of creating a satellite communications empire.
 But right now, Mr. McCaw also has pressing problems with his two major land-based telecommunications investments: Nextel Communications and Xo Communications. 
 Both are deeply indebted, rapidly expanding money-losing voice and data communications companies that, unlike the satellite ventures, are accountable to public shareholders, as well as bond and note holders. Before either Nextel or Xo have a chance of breaking even, they need to raise billions of dollars in new loans or equity to complete their ambitious development plans. 
A year ago, doubts about their ability to raise the money were offset by the McCaw mystique. After all, the visionary Seattle entrepreneur had become a legend for his ability to use borrowed money to expand his family's cable television business and then McCaw Cellular. In both cases, financing pressures eventually rose to the point the Mr. McCaw decided to sell, but investors who had hitched their fortunes to Mr. McCaw's vision profited handsomely. 
The sale of McCaw Cellular to AT&T for $11.5 billion in 1994 was particularly stunning. Some of Mr. McCaw's resulting fortune was plowed into rescuing Nextel, a nearly bankrupt wireless carrier that was attempting to break into the crowded cellular market using digital radio communications technology developed by Motorola. The successful revival of the company by managers Mr. McCaw installed after he gained control in 1995 added billions of dollars to the parterships and trusts he controls. 
In 1998, Mr. McCaw rounded up former McCaw Cellular executives to create Nextel Partners, an affiliate of Nextel Communications that extends its wireless technology to small and midsize cities. Nextel Partners raised more than $470 million in its own initial public offering last year. 
Meanwhile, Mr. McCaw had also founded and taken public NextLink Communications, a company based in Reston, Va., that started out as developer of fiber optic networks to provide phone and data services to business customers. After acquiring radio spectrum the government auctioned off for new wireless services and buying an Internet networking company, NextLink changed its name last fall to Xo Communications.
Both Nextel and Xo were organized with special classes of stock and management agreements that gave Mr. McCaw ultimate control. The reputations of Mr. McCaw and the executives he has recruited to work with him helped generate billions of dollars of investment from banks, fund managers and venture capitalists. Forstmann-Little alone put more than $1.2 billion into Xo and its affiliates.
In the last year though, investors have become increasingly cautious about the aggressive growth tactics of the McCaw-controlled companies. And in recent months, as the economy has slowed and numerous telecommunications companies have stumbled, the shares of the McCaw ventures have fallen to the point that institutional investors have begun to think the unthinkable. Could these companies eventually be forced into bankruptcy reorganization?
Nextel, which had $5.7 billion in revenues last year and more than 6.7 domestic subscribers, says it has roughly $7 billion in available financing and $14 billion in long-term debt. Although revenues are growing rapidly, analysts figure the company spent nearly $3 billion more than it brought in last year and may run up a similar cash shortfall this year. Last month, the company trimmed projections for subscriber growth in the current quarter to 500,000 from the previous forecast of 530,000 and said that cash from operations might be 15 percent lower than in the previous quarter.
The company also had to drop plans for a public offering to raise money for Nextel International, the wholly owned subsidiary for Nextel's overseas holdings, as investors fled the telecommunications sector. Many analysts figure Nextel could go well into 2003 without having to raise cash. But that assumes a round of cuts in the company's planned expansion and other belt-tightening. -- Such moves would save cash but could leave the company less competitive in the long run.
"Its prospects don't look as good as they did," said Frederick Moran, an analyst who follows Nextel for Jefferies & Company. "The stock got ahead of itself due to its seemingly endless growth prospects. But with the onslaught of competition, tight capital markets, and a possible recession, the company has lost some of its subscriber growth momentum."
With Nextel's shares down from $79.81 just over a year ago to $12.31 last Friday, The 11 percent stake in Nextel owned by Mr. McCaw's investment group is worth some $5 billion less. But his more immediate concern must be Xo, in which he and his partners have a 22 percent stake. Xo shares ended trading Friday at $3.31, down from their peak of $66.25 13 months ago.
Xo is on course to run out of cash within a year, and investors are nervously wondering what steps, if any, Mr. McCaw plans to support it. Mr. McCaw bought 29,500 shares at $17.48 a share early this year, according to a recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, but a purchase of outstanding shares is not the kind of endorsement the investors have in mind. Xo's own projections, which may now be too optimistic, suggest a need for roughly $2.5 billion in new loans or equity to carry into 2005, the year it expects to start breaking even.
"I must have gotten over 100 calls from institutional investors wanting to know if he'll step up," Aryeh Bourkoff, a UBS Warburg debt analyst, said last Wednesday. That was the day after Xo's shares dipped below $3 and bad news was swirling about the financial woes of similarly debt-laden rivals like Teligent and Winstar. 'A funding gap is death in this market, " Mr. Bourkoff said.
Responding to the anxiety, Xo issued a statement late Wednesday attempting to reassure investors. Daniel Akerson, the company's chairman and chief executive, said that the company had $3 billion in cash available. That was enough, he said, to allow Xo to "weather the carnage that the telecommunications industry is now experiencing." Xo said it expected to be able to raise money in the future and to take advantage of the opportunities created by the current industry shakeout.
It seems unlikely, though that there will be a major infusion of cash from Mr. McCaw and his partners anytime soon. "It's not Craig's approach to just throw money at things," said Dennis Weibling, president of Eagle River, Mr. McCaw's investment holding company. "There is a lot you can do to adjust the burn rate." Mr. McCaw is actively involved in Mr. Akerson's effort to revise Xo's business plans to reduce the financing gap and delay the day it needs more cash, according to Robert Ratliffe, Mr. McCaw's spokesman.
Mr. McCaw has plenty of incentive to keep his companies afloat. As things stand now, Nextel and Xo have so much long-term and secured debt compared with the market value of their assets that his own equity interests might well become worthless in a bankruptcy reorganization. A lot of investors are hoping he has not lost his touch for engineering profitable escapes from tight financial corners.

HEADLINE: Fears on Privacy Law Spur Warning by Armey 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SCHWARTZ 

 BODY:
A top Republican leader in the House is sending a strong message to lawmakers hoping to address the privacy worries of their constituents this year: go slow. 
 The message will be delivered today in a letter from the majority leader, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, to all House Republicans. 
 The letter's wording is both folksy and stern. "I don't want strangers poking around in my business any more than they want me poking around in theirs," Mr. Armey writes, but "in the fast-paced world of the Internet, we must avoid silver-bullet solutions that will quickly become obsolete or leave ourselves vulnerable to criticism that the government is not meeting the standards it requires from others." 
The letter, said Richard Diamond, a spokesman for Mr. Armey, is an attempt "to lay out this issue for members" and to show "the various traps and pitfalls that await on privacy issues if they do it wrong."
Few issues have risen to prominence as quickly as privacy. As Americans have gone online by the millions, they have become increasingly concerned over ways that their digital footprints can be traced, especially by companies that use personal data for marketing.
The Federal Trade Commission recommended that Congress legislate privacy standards for Web sites, and a number of lawmakers have filed bills intended to fill in the patchwork of privacy laws on the books. 
Mr. Armey's letter says that the new economy is a target that moves too fast for government to address with any competence. "Congress is an inexperienced and amateur mechanic trying to tinker with the supercharged, high-tech engine of our economy," it says. "We need to be careful not to let our good intentions get in the way of common sense." 
The leader of a technology industry trade group said the Armey statement was welcome. "I think the tide is turning away" from strong new privacy legislation, said Jonathan Zuck, head of the Association for Competitive Technology in Washington. A rush to pass poorly drafted privacy bills, Mr. Zuck said, would result in the introduction of "a host of unintended consequences without the benefits that they seek." 
But Edmund Mierzwinski, consumer program director at the United States Public Interest Research Group, said that the real purpose of the letter is to help business evade regulation and to prevent House Republicans from trying to bring new privacy bills forward.
"Really, the leadership is sending a message not only to the public, but also to the rank and file," Mr. Mierzwinski said. "It's clear to me that the K Street forces are out, and they are pushing their anti-privacy agenda, and they've convinced the leadership to make it their agenda." 
The letter from Mr. Armey tries to shift the privacy debate away from a focus on business excesses to those of government. He cites an October 2000 report by the General Accounting Office as saying that only 3 percent of federal Web sites met all standards proposed by the F.T.C.
"The government should review its own practices before it becomes too preachy about privacy." Mr. Armey wrote. 
He cited health privacy regulations issued by the Clinton administration, assailing the rules as violating citizens' privacy by giving the Department of Health and Human Services overly broad authority to collect medical records from regulated companies. 
The Bush administration's secretary of health and human services, Tommy G. Thompson, has announced that he will delay and reconsider the rules.

HEADLINE: Income-Tax Enforcement Is Broadly Declining, New U.S. Data Indicate 

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Broad enforcement efforts against individual taxpayers by the Internal Revenue Service have fallen by half or more since the early 1990's, according to new data from the Justice Department and the I.R.S. 
 The tax agency has become much less likely to question those with unreported income, to take taxpayers to court or to seize their property. For example, the I.R.S. took civil court action in 641 cases against recalcitrant taxpayers last year, down from 2,519 in 1992. 
 The figures on enforcement come from a study by the Transactional Records Access Clearinghouse at Syracuse University, which was released yesterday. 
The report confirmed that audit rates are also down sharply, to one in 204 for taxpayers with incomes of more than $100,000, not adjusting for inflation, from one in 9 in 1989. The study also showed that the audit rates vary a great deal by region, both for both individuals and corporations. 
These findings came three days after the Senate Finance Committee was told that the I.R.S. had become so weak and ineffective that hundreds and perhaps thousands of promoters are marketing tax frauds, especially over the Internet.
The criticism of the I.R.S. as ineffective contrasted with Congressional criticism of I.R.S. zealousness in 1997 and 1998, fueling restrictions on the agency's enforcement and leading to a new emphasis on taxpayer service. 
Charles O. Rossotti, the Internal Revenue Service commissioner, did not challenge the new study's findings. 
In a recent letter to the Senate Finance Committee. Mr. Rossotti said that without more personnel, the I.R.S. could not pursue many issues raised in computer checks of tax returns and as the result of information reported by employers, banks and other sources of income. 
The I.R.S. took action in 1998 in only one of every six cases where its computers showed income from employers and others that was not reported on tax returns, down from pursuit of almost two-thirds of such cases in 1991, the latest data show. 
Correction notices, which ask taxpayers to explain discrepancies in their reports, or to pay additional taxes, were sent to 1.4 million taxpayers last year, down from 4.8 million in 1991, the study indicated.
Actions to seize property from taxpayers have all but halted, the study said, falling to 174 last year from more than 11,000 in 1991. Criminal prosecutions have fallen by half since 1992, to about 50 cases a month.
Audit rates varied substantially by region, the study found. Just one in 588 taxpayers in Georgia with incomes of $100,000 or more was audited last year. The audit rates for taxpayers with such incomes in upstate New York, New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland, Michigan, Virginia, West Virginia and in metropolitan Houston were all about one in 400, or less. The strongest such audit rate occurred in Los Angeles -- one in 69. 
The drop in I.R.S. efforts to enforce the tax laws is not limited to individuals. Last year, the I.R.S. audited 31 percent of the largest corporations, down from 55 percent in 1992, the Syracuse University analysis showed.
In addition, the I.R.S. appears to be concentrating its resources on fewer corporations. The number of hours devoted to such corporate audits fell by just 9 percent, suggesting that the search for major corporate tax-evasion schemes is consuming a big share of the dwindling I.R.S. capacity to audit such businesses.
The agency also treated companies differently, based on where they were situated. For example, in upstate New York from 1997 to 1999, three of four of the biggest corporations were audited each year, while only one in five in Delaware and Maryland bore such scrutiny. 
"These differences mean that the big companies in upstate New York have a real economic disadvantage, compared with those in areas of the country where corporate audit rates were far lower," said David Burnham, co-director of the Syracuse University clearinghouse, which gathers data on how a variety of federal agencies operate.
The new data also suggest that the I.R.S. could deploy its corporate auditing staff more efficiently, Mr. Burnham said. Auditors in upstate New York are asked to recommend less in additional corporate payments per hour than auditors elsewhere, he said. 
Terry Lemons, an I.R.S. spokesman, said that the discrepancy in audit rates might reflect issues affecting different industries rather than any difference in the vigor of agency audits in different regions.

HEADLINE: Media; 
Those who want to control information find an ally in a public that seems to accept restrictions.

BYLINE:  By Felicity Barringer 

 BODY:
NEWSPAPERS' basic needs are simple. They need money for presses, paper and workers. They need readers, the better to get advertising revenue. They need information, the better to get readers.
 At this year's relatively somber convention of the American Society of Newspaper Editors in Washington, the public and private conversations indicated that there was less of everything. Less advertising revenue is likely to mean circulation price increases -- which tend to accelerate a decline in circulation, which has been dropping for 15 years. 
 But as nasty as the budget numbers are, the forces involved are familiar. What is happening with information is new. With more of it available than ever before, the ranks of those trying to control and limit information have rapidly expanded, and the public appears willing to accept new restrictions. People are more worried about their own privacy -- say, the confidentiality of medical records -- than abstractions about the public's right to know.
What is going on? It is partly a privacy backlash created by the Internet-driven, exponential growth in accessible information. It is also the new economics of the information age, which gives increasing value to all kinds of things, from real estate prices to voter registration lists to the photographic images or the play-by-play facts from sports events. 
And it is partly the perennial desire of government and business to avoid embarrassment or damage to their assets -- desires codified in nondisclosure agreements in business, in legislation passed by Congress last fall but vetoed by President Bill Clinton, which would have made it a felony to reveal "properly classified" information. Not to mention the sporadic resistance or delay that greets information requests that should be routine under freedom of information laws.
President Bush, asked by an editor about information restrictions, said, "There needs to be balance when it comes to freedom of information laws." He said that his administration would cooperate with such a request "when it does not jeopardize national security." 
There was nothing in the answer that foreclosed the president's options, should the C.I.A.-backed antileaker bill make a comeback. 
But for all the concern about that legislation, the legal ground on which it can be fought is well trodden, defined by things like whistle-blower protection laws and the Supreme Court's decision in 1971 to permit The New York Times to resume publication of a secret government history of the Vietnam War.
The legal ground of the new information battles is less familiar. The dispute between Major League Baseball and newspapers over who controls the use and the transmission of game photographs is rooted in intellectual property law and contract law -- the contract, in this case, being the press credential used by photographers to enter the stadium.
The fight, which appears near resolution, involves the limits professional baseball seeks to place on things like the use of game photographs for other commercial uses, like posters. In the early stages, it involved the suggestion that teams could use newspaper photographs for their own commercial purposes, for a token fee, and that they had a right to restrict the transmission of play-by-play facts during a game.
Noting that most sports teams and leagues have Web sites and, like many Web site owners, are trying to figure out how to make money online, several journalists on a panel about sports credentials pointed out that the leagues, as publishers, were restricting their publishing competitors. After all, someone following a game on the Web is likely to go to the site with the freshest information and best photographs.
Those arguing on the league's side have said that the credentials issue is unrelated to Internet concerns. "Internet issues are not central to anything that is going on," said Bob Bowman, the president and chief executive of Major League Baseball Advanced Media, in a panel discussion at the editors' meeting.
During last fall's Olympic Games, Internet concerns -- and the desire to protect the lucrative broadcast rights owned by NBC and others networks -- were paramount for the International Olympic Committee when it barred athletes from keeping online diaries for Web sites of their hometown newspapers. The Internet was the backdrop for the National Basketball Association's unsuccessful court fight to keep Motorola and a sports data service from sending game information to their subscribers' pagers.
Rich Jaroslovsky, the managing editor of The Wall Street Journal Online and president of the Online News Association, said that his core worry was that, whatever the motivation, "These restrictions are being imposed on journalists as a precondition of their ability to cover the event." 
"We should not just be picking on baseball," Mr. Jaroslovsky said. "This goes far beyond baseball and beyond sports teams. If this is not checked, it will become pervasive."
Just as the legal grounds are less familiar in some of these information battles, the battles of public perception are less favorable. Polling conducted by the editors' group and the Freedom Forum showed that ringing defenses of the right to know sound off key when personal information were bought and sold.
A survey last fall of 1,005 adults showed that 56 percent of those polled found it completely acceptable or somewhat acceptable if privacy laws hampered efforts by news organizations to investigate wrongdoing. The survey had a margin of error of plus or minus three percentage points.
So what chance does The Orlando Sentinel have in getting support in its court fight to overturn a new state law limiting access to autopsy photos? The newspaper had sought to have an independent doctor examine the autopsy photos of the race-car driver Dale Earnhardt, who died in a crash at the Daytona 500, and test Nascar's claims about the cause of death.
The newspaper obtained a court-mediated agreement, but the law is in effect. Yesterday, the court battle was the focus of an antimedia call to arms by Mr. Earnhardt's widow, Teresa, urging people "to speak up, for one day you may find yourself facing down a powerful media company seeking personal and private records about you or your loved ones for no benefit, only harm."

HEADLINE: Minority Staff Members In Journalism Are Fewer 

BYLINE:  By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
The math presented by the American Society of Newspaper Editors 24th annual survey of minorities was simple: 596 minority journalists were hired in 2001 and 698 left the profession, dropping the total number to 6,563 from 6,665. Minorities now make up 11.64 percent of journalists, the survey showed, compared with 31 percent of the national population.
 The numbers and percentages fell among all four groups counted. The greatest percentage loss was among American Indians, whose numbers declined by nearly 15 percent. American Indians, the smallest group of the four, had the greatest numerical loss, ending 2000 with 249 journalists, down 43. 
 The opportunities generated by the robust economy of early 2000 likely contributed to the fall-off of minority numbers among the total work force, which increased last year to 56,393 reporters, editors, photographers, page designers and graphic artists. Small newspapers, with daily circulations below 50,000, had the most trouble retaining minority staff members.
The number of Asian-American journalists declined by 22; they now make up 2.3 percent of the work force, according to the survey. There were 27 fewer black journalists, taking that group's percentage down to 5.23. There were four fewer Hispanic journalists in 2000; Hispanics make up 3.66 percent of all journalists.
The number of women in newsrooms rose slightly, to 21,062. They now make up 37.35 percent of the work force.
For the leadership of the editors' group, whose members make the hiring decisions, the trend was depressing. Charlotte Hall, the managing editor of Newsday and the chairman of the society's diversity committee, said in a statement that newsrooms needed to be places where journalists of color could flourish, where they felt welcome.
For others, it was infuriating. At a panel discussion at the editors' annual meeting, William Sutton Jr., the president of the National Association of Black Journalists and deputy managing editor at The News and Observer in Raleigh, N.C., argued that publishers needed to goad editors by tying annual bonuses more closely to hiring goals. The majority of editors have not made it important, he said.
Among large-circulation papers in the New York region, Newsday had the highest minority representation in its newsroom, with 24 percent. For The Star Ledger in Newark, the figure is 19.8 percent. At The Daily News, 18.6 percent of newsroom employees are minorities; at The Wall Street Journal, 17.1 percent. Minority journalists make up 16.2 percent of the newsroom of The New York Times and 13.9 percent of the newsroom of The New York Post.

PERSON: Milan Protic 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
A Politician Returns to the U.S. as a Voice for Yugoslavia

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
WHEN Milan Protic reopened the embassy of Yugoslavia last month, it was like stepping into a haunted house, he said. Most of the furniture was in storage and a thick layer of dust and grime coated the few items that remained: a cheap phone and an ancient computer.
 It was hardly a glorious return to the United States for the first ambassador of a newly democratic Yugoslavia, which sought to renew ties with Washington after the long-awaited collapse of the Serbian nationalist government of Slobodan Milosevic. 
 Mr. Protic had been waiting -- and working -- for that to happen since 1992, when he left the University of California at Santa Barbara after studying and teaching European history there for a decade to become an opposition leader in the Democratic Party of Serbia. 
He remains wistful about his years in Southern California, where he played basketball, acquired nearly perfect English and, he said, learned the value of intellectual tolerance. But he voices no regrt at leaving.
"I couldn't imagine sitting back in California, enjoying the nice weather with my beloved students while such important things were happening in my homeland," Mr. Protic said.
Yet for Mr. Protic (pronounced PROH-titch), a lifelong anti-Communist and opposition leader, selecting new carpets was a welcome diversion from the diplomatic task immediately thrust upon him: persuading American policymakers that his government was cooperating with efforts to prosecute Mr. Milosevic and other former officials at the war crimes tribunal at The Hague.
Within days of his arrival, Mr. Protic staked his credibility on an insistence that Mr. Milosevic's arrest was imminent. At the end of March, hours after an American-imposed deadline had elapsed, Yugoslav authorities at last followed through. Bush administration officials, relieved, immediately certified Belgrade's cooperation on war crimes and prevented Congress from withholding about $50 million in much-needed economic aid.
But the Hague tribunal is just the most visible irritant in relations between Yugoslavia and the United States, Mr. Protic acknowledged. His compatriots feel lingering resentment toward the West for a bombing campaign to drive Yugoslav troops out of Kosovo province that many perceived as indiscriminate and anti-Serbian. 
And in Washington, officials from both parties are skeptical that President Vojislav Kostunica is prepared to come to terms with the exceptionally brutal policies of ethnic cleansing carried out by the Milosevic government as the Communist-era Yugoslavia split apart.
In an interview, Mr. Protic, a big-shouldered 6-foot-6 with a gentle manner, said the West was demanding too much too fast by demanding a trial for Mr. Milosevic in The Hague. Instead, he said, the deposed president -- one of about 15 war-crimes suspects believed to be in Yugoslavia -- should stand trial at home.
"We strongly believe it's up to us to deal with Milosevic in the first place," he said. "Our people deserve that. It was our people who overthrew him. It wasn't done by NATO, or even with the assistance of the U.S. government."
Sounding alternately adamant and accommodating, Mr. Protic, 43, is a deft interlocutor in the uneasy relationship between his nation and the United States.
He is the great-grandson of Stojan Protic, who served as prime minister of the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes (which became the Kingdom of Yugoslavia in 1929). He grew up in a family of non-Communist intellectuals and attended law school in Belgrade before his sojourn in California. Once he returned to Yugoslavia, as Mr. Protic and his colleagues charted a course of nonviolent opposition to Mr. Milosevic, the United States and NATO veered between negotiating with him, rolling back his expansionism and bombing Belgrade.
"I felt it was unfair to bomb our people because they couldn't cut a deal with Milosevic," Mr. Protic said. "I always felt we were innocent victims because of a misunderstanding between Milosevic and the international community."
Last October, after Mr. Milosevic tried to manipulate the results of an election that the opposition seemed to have won, Mr. Protic and hundreds of thousands of Yugoslavs poured into the streets in protest. With his childhood home just a stone's throw from City Hall, Mr. Protic said, he was surrounded by familiar faces, defiant and weeping.
THE police ringed the protesters, and throughout the tense night of Oct. 5, the only thing that was clear was that a decisive moment had arrived. Mr. Protic pleaded with the crowds to avoid bloodshed.
"You're either going to prevail and become a part of a great historical victory for your people, or you're going to disappear or be annihilated," he said. "Curiously for me, that was a very soothing feeling."
He recalled with pride how his father, a onetime law student who had been expelled for his anti-Communist activities, had greeted him the day the opposition triumphed.
"He said, 'Listen, son, I've been waiting for this for 60 years,' " Mr. Protic said. "He didn't even ask me how I was."
For his part, Mr. Protic was elected mayor of Belgrade, becoming the first elected official of the democratic government. The city he briefly ran was filthy and impoverished but still cosmopolitan, and ultimately resilient, he said.
Now that he has become ambassador, he said, he has promised his wife and centsfamily that the three years he expects to spend in Washington will be his last foray into politics.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Metropolitan Diary 

BYLINE:  By Enid Nemy

 BODY:
DEAR DIARY: 
I live in Richmond, Va., and was visiting New York on St. Patrick's Day when a contingent of firemen passed by in the parade. Suddenly, one fireman broke rank, ran to the side of Fifth Avenue and 84th Street, knelt on the pavement and proposed marriage to his girlfriend. She said yes, grabbed his face and gave him a huge smooch as the crowd applauded. The fireman then took out an engagement ring and slipped it on her finger. She gave him another huge smooch and the crowd went wild with delight. He then lifted her over the parade barrier and they walked arm in arm up Fifth Avenue to a new life. What a town!
 LAWRENCE P. HAWKINS
A long line of skiers waited to buy lift tickets in Vail, Colo., when another sales window opened and Morton Landowne and another man jumped over to it at exactly the same moment. Not wishing a confrontation, Mr. Landowne motioned to the man to go ahead of him. Then, as he put it, "feeling proud of my consideration and graciousness" and wanting the gesture to reflect well on his hometown, he told the man, "I just wanted you to know that I am from New York City." To which the man replied, "I am, too, so I know how hard that was for you."
Barbara Maher enjoyed this sign posted at Gray's Papaya at 72nd Street and Broadway. "Bummer!!! Starting April 15 we are forced to raise our popular 'recession special' to $2.45 (tax included). Please don't hate us!!!"
Elaine Whitehouse was walking uptown toward 38th Street when she noticed a well-dressed woman walking a well-groomed Pomeranian. They were advancing toward another dog walker with two small dogs on leashes. "Don't bark. Don't bark. Don't bark," the Pomeranian's mistress muttered as the dogs got closer. When the three dogs were almost nose to nose, the Pomeranian burst into a snarling frenzy, barking and straining against its leash. The two small dogs responded in kind, snapping and growling. Once they had been dragged away, the Pomeranian's owner hissed: "I knew it! You'll never have any friends!"

Dear Diary:
I knew it wasn't going to be a good day when my doorman called me at work and said, "Are you sitting down?" Fortunately, I was.
He then informed me that a four-man construction crew that was scheduled to demolish and remodel the kitchen in an apartment four floors above mine had accidentally ripped out my kitchen. The crew was apparently ready to go on to demolish my bathroom when the woman who had commissioned the work, wondering why her contractor hadn't arrived, was told by the building staff that the crew had indeed arrived -- four floors below. She ran down to my apartment to stop the carnage.
How, you may ask, did this happen? First, the number on the work order was accidentally transcribed as my apartment number. I was told later that there were several construction jobs going on in the building. 
How did the crew get into my apartment? My 18-year-old son, home from college for vacation, readily let the men in, believing they were building maintenance men and having heard us, at various times, discussing work we were planning to have done. Once my son let them in, he went off to the dentist.
It's true that in a city where surgeons sometimes operate on the wrong side of the brain, this fiasco is ultimately harmless, though expensive and inconvenient. The contrator has promised restitution. The check is not yet in the mail.
 JEROME C. KATZ
CHECK MATE
For gracious gloves I search with care
But travail comes to naught;
No two the same are anywhere
A pairilizing thought.
This one's aright, the next awrong
In some unlikely way;
And here's a short that can't belong,
A matchless disarray.
I stumble stunned, and glumly gaze
At leathers, suedes and knits.
Perhaps this sad assorted maze
May someday give me fits.
But should you choose to greet me now
I hope you'll understand
And raise no disapproving brow
At what I have on hand.
 PAUL HUMPHREY

Dear Diary:
As a 5-year-old in New York City in 1941, I was allowed to walk to the corner of our Riverside Drive block in the afternoon to buy a hot dog for 5 cents. My grandfather, a doctor, who paid for these excursions, was away one day on house calls. Looking in my "secret" box, I found four pennies and headed for the yellow umbrella. Seeing me approach, my regular vendor began placing sauerkraut and mustard on my hot dog. When I handed over my 4 cents, he looked at me, looked at the roll and bit a fifth off the end. It was my first business negotiation, but one fully understood by both of us. I didn't become ill, so my grandfather's threat of "going to the Health Department" was not realized. I am still alive and still enjoy my New York City hot dogs, but I don't share bites anymore. NORMAN LEBHAR
AGING ATHLETES
When we were young, we relished sports;
You should have seen us score.
But now the points are getting sparse --
Just thinking makes us sore.
Yet age can be a wondrous thing,
Or so it's understood:
In memory, as games go on, 
Our skills seem twice as good!
 ROGER FENDRICH
 Eleanor Meyerhoff was in a wheelchair in a rehabilitation hospital, and her inspiration for recovery was a vigorous, independent octogenarian who was recovering from heart surgery. Each morning, arms swinging, he would stride past her open door as he circumnavigated the hospital corridors. One morning, she awakened to see him striding past holding a full-scale walker high above his head. "Do you know what that is all about?" Ms. Meyerhoff asked her roommate. "Yes," said the roommate. "Yesterday the nurses told him he would not be allowed to take his walks unless he held on to a walker, so he's complying."

HEADLINE: COLLISION WITH CHINA: THE CREW; 
In Third Visit, U.S. Diplomats Meet With Only 8 of 24 Detained Americans

BYLINE:  By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: HAIKOU, China, April 8 

 BODY:
Despite asking for "unfettered" access to the detained crew members of a downed American surveillance aircraft here, American diplomats were allowed early today to meet with only 8 of the 24 at their third meeting with the crew members and were denied a fourth meeting later in the day.
 The diplomatic team, headed by Brig. Gen. Neal Sealock, the defense attache from the American Embassy in Beijing, waited without word today on its request to meet with the crew twice a day. 
 The crew remained holed up in the officers quarters of a sprawling low-security Chinese Navy base in the southwest of this economically depressed city on southern China's Hainan island. 
The gate to the camp, a square, whie-tiled archway bearing a large, faded red star with the Chinese numerals for 8 and 1 pained in its center, sits at the end of a road scattered with grimy auto repair and hand-carwash shops. The numbers refer to Aug. 1, 1927, the date of a Communist uprising in the city of Nanchang, which represented the establishment of what became the People's Liberation Army.
Sailors in and out of uniform strolling through the gate today claimed no knowledge of their special guests, who are housed mostly two to a room in a building on the base. Guards at the gate, though, turned tongue-tied when asked about the Americans.
Hainan is a military stronghold for China's South Sea Fleet, a modest collection of about 50 ships and several airbases, including the one at Lingshui on the southeast end of the island where the American crew's crippled EP-3E Aries II aircraft landed a week ago after colliding off the coast with a Chinese F-8 jet. The American plane remains on a runway at the air base.
The American officials in Haikou confirmed that General Sealock and a consular official, Ted Gong, were able to meet with only some of the crew today at a long-delayed meeting that took place between 1 and 2 a.m. It was not clear how the eight crew members were selected for the meeting.
China has not yet assigned a status to the 21 men and 3 women that it has in custody. Although China says the American pilot broke Chinese laws by entering its airspace and landing at a military base without permission, it has not said that any member of the crew has been formally arrested. 
And China has not, for example, described the Americans as detainees, a status for which there are clear rules regarding consular access and other matters under a 1980 bilateral agreement. Under the rules of that agreement, for example, there would be no need for the tedious two- or three-hour meeting to negotiate the terms of each meeting with the crew.
China has said only that they are keeping the crew for their own investigation of the incident. An article in the military's Liberation Army Daily today said that Beijing is entitled to "thoroughly investigate" the crew and its plane. 
One thing complicating negotiations for the crew's release is believed to be the involvement of China's conservative military, which has the crew in custody.The military hopes to use th incident to force the United States to stop military surveillance flights off China's coast.
China continued searching for the pilot of the jet that crashed into the sea after hitting the American plane a week ago, though few people believe that he will be found alive. The Chinese media have already reported that the area where he was last spotted descending by parachute is frequented by sharks.
Still, the search, reportedly the biggest ever by China's navy, is continuing amid a nationwide propaganda campaign promoting the pilot as a national hero. Today, China said the search was joined by more than 800 fishing boats from various parts of China, including Taiwan, over which Beijing is trying to regain sovereignty.
Many people in China believe that the American crew will not be released until the search has been called off and the country has gone through what it believes to be an appropriate period of mourning.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Brig. Gen. Neal Sealock saw some of the crew early yesterday. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Bodies of 16 Recovered From Crash In Vietnam 

BYLINE:  By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, April 8 

 BODY:
Recovery teams removed the bodies today from the crash of the helicopter searching for remains of American soldiers missing from the Vietnam War.
 The helicopter crashed into a mountainside in central Vietnam on Saturday, killing all seven Americans and nine Vietnamese aboard. The Russian-made MI-17 helicopter, with its Vietnamese pilot, was part of a major cooperative search operation throughout Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia and southern China that has been under way since 1985 for missing American servicemen. 
 The search for the Americans, about 2,000 of whom are still missing, has been the cornerstone of Vietnam-American relations, an arena of cooperation embraced by both sides as they grope toward a more open political and economic relationship. 
Officials said they were still investigating the cause of the crash, the first loss of life since search operations began. Witnesses said they saw the helicopter making strange swinging movements in hazy weather before crashing and burning.
"The helicopter tilted side to side, then fluttered up and down in an abnormal patern," said Nguyen Viet Cuong, a local resident, speaking by telephone. "The helicopter crashed into the mountain and exploded. We all saw flames flare up."
Local officials said recovery teams carried the bodies in stretchers 30 minutes down a hillside for transportation by car to Hanoi. American officials said the bodies of the Americans would be returned to the United States but withheld the victims' names pending notification of next of kin.
The former enemies with a mutual tragedy issued statements of condolence today. President Bush offered condolences to the families of those killed, saying: "Today's loss is a terrible one for America. Although not lost in a hostile act, like those for whom they search, they too have lived lives of great consequence, answering a calling of service to their fellow citizens."
Vietnamalso issued a statement, saying, "On behalf of the government of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, Foreign Minister Nguyen Dy Nien has sent his deep condolences to the families of the Vietnamese victims and at the same time to the government, the people and the families of the United States."
The helicopter was part of an advance mission for a 95-member American team due to arrive from its base in Hawaii in early May to investigate six possile recovery sites, said the task force spokesman, Lt. Col. Franklin Childress, speaking from Hawaii. "We've been flying in this type of aircraft for a number of years and this is the first accident," he said. "Every mission is a dangerous mission. It's a very difficult area to operate in. Sometimes you can go in an area that's totally clear. And then right over the next hillside, it's totally fogged in."
The accident occurred near Thanh Trach village in Quang Binh Province, about 280 miles south of Hanoi. Quang Binh, the southernmost province of what was then North Vietnam -- just north of the demilitarized zone -- was heavily bombed during the war and contains many crash sites.
Advance teams like the one involved in the crash prepare base camps and supplies for the arrival of recovery teams at sites where probable remains have been identified.
The Hawaii-based operation, known as the Joint Task Force-Full Accounting, maintains a permanent team of Americans in Vietnam, working with Vietnamese investigators. It conducts about 10 major operations each year, involving dozens of American experts from Hawaii, each lasting about 30 days.
Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld said the crash involved the first loss of life either side has suffered in 65 joint missions in Vietnam.
"Since 1985, American teams, with the full support of their Vietnamese counterparts, have conducted investigations and excavations in that country," he said. "As a result of this sustained cooperation, we have recovered and identified the remains of more than 600 Americans and continue to search for those still missing in Southeast Asia."
The United States spends from $5 million to $6 million a year on recovery operations in Laos, Vietnam and Cambodia, officials said. This year, five operations are planned in Laos, four in Vietnam and one in Cambodia, Colonel Childress said.
The task force has recently expanded to search for missing soldiers from World War II and the Korean War.
Although it has helped the United States in its search operations as the price of improved relations and trade, the Vietnamese government has no organized program to search for its own missing soldiers, which it estimates at 300,000.
There is no official estimate of missing soldiers from the defeated army of the former South Vietnam, which was allied with the United States. More than three million Vietnamese are estimated to have died in the war.

GRAPHIC: Photo: An officer stood guard yesterday near Thanh Trach, where seven Americans and nine Vietnamese died in a helicopter crash on Saturday. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Rebuilt City Starts to Feel Effects of the Slowdown 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH 

 BODY:
Halfway across Fort Pitt Bridge, a city of glittering office towers and graceful overpasses appears in the afternoon sun. Downtown Pittsburgh blares prosperity. But enter one of these office towers, to visit with Dennis Yablonsky, who tries to generate corporate investment, and a different image intrudes. The slumping national economy governs his days.
 After steel declined, Pittsburgh nurtured high technology companies and dot-com start-ups, and as they grew, a more diversified city thrived in the 1990's. Mr. Yablonsky's task, as president of Pittsburgh Digital Greenhouse, an economic development initiative, is to keep the expansion flourishing. The latest strategy is to make Pittsburgh a center for the design of computer chips, using Digital Greenhouse's public and corporate money to lure companies. Just five companies have nibbled so far, gingerly setting up shop here, employing in total only 20 people -- far off the old pace of job creation. 
 "We are trying to get a lot of companies to put semiconductor design centers here, but one-third to one-half tell us they want to defer any decision and we should call back in the future," Mr. Yablonsky said. "That is a message we started hearing in January." 
Everywhere in Pittsburgh, and in cities like it around the country, business executives are cutting back. Their curtailment of investment spending and expansion plans is contributing to what now appears to be a nationwide slide toward recession. That is likely to dash hopes -- not only among ordinary Americans but on Wall Street and in Washington -- for a quick recovery from the stock market rout without much damage to the economy.
The March employment report addd more cold water. Employers shed 86,000 jobs in March, the Labor Department reported on Friday. That was the largest drop for one month since November 1991, when the economy was wobbling out of a recession. 
American business is losing its exuberance, and that is now the biggest drag on the $9 trillion economy. Consumers are still spending, if not quite as enthusiastically as before, at least enough to hold up their end.
Home construction and auto sales, two other pillars of the economy, remain solid, and job growth, while slowing, has not yet braked enough to push the jobless rate above a still low 4.3 percent.
Capital spending is lagging, and that is starting to pull down the rest of the economy. As executives wake up to overcapacity, shrinking profits and an unfriendly stock market, their spending for all sorts of ventures and equipment has fallen from an annual growth rate of 21 percent in the first quarter of 2000 to a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent in the fourth quarter. Two-thirds of the decline in the economy is a result of the pullback in business investment, the Commerce Department reported.
While Mr. Yablonsky waits, little setbacks are weakening companies already here. Cities that diversified and thrived in the 1990's, shedding their reliance on a single industry, are entering their first hard times in their new garb. That exposes a different vulnerability. Pittsburgh, minus the steel giants, must continually add small, vigorous enterprises to sustain prosperity, and the momentum is fading. "The slowdown has also reduced the number of jobs that companies in Pittsburgh want to fill," Mr. Yablonsky said.
None have announced mass downsizings, but there have been numerous small layoffs, particularly among the once-flourishing start-ups like OnlineChoice.com, founded by Sanjay Chopra, a 33-year-old Carnegie Mellon University graduate, who won an entrepreneur of the year award in Pittsburgh in 2000. Last month, Mr. Chopra was removed as chief executive. "It is surprising how quickly markets evaporate," he said afterward.
The idea behind OnlineChoice is to recruit thousands of consumers over the Internet and combine their buying power to purchase items like phone services, electricity or insurance at a discount. Unable to turn a profit or obtain new venture capital since last spring, Online has shrunk to 15 employees from 60. And far from investing in equipment, it has sold 12 idle computers, an extra copier and the office coffeemaker.
OnlineChoice's experience helps to explain the increase in Pittsburgh's unemployment rate, to 4.1 percent lately from an average of 3.7 percent last year. That is still slight, but many companies are no longer expanding. As a result, job applicants wait, wages are rising more slowly and bonuses are smaller.
"The M.A.'s and Ph.D's coming out of our universities used to have jobs before they graduated," said Wilbur S. Harmon, vice president for human resources at ANSYS, which develops software to test products and is one of the few dot-coms here still hiring. "Now they are graduating without jobs."
Outwardly, the city seems to be thriving. The University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, the city's largest employer, with 28,000 on the payroll, continues to expand, partly through acquisitions. Home sales are strong, and new office buildings, started last summer before the slowdown, are in mid-construction. While the city has lost more than 100,000 steel jobs, it has replaced them with jobs in other industries.
Some $25 million a month flows into Pittsburgh, mostly in state and federal money, for the construction of a football stadium in addition to the just-completed baseball stadium and a convention center now rising along the Allegheny River. It is a vast riverfront project, employing 1,500 construction workers. That pleased Jack Shea, president of the Allegheny County Labor Council in central Pittsburgh.
"We have a mayor who is proactive in public investment," Mr. Shea said, pointing to a green "Tom Murphy for Mayor" cap displayed on his credenza. "The slowdown has not manifested itself in my life yet, except for the pockets of layoffs at dot-com companies. And we don't represent those workers."
But if Mr. Shea is at peace, Victoria K. Barnhart is increasingly uneasy. She runs Barnhart's Honda/ Suzuki dealership, selling motorcycles and small all-terrain vehicles along Route 79, on the southern fringe of the metropolitan area. Sales began a decline in October, but jumped back in February, only to fall again in March when they should have spiked in anticipation of spring.
"We cannot figure out what people are thinking," Ms. Barnhart said as she walked through a warehouse stacked nearly full of the balloon tire A.T.V.'s. Farmers like the vehicles for getting around in the fields, and until last fall there were more than enough customers for Barnhart's and a competing dealership that opened in 1999 about 30 miles down the highway. Now, the competition is a threat, one investment too many.
"Neither one of us is going to get as many sales as we should in this slowing economy," Ms. Barnhart said. "I am going to hang in and hope that my competitor decides to quit."
The slowdown is seeping into other corners. Revenue from a local sales tax has sagged, suggesting that retail sales are beginning to weaken. The family-owned William A. Fischer Carpet Company, which Ann Fischer has run since her husband's death in 1999, installs carpets in hotels and offices, and orders have fallen precipitously since December.
"Companies are deferring," Mrs. Fischer said, invoking a word frequently heard in Pittsburgh these days. "We'll be O.K. until July, and we'll have men on vacation, which should get us through the summer."
In a city where the average age is higher than almost anywhere else in the country, hundreds of thousands of retired steelworkers draw pensions as well as Social Security, and that income keeps coming, immune to a slowdown. But those still employed in the steel industry are not so fortunate. One of the largest employers, the Allegheny Ludlum Corporation, with 3,200 steel workers in the area, has cut overtime more than 50 percent, a loss the United Steelworkers of America says it cannot offset through wage increases in contract negotiations just starting.
"They have to accept a lower standard of living," said Andrew Palm, a district director for the steelworkers' union. "These are older workers and what you try to do is get more on the pension side."
Manufacturing's woes precipitated the national slowdown, and manufacturers here see hard months ahead. Frank A. Archinaco, executive vice president of PPG Industries, goes out of his way to express the pessimism that drives his company to consolidate factory operations, reduce overtime and trim costs -- all in the name of bringing capacity into line with demand. 
PPG, which has its headquarters here, makes auto glass and industrial paint. The research and development labs are also here, with more than 800 employees.
"We have not reduced our R. & D. spending, but we have tightened to get rid of weaker performers," Mr. Archinaco said. "It should not take a downturn to get rid of poor performers. We should have done that anyway and now we are forced to do so."
Peter C. Johnson, a surgeon, faces a different constraint. He is the chairman of TissueInformatics, a biotech start-up that develops software to analyze human tissue.
But like other high-technology companies, TissueInformatics does not generate enough revenue to finance expansion, and Dr. Johnson raised only $4.5 million from investors last year, instead of the $20 million he had sought. So he postponed plans to develop a databank of tissue samples, holding the payroll at 40 people instead of the nearly 80 he once planned to have by now.
"In a booming economy, speed is important to beat others to market," Dr. Johnson said. "But in a slowdown, the emphasis must shift to good tactics to sta4 alive."
That is also the way that Richard S. Kushner, a senior director of marketing at Marconi Communications, sees it. As a manufacturer of communications switches for telephone and Internet companies, Marconi, which has its North American headquarters here, has been hurt by the cutback in capital spending. 
Revenue is growing more slowly, and to keep it from flagging even more, Mr. Kushner is pushing a new virtue of Marconi's equipment: Rather than use it for expansion, he tells customers, buy it or lease it to cut costs.
"Our customers are increasingly capital constrained," Mr. Kushner said, "so they come to us for an operating agreement and they lease the equipment, which we then install and maintain and operate and manage." Still, Marconi's once rapidly growing staff has leveled off at 1,800 employees. And there are other adjustments. Marconi had long made donations to support the city's arts.
"We are declining some requests outright this year," a Marconi spokesman said. And last month, the company pulled a television commercial that used to call attention to its "aggressive hiring" in the Pittsburgh area.

U.S. Warns China of Harm In Spy Plane Standoff
The Bush administration warned Beijing that its relationship with the United States risked further harm if the crew of a downed American spy plane remained in detention. Officials again firmly rejected the kind of apology China has demanded for the plane's collision with a Chinese fighter jet, and insisted that the United States would not give up its right to such eavesdropping flights. HEADLINE: Cornell Will Open A Medical School In the Persian Gulf 

BYLINE:  By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
In one of the biggest deals yet in the growing export of American higher education, Cornell University is establishing a branch campus of its medical school in the Middle East, where students will receive the same diploma as those 6,700 miles away in New York City.
 Cornell will announce today that it will create the Weill Medical College of Cornell University in Qatar, a tiny, wealthy Persian Gulf nation that has agreed to spend $750 million on the school over 11 years, including a fee to Cornell. 
 American universities have increasingly been establishing programs abroad, from student exchanges to research institutes to distance education programs conducted over the Internet. But few, if any, are as comprehensive as the Cornell agreement, which will give a full Ivy League medical degree to students who may never set foot in the United States. And many are encountering challenges. 
Cornell's president, Hunter R. Rawlings III, said he and others were initially concerned about conditions in Qatar. The university investigated everything from human rights and the treatment of women to the country's political stability.
"Some of our Jewish trustees and alumni were especially concerned," Dr. Rawlings said. "But as they learned more about Qatar and its ambitions, they were willing to proceed." 
He said the medical college in Qatar would have a nondiscrimination policy, just as the one in New York does, and would accept Jews -- and even Israelis -- as faculty members and students. 
"We are bound to a nondiscrimination policy and we will respect that," said Abdulredha Abdulrahman, the managing director of the Qatar Foundation, which is financing the project. "Entrance will be controlled by Cornell. This has nothing to do with nationalities. Anyone who is qualified is welcome."
Robert Zemsky, a professor and director of the Institute for Research on Higher Education at the University of Pennsylvania, predicts that there will be many more instances of American universities venturing abroad. "There is a major international market emerging in higher education."
He points to examples like the University of Chicago's executive M.B.A. program in Singapore and Barcelona, and another project in Singapore in which the Johns Hopkins medical school trains doctors to be researchers, but does not award a degree. He said that Cornell appeared to have dealt with challenges that have sometimes stymied other American universities seeking to go abroad, including language (the Qatar medical school will be conducted in English), economics (Qatar is paying the bill), and whether the American university is seen as a carpetbagger (Qatar wanted Cornell to come, and has treated Cornell officials like dignitaries).
"We are very familiar with education in the United States and knew that Cornell was among the top 10 medical schools," Mr. Abdulredha said. "We found Cornell very keen."
The foundation, established by the emir of Qatar and led by his wife, Sheika Mozah bint Nasser al-Misnad, has committed to pay an estimated $750 million to operate the medical college for 11 years. Neither Cornell nor the foundation would discuss the size of the management fee, or of a donation that the foundation is also making to the medical school. Both say that the donation was not a factor in the agreement. 
Cornell will control the curriculum, the faculty and the admission of students, who will have to take the same tests and meet the same standards as those in New York, the university said. 
Cornell's medical college is among the most selective in the United States. This year's entering students -- 101 in all -- were chosen from 6,344 applicants and had a 3.7 grade point average on their science courses in college. 
Cornell is aiming for an entering class of about 50 students in Qatar, drawn from there and other countries, within the Arab world and without. Mr. Abdulredha said the agreement called for 70 percent of the class to come from Qatar unless too few Qataris qualify, in which case more students from outside the country will be admitted. If too few total students qualify, the class will be smaller, but Mr. Abdulredha said he did not expect that problem. "We will get the brightest students from Qatar and the region, and they will excel," he said, "We have the brains. We don't have the education system." 
Qatar, an oil- and gas-rich neighbor of Saudi Arabia with 750,000 inhabitants, many of them foreign workers, is smaller than Connecticut. It has no medical school and is trying to create an education city anchored by an array of elite American universities in the capital city, Doha.
Qatar is widely considered among the most forward-looking of Arab states. A Qatari satellite television station, Al-Jazeera, beams frank public affairs discussions and interviews, including talks with Israeli leaders, into homes across the Middle East.
An Israeli trade representative office opened in Qatar five years ago and has remained open over the past six months despite pressures on Qatar to close it in solidarity with the Palestinian uprising. 
As part of the medical school arrangement, Cornell will also run a two-year science-intensive premedical program to prepare students to apply. That program will begin taking students next year, and plans call for the medical school to open two years later. Students who complete the premedical program will not necessarily be accepted to the medical school; they will still need to take the medical school boards and apply to the medical college. 
When the Qatar Foundation first approached Weill Cornell Medical College two year ago, it found immediate interest. Dr. Antonio M. Gotto Jr., the dean, studied abroad as a Rhodes scholar. As a cardiologist, he treated many foreign patients, including many from the Middle East. 
He also created an office of international medicine at the medical school, where nearly half the students take a medical elective in a foreign country.
"I am convinced that medicine and health are global problems," he said, "and we in the United States have an obligation to work with the rest of the world."
"The initial reaction from many people was," he added, " 'Why on earth would you want to do something like that?' "
He ticked off the arguments he heard against the project: "It's far away. It could be dangerous. They have very different customs. You might dilute your resources, and distract your management. You may not be able to recruit faculty or find students. Some of your alumni and friends may not understand it."
After extensive discussion and trips to Qatar, the medical school's leaders decided to go ahead. They plan to have about 65 faculty members in Qatar, and to supplement their teaching with courses in New York, presented over live video.
Dr. Daniel R. Alonso, a pathologist and former senior associate dean for academic affairs at the medical school in New York, will be dean of the new Qatar campus. He said he planned to go to Qatar next year and remain at least until the first class graduates, in 2008.
"How often do you have the chance to do something unprecedented like this?" Dr. Alonso, who was born and raised in Argentina, asked last week. 
Sanford I. Weill, the business executive who is chairman of the medical school's board of overseers and whose name the medical school bears, acknowledged that there were uncertainties involved in the project. 
"I don't think Arab-Jewish relations are the issue at all," he added. "This is about health care, medical education and medical research. We're not in the political business; we're in the science business, the education business."
Mr. Abdulredha acknowledged the political tension and said, "For an American university to come to this part of the world requires lots of studies and assurances."
Cornell is only one of the universities that the Qatar Foundation has approached. The University of Virginia came close to establishing an undergraduate college, winning approval from both the State Legislature and its own trustees. But it ultimately backed off, citing concerns over accreditation. (Cornell says it anticipates no problems with accreditation.)
The Qatar Foundation is continuing to talk to other top universities about setting up programs in business, engineering and information technology, although it will not name them. (Virginia Commonwealth University is already running a design program.)
"I think after Cornell, the others will follow," said Mr. Abdulredha, who earned his bachelor's degree in Britain and a graduate degree at the University of Texas. "A lot of people don't believe we will succeed," he added, "but I think we will surprise them."

HEADLINE: California Energy Plan Punishes the Good Guys 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 The problem with setting California's energy baseline at any percent of the amount consumed a year ago during the comparable billing period is that it profoundly penalizes the consumers who have already been conserving power (Economic Scene column, April 5). 
 There are those of us who lived through the energy crisis in the 1970's and have been responsible about power ever since. 
For those who have been wasteful, to reduce power usage by 10 percent will be simple. For those who have been conserving, it is hardly fair to penalize them when there may be no areas in which it is possible to conserve.
I suggest that we set a baseline that allows a modestly sized home to be run efficiently. Any amount over that would be billed at a much higher rate.

JEANNETTE GRANT
Occidental, Calif., April 5, 2001

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
Wieden & Kennedy Is Cutting Staff 12%

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliot 

 BODY:
In another sign of the effect of the slowing economy on advertising, Wieden & Kennedy is laying off 12 percent of the 314 employees at its headquarters in Portland, Ore., and its New York office. 
 They are the first major dismissals at the agency since June 1998; overseas offices in Amsterdam, London and Tokyo are not affected.
