HEADLINE: For the Poor, a Lawyer With 1,600 Clients 

BYLINE:  By JANE FRITSCH and DAVID ROHDE 

 BODY:
Last year, Sean P. Sullivan had 1,600 clients, all of them poor and charged with crimes. He did not have to hustle to get the work. His thriving law practice came courtesy of New York City, whose courts appointed him to all the cases, a record number for one lawyer in a single year.
 On a recent Thursday morning, he ambled into the Manhattan Criminal Courts Building in a rumpled gray suit, a shirt with a frayed collar and a stained necktie. Entering a packed courtroom, he called out the names of his first five clients. Two waved to him from the audience. He nodded, plopped down on a bench and went to work on a crossword puzzle. 
 Over the next four hours, Mr. Sullivan would represent a dozen defendants, and as they waited, half would complain bitterly that he never returns phone calls or that he runs away when they try to speak to him. Twice that morning, he would show up in the wrong courtroom. A colleague would have to fill in to represent a client whose court appearance Mr. Sullivan could not make. 
He would miscalculate by several weeks the amount of time remaining before one client's case would have to be dismissed under speedy-trial rules. He would learn that another client had grown so frustrated with him that he had come up with the money to hire a lawyer. And back in the cramped office he shares with 11 other lawyers, he would admit that he had no particular filing system. 
"I use the same filing the judges do," he said, tossing an imaginary folder toward an imaginary point on his cluttered desk. "They just throw it in the basket and someone else files it." But Mr. Sullivan cannot afford to have someone put his files away. Court-appointed work, he lamented, just does not pay enough. "Sometimes I come back here and I throw it down and then when the deadline comes for the motions, I miss them."
At the age of 38, he summed up his attitude toward his job with a baseball analogy. "Some guys can be in the major leagues and be frustrated they're not living up to their potential," he said. "Another guy can realize he's going to be a .250 hitter and be happy he's a .250 hitter. I can do this, and there's some satisfaction out of doing something and doing it reasonably well."
Mr. Sullivan was paid $125,041 by the city last year. He is one of dozens of private attorneys who, working alone, represent hundreds, even thousands, of indigent clients each year in a court system so desperate for lawyers that it puts no limit on the number of cases any one lawyer may take.
Mr. Sullivan acknowledged that clients complained about him but said he did a good job. "It's a high-volume place," he said. "I'm a symptom of the problem." 
Nearly four decades after the United States Supreme Court ruled in Gideon v. Wainwright that indigent defendants have a right to legal counsel, almost no part of New York City's plan for providing the lawyers functions as it was intended.
More than most big cities, New York relies on private lawyers to represent defendants who cannot afford to hire their own. Most big cities assign such cases to public defender's offices, government agencies that have hundreds ofstaff attorneys, supervisors and support personnel, like investigators, social workers and secretaries.
In New York, the Legal Aid Society, a nonprofit organization, was supposed to function like a public defender's office, representing nearly all indigent defendants. But Legal Aid, weakened in a dispute with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, now represents only about 50 percent of the roughly 385,000 people arrested for misdemeanors and felonies each year.
In sharply cutting Legal Aid's budget, the mayor also diluted the strength of a powerful force that regularly pursued civil cases to protect suspects' rights in the criminal justice system. 
In the new system created by the mayor, several smaller organizations are now given 18 percent of the cases.
That leaves about 115,000 defendants in need of lawyers. To fill the gap, the city turns to private lawyers, not only for those defendants, but also for roughly 170,000 more who are given summonses each year for low-level violations as part of Mr. Giuliani's quality-of-life campaign.
Judges, lawyers and defendants say the system is at the breaking point.
"We too often see lawyers who were woefully unprepared, did little to investigate, were ignorant of the applicable law, had inadequate trial skills and did not appear to be committed to their client's cause," said Richard M. Greenberg, the attorney in charge of the Office of the Appellate Defender, a nonprofit organization that handles appeals of criminal convictions.
For indigent defendants, even those charged with the least serious transgressions, the stakes are growing. New laws have made criminal convictions grounds for denying people jobs, evicting them from city-owned housing, denying college financial aid and cutting off welfare benefits.
The flood of cases comes at a time when the number of lawyers willing to represent the indigent has dropped sharply, to 1,200 from 2,200 in 1993. Their chief complaint is New York's pay, $40 an hour in court and $25 an hour out of court, the second-lowest rate in the nation. Only New Jersey pays its appointed lawyers less -- $30 an hour in court and $25 out of court -- but most indigent defendants in New Jersey are represented by the state's vast public defender system.
More than a year ago, Judith S. Kaye, New York State's chief judge, said there was an "acute shortage" of lawyers for the poor and the problem had reached a crisis stage. Little has changed since then.
The problems have escalated over a period of years and have become "more and more dire," said Jonathan Lippman, the state's chief administrative judge. "I've never seen it like this, and I've been in the system for 30 years," Judge Lippman said. "Day in and day out, we are struggling to level the playing field. This can't continue."
The city spent $125 million on indigent defense last year, up from $116 million in 1995. But adjusted for inflation, that is a drop of 11 percent. 
During the same period, the number of arrests for misdemeanors and felonies rose by 30 percent, and the budget of the city's prosecutors rose by 6 percent, adjusted for inflation, to $220 million from $179 million.
A committee appointed by the State Legislature and Gov. George E. Pataki is trying to reach an agreement that would raise rates for appointed lawyers, but the members are struggling to work out whether the state should pay part of the cost. The Legislature sets the pay rates but the city pays the bills.
In the past, there has been little discussion of alternatives to appointed lawyers, like the public defender systems used in other states. But New York officials are beginning to consider revamping the entire system, according to Katherine N. Lapp, Governor Pataki's criminal justice adviser.
If the state ends up paying for a wage increase, it could mean state oversight of a system that now has little monitoring.
City and court officials do not monitor, for instance, how many cases a particular lawyer has pending at any given time. Nor do they stop overextended lawyers from taking on more cases. And they do not review the work that lawyers do on individual cases, other than to check for double-billing.

The Crush
Caseloads Stretch Into the Hundreds
Last year, the 20 busiest private attorneys were assigned to represent more than 9,000 defendants whose cases went past arraignment, and hundreds more
who agreed to plea bargains on the day they were arrested, according to city records and the bills submitted by the lawyers.
In all, at least 28 lawyers were each assigned more than 300 cases last year. At least 13 had more than 400, placing them beyond the caseload limit set by New York City's courts for the Legal Aid Society and similar organizations. Standards cited by the National Legal Aid and Defender Association say that no lawyer should handle more than 150 felonies or 400 misdemeanors in a year. And the American Bar Association code of responsibility says lawyers have a duty to refuse cases if they lack the time or expertise to handle them.
Sara Goldman, a lawyer from Leonia, N.J., represented 805 defendants charged with parole violations last year, nearly 10 percent of the 8,500 parole cases in New York City and more than double the recommended case limit. If convicted, the defendants are usually returned to prison.
Ms. Goldman's cases are heard in the half-dozen parole courtrooms crammed into three trailers on Rikers Island. At a typical session one Friday morning last December, she met 10 new clients and arranged for 6 to plead guilty. The other four cases were postponed, and she was done before lunch.
For most cases, she bills the city for one hour of work in court and three hours out of court. The out-of-court work generally involves opening a case file, preparing a written notice that she has been assigned to the case and, after the case is over, reviewing the judge's decision and closing the file. Sometimes, she bills for 30 minutes of case preparation. She was paid $118,027 for her work last year.
In an interview, she acknowledged that she sometimes interviews her clients in the courtroom, in the presence of the prosecutor and the judge. She said they do not pay attention to her conversations with defendants.
"I think I do a good job," she said, "but I've been doing it for a long time." In parole cases, she said, defendants do better with an experienced appointed lawyer than with a lawyer they might hire. "They could have Johnnie Cochran, and he wouldn't be able to get them a better deal."
Arleen Ralph, a Brooklyn lawyer, handled at least 560 cases last year, according to city records, but there were dozens more that went uncounted. The city does not track the number of cases lawyers handle during arraignment, when many are resolved with a quick plea bargain. Whatever Ms. Ralph's total, it was well beyond the maximum of 400 recommended for misdemeanor cases.
Ms. Ralph's clients typically pleaded guilty, as do most defendants charged with misdemeanors. Working from an office on Court Street, she has made indigent-defense work into a full-time job. 
Ms. Ralph did not respond to telephone messages and a letter sent to her office.

The Fallout
Legal Aid Is Hobbled
In a complex arrangement established in 1965, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court was given responsibility for ensuring that indigent defendants in New York City had lawyers. The Legal Aid Society was supposed to take nearly all cases. Private lawyers were to be given only homicide cases and the small number of cases in which Legal Aid had a conflict of interest; for example, a case with two clients accused of committing a crime together.
The private lawyers were to be assigned and monitored by the Appellate Division, choosing from a list of lawyers who had signed up in advance.
Over the years, private lawyers have been allowed to take an increasing number of cases, tens of thousands by 1994. After Mayor Giuliani took office that year, he said he planned to reduce the role of appointed lawyers drastically and shift the cases back to the Legal Aid Society.
But when Legal Aid lawyers went on strike in late 1994, Mr. Giuliani reversed course, vowing to eliminate the society's "monopoly." He cut Legal Aid's budget by 25 percent and arranged for seven new organizations to take limited numbers of cases. Mr. Giuliani said the new groups would create competition that would improve the general quality of legal work. They would also lessen the effect of any future strikes by Legal Aid.
At the same time, the mayor began a quality-of-life campaign that flooded the courts with thousands of new cases. Far from eliminating private lawyers, he had made them more necessary than ever.
Now, judges often bypass administrative procedures and assign lawyers on their own, sometimes drafting anyone who happens to be in the courtroom.
Some lawyers complain that judges, under pressure to move a huge volume of cases through the system, force more cases on them than they can handle. In a pending lawsuit seeking higher pay rates for appointed lawyers, several filed affidavits describing court officers and judges who walk the halls of the courthouses looking for lawyers to represent indigent defendants. 
The lawsuit, filed by the firm Davis Polk & Wardwell on behalf of the New York County Lawyers' Association, describes a system "in the grasp of a steep downward spiral." Many appointed lawyers, the suit says, "do not have functioning law offices with essential legal research facilities, secretaries, message takers, investigators, legal assistants or other basic support services."
For a large number of assigned lawyers, the suit says, trial preparation is a "dreamlike fantasy made distant by the need to put food on the table."
A hobbled Legal Aid Society represented about 200,000 indigent defendants last year, roughly the same number it did six years ago but with a fraction of the resources. The city cut the society's budget to $60 million from $80 million in 1994, forcing deep cuts in personnel. Its roster of staff lawyers has dropped to 340 from 517, and the number of supervisors has dropped to 37 from 103. The staffs of investigators and social workers have been cut in half.
"We're starving for resources," said Daniel L. Greenberg, the executive director of Legal Aid. The society has filed a lawsuit in federal court alleging that Mr. Giuliani breached the city's contract with Legal Aid and unlawfully retaliated for the 1994 strike.
Citywide, 200 of the society's lawyers have caseloads beyond the recommended limit of 400. Particularly hard hit is Legal Aid's office in Manhattan, where the deluge of cases generated by the quality-of-life campaign has been heaviest.
Many of the most experienced lawyers and supervisors have fled the Legal Aid Society to take jobs with the new defense groups established by the mayor. The new groups often pay more and, unlike Legal Aid, have caseload limits set by their contracts with the city.
There are other signs of strain at Legal Aid.
Last December, an appeals court in Brooklyn threw out the conviction of a Legal Aid client on the grounds that the lawyer had botched the case. The defendant, Kevin Maldonado, had been in prison for three years for a robbery he says he did not commit.
Mr. Maldonado, now 25, was arreste in 1995 at Newtown High Shool in Elmhurst, Queens, where he had gone because his nephew had gotten into trouble. As Mr. Maldonado sat in an office, a student passed by and said Mr. Maldonado had been one of the five strangers who had robbed him in a stairwell two months earlier. The police were summoned and he was arrested.
Mr. Maldonado, a construction worker with no criminal record, rejected a plea bargain that would have given him five years of probation. His first trial ended in a hung jury, and he was again offered probation. But, insisting that he had been at work at the time of the robbery, he demanded a retrial.
A new Legal Aid lawyer, Manuela Grobe, was assigned. But at the retrial, she did not call three defense witnesses who had testified at the first trial, according to trial transcripts and other records. And, like the first Legal Aid lawyer, she did not contact two alibi witnesses who would have testified that Mr. Maldonado was at work at the time of the robbery. He was convicted and sentenced to 5 to 15 years in prison.
It was only after Mr. Maldonado's family and co-workers hired a lawyer, Elliott B. Leibowitz, that the two additional witnesses were contacted. A nonprofit group called Appellate Advocates took the case and won the reversal. Michael Brovner, an assistant district attorney in Queens who was recently assigned to the case, said in February that he would demand a third trial.
Last month, Mr. Maldonado gave up his fight and pleaded guilty in exchange for a sentence of time served. He said he wanted to go to the Dominican Republic to see his father, who is ill, before he dies. "There's no justice in this country," he said in a recent interview. "They be playing with people."
Ms. Grobe died in 1997, but at a hearing after the conviction she testified that she believed that her cross-examination of the victim had been so effective that Mr. Maldonado would be acquitted. Susan L. Hendricks, the deputy attorney in charge of Legal Aid's criminal defense division, said the handling of the Maldonado case had been assessed by supervisors, who agreed that Ms. Grobe's trial strategy was appropriate. She said she could not elaborate.
But Ms. Hendricks acknowledged that the Legal Aid Society is having difficult times. After five years of city cuts, the organization "is at the breaking point," she said.
"We're holding things together with bubble gum and string," she said. "We don't have enough lawyers, we don't have enough investigators, we don't have enough social workers. We don't meet the standards for any of this."
Perhaps more significant, Legal Aid has fewer resources to devote to the sort of class-action litigation that has forced systemwide changes in the past. In 1991, for instance, the Court of Appeals, New York State's highest court, ruled in a case brought by Legal Aid that suspects must be released if they are not arraigned within 24 hours. Until then, suspects frequently spent days in jail before seeing a judge.
The city keeps a close watch on the Legal Aid Society, requiring that it file monthly reports on its activities and on the number of cases handled by each staff lawyer. And each year, the Appellate Division commissions a report on its performance, as well as on the performance of the smaller groups.

The Oversight
Lawyers Receive Scant Monitoring
But no one monitors the performance of the vast majority of the appointed lawyers who represent the indigent. Only once in the last 36 years has there been a review of the lawyers, and then only for those who handle felonies in Manhattan and the Bronx.
That effort, begun in 1994 by a volunteer committee that screens the lawyers for the Appellate Division's First Department, has just been completed. The volunteers, working with no staff or funding, checked with judges and other lawyers, but did not review work on individual cases. About 60 of the 600 lawyers reviewed were removed from the indigent-defense pool.
"If we could have staff support, it would make a world of difference," said Norman L. Reimer, a former chairman of the committee. "You can't just have people coming in and taking as many cases as they want and working as many shifts as they want and expect them to render quality."
Harvey Fishbein, the current chairman of the committee, said there were no plans to review the hundreds of lawyers who handle misdemeanor cases. "You can't just ask people who are doing this on a voluntary basis to put in the hours it takes to do the recertification work," he said.
In Queens, Brooklyn and Staten Island, there are also no plans to review the felony or misdemeanor lawyers.
So it is largely left to the appeals courts to examine the work of appointed lawyers. But most cases end with plea agreements and are never appealed. The courts are so overcrowded and the push for guilty pleas is so strong that less than 1 percent of misdemeanors and 6 percent of felonies go to trial.
In recent years, appeals courts have criticized appointed lawyers for a range of failings. In one case, a lawyer filed no motions and failed to request the proper jury instructions. In another, the lawyer made an incorrect legal argument. And in a third, a lawyer failed to interview a witness before calling him to the stand and ignored warnings from another lawyer that the witness's testimony would "bury" his client.
Mr. Reimer, the former head of the screening committee, said the errors were not surprising. "The starvation of this system over the past 15 years has resulted in a complete evisceration of quality," he said. "You don't have to be a rocket scientist to see that if you starve the system and play one group off the other for survival, you're going to drive it down, and that's what has happened."
Mr. Fishbein said he would like to return to a system that relies primarily on a strong central defender. Private lawyers, he said, should be used only for cases in which the central defender has a conflict of interest. 
"Only a strong defender service would have a voice in the criminal justice system," he said. "Being fractured and divided, the defender services don't have a voice. A unified voice would be much stronger."

Two-Tier Justice

This is the second of three articles examining the representation that New York City offers to indigent defendants. The first article dealt with homicide defendants. Articles in this series are available at The New York Times on the Web:
www.nytimes.com/metro

HEADLINE: Seizing the Phone Giants' Turf; 
Upstart RCN Digs In Despite Industry's Turmoil

BYLINE:  By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
David C. McCourt, the RCN Corporation's chairman and chief executive, says he did not set out to become a pioneer, at least not in the telecommunications industry.
 When Mr. McCourt returned to Boston two decades ago after graduating from Georgetown and working for 18 months as a probation officer's aide in Washington's hardscrabble Anacostia neighborhood, he just thought he was going home. 
 "When you grow up in New England," he said, "you just expect that you're going to return." 
Mr. McCourt, now 44, was not simply going home. He was returning to his father's trade: construction. In 1981, Mr. McCourt found himself digging trenches all around Boston for entrepreneurs who wanted to deliver a then-novel service called cable television. 
Twenty years later, Mr. McCourt is still laying cables and building networks, though he and RCN are now based in Princeton, N.J. ("In the 200 years since my family moved over from Ireland, I'm the only male McCourt to leave Boston; I still have to explain myself at Christmas," he says.) And he is also building a special place for himself in the telecommunications industry.
That is because 5 years after the Telecommunications Act of 1996, which promised to open broad vistas of competition in formerly cloistered markets, RCN is the only company of significant size that is focused on giving consumers an alternative to the local telephone and cable television monopolies for a combination of local phone, cable TV and high-speed Internet services. AT&T, WorldCom and a few cable companies have made efforts to give consumers an alternative source of local phone service, but no other significant company is competing against local incumbents with RCN's breadth of services. 
After the telecommunications act, hundreds if not thousands of new companies sprang up to deliver local communications services in competition against old local phone giants like Bell Atlantic and Southwestern Bell. But most of those companies look for business customers. And logically so: a midsize business, after all, might spend tens of thousands of dollars a month on communications.
Then there was RCN, quixotically building networks in residential neighborhoods, hoping to sign up households that might spend $100 a month on phone, cable and Internet service. By the end of last year, RCN sold at least one of those services to about 985,000 homes, mostly in New York City and other parts of the Northeast, but also in Chicago and along the California coast.
"The vision has always been to build a new network for the residential environment that's capable of selling all of today's services -- voice, video and data -- with plenty of capacity for tomorrow's services," Mr. McCourt said in an interview last week.
These can be tough times for telecommunications visionaries. Many of the local communications start-ups are starved for capital, their very existence now in question. A year ago, for instance, shares of Teligent were trading as high as $55.50. On Friday, Teligent's shares closed at 37.5 cents. Last week, Winstar Communications, whose shares touched $56 around this time last year, announced that it would cut 2,000 jobs. On Friday, Winstar's shares closed at 40.6 cents.
And there amid the carnage stands RCN. Mr. McCourt is not happy that his stock closed on Friday at $3.97, down from a 52-week high of $55. Nor is he happy that RCN, to conserve cash, has had to scale back its plans to enter new markets. 
In addition, a fair number of analysts think that RCN's sales, general and administrative costs are far too high, a problem that Mr. McCourt has at least tacitly acknowledged and is moving to fix. Mr. McCourt openly admits that RCN's so-called "back office" systems, the computers that keep track of customers and bills, installation requests and service problems, need a lot of work.
But RCN might just have a vital ally as it tries to tighten its budget: time. At the end of last year, RCN had $1.7 billion in cash on hand and another $500 million available in a line of credit. Most analysts appear to believe that the company is in no danger of going under any time soon.
"I'm a big believer in the long-term outlook for this company; our model does indicate that the company's scaled-back business plan is indeed fully funded," said Mark Kastan, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston. He added, however, that he thought the company's cash reserve would eventually hit a low of only about $150 million, rather than the $500 million that RCN had predicted.
The fact that RCN does not appear to be in danger of going out of business any time soon is surely a comforting thought to its employees, investors and customers. But RCN's mere existence carries a larger significance: It is possible for a small start-up company to challenge the local telephone behemoths and cable television incumbents and give residential consumers a choice of provider for both basic communications services and fast Internet access.
According to the Federal Communications Commission, big businesses and institutions had about 46.5 million phone lines at the end of last June. Of those, 17.5 percent were served by competitive carriers (not the dominant local telephone companies). For corporate customers, competition clearly is taking hold. 
But at the same time, homes and small businesses had about 145.1 million phone lines and of those, only 4.6 million, or about 3.2 percent, were served by new carriers. Competition is obviously coming much more slowly to consumers than it is to business customers (which may be why, relative to inflation, local phone service is generally no cheaper now than it was 15 years ago).
One of the challenges in competing with the dominant local phone companies is that in order to generate sustainable profits in the telecommunications, a company usually has to own substantial network assets of its own: fiber optic lines, switches and other equipment. The Telecommunications Act required big incumbent local phone companies to sell access to pieces of their networks -- like the copper lines that run into almost every home and business -- to other carriers. But each part of a network that is leased by a new carrier rather than built and owned reduces that new carrier's chances for profitability.
"You need to own your own network to have a viable business plan," Mr. Kastan said. "And to do that you need to raise a huge amount of capital."
That voracious appetite for capital is one reason so many competitive local carriers are in trouble. In the current economy and stock market, the capital markets are essentially closed to them, making it difficult to raise money for network construction and for weathering the up-front losses the new networks incur.
One key reason many analysts expect RCN to survive the downturn is that Mr. McCourt raised billions of dollars when the getting was good. Having parlayed his cable ditch-digging skills into small communications companies -- one in Boston, a second in London -- that he nurtured and then sold, Mr. McCourt used his proceeds in 1993 to start a partnership with the Peter Kiewit construction empire, to take control of a small communications company in Pennsylvania called C-Tec. After a series of spinoffs, Mr. McCourt kept the company that is now called RCN -- the name was derived from "residential communications network" -- which he moved to Princeton.
In 1999, Paul G. Allen's Vulcan Ventures agreed to invest $1.7 billion in RCN and still owns about 27 percent of the company. That year, RCN also secured a $250 million investment from Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, the investment firm, which still owns almost 8 percent of the company. In addition, RCN made secondary stock offerings in both 1998 and 1999.
Another key to RCN's viability has been the relatively efficient way that the company has built its networks. Part of that is simply the operational know-how from Mr. McCourt's long construction experience. But the company has also marshaled its resources by concentrating on relatively densely populated areas, often with many apartment buildings, rather than trying to string together single-family homes. 
But while deep pockets and careful construction are necessary for a new local carrier, there is also the complicated business of running a communications carrier. The mundane but crucial tasks include scheduling and dispatching installation technicians efficiently and making sure that customers are being billed every month (and cutting off customers who don't pay). Many a start-up has stumbled on such basic steps, and so far RCN's record on these matters has been mixed. 
"The issues right now are expense control and upgrades of the back-office systems," Mr. Kastan said. "They have the right strategy, but this company will have to demonstrate a lot more on the expense control and the system-upgrade sides before they really get out of the woods. I'm a big believer in McCourt. But they need to show better execution."
Mr. McCourt acknowledges the need for RCN to tighten up its operation. This year, he recruited two senior executives to ride herd on expenses and the company's field technicians. And last week, the company announced it would buy a new billing and customer management system from the Convergys Corporation.
The billing system is of particular concern because many of RCN's customers who use the company for multiple services now receive multiple bills each month. Unified billing would probably please customers and would also give the company more flexibility in offering promotions and lower prices for people who subscribe to a package of phone, cable and Internet services. It might also enable the company to sign up more customers more efficiently.
"We kept getting phone and cable on separate bills and over all, it did seem more expensive than what people in other buildings were paying," recalled Ashley Quigley, 24, an executive conference planner in Manhattan. Until last fall, she lived in an apartment building on the Upper East Side served by RCN. Despite the billing issues, "I was impressed that the service people I dealt with were actually intelligent and efficient human beings," she said. "The service people were really good."
Mr. McCourt, who is married with two children, says he has no intention of leaving RCN. But he concedes that the day may come when he is no longer the right person for day-to-day management. 
He said he expected his eventual successor to come from within the company. RCN's senior management team includes Michael A. Adams, Mr. McCourt's longtime business partner, who is now president of RCN's wholesale and strategic development group; Robert J. Currey, RCN's vice chairman and former chief executive of 21st Century Telecom Group, a small local carrier in Chicago that was acquired by RCN last year; and Jeffrey M. White, president of RCN's customer and field operations group, who was formerly the chief financial officer and No. 2 executive at Telecom New Zealand.
"It takes a different skill set to come up with an idea and start a company than it does to run it and maybe take it to the next level," Mr. McCourt said. "Might I be chairman at some point and someone else is C.E.O.? Maybe. But I will see RCN's dream become a reality. I'm not going to sell out. I think I'm qualified to finish that dream."

HEADLINE: Hopes for Change in Jordan Are Beginning to Fade 

BYLINE:  By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, April 7 

 BODY:
The billboards loom large over highway intersections, showing people from various walks of life. One features a yuppie in rimless eyeglasses and a tie, the next a village womn with a gold tooth wearing a head scarf and embroidered dress.
 "Jordan" the advertisements proclaim in huge, stylized Arabic letters, while smaller script flowing near the bottom quotes a line of medieval poetry that translates loosely as "You reap what you sow." 
 Adil Milhameh supervises a restaurant grilling chickens a few hundred yards from one billboard, and he waves dismissively when asked about it, saying, "Please ask someone else because I have no idea what it means."
The answer you get depends on whom you ask, and invariably mirrors the debate over the direction King Abdullah II, who is scheduled to meet with President Bush in Washington on Tuesday, has pointed this small desert country since assuming the throne two years ago. 
To the brash young consultant class brandishing East Coast M.B.A.'s who swirl around the 39-year-old king, the advertisements embody a thoroughly modern Jordan. They applaud the royal court for commissioning a British advertising agency to develop a slogan exhorting Jordanians to work harder as they join the globalization parade.
To many Jordanians outside the royal circle, the ads represent folly. They are too Western, too cerebral and too expensive. The business model for selling detergent cannot be applied to transforming a conservative, tribal society, they say, and the attempt indicates a dangerous detachment from a people feeling adrift, impoverished and doubtful about promised economic and political change. 
"I had hoped that something was going to change in Jordan, that we would get things like free speech and freedom of the press," said Emad E. Hajjaj, Jordan's leading political cartoonist. He was questioned by the secret police and ultimately fired from his job at a government-controlled newspaper after a series of cartoons mocking the leading cell phone company, bureaucrats opposing privatization and the king. "The situation is the same as it was before, maybe getting worse."
Before, of course, refers to the 47-year rule of King Hussein. Just before his death in February 1999, he abruptly switched the line of succession to the next generation, from his brother Prince Hassan to his own oldest son. 
The new king, born of an English mother and educated almost entirely outside Jordan, was unexpectedly catapulted onto the throne from his job as special forces commander. 
The sniping started early about Abdullah's poorly pronounced, barracks Arabic; about his seeming inability to travel anywhere in the world with fewer than 100 people; and about what many call the admittedly impossible task of matching the royal stature that his father projected both at home and regionally. 
Abdullah has, by all accounts, worked hard. He can now make a speech in classical Arabic that is passable, if not poetic. He spends more time at home and last month was host for a meeting of Arab leaders. 
The fact that nobody stormed out or engaged in the past practice of heaving plates at each other was considered something of an achievement for the king. (Jordanians flipping between local television and satellite channels noted that the former praised the summit meeting as a triumph while the latter detailed the failure to agree on lifting United Nations sanctions against Iraq.) 
Leading up to his meeting with Mr. Bush, the king has been in Washington this week, lobbying for improved economic ties and greater American involvement in ending Israeli-Palestinian violence.
Since his first speeches, Abdullah has promised Jordanians democracy with all its trimmings and economic growth. In emphasizing the economy, he talks less about political change. Information Minister Taleb Rifai said November elections might be postponed briefly. 
On the economic front, Jordanians credit the king with many achievements, including negotiating a rare free trade agreement with Washington (its approval is still pending in Congress), rewriting dozens of laws to attract investors, and marketing Jordan as a potential mecca for Internet technology. 
But many worry about haphazard implementation. To take one instance, English and computer instruction was inaugurated in elementary schools, but critics say computers were delivered to teachers untrained in using them. 
Last weekend the palace organized a Dead Sea retreat for 300 private and public sector leaders to discuss goals for economic and social change. Those close to the king extolled his atypical consensus building, while many others grumbled about being props lending a domestic stamp of approval to ideas dreamed up by an American consulting firm. 
Jordan is to an extent hobbled by its geography, sandwiched between Iraq and the West Bank. Bloodshed there in the last seven months has not only savaged Jordan's crucial tourism industry -- visits early this year were down by one-third -- but also made investors wary. 
Trade with Iraq that once earned Jordan more than $1 billion annually is now about one quarter that. Per capita income for an average Jordanian, $1,187 in 1998, slipped $20 a year later. Officially nearly 16 percent of Jordanians ae unemployed, but unofficially up to one in three has no job. 
"I hear that the government is encouraging investment, but you don't see it on the ground -- there is nothing in real life," said Amin Tamim, who owns a downtown business selling bathroom parts. 
Jordan has always had certain fault lines. The most pronounced lies between native Jordanians and Palestinians, who form the business elite and at least 50 percent of the 5 million population. At a recent soccer match, fans of a native Jordanian team chanted for Israel to strengthen its army and for the king to divorce his Palestinian wife, Queen Rania, 30. 
In good times this could be dismissed as adolescent exuberance, but in hard times anything might spark unrest. One demonstration last fall in support of the Palestinian uprising against Israel ended with marchers smashing expensive cars. Mass protests have largely been denied permits since then, including one this week by professional unions. 
The unions spearhead opposition to the 1994 peace treaty with Israel, and in January their Antinormalization Committee published a list of individuals and businesses it said should be boycotted for dealing with the enemy. It included prominent names like the royal court chief. The secret police soon hauled seven committee members out of bed in the middle of the night and off to jail. 
"The authorities still think of themselves as Big Brother, that they know what is right for the country," said Asma Khader, a human rights lawyer who says the government should have taken the list-makers to court for slander and inciting violence. 
The government makes no apologies. "It had to be stopped -- it was becoming like the Inquisition in Spain," said Mr. Rifai, the information minister. "Nothing was done outside the existing law. If you tell me the existing law needs to be changed, well, maybe."
Some Jordanians draw a parallel between their country and Syria next door. Its young leader, Dr. Bashar al-Assad, also unexpectedly inherited a country from his father and promised to transform it. Although Jordan is far freer than Syria, there are parallels in that the secret police, tribal politics, cronyism and an entrenched bureaucracy all work to smother change. 
"What difference does it make if you have a young driver but it's still the same old vehicle?" said Adnan Abu-Odeh, a former United Nations envoy and adviser to King Hussein. "Until the vehicle is changed, you can't expect any real difference."

HEADLINE: Essay; 
The Purloined Treaty

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
You will be relieved to learn that France's copy of the Treaty of Fontainebleau -- signed by Napoleon Bonaparte in 1814 but which mysteriously vanished from the French national archives in 1988 -- has been safely in F.B.I. hands for five years.
 That's how long it has taken Mary Jo Molasses, the dilatory U.S attorney in New York, to prosecute a couple who tried to sell the treaty through an auction house in 1995. In the document, Napoleon -- crushed by russia, Austria and Russia -- abdicated as emperor before being exited to Elba. 
 I discovered the Case of the Purloined Treaty in a little gem of an article by Robert D. McFadden, the patron saint of rewrite men, who next month will celebrate his 40th anniversary at The Times. McFadden's story invites the question: What is an international treaty worth? 
At its best, a treaty is worth a nation's honor. What Germany's Theobald von Bethmann-Hollweg derided in 1914 as a mere "scrap of paper" was Britain's guarantee of Belgium's neutrality, which took the British into World War I. A long generation later, that Western reputation for sticking by agreements to stop aggression gave credibility to NATO, thereby averting a war.
But sometims treaties are worthless. In bellicose statements just after the Aries collision, China -- seeking to extend its territoriality far from its shores -- evoked the Law of the Sea Treaty. That was a product of the Carter era, almost turning ownership of the ocean's resources over to a new U.N. bureaucracy supposedly representing "all mankind." 
Some of us derided that treaty to undermine free enterprise by using its unfortunate acronym -- LOST -- and Ronald Reagan saved the U.S. from signing it. We adopt as custom useful provisions in LOST about free passage, but the U.S. is not signatory to its socialist aims and we were not obliged to attend to China's fulmination. 
Another attempt to draw the U.S. into a protocol against our national interest was pressed a few years ago in Kyoto, Japan. 
That would have forced the U.S. to roll back its emission of carbon dioxide in this decade to 7 percent below 1990 levels -- at immeasurable cost in economic growth and jobs -- while countries like China, India, Mexico and Brazil go on apparently hotting up the planet. President Clinton, after milking the issue for the publicity, never submitted the global deal to the Senate for ratification. 
Let's stop and think this through, said George W. Bush, thereby outraging environmentalists. The new president had erred in a campaign document by including carbon dioxide as a pollutant, a "promise" not much noted last summer. When he corrected himself last month, greens turned purple, accusing him of breaking a solemn pledge. But is it wise to leap into signing treaties, which become the supreme law of the land, without full knowledge of real sacrifices required? 
Another international agreement attracting those afflicted with treaty-itis is to establish an International Criminal Court. Its goal sounds noble: to make permanent a process begun in Nuremberg to bring war criminals to justice. Three years ago, at a U.N. conference in Rome, 116 nations signed up. But not us, and not Israel. 
That's because the agreement empowers a global court to arrest, try and imprison American, Israeli and other citizens of democracies for an undefined crime of "aggression." With no Security Council veto to restrain the I.C.C., its prosecutor would surely accede today to an Arab League request to indict Israeli soldiers, and tomorrow to indict any U.S. officeholder or servicemember who dared to offend a local dictator. 
An international prosecutor, answerable to no nation and unrestrained by any Bill of Rights, is the rest of the world's weapon to bring the too-sovereign superpower to heel. Were we to subject ourselves to the rule of the lawless, no U.S. sailor or president could travel abroad without becoming vulnerable to arrest by a politically motivated prosecutor. 
Multilateral treaties that weaken the U.S. do not strengthen freedom abroad; uni- is not iso-. In our reluctance to appear imperious, we could all too quickly abdicate leadership by catering to the envious crowd. After his calamitous retreat from Moscow, Napoleon said with rue, "From the sublime to the ridiculous is but a step."

HEADLINE: America Is Borrowing Trouble 

BYLINE:  By Franco Modigliani and Robert M. Solow; Franco Modigliani and Robert M. Solow are Nobel Prize winners in economics and professors emeriti at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. 

 BODY:
Many have criticized President Bush's proposal for a deep and lasting cut in income taxes, but hardly anyone has addressed its implications for what may well be the greatest potential danger facing the economy in the years to come: the large and growing deficit in our international trade balance. A massive, permanent tax cut would make the international economic position of the United States worse, not better. This is in addition to its other disadvantages. 
 The past decade has been one of exceptional economic vigor: output increased nearly 40 percent, investment more than doubled and consumption grew just over 40 percent, pushed by a spending spree that reduced personal saving to near zero. But this rosy picture was accompanied by one worrisome development: throughout this period, spending grew faster than what the country earned, spilling over, in large part, into a growing trade deficit. By the end of 2000, the excess of expenditure o
er income had reached about 4 percent of America's gross domestic product and was apparently still on the rise.
 For a country, just as for a family, there are only two ways of getting the money to spend more than one's income: borrowing it and selling assets. In the case of nations, the creditors and the buyers of the assets are foreigners. And inded, throughout this prosperous past decade the United States sold more and more assets, like government bonds and shares in its companies, and went deeper and deeper into debt.
But why should one worry about this development? It is not serious as long as the debt is small and remains under control so as not to worry creditors. But if the debt is not under control, or if some event makes the debtor appear less creditworthy than before, the creditors may decide that they are not willing to finance a country's growing debt -- for fear of a depreciation of the debtor's currency that lowers asset values in their own currencies. They may even want to liquidate part of their investment in search of diversification. If such a thing happened to the United States, there could be very unpleasant consequences for Americans.
Depreciation of the dollar would make imports so expensive and exports so cheap as to eliminate the trade deficit. But this depreciation would create a further motive for foreigners to liquidate their American assets, dumping the dollars so obtained in exchange for foreign currency. The size and power of the American economy has protected us from capital flight in shorter episodes of unfavorable trade balance, but there is no guarantee that this will remain true. Nor could the dollar be propped up through purchases by the Federal Reserve or the Treasury, since their small reserves of foreign currency would be woefully inadequate to stem the tide. (The United States reserves amount to some $60 billion compared with a current trade deficit of $400 billion a year, just two months' borrowing.)
Thus a flight from the dollar would produce a deep devaluation and accompanying rise in the prices of imports and of things made with imports. At worst we might experience a wage and price spiral, calling for sharply higher interest rates. The final result could be falling investment and output, and high unemployment. And our weakness would be very likely to spread to other countries.
Few believe that this hard-landing scenario is an immediate threat. But there is good reason to believe that if nothing is done to change the current course, the probability of a costly ending will keep increasing. To avoid that danger, the administration and Congress should develop a plan that promptly stops the growth of the trade deficit, then reduces it to zero and possibly produces a positive balance, allowing for some repayment -- and all this without an appreciable increase in unemployment.
The success of such a plan would rest on two main ingredients: a gradual reduction of total domestic expenditure relative to income -- that is, a rise in national saving -- and an increase in net exports. These two components should proceed hand in hand; indeed, given the current level of demand for domestically produced goods and services, if we added to it by shifting more of our output to exports prematurely, the result would be inflationary pressures. Conversely, a reduction of domestic demand would have to be ountered by an expansion of net exports to avoid creating a contraction in output and employment.
Unfortunately, there is no evidence that the administration and Congress are concerned with the balance of trade issue or are even aware of it. On the contrary, President Bush is galloping in exactly the wrong direction with his advocacy of using the likely (though by no means certain) large forthcoming budget surplus for a deep, permanent tax cut, rather than for retiring the debt or endowing Social Security -- or both.
The president's proposal is just the opposite of the needed increase in national saving, and the consequences would be very negative. First, it would raise consumption by roughly one dollar for every dollar of tax reduction -- which is precisely what the supporters of the bill claim to be its justification. But, given the limitations on our labor force and our abiity to produce, the rise in consumption would sooner or later produce some combination of the following unhealthy outcomes: significant inflationary pressures, in part undoing the tax rebate; a likely rise in interest rates to counter the inflation, leading to a reduction in investment; and a further increase in the trade deficit.
Can anyone really favor encouraging a further expansion of the recent spending spree at the expense of investment, the source of future growth? Or reducing taxes at the expense of a sharp addition to future taxes, required to service a much larger debt at higher interest rates? Or supporting a tax cut financed with money borrowed abroad, even in the favorable case in which foreign lenders would be prepared to finance a rapidly growing debt?
If Congress is acting responsibly, the least it can do is to postpone a deep permanent tax cut until this trade balance has turned positive.
But, some tax-cut proponents will argue, what if right now there is a clear danger of a significant economic contraction? If this were clearly the case -- and it is still in doubt -- then some measure to support demand might be appropriate. But the best approach would be to expand net exports, helping both domestic demand and the trade balance -- perhaps by aiming at a controlled, limited devaluation of the dollar and by encouraging other countries, like Europe, to pursue more expansionary policies in their own interest.
It may even be justifiable to consider a modest, temporary tax cut, but with a warning that theory and evidence suggest that transitory tax cuts are likely to produce only limited, quick effects.

HEADLINE: Baghdad Journal; 
O Iraqi Youth, Dig It, the Time Has Come to Rock

BYLINE:  By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq 

 BODY:
"What's wrong with you guys? You're all such a bunch of quitters!" said the brittle-voiced young woman doing the afternoon stint as disc jockey on the most popular radio station in Iraq, Voice of Iraq FM.
 A call-in program, conducted in Eglish, was in its second hour, and no one had successfully answered any of the prize-winning questions. "It's so easy!" the D.J. said, her tone heavy with exasperation. "All I'm asking is, tell me the Metallica song that won a Grammy in 1989!" A few minutes later, another caller couldn't name the "four different types" of music sung by Bob Dylan, and still another faltered when asked to name the "godfather of heavy metal." 
 "Give me a break," the caller stumped by the heavy metal question said, eager for a prize -- for women, a shopping spree at a fashionable Baghdad boutique; for men, a six-month membership in a popular body-building club. But the D.J. was unsparing. "Seems like you are such a loser," she said. "I don't like to say that, but you are!" 
In the land of Nebuchadnezzar, of the Islamic caliphs, and of Saddam Hussein, radio has gone cool -- or as cool as a team of young producers and on-air personalities can make it.
Baghdad, after all, has been isolated from the world by a decade of economic sanctions. And the visa requirements of Western countries, the jamming of foreign radio broadcasts, and Mr. Hussein's stringent restrictions on who can go abroad, have not made it easy to keep up with what is hip in London, Los Angeles or New York.
Still, to be driving through Baghdad and have your taxi driver tune in to "FM," as the station is commonly known, is to experience a sort of somersault of the mind. Mr. Hussein's Iraq, for a decade, has produced some of the most virulently anti-American propaganda anywhere. 
In newspapers and newscasts -- even those on "FM" -- President Bush is "the little criminal" (his father is the big one, for having assembled the military alliance that drove Iraq from Kuwait in 1991). And the sanctions, although imposed by the United Nations Security Council, are America's way of "annihilating an entire nation."
Why, then, is the government allowing a radio station to draw millions of listeners with programming that speaks to, and may encourage, an addiction to things American, especially among Iraqis drawn to rock, rap and country music -- and, what's more, broadcasting in English? And why are its programs broadcast over the tightly regulated, state-owned broadcasting network? 
The answer, in part, lies with the station's owner -- Uday Saddam Hussein, the older of the Iraqi ruler's two sons, a man with a notorious capacity to shock. Iraqi opposition groups abroad, and the State Department's annual human rights reports, have declared for years that Uday Hussein, now 36, has a history of violent and unpredictable behavior. This is said to have included shooting and knifing to death individuals who have crossed him and ordering executions or the amputation of hands for those accused of having shamed the country.
One report in recent years said that he had imprisoned members of Iraq's national soccer team after they lost an important match. 
In Iraq's highly secretive, fear-driven society, it is impossible to determine whether such stories are true, or, as government officials contend, invented to discredit Saddam Hussein and his son. In any case, Uday Hussein, now a member of Parliament and for years president of the country's Olympic Committee, has added a powerful string to his political bow -- and, his loyalists claim, a strong following among young Iraqis -- by founding "FM" and a sister television channel, Youth TV.
Jawad al-Ali, who has run the two stations since Uday Hussein drafted him from the No. 2 position in the state broadcasting network in 1993, said in an interview that "FM," at peak hours, draws 95 per cent of the listening audience across Iraq, and that Youth TV, also broadcast over the state network's facilities, also draws a lopsided slice of the viewing audience with its two channels -- 75 percent.
If accurate, the figures suggest that the Stalinist fare offered by the only state-owned television channel has alienated Iraqis -- particularly the two-thirds of the 23 million population under 30 -- in droves. This, to anybody who has watched the channel, is scarcely a surprise. 
Evening broadcasts feature stone-faced announcers reading vehement denunciations of the United States, interspersed with long sequences of Saddam Hussein meeting top officials or accepting frenzied welcomes from crowded ranks of ordinary Iraqis.
Youth TV has a sports channel and a "general" channel, whose main attraction is pirated Hollywood movies that have become a focal point of Baghdad social life. The movies include recent releases, with a heavy emphasis on tough-guy films starring Sylvester Stallone, Arnold Schwarzenegger or Jean-Claude Van Damme. Mr. Ali acknowledged that many of the movies were recorded off foreign satellite movie channels and rebroadcast without permission 
Satellite television is denied to all but the most privileged Iraqis by a law that provides severe penalties, including imprisonment, for owning a satellite dish. But Mr. Ali seemed to revel in answering a question about the pirating, turning his answer into a gibe at the United States, delivered with a half-smile. "We say you stole all the world, so just let us steal this small part," he said.
As for Uday Hussein's stealing the state network's audiences -- and offering markedly less hagiographic coverage of Saddam Hussein -- Mr. Ali said that Uday Hussein had put the idea of starting the private stations to his father, who enthusiastically endorsed it.
The private channels have drawn attention for gentle prodding of the government in their news coverage and documentary programs. But Mr. Ali stiffened when asked if a program featuring the interior minister, in charge of police and prisons, had featured complaints about human rights abuses. "Absolutely not," he said smoothly. "No one has said anything like that."
Among Iraqis, there is quiet -- very quiet -- discussion about the role Youth TV and the FM station could play in the eventual succession to Saddam Hussein, who is 63 and the subject of persistent rumors in recent months, officially denied, that he is ill with advanced lymphatic cancer. In an assassination attempt in 1996 that was ascribed to Iranian agents, when a rocket-propelled grenade was fired as his sports car on a Baghdad street, Uday Hussein was critically wounded and spent months recuperating. 
Now, he has moved back into the public eye.
Iraqi opposition groups based in London and New York have speculated that his role as a broadcaster is part of a behind-the-scenes struggle for the succession with his brother, Qusai, who is 34 and a major political figure in his own right. Qusai Hussein is the leader of the army's elite Republican Guards, and, some say, oversees the most powerful security and intelligence agencies. One recent rumor about Saddam Hussein's health said he had appointed a family council, headed by Qusai Hussein, to govern the country in the event of his death.
But if there is a family power struggle, Mr. Ali refused to be drawn out on the subject. "Uday Hussein is a popular man, with or without Youth TV and FM," he said. "He is the son of the president, and of course you know he is very intellectual, he has a Ph.D. in international politics."
As for his own prospects, in the kind of high-profile job that has seen many prominent Iraqis fall from grace, sometimes fatally, the broadcast chief smiled. Was it not inevitable, given the Western-style, laid-back programming offered by FM and Youth TV, that he would eventually go a step too far, he was asked.
"Everybody makes mistakes, but so far, I've made no big mistakes," he said. Then, after a pause, he added, in Arabic, "al Hamdulillah," "Thanks be to God."

HEADLINE: OPPOSITION BUILDS TO SPENDING CUTS IN BUSH'S BUDGET 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8 

 BODY:
Even before Monday's formal release of President Bush's detailed budget and the cuts it would make in various domestic programs, influential constituencies have begun to howl in protest.
 But Vice President Dick Cheney warned Congress today not to go too far in restoring spending, saying Mr. Bush would reject spending that he viewed as excessive. 
 "The president has the right to veto appropriations, and this president is eager to veto appropriations that come in over budget," Mr. Cheney said on the ABC News program "This Week." "If Congress is going to pass porked-up appropriations measures, they will run into a veto." 
Mr. Bush will release full details of his $1.96 trillion budget on Monday, providing fresh examples of his proposed cuts in corporate subsidies and in some housing, health and social welfare programs.
The White House says the cuts are needed to put federal spending on a more sustainable path after several yea0s of rapid growth. But some members of Congress from both parties have objected that the cuts are compelled mainly to pay for the large tax cuts Mr. Bush has been seeking.
Lobbyists, having learned many of the details, are mobilizing efforts -- with their allies in Congress -- to preserve or expand the programs.
Mr. Bush says he can save billions of dollars by reducing "corporate subsidies," eliminating "duplicative nd ineffective programs" and wiping out pork barrel projects approved at the behest of individual lawmakers. But the reality is often more complex than the White House suggests.
The president will, for example, propose eliminating federal loan guarantees for people who buy commercial ships built in American shipyards. The White House says such subsidies for oil tankers and cruise ships are not needed.
The American Shipbuilding Association is determined to get $100 million of loan guarantees this year, and it has lined up support from powerful Republicans from coastal states like Mississippi (Senator Trent Lott), Louisiana (Representative Billy Tauzin) and Alaska (Senator Ted Stevens). 
Cynthia Brown, president of the shipbuilders association, does not like the word subsidy. Ms. Brown insists that the loan guarantees are a way to preserve shipbuilding capabilities essential to national security at a time when Navy ship procurement is "at a rock-bottom low." The loan guarantees are made under a 1936 law passed at the request of Franklin D. Roosevelt, who wanted to revitalize the merchant fleet.
Mr. Lott and Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, recently wrote Mr. Bush, saying the loan guarantees should be increased to "historic levels." A bipartisan group of 10 House members sent Mr. Bush a letter seeking $100 million for such guarantees, which is more than three times as much as Congress provided for the current year. The money, they said, would help finance construction of environmentally safe double-hulled oil tankers and large oceangoing cruise ships.
On Feb. 28, Mr. Bush issued an outline of his budget, giving a peek at his plans and priorities. In the five weeks since then, lobbyists have ferreted out details and sharpened their arguments against Mr. Bush's proposals. Lobbyists will use the next two weeks, while Congress is in recess, to present their cases to lawmakers back home.
The National Association of Children's Hospitals and the American Academy of Pediatrics have joined members of Congress trying to prevent cuts in children's programs. The administration wants to trim $35 million from a $235 million program for training doctors at children's hospitals. 
Senators Christopher S. Bond, Republican of Missouri, and Mike DeWine, Republican of Ohio, and several Democratic senators -- Dianne Feinstein of California, Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts an Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut -- have expressed concern.
Bush administration officials said the program, at $200 million, would still provide much more money than was available last year. In any event, they said, the money is used mainly to train doctors, not to care for patients, and other programs provide care to children.
The National Association of Housing and Redevelopment Officials is fighting other proposed cuts, including one to slice $700 million from a program for construction and repair of public housing. Congress provided $3 billion for the public housing capital fund last year.
The housing association's Web site, www.nahro.org, includes an "action alert" with "talking points" for local housing officials to use in lobbying lawmakers during the Congressional recess.
Likewise, a wide range of businesses are scrambling to protect the Export-Import Bank from cuts that will be proposed by Mr. Bush. Defenders of the bank include the United States Chamber of Commerce, the National Association of Manufacturers and exporters of all sizes. They recently sent a letter of protest to the White House. "A reduction in Ex-Im Bank financing will translate directly into fewer U.S. exports and a consequent loss of export-related jobs, at a time when the slowdown in U.S. economic growth is already resulting in large-scale layoffs," the letter said.
Mr. Bush is expected to propose a 24 percent reduction in the bank's budget, below the current level of $927 million. Representative Jim Kolbe, the Arizona Republican who is chairman of the House Appropriations subcommittee responsible for the bank, said, "We need to be expanding, not reducing, the amount the bank gets." 
Thomas J. Donohue, president of the Chamber of Commerce, said a record trade deficit last year highlighted the need for such assistance.
Stephen Moore, a senior fellow at the libertarian Cato Institute, praised Mr. Bush for trying to reduce what Mr. Moore called "corporate welfare programs."
But Mr. Moore said: "The programs are very difficult to eliminate because powerful corporate interests spend a lot of money to retain them. Some of the biggest donors to the Republican National Committee and to individual Republican candidates receive grants, loans, loan guarantees and insurance under these programs."
Mr. Bush will also propose eliminating federal subsidies for loans made under the main lending program of the Small Business Administration. He would raise fees charged to borrowers and to lenders.
The lenders are lobbying against Mr. Bush's proposal. They deny that they receive any federal subsidy. They say the White House overestimates the number of defaults that will occur. And they say the president's proposal would sharply reduce the ability of small businesses to obtain the capital they need to grow and prosper.
The lobbying campaign is led by the National Association of Government Guaranteed Lenders, a trade association of 700 institutions ranging from giants like the Bank of America and Citibank to small local lenders. The association, based in Stillwater, Okla., was created in 1985 for one purpose: to represent banks that make loans under section 7(a) of the Small Business Act.
Senator Christopher S. Bond, the Missouri Republican who is chairman of the Committee on Small Business, opposes Mr. Bush's plan. The proposal, Mr. Bond said, would deny credit to small businesses at a time when the economy was slowing and loans were more difficult to obtain.
Mr. Bush also plans to reduce the budget for one of President Bill Clinton's favorite programs, Community Oriented Policing Services, to $855 million next year, from $1 billion this year, administration officials said. Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, said this would be a serious mistake, "a misguided retreat from our commitment to keep crime down." 
Administration officials said there was no proof the program had reduced crime, and they said the hiring of police officers was mainly a local responsibility.
Mr. Bush wants to save $25 million by eliminating a disaster preparedness program known as Project Impact. He said the program, run by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, "has not proved effective." 
Senator Patty Murray, Democrat of Washington, has won support from the Senate for her efforts to save the program, which shores up buildings to minimize damage. The project, Ms. Murray said, saved lives in the earthquake that jolted the Pacific Northwest on Feb. 28.

Chart: "Proposed Cuts in Some Programs Energize Defenders"
Even before President Bush releases the full details of his budget proposal to Congress, lobbyists and Congressional supporters of some programs have begun to protest some of the proposed cuts. A few examples, gleaned from interviews and budget documents.

AGENCY OR PROGRAM AND PROPOSED CUTS: Ship loan guarantees -- Eliminate federal loan guarantees for buyers of commercial ships built in American shipyards.
LOBBYISTS OPPOSING THE PROPOSED CUTS: American Shipbuilding Association.
MEMBERS OF CONGRESS OPPOSING THE PROPOSED CUTS: Senators Trent Lott of Mississippi, John B. Breaux of Louisiana and Ted Stevens of Alaska. Representative Billy Tauzin of Louisiana.

AGENCY OR PROGRAM AND PROPOSED CUTS: Export-Import Bank -- Cut the budget by roughly one-fourth.
LOBBYISTS OPPOSING THE PROPOSED CUTS: U.S. Chamber of Commerce, National Assoc. of Manufacturers, U.S.-China Business Council, many exporters.
MEMBERS OF CONGRESS OPPOSING THE PROPOSED CUTS: Representative Jim Kolbe of Arizona.

AGENCY OR PROGRAM AND PROPOSED CUTS: Children's hospitals -- Reduce federal spending for training of doctors at children's hospitals.

HEADLINE: MEDIA; 
Management Walks a Unified Line in the Hollywood Talks

BYLINE:  By RICK LYMAN 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 8 

 BODY:
Normally, they are the best of enemies, scrapping over film and television projects, competing to sign major stars, plotting to outmaneuver one another for the prime release dates, sometimes even going so far as to take undisguised glee in the misfortunes of the others. 
 But now, the major studios and TV networks find themselves thrust together to negotiate contracts with Hollywood's writers and actors, bound by a two-decade-old vow of consensus under which no conclusion can be reached unless everyone agrees to it -- in effect, putting everyone at the mercy of the most stubborn person in the room. 
 How the companies cooperate on the main goals while maneuvering to secure their own agendas will be one of the driving forces determining whether the Hollywood entertainment machine keeps humming through the summer or clicks off like a light bulb.
The prospect of dual strikes by writers and actors, which would, together, effectively shut down the entertainment industry in Southern California, is growing more urgent.
On one side of the table sits the Writers Guild of America, representing some 11,000 movie and TV writers, whose contract expires on May 1. Later, negotiators for the estimated 135,000 actors represented by the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, whose contract expires on June 30, will begin their talks. 
Opposite them sit Nicholas Counter, the president of the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers and chief negotiator for the studios and networks, and representatives from some of the alliance's top members.
The alliance represents 350 production companies and studios, but in practice the dominant members are those referred to by both sides as "the companies," meaning the major Hollywood movie studios and the production arms of the broadcast and cable TV networks. It is these big players that dominate the negotiation committee, whose unanimous agreement is required for any settlement.
While these top companies share many of the same concerns about keeping production costs low and minimizing wage increases, they also have their differences and their own sets of goals and demands that they will have to negotiate, not only with the guilds but with the other members of the management team.
Not all members of the alliance are equal, not even the major ones whose top executives have come to play a dominant role in the negotiations. The most striking difference is one of scale. Four of the companies are simply larger entertainment entities than the others: AOL Time Warner, whose huge holdings include the Warner Brothers movie studio and the fledgling WB network; Viacom, whose holdings include Paramount Pictures and CBS; Walt Disney, which includes the Disney movie studios and ABC; and the News Corporation, which includes 20th Century Fox film studios and the Fox network.
"Basically, there are four big players in the room and the rest of us are pipsqueaks," is the way one executive from a smaller entertainment company put it.
Universal Studios, recently acquired by Vivendi, a French conglomerate, is also now a huge Hollywood player, though Vivendi's eclectic mix of businesses, including film production, cable TV and water services, makes it unclear how it will fit in with the other media heavyweights. Indeed, Vivendi has not yet played a dominant role in the current talks, people on both sides said. 
And as for Sony and its Columbia Pictures subsidiary, its mix of film production and digital enterprises is overshadowed by the hardware businesses of the parent company, based in Tokyo, keeping it from wielding the same authority across the entertainment spectrum as the studio-and-network companies like Disney and Viacom.
Indeed, the prominence of those four big players has been mirrored in the executives who have played dominant roles in the negotiations thus far. Although Mr. Counter is the chief negotiator for producers in the talks, the executives who have played the largest roles in the crucial discussions over economics, according to officials on both sides of the table, have been Barry Meyer, chairman of Warner Brothers; Robert Iger, president of Disney; Jonathan Dolgen, chairman of the Viacom Entertainment Group; and Peter Chernin, the News Corporation's chief operating officer. Mr. Meyer and Mr. Iger have taken the lead in public, speaking at news conferences and briefings for the news media.
In the talks over so-called creative rights, the contentious issues involving writers' perception that they are treated as second-class citizens in the moviemaking process, the lead players have been the DreamWorks SKG co-founder Jeffrey Katzenberg; the chairwoman of the Paramount Motion Picture Group, Sherry Lansing; and the president of Warner Brothers, Alan Horn, though Mr. Katzenberg has played the leading public role.
For the first time since such negotiations began a half-century ago, a majority of the studios taking part are owned by huge media conglomerates that also own major networks, putting them in the potentially conflicting position of seeking demands that would benefit their production divisions while being economically disadvantageous to their network arms.
"Everyone knows that when they come into these negotiations they must be wearing their producer hats, not their network hats," said one studio executive involved in the talks. "These talks are on behalf of the producers, the production companies. And believe me, if someone tried to take a position that was more beneficial to some other division, like a television network, it would be pointed out very vigorously by the others in the room. These are not shy, submissive people."
Part of what keeps people in line is taking the long view, Mr. Counter said. "Whether it's a TV issue or a theatrical issue, every company in the room realizes that their mix of programs and movies change from time to time," he said. "While they may not be particularly heavy at the moment in TV, in two or five years, they may well be. Right now, Fox has the most television production. Three years ago, it was Warner Brothers. Three years from now, it could be any one of them."
Early in the talks, there was some speculation that the increasing corporatization of the studios -- which has transformed them from independent enterprises presided over by men called moguls to buttoned-down divisions of huge media conglomerates -- might create a situation in which differences among them could fracture their shield of unanimity. But few now expect this to happen. In fact, many argue that the combination of so many studios and networks has made the companies more alike than they have ever been.
"What is different is that most of these companies have other businesses that they can rely on for revenues, if there's a strike," Mr. Counter said. "They're not solely in the business of producing television programs and movies. They're also more similar. Many more of them have both studios and networks, and most have some sort of cable outlets, so there's a great deal of agreement on goals."
Because so many of these companies have holdings in so many different areas -- AOL Time Warner has its Internet empire as well as publishing and other concerns; the News Corporation has a global network of newspapers, publishing, cable and satellite TV -- they are more likely to be able to weather a strike in one part of their empires. 
But it is not the case for all of the management parties in the talks. DreamWorks, for instance, remains largely a movie production company, with some smaller involvement in popular music and TV production. Unlike older studios like Warner Brothers, the seven-year-old DreamWorks has no deep library of films that it can draw on for revenue in a strike. And many other, much smaller production companies are in a similar position. 
In another sense, though, companies without TV networks or cable divisions may be in a stronger position to weather the early months of a strike. That is because the studios have been able, through accelerated production schedules the last six months, to stockpile enough films to last well into 2002. It is the networks, needing fresh material for the fall season, that would feel the initial brunt of a strike.
It is the rule of unanimity, Mr. Counter said, that kept the various parties focused on the issue they have in common -- the desire for lower production costs -- rather than on the issues raised by their individual situations.
A prime example of this is the special exemption that the fledgling networks -- Fox, WB and UPN -- were able to negotiate regarding residual payment. When the Fox Network first started out, it argued that since it was not yet as established as networks like NBC or CBS, it could not pay writers and others as much in residuals as those networks did. This year, however, the writers guild insisted that Fox pay the full freight, arguing that it had received no discount when it negotiated against the major networks over things like professional football broadcast rights. 
When the talks broke off last month, management offered to raise Fox's residuals to 75 percent of the amount paid by the major networks. But keeping Fox's residuals low is a prime example of an issue that is of keen interest to one party while not at all in the interests of others whose companies also own big networks.
What happens when something like this occurs? 
Representatives from both sides use the same analogy to describe the process, that of a Congressional appropriations bill. "You've got one senator with a pet road project and another senator with a pet dam project, and they agree to support each other's project in the interests of getting the overall appropriations bill passed, which all of them want," one studio executive said. 
The key, Mr. Counter said, is maintaining that unanimity.
"We've got to have an absolutely firm position," he said. "Technically, any member of the alliance that broke away and tried to make their own agreement with the unions would be in violation of their agreement with the other companies and liable for damages. But that's not going to happen. We've been through some tough times over the years, and the rule of unanimity has always worked."
