HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET: THE BREAKDOWN; 
Who Gets What Slice of the President's First Federal Budget Pie

BYLINE:  By WARREN E. LEARY 

 BODY:
Research
 The Bush administration's proposed spending on science next year, with the exception of biomedical research, is generally characterized by either flat budgets or small increases that barely keep up with inflation. 
 NASA would get a modest increase but would have to cancel some programs.
Proposed budgets for most scientific agencies contain some new initiatives, but money for new programs generally comes from reducing existing programs and working within the confines of this year's levels. 
The National Science Foundation, which sponsors most of the nation's university research and science education programs, would get a 1.3 percent increase, raising its budget to about $4.5 billion. The agency's money for science and engineering research would increase only 0.5 percent, to $3.3 billion, but its education budget would increase 11 percent to $870 million.
Smaller scientific agencies also saw the same modest proposed increases. The National Institute of Standards and Technology, part of the Department of Commerce, saw its research spending request increase from $312 million to $347 million, with increases going to materials science and physics programs. The U.S. Geological Survey, the Department of Interior agency that maps the nation and supports land and resource research, would have about a 6 percent budget reduction to $814 million.
NASA's administrator, Daniel S. Goldin, characterized the situation of research agencies today at a budget briefing, saying: "The president has told us that we must live within our means. Doing so will require some difficult decisions."
Under the proposal, NASA would receive a 1.5 percent increase to $14.5 billion, a level that requires canceling several programs, including one that would send a robot craft to Pluto, and stretching out others, like an orbiting infrared telescope. As another belt-tightening measure, Mr. Goldin said the new budget would no longer cover so-called earmarked programs mandated by Congress but not accompanied by extra money.
The budget allots $2.1 billion for the International Space Station, about the same as last year. But it requires NASA to curtail future spending on the project, including canceling planned sections of the station, to absorb an estimated $4 billion in cost overruns expected over the next five years.
Even with these financial constraints, the agency said it would begin about 50 new projects, including research on an aircraft that can change its shape in flight, much like a bird that stretches or contracts its wings and feathers to optimize its performance in the air. WARREN E. LEARY

HEADLINE: Public Interests; 
Attack of The Killer Utilities

BYLINE:  By GAIL COLLINS 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO 

 BODY:
The weather last weekend was so bad here that the television weatherman apologized to tourists. The state's biggest utility declared bankruptcy. San Francisco's economy is tubing, and in Los Angeles the movie industry is slouching toward a strike.
 And then there is the California prune glut. "This is not going to turn around overnight," warned a prune industry spokeswoman recently. 
 Unlike the dot-com crisis, the energy crisis and the scriptwriter crisis, however, the prune crisis comes equipped with its own message of hope. The prune people have changed their product's name to dried plums. "When it's dried plums, people seem to listen more," said Peggy Castaldi of the California Dried Plum Board. The other day I heard a TV anchorman refer solemnly to "the fruit formerly known as prunes."
This is the kind of creativity California needs more of. Gov. Gray Davis (the politician formerly known as possible presidential material) went on TV the other day to explain his new energy plan, which sounded a whole lot like the old energy plan, and it was a disaster. They had barely turned off the studio lights before Pacific Gas & Electric declared bankruptcy.
Think how much better Mr. Davis would have done if he had dropped the talk about three-tiered pricing policies and simply announced he was changing electricity's name to potentially dangerous voltage. It would sound so much more pleasant when people are informed they won't be getting any.
As the whole world knows, the state deregulated its utilities back in the mid-90's -- at approximately the same time the dried-plum makers started planting too many trees. Since then wholesale energy prices have skyrocketed, while consumer prices stayed capped. The utilities lost a pile of money and the rest is all rolling blackouts and Chapter 11.
There are no heroes here. The day before the bankruptcy filing, P.G.&E. handed out more than $50 million in bonuses to its employees. In the few hours between his speech and the giant utility's announcement, Mr. Davis found time to attend a campaign fund-raiser in La Jolla.
State Senator Steve Peace of San Diego, one of the legislative experts on energy matters, canceled all his appointments and flew back to the State Capitol, declining comment. "He's not in a frame of mind to talk. He's just kind of in this funk," said his spokesman, Art Castanares.
Mr. Peace is widely regarded as the chief author of the bill that deregulated the state's utilities -- a distinction that has made him the first California state senator to achieve celebrity status without being married to Jane Fonda.
"People come up to him in restaurants," said Mr. Castanares, who acknowledged that when this happens, their intentions are generally hostile.
Personally, I cannot imagine feeling negative about Mr. Peace, who underwrote his political career by producing the movie "Attack of the Killer Tomatoes." But somebody has to take the fall.
Mr. Peace would prefer to blame Texas-based energy suppliers who have made a fortune on California's woes. "He says if we don't do something we might as well raise the Texas flag over the California Capitol," reported his spokesman.
The chances that anybody will come up with a short-term solution to California's problems are slim to none, so the question of whom to blame takes on a certain desperate tone, like a high-stakes game of Clue. (It was Gray Davis, with a revolver! George Bush, with a candlestick! Pete Wilson, with a rope!) One particularly popular nominee is Ralph Nader, who backed a state referendum that theoretically could have discouraged investment in new power plant construction. It was defeated, but blaming Ralph Nader is so appealing that nobody wants to drop the option.
Californians are definitely feeling cranky, and short on team spirit. The state is attempting to encourage conservation by weaning residents away from their second refrigerators, but the major appliances are not going quietly. "I absolutely need it," a 78-year-old widower who lives alone told The Los Angeles Times.
On the bright side, soon a bankruptcy judge will enter the fray and there will be a new villain to blame when he starts giving out rate hikes to Pacific Gas & Potentially Dangerous Voltage.

TWO CUSHMANS, THEN ONE

BYLINE:  By Charles V. Bagli 

 BODY:
 Cushman & Wakefield, a New York-based international real estate services company, said yesterday that it would acquire Cushman Realty, based in Los Angeles, in an effort to expand its presence in California and Texas. The combined company would have revenues of about $900 million, with 965 real estate brokers in 174 offices. 
The companies did not disclose the sale price. The boards of both companies must approve the deal. Arthur J. HEADLINE: New York, Still Falling Behind 

BYLINE:  By Richard Lowry; Richard Lowry is the editor of National Review.

 BODY:
Rudolph Giuliani saved New York from the abyss. Shouldn't that be enough? Perhaps for Mr. Giuliani, who will be considered by many to be one of the great reform mayors of the 20th century, but not for the city.
 The recent burst of vitality in New York, fueled by immigration and a soaring stock market, shouldn't obscure a steady loss of economic ground to the rest of the country in the last 30 years. With the Wall Street boom ending, the last few years may soon look like a false dawn. 
 This is why it is crucial for the next mayor to carry Mr. Giuliani's nascent economic initiatives forward, even though it will mean confronting the city's stale political orthodoxy and entrenched status quo.
New York operates on a Depression-era economic model. Public works Keynesianism seemed like a brilliant idea 60 years ago, when the New Deal was new. But it put the city on a fiscal treadmill of ever-rising spending, taxes and debt. Even Mr. Giuliani, frugal by New York standards, will leave the city facing a potential $2.4 billion budget shortfall in the first full fiscal year after he leaves.
As economic liberalization has swept the globe, it is now understood almost everywhere that excessive taxation hampers economic growth. Except, apparently, in the financial capital of the world.
Set aside the city's smaller taxes -- the hotel occupancy tax, the three different auto taxes, the six excise taxes. That still leaves the "major" taxes: the property tax, the commercial rent tax, the mortgage recording tax, the real property transfer tax, the personal income tax, the general corporation tax, the banking corporation tax, the unincorporated business tax, the sales tax and the utility tax.
Most cities have only a few major taxes, financing their operations with, say, a property tax and a sales tax. New York has them all. And, in comparison to other major cities, its taxes enjoy the Lake Wobegon effect -- they're all above average.
First, New York has something most other cities don't: its own income tax. But its shoppers also pay an astronomical sales tax. And even New York's property tax, while much lower for single-family residences than that in some of its surrounding suburbs, is higher overall than the average for the country's 10 largest cities.
This tax regime gives every other area in the country -- especially the South and the Sun Belt, where taxes are generally much lower -- an invaluable edge over New York.
Mr. Giuliani has tried to pare back taxes around the edges. In 1994 he cut the hotel occupancy tax, which had noticeably depressed the city's convention business. He has scaled back the commercial rent tax, which gives businesses a direct incentive to locate elsewhere. But just tapping on the brakes isn't enough. The personal income tax rate, for instance, is still higher than it was when Ed Koch left office at the end of 1989.
Cutting taxes is impossible, of course, so long as the spending side of the city's ledger is so high. In his first term, Mr. Giuliani kept the budget under control. But discipline slipped in his second term: spending has increased at roughly three times the rate of inflation.
Meanwhile, debt service costs have risen from $2.8 billion annually to just under $4 billion since Mr. Giuliani took office in 1994. The city projects major new capital commitments over the next decade that will further increase the debt.
There is steady upward pressure on New York's budget from the most powerful interest group in the city: the public-employee unions. Their clout in city elections gives them too much control over the leaders of the city government that sits across from them at the bargaining table. The result, typically, is fat contracts that keep the city payroll large, taxes high -- and, not coincidentally, public-sector unions powerful.
Mr. Giuliani tried to break this expensive and enervating cycle, to no avail. The hospital workers' union made it impossible to reform the city's bloated health care system. The teachers' union resisted efforts to shake up the schools. These agents of the status quo have the city's politics and finances in a headlock.
If Mr. Giuliani saved New York from a 30-year crime wave and the stagnation of the Dinkins years, the next mayor needs to take a further step forward: creating the conditions for effective competition with other cities. There is no reason New York's entrepreneurs can't be as free and as vibrant as those in some faraway Southwest suburb -- unless New Yorkers are ready to concede that the future, despite Gotham's recent nice run, really belongs to someplace else.

HEADLINE: Bush Encourages Resolution Of Conflict in Oil-Rich Region 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9 

 BODY:
President Bush urged the leaders of Azerbaijan and Armenia today to keep up momentum toward a peaceful resolution to the conflict in the mountainous enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh.
 Mr. Bush held separate meetings with the Armenian president, Robert Kocharian, and President Haydar Aliyev of Azerbaijan at the White House in the wake of their peace talks last week in Florida, which ended on an upbeat note with both sides reporting excellent progress. 
 The two former Soviet republics have been split for 13 years over the Nagorno-Karabakh region, dominated by ethnic Armenians who tried to secede from Azerbaijan in 1988.
About 35,000 people have died in the conflict, which also drove some 800,000 Azeris from their homes before a formal cease-fire in 1994. Despite the truce, about 200 people are killed each year by land mines and snipers, destabilizing Azerbaijan.
Some interests in the United States are eager to see an end to the conflict, in the hope that stability will help Azerbaijan become a major oil supplier for Western markets.
"The president encouraged both leaders to keep at the process, to work to overcome the differences," said a senior administration official.
"And all the parties to the discussion agreed that peace will bring considerable benefits to the region, to the peoples of both countries and to the entire South Caucasus region and beyond," the official said.
Mr. Bush invited the two leaders in for meetings as a sign of respect for the work they did last week in Key West, Fla., in talks held under the auspices of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, with the aid of American, French and Russian mediators.
Mr. Aliyev told reporters after the meeting, "We are hopeful the United States of America and other co-chairs will intensify their efforts in order to achieve peaceful resolution to this conflict."
Two senior American officials who briefed reporters declined to provide details on the differences remaining between the two sides and how close they were to an agreement.
Items on the table in the Key West talks included the presence of Armenian forces in the disputed region, trade blockades that have crippled the local economy, the resettlement of refugees left homeless by the war, and how much autonomy the Nagorno-Karabakh region should have.
Mr. Aliyev would also make no predictions, and Mr. Kocharian left without talking to reporters. "I haven't had a chance to measure how close we are now," Mr. Aliyev said.
Meetings in January and earlier this month in Paris failed to make headway. The pair are to meet again in Switzerland in June.
One senior American official praised the roles of Russia and France in the peace effort, and cited Russia's involvement as an example of the genuine cooperation the United States can make with Russia at a time of some frictions with Moscow over American plans for a missile defense system.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET: THE BREAKDOWN; 
Who Gets What Slice of the President's First Federal Budget Pie

BYLINE:  By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Military
 The $310.5 billion that President Bush proposed for the Department of Defense today amounted to little more than what Pentagon officials said was a rough draft of a final defense budget to be unveiled next month. 
 Mr. Bush included a promised $1.39 billion increase in military pay and benefits and $2.6 billion for new research and development, but the proposal provided few other details of how he intended to reshape the nation's military. 
The president's proposal was so scant on details, in fact, that budget officials from the four armed services did not even bother to stage their traditional budget briefings to outline the effect on weapons production and other programs.
At the Pentagon, officials said Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld would unveil a detailed budget once he completed reviews of the nation's military strategy and structure.
That is now expected around mid-May, which is still enough time for the Congressional debate over appropriations bills and, Pentagon officials believe, for a significant increase in military spending.
The $310.5 billion budget outlined today largely reflected the last spending projection made by President Bill Clinton, whom Mr. Bush repeatedly criticized during the 2000 campaign as eroding the nation's armed services.
While many other federal agencies faced spending cuts, the proposal for the Department of Defense represented a 4.8 percent increase over its $296 billion budget this year. The increases largely reflected inflation and the pay and research proposals already detailed by Mr. Bush. 
The proposal included only one area of significant cuts: spending for the purchase of weapons, which Mr. Bush proposed dropping to $59 billion from $62 billion. Pentagon officials, eager to expand weapons purchases, said the cut should be disregarded and predicted that Mr. Rumsfeld's review would result in a large increase for new weapons.
The overall defense budget also included $14 billion in spending on nuclear weapons by the Department of Energy and another $1.4 billion in other areas of the government, for a total of $325 billion.
The Department of Energy's weapons budget would remain essentially flat, but Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham said he planned to re-establish the capacity to produce plutonium pits, a crucial component in nuclear weapons. STEVEN LEE MYERS

HEADLINE: Back in Business; 
Supply-Side Economists Regain Influence Under Bush

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Stephen J. Entin has just about every credential that a true supply-side economist could want. He holds a graduate degree from the University of Chicago. He worked in the Reagan Administration's Treasury Department. He runs a Washington research center, and its Web site contains photographs of him with Jack Kemp and Steve Forbes, the two political figures who have probably done the most to keep the tax-cutting flame alive.
 During the 1990's, Mr. Entin said, he never set foot inside the White House or the Old Executive Office Building, where much of the work of the president's staff is done. In the first two months of the Bush administration, he has visited three times. 
 On the face of things, supply-side economists -- a fairly small group who argue that lower tax rates are the key incentive to promoting economic growth -- appear to have returned to their influential role of the early 1980's. After a decade of relative anonymity, working for trade groups or researching issues that had little chance to become policy, they again have a seat at the table of power as a new president has made a big tax cut the central focus of his first year. 
But ask them what they think of the White House proposal, and their responses are surprisingly tepid. "It could have been a lot worse," Mr. Entin said. Alan Reynolds, the director of economic research at the Hudson Institute here, added, "It's a hodgepodge, a mixture of good and O.K." And Kevin Hassett, a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute here, said: "The sun is shining again. It's certainly not heaven, but it's nice to see."
These mixed feelings highlight the unusual role that supply-siders are playing in the current political debate. Even as they attend top-level meetings -- and even though they express confidence that the White House will try to do much of what they want before President Bush's first term ends -- they find themselves frustrated on two main issues. 
Unlike two decades ago, when President Ronald Reagan cited the work of Arthur Laffer to argue that tax cuts could actually increase government revenues, currently the supply-sider position does not comprise the core of the administration's publicly stated rationale for a tax cut. Instead, President Bush has more often described his plan as a stimulus, using the language of the supply-siders' longtime intellectual rivals, Keynesians, who believe the government can best jump-start a slowing economy by spending more, either through tax relief or new programs.
In addition, the president's proposal, even before the Senate moved to scale it back, did not include some of the supply-siders' other favorite ideas, like cutting the tax on capital gains or reducing corporate taxes.
Lawrence B. Lindsey, Mr. Bush's top economic adviser, who made a name for himself in the 1980's with a Harvard economics dissertation that defended the 1981 tax reduction, has told conservative groups that such moves are not a high priority now. 
Still, most supply-side economists say they remain optimistic that their differences with the White House relate more to political strategy than to economic philosophy. With the economy in a slump, a senior White House adviser said, the administration simply believes that the Keynesian rationale for a tax cut has the best chance of winning public support. If Mr. Bush can overcome the opposition of Democratic leaders in Congress, supply-siders expect he will turn to other items on their wish list in the second half of his term. 
"The president understands tax reduction in the way Reagan did," said Lawrence A. Hunter, the chief economist at Empower America, a group here run by Mr. Kemp, the former representative who was a driving force behind the last large tax cut, the one in 1981. "That said, the president is a good politician."
The White House has given the economists good reason for their confidence. Mr. Lindsey, in his standard speech these days, says: "Let's face it. The federal tax code is a mess, and it is going to need substantive reform. But we picked a number of particular reforms that we think need doing right away."
Such comments also fuel the criticism of more liberal economists who say that Mr. Bush's tax cuts are largely a boon to wealthy Americans, rather than the economy as a whole, and that the government cannot afford the plan he submitted to Congress this year. The White House says its plan will cost $1.6 trillion from 2002 to 2011. Opponents say the actual figure will exceed $2 trillion because of higher borrowing costs, a recently revised estimate of the revenue loss from eliminating the estate tax and various plans to make the cut effective in 2001. 
The House has passed an early version of Mr. Bush's plan, but the Senate voted last week to limit the tax cut to about $1.2 trillion. 
At its heart, supply-side economics -- also often known as neo-classical economics -- holds that decisions made by individuals and businesses should not be distorted by regulations and taxes. Left to their own devices, consumers and managers will collectively make decisions that will cause the economy to soar.
The most fervent advocates go further, contending that overall tax receipts should rise even as rates fall. The Laffer curve -- generally shown as a sideways "U" with tax rates on one axis and government revenues on the other -- depicts this outcome, but after the huge budget deficits of the 1980's many economists discount it as a gross exaggeration. 
"When you say supply side, you think of people who say tax cuts pay for themselves, and I don't think any serious economists believe that," the adviser to President Bush said.
Supply-siders credit Herb Stein, the late economic adviser to President Richard M. Nixon, with inventing the term in 1976, even though he used it in a speech that criticized the notion that the federal budget affected mainly production, or the supply side of the economy, and not demand. Still, the editorial page of The Wall Street Journal and conservative economists like Robert Mundell, Norman B. Ture and Jude Wanniski quickly embraced the term.
Republican politicians, chiefly Mr. Reagan and Mr. Kemp, soon made tax cuts the crux of their economic proposals. In 1981, Mr. Reagan signed the Economic Recovery and Tax Act, lowering tax rates and cutting the top income tax rate from 70 percent to 50 percent.
The decade that followed -- a generally strong one for economic growth, but also one with rapidly rising budget deficits -- was not the panacea that supply-siders had predicted. Even so, their ideas picked up some support among economists.
"The debate is now about the magnitude of the effect on behavior and its role in policy, rather than about whether tax cuts affect behavior," said Joel Slemrod, a University of Michigan tax expert who says supply-siders overstate the benefits of tax cuts.
But the shift has been subtle, and supply-siders were hardly among Washington's power brokers during the last dozen years. In 1990, President George Bush and a Democratic-controlled Congress raised taxes, pushing up the top rate to 31 percent after it had been cut to a low of 28 percent in 1986. In addition, while the Reagan administration included many hard-core supply-siders, the elder Bush's administration was not particularly open to hearing the supply-side argument.
"That was frustrating to a lot of people," Mr. Hunter said.
Then Bill Clinton took office and pushed through a tax increase in 1993, saying it would help narrow the budget deficit.
At the time, supply-siders argued on television and in newspaper articles that higher tax rates would cause investment to dry up and the economy to stagnate. Instead, American businesses spent trillions of dollars on new equipment, unemployment fell to levels not seen since the 1960's and the economy enjoyed its longest expansion ever.
"It's hard to find any prediction that was more wrong," said Benjamin Friedman, an economist at Harvard University.
Out of step with the Clinton administration, the supply-siders quickly lost status in Washington. Mr. Hunter, for example, was fired from his job as the chief economist at the Chamber of Commerce, a business lobbying group. "I got thrown out," he said. The chamber "wanted a seat at the table."
Mr. Hunter made his way to Capitol Hill after the Republicans had taken over in 1995. Other supply-siders worked at research centers and wrote papers about retirement accounts, the Social Security earnings test and other details.
"We didn't disappear," said Gary Robbins, a senior research fellow at the Institute for Policy Innovation. "We kept sharpening our nails on the scratching post. We just weren't being heard."
Now they are, although few of them actually hold posts in the administration. Mr. Bush's top economic officials -- including Mr. Lindsey; the Treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill; and R. Glenn Hubbard, named to be the next chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers -- like to think of themselves as pragmatic conservatives, rather than true believers of supply-side theory.
Mr. O'Neill, the former chief executive of Alcoa, even committed something close to supply-side heresy when he said in January that corporate managers did not make decisions about how much money to spend on research and development based on the taxes they face. And Mr. Lindsey, in a meeting with supply-side economists earlier this year, said the country was suffering because businesses had recently invested too much money in new equipment and technology.
"That surprised a lot of people," said Mr. Hunter, who attended the meeting. 
But White House officials say they do want eventually to overhaul the tax code. First they want to pass a tax cut, Mr. Lindsey said. Then a consensus might emerge about further changes, much as Congress followed its 1981 tax cut with a 1986 bill to lower many rates and eliminate some loopholes, Mr. Lindsey said. 
Mr. Lindsey said neither he nor President Bush liked to identify themselves strictly as members of one school of economic thought. Supply-side economics is one of three main streams of economic thought, Mr. Lindsey added. 
Keynesian theory helps governments manage the short-term business cycle, he said. Monetarism describes the proper role for the Federal Reserve in setting policy. And supply-side theory allows policy makers to think about how to enhance long-term growth.
Because the president was a business executive for many years, Mr. Lindsey said, "I think he is most comfortable with the third."

HEADLINE: The Tailors Behind the Tailors Behind the Man 

BYLINE:  By GINIA BELLAFANTE 

 BODY:
There were five of them -- two-button suits, some in navy, some in gray, all made from a wool bearing the sort of name that could be applied to a defense weapon, Super 120. The suits were part of George W. Bush's inauguration wardrobe, an assemblage that also included a black cashmere overcoat and a single-breasted tuxedo.
 At the time of the inauguration, credit for Mr. Bush's clothes went to Gassane Tailors, a maker of custom suits in Austin, Tex., which also outfitted Lyndon Johnson and has dressed Mr. Bush for the last six years. But a recent visit to Giliberto Designs in Manhattan's garment district revealed that the president's clothes were made far from the center of Stetsons, in a sewing room on West 36th Street that might have provided a location for a De Sica film. On a rack at Giliberto hung a tagboard pattern approximating the president's frame, with the words "George W. Bush, January 2001" inscribed on it. 
 What Ghassan Karim, a co-owner of Gassane Tailors, did for Mr. Bush was to visit him at the governor's mansion in Austin and take his measurements, Mr. Karim said. Those measurements were then quietly sent to Rosario Giliberto Sr., a 63-year-old Sicilian-born tailor and an owner of Giliberto Designs, who, with the help of assistants, made the preliminary patterns, cut the garments and sewed them together. Mr. Karim merely tweaked the pattern ("I said, 'You do this, you do that' ") and administered the final touches, he explained.
It is a fairly well-kept secret in the world of men's wear that those who call themselves custom suit makers (or makers of slightly less personalized made-to-measure ones) often do not take hand to scissor, needle and thread. Although Mr. Karim does sew some suits himself in Texas, he often sends others to Giliberto in New York. 
Similarly, a visit to Mohan's Custom Tailors on East 42nd Street will result in a suit made not in a back room, but in Hong Kong, Mohan's owner, Mike Ramchandani, acknowledged. At Paul Stuart, made-to-measure suits are made off premises, a publicist for the store confirmed, though she would not divulge where. And James Jurney, an owner of the hip custom suit maker Seize sur Vingt in NoLIta, will design a suit's outline -- three-button versus four-button, narrow lapel or wide -- and take his client's measurements "with these medieval-looking devices," he said. But in the next step, he sends the measurements, along with fabric, to Rocco Ciccarelli Custom Tailoring in Long Island City, Queens. That is where patterns are made and suits are sewn together. Mr. Jurney has an in-house tailor attend to the final nipping and tucking.
The customer who comes in assuming that the guy with the tape measure around his neck is the one making the trousers in the basement is arguably not being told the whole story. But Suzanne Kilgore, the executive director of the Custom Tailors Association of America, a 300-member group, counters that it doesn't matter. "The customer isn't getting duped, because he is still getting a custom suit," she said.
"Rocco makes the pattern," she added, referring to Rocco Ciccarelli, "and it hangs on the famous hook."
Mr. Ciccarelli's hooks do have a certain mystique in the winnowing sphere of custom men's wear. A third-generation tailor who immigrated from Rome in 1955, Mr. Ciccarelli shares with Mr. Giliberto the status of premier tailor-behind-the-tailor. Trained at the legendary Italian house of Caraceni, Mr. Ciccarelli now derives most of his business from other tailors, about 30 of them around the country, he said. His 13,500-square-foot workroom is replete with 40 stitchers toiling at old Singers, many of whom appear to have their 50's and 60's behind them.
Mr. Ciccarelli, like the Giliberto Designs outfit, has private clients who come to him directly. Clients who bypass the front men pay about 30 percent less for the custom suits that generally cost between $1,800 and $8,000 from a neighborhood tailor, who farms out the work.
While there still exists a small community of custom tailors in New York who actually fashion suits with their own hands -- typically at the rate of one a week -- many others turn to Mr. Giliberto and Mr. Ciccarelli because their operations have something of a monopoly on the skilled labor needed to make high-end men's wear. "There are so few gifted cutters left," Jack Simpson, the creative director of Dormeuil, a custom tailor and fabric purveyor on the Upper East Side, who has occasionally used Mr. Ciccarelli's services, said. "It's getting tougher and tougher to find hands. The generation that should be coming up, isn't."
There's a joke in the trade regarding the diminished labor force. "I'll call the union, and I'll say we're looking to hire," Mr. Giliberto's partner and son Anthony Giliberto said. "They say to me, 'Oh, yeah? Call Cavalry Cemetery.' "
Having made suits in New York for 47 years, Mr. Giliberto Sr. observed that between 40th Street and 32nd Street there once were 18 custom tailoring operations like his. Old age and escalating New York rents resulted in many closed businesses. "Now, there's hardly anyone," he said. "There are no tailors left in New York."
In fact, there are 7,485, according to United States Census Bureau figures from 1990, the most recent statistics available. The number dropped from 9,700 in 1980. Many, however, specialize in alterations. 
"After the Second World War, many of the most skilled hands came from Italy, where tailoring was an honored profession," Mr. Simpson of Dormeuil said. The number of Italian-born tailors in New York declined even more precipitously between 1980 and 1990 than that of all tailors -- a reduction of more than 50 percent.
While the Gilibertos and Mr. Ciccarelli, all of whom wear ties to work every day, still have aging, primarily Italian tailors and seamstresses in their employ, they must now look to new immigrant populations when hiring. The younger Mr. Giliberto seeks talent by putting ads in Chinese and Pakistani newspapers distributed locally. Koreans and Dominicans, according to census figures, are also adding to the pool.
However anachronistic the world of custom tailoring might seem in the age of Dockers and Prada suits, there are no signs that its life span will be foreshortened. "People talk about the bad economy," Rosario Giliberto said. "Yes, I have a client who lost $11 million in the past few months, but he's got billions, does it really matter?" Last week, the tailor had in his hand a miniature work in progress, a custom blue suit for a 6-year-old.
Fortunately for people like Mr. Giliberto, the whole let's-have-a-meeting-in-our-swim-trunks culture is starting to erode. Sobriety is talking hold, and in certain circles that will always mean a $3,500 two-button.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET: NEWS ANALYSIS; 
Putting Faith In Discipline

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9 

 BODY:
The budget debate in Congress over the last two weeks revolved around one central dispute. Democrats argued that President Bush's proposed $1.6 trillion, 10-year tax cut could throw the budget back into deficit. Republicans countered that with $5.6 trillion in surpluses projected over the next decade, plenty of money would be available to reduce taxes and meet the government's needs.
 The budget the president released today showed that on paper, the numbers add up, as long as the politicians are as disciplined as he insists they should be about controlling spending. 
 But the budget reaches that point by assuming that spending on the vast majority of government programs will be less than what would be needed to keep up with inflation and population growth and by allocating no money or a very low amount for some costly measures that Mr. Bush himself endorsed either in his campaign or since he has been in the White House.
"What jumps out and hits you between the eyes is all the unaccounted-for costs," said Stephen Moore, a budget specialist at the Cato Institute who is also president of the Club for Growth, a conservative political action committee.
Stanley E. Collender, managing director of budget consulting at Fleishman-Hillard, the public relations and consulting firm, agreed with that analysis, saying, "The budget works mathematically. Whether it's realistic is another matter."
In his presidential campaign, Mr. Bush portrayed himself as a compassionate conservative. On the scale weighing compassion against conservatism, the first Bush budget is definitely conservative, given the emphasis on a large tax cut that would mostly benefit the well-to-do. It could also be called compassionate in that spending on basic government services would not be eliminated, no departments would be abolished and no big programs would be wiped off the books.
Unlike Ronald Reagan's first budget in 1981 or the one proposed by Speaker Newt Gingrich and his followers after Republicans gained control of Congress in 1995, this is not a revolutionary budget.
"It says more about the future than the present," said Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office when Democrats controlled Congress and now the president of the Urban Institute. 
"He is talking about constraining future choices by promising that a large portion of the projected surpluses will be devoted to tax cuts," Mr. Reischauer said.
Beyond the president's pet causes like education and medical research, the budget allows no room for growth in the day-by-day government programs that are dear to the hearts of many lawmakers, and it actually calls for cuts in some areas like support for farmers.
The votes in the Senate last week left doubt as to whether the president could sustain this approach. In addition to reducing the proposed 10-year tax cut to $1.2 trillion from $1.6 trillion, the Senate voted to increase spending above the president's levels in education, agriculture, health insurance, veterans' benefits, energy and the environment.
The president would increase government spending in such areas in the fiscal year 2002 by 4 percent over 2001. The Senate would more or less double that.
"Boys will be boys," said Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the president's budget director, dismissing today what the Senate did last week as "free votes."
But Mr. Moore, who concentrates nowadays on raising money for Republicans in Congress, said the president might have to rethink some of these policies.
"These farm states are Republican states now," Mr. Moore said, alluding to the president's plan to trim agriculture programs.
Even more important in assessing the president's budget is the meager treatment the budget gives four big-ticket items that could cost the country a large sum of money over the next decade: private investment accounts under Social Security, prescription drug coverage under Medicare, a missile defense system and revision of the alternative minimum tax.
On Social Security, the budget seems to make $600 billion available over the next 10 years for changes in the Social Security system, presumably including Mr. Bush's campaign proposal to allow workers to use a portion of their Social Security taxes to establish personal investment accounts. Mr. Bush wants a commission to figure out how to do it.
The best estimates are that if people are allowed to use two percentage points of the 12.4 percent they and their employers pay in Social Security taxes to create private accounts, it would cost the government $1 trillion -- without making the Social Security trust fund any less solvent than it is now.
The budget sets aside $153 billion to give insurance for prescription drugs to the elderly and disabled people covered by Medicare. Lawmakers from both parties consider such insurance a political imperative, and most agree that the cost would be much higher than the president's figure. The latest calculation by the Congressional Budget Office is that this would cost at least $400 billion over the next 10 years.
Mr. Bush has suggested that savings could be found elsewhere by making big changes in the structure of Medicare, but he has given no clue how he might accomplish that.
The Defense Department is in the middle of a thorough review of its entire strategy and structure. When it is completed, the administration will almost certainly propose a missile defense shield much more elaborate than anything the Clinton administration contemplated. This could cost hundreds of billions of dollars over the next decade, and it is not reflected in the budget.
Finally, the White House and experts in Congress agree that if Mr. Bush's tax plan is enacted, an obscure part of the tax code called the alternative minimum tax will have to be revised. 
The purpose of this tax is to guarantee that rich people with large deductions cannot escape taxation. But if the Bush plan becomes law, the alternative minimum tax would apply to more than 35 million taxpayers, many of them far from wealthy, and would deny them the benefits of a tax cut. The expert tax staff in Congress estimates that it could cost nearly $300 billion over 10 years to fix the problem.
The budget sets aside about $800 billion over 10 years in what the president calls a contingency fund to take care of these unallocated costs. But the four big-ticket items alone would far exceed that amount. Nothing would be left for spending that cannot possibly be anticipated now -- for natural disasters or new commitments overseas or for any of the multitude of unexpected matters that arise each year and demand the government's attention and dollars.
And that is to say nothing of the baubles this president, like any other president, is going to have to promise individual members of this evenly divided Congress in order to win what are bound to be close votes on his top priorities.

HEADLINE: COLLISION WITH CHINA: THE OVERVIEW; 
U.S. Shies Away From Threats In Plane Standoff With China

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9 

 BODY:
President Bush's senior advisers have concluded for now that the most severe acts of retaliation they could threaten in the spy-plane standoff with China -- selling advanced arms to Taiwan, restricting trade, derailing Beijing's bid for the Olympics -- would not speed the release of the 24 American crew members and could harm longer-term interests in Asia, administration officials said.
 One official involved in the first review of those options said today that "it became clear how little room for maneuver either side has" in a relationship that is "this interdependent and complex." 
 The official acknowledged that the administration is under growing pressure from conservatives in Congress to threaten stronger action, but has also been warned by business executives to assess any boomerang effects on the American economy before threatening trade sanctions. 
The absence of palatable options explains why Mr. Bush has issued only the blandest warnings to the Chinese about the diplomatic and economic risks they run in continuing to hold the Americans. 
The president issued two general warnings early last week, followed by far more conciliatory expressions of regret for the loss of their fighter pilot in the collision over the South China Sea. The American plane landed on Hainan island after the collision, which occurred on April 1. 
Today, Mr. Bush issued only the briefest of comments, saying each day the crew is held would "increase the potential that our relations with China could be damaged."
But his spokesman, Ari Fleischer, was pressed on how relations might be damaged. He retreated into ambiguity, and noted that two weeks ago, before the collision, Mr. Bush met in the Oval Office with Deputy Prime Minister Qian Qichen and talked about ways the countries could work together. "Much of the good they talked about can go wrong, or will go wrong," if the standoff continues, Mr. Fleischer said. 
But American officials acknowledge that neither side has much room to inflict harm on the other, unless they are willing to make major diplomatic and economic sacrifices. 
"The reality is that the Chinese hold the short-term tactical cards, because they have the crew, and we hold the long-term strategic cards," said one senior diplomat. "And both sides are using those to circle the other" as the talks drag on.
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell put in play the mildest of sanctions on Sunday, when he seemed to suggest that Mr. Bush might cancel a state visit to Beijing after he attends the annual summit meeting of Asian-Pacific leaders in October, which was scheduled long ago for Shanghai.
"The whole environment is at some risk right now," he said.
And this afternoon, Senator Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey and a long-time supporter of selling arms to Taiwan, said, "Soon it will become questionable whether it is appropriate to have both an ambassador and hostages in the same country." 
Mr. Torricelli and other members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee had held their tongues until now, after General Powell asked them last week to let the administration continue to seek diplomatic solutions.
But General Powell conceded then that if the crew remained in China a second week, it would be more difficult to keep members of Congress from publicly pressing for harsher steps.
Two White House officials tonight dismissed the idea of recalling the ambassador to China, Adm. Joseph W. Prueher, for consultations. One noted that because he is a former commander of military forces in the Pacific, "he's the only one we have whom the Chinese military really respects." 
Administration officials involved in the internal conversations about the standoff say, for example, that the United States probably does not have the clout with the International Olympics Committee to derail China's bid for the 2008 Games -- even if the Bush administration determined that was a wise course. There has been no public discussion of a possible American boycott of the Games if they are indeed held in Beijing. 
Similarly, any threat to delay China's entry into the World Trade Organization, while perhaps satisfying to critics who argue Congress should never have agreed to China's admission, could work to China's short-term advantage.
Ever since Congress acted to grant China permanent normal trade relations -- which takes effect only after China is admitted to the trade body -- Beijing itself has dragged out talks with the W.T.O. about the specifics of its admission. China must still reconcile differences in individual agreements it has made with members of the organization, a time-consuming process. 
Each year that its admission is delayed is another year that China can delay opening its markets to foreign competition, giving its state-run companies more time to adjust.
Experts on Chinese trade, including Nicholas Lardy of the Brookings Institution, have noted that a delay in opening China's market might be welcomed by many Chinese officials. "They might not be heartbroken," Mr. Lardy said.
One American diplomat drawn into the debate about possible sanctions because of his long exerience in dealing with China concluded, "We'd be hurting American carmakers and banks and workers as much as we'd be hurting the Chinese." 
And the option many in Congress are clamoring for -- selling Taiwan advanced arms and destroyers equipped with the Aegis radar system -- also has its drawbacks.
"Look, if we have a bad relationship with China, does it make sense to sell more weapons to Taiwan?" asked one senior Bush administration official. "That would be ridiculous -- almost as ridiculous as the converse, that if we have good relations with China, we should starve the Taiwanese of what they need."
In fact, officials say, before the collision, the administration was leaning toward selling Taiwan Kidd-class destroyers, which have less capable weapon systems than the Aegis, and deferring any decision on the Aegis system, which the Chinese say they would attempt to overwhelm with more weaponry of their own.
Under that plan, the destroyers and the Aegis systems would be ordered for the United States Navy -- with the understanding that they could be transferred to Taiwan. But even if that was Mr. Bush's intent last month, if he pursues that track he could be accused by pro-Taiwan lawmakers of watering down the sale in order to appease the Chinese and get the crew members back.
"Beijing has made it impossible for the Bush administration, no matter what it decides," Senator Torricelli said in an interview today. "They cannot appear to have compromised on their previous intentions. In fact, every day that passes in this will make it harder not to do the sale of the Aegis destroyers. The only one who has benefited is the Taiwan military."
In the State Department, however, officials are worried that administration action could box in China's president, Jiang Zemin. "What happens to Jiang, and our hopes for avoiding a hard-line successor, if he lets the crew go and then we turn around and sell more gear to Taiwan?" one senior administration official said. 
While the official debate continued, American officials exacted Washington's strongest form of social revenge this evening. The Chinese embassy had long ago invited Secretary Powell, diplomats and members of Congress to a party welcoming Yang Jiechi as the new Chinese ambassador to Washington. Mr. Powell did not attend, and neither did any other senior administration officials.
"We're all very, very busy," one senior diplomat said tonight.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET: THE OVERVIEW; 
FIRST BUSH BUDGET PROPOSES TO RAISE AID FOR EDUCATION

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9 

 BODY:
President Bush unveiled his first budget today, describing his plans to increase federal spending on education and biomedical research while curtailing what he described as "recent explosive growth" in other federal programs.
 Under Mr. Bush's proposal, federal spending would rise by $104 billion, or 5.6 percent, to a total of $1.96 trillion in the fiscal year that begins on Oct. 1. 
 In the last eight years, under President Bill Clinton, federal spending grew an average of 3.5 percent a year, as military spending was held down, the growth of health spending slowed and the Treasury reaped the fruits of deficit-reduction efforts begun under Mr. Bush's father, President George Bush. 
Two-thirds of the entire increase next year would go to six programs: Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, education, the National Institutes of Health and the Pentagon.
By contrast, Mr. Bush would sharply reduce farm programs, especially those that supplement the income of farmers.
"This budget offers a new vision of governing for our nation," Mr. Bush told Congress, which will carefully weigh his proposals as lawmakers write appropriations bills in the coming months. After a brief meeting with his cabinet this morning, Mr. Bush added: "It's a budget that protects taxpayers, protects children, protects our surplus. It represents compassionate conservatism."
The shape of the budget was heavily influenced by Mr. Bush's top priority, a commitment to reduce taxes by $1.6 trillion over the next decade. The Senate voted last week to scale back the tax cut; the amount of that cut, to be worked out with the House, will affect decisions on the budget. 
Democrats asserted that Mr. Bush had cut worthy programs to accommodate the tax cut.
They cited, as examples, his plans to cut aid for the hiring of local police officers, the training of doctors at children's hospitals and the conservation of energy.
But Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the president's budget director, scoffed at such criticism. "It's completely fallacious," he said. "I think 'fatuous' might be a better word." 
Mr. Daniels said the new budget would achieve substantial savings from last year's budget just by canceling appropriations that had not been requested by Mr. Clinton -- money earmarked by Congress for specific projects, including roads and bridges and other public works.
Mr. Bush said his budget would produce a surplus of $231 billion in 2002, down from a projected surplus of $281 billion this year and an actual surplus of $236 billion last year.
In drafting his proposal, Mr. Bush focused on controlling discretionary spending, which is subject to annual appropriation and accounts for about one-third of the total budget. Under the president's budget, discretionary spending would rise by 4 percent, or $26 billion, in 2002 compared with average annual increases of 6.2 percent over the last three years.
In keeping with Mr. Bush's proposal to "leave no child behind," the Education Department would get one of the largest budget increases: $4.6 billion, or 11.5 percent, raising its total to $44.5 billion next year. That follows an increase of $10 billion approved by Congress in December for the current year.
The overall budget for agriculture activities would be chopped to $15.8 billion next year, from $29 billion this year. Spending on other activities would raise the total for next year to $17.9 billion. The budget of the Commodity Credit Corporation would be reduced to $8.3 billion, from $21.6 billion, and it would decline in subsequent years, to $6 billion in 2006.
The Bush administration said that "farm conditions are improving," an assertion disputed by lawmakers from farm states, who will strenuously resist the proposed cuts. 
Congressional aides said they were perplexed by the budget request for farm programs. Administration officials are apparently counting on Congress to provide emergency aid to farmers, as Congress has done in each of the last three years, to compensate for falling commodity prices and crops lost to bad weather.
Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, the senior Democrat on the House Budget Committee, said he doubted that Mr. Bush could win even Republican support for some of the "bewildering, curious cuts in this budget."
The president's budget continues many programs, with modest cutbacks or small increases, providing less than required to keep up with inflation.
The narrative explanation of the president's proposals has little of the fiery language in which Republicans used to attack the federal government and its role. Such language was characteristic of budget documents issued by President Ronald Reagan and his budget director, David A. Stockman, and by Richard G. Darman, the budget director for Mr. Bush's father.
For the first time in nearly two decades, the president's budget does not seek cuts in Medicare payments to hospitals. Richard J. Pollack, executive vice president of the American Hospital Association, praised Mr. Bush for refraining from such cuts, at a time when he said "more than half of America's hospitals are in financial distress."
The budget for the National Institutes of Health would rise by $2.75 billion, or 13.5 percent, providing $23.1 billion for biomedical research next year. This is the fourth installment of a five-year plan to double the budget of the institutes from 1998 to 2003. Congress devised the plan, and Mr. Bush has embraced it.
Mr. Bush's budget for 2002 provides the first detailed look at his priorities. In some respects, it may already have been overtaken by events on Capitol Hill.
Mr. Bush seeks $153 billion for prescription drug benefits and other, unspecified changes in Medicare over the next decade. But Republicans and Democrats alike say that twice that amount is the minimum that will be required for drug benefits, at a time when drug spending is rising more than 15 percent a year in many private health plans.
Mr. Bush tried to put his imprint on federal spending by cutting some of Mr. Clinton's favorite initiatives, including one to put 100,000 more police officers on the street. The budget for this program, Community Oriented Policing Services, or COPS, would be reduced by 17 percent from its current level of $1 billion. Some of the remaining money would be used to strengthen security at schools.
Mr. Bush's budget shows that he often prefers tax credits and other tax incentives, rather than direct federal spending, as an instrument of social policy. 
For example, Mr. Bush proposed new tax credits up to $2,000 a year to help uninsured people buy health insurance. He also proposed a tax credit to help families buy equipment that uses solar energy to generate electricity or to heat their homes.
Like presidents before him, Mr. Bush deployed numbers in his budget to justify his proposals. When he wanted to take credit for an increase that had already occurred in popular programs, like those of the National Science Foundation, he compared his request for 2002 with the amount spent in 2000. But when he wanted to cut programs, he criticized big raises made by Congress and Mr. Clinton in 2001.
Under Mr. Bush's plan, the White House said, from 2000 to 2002, the budget of the National Science Foundation will grow by 15 percent, to $4.5 billion. But Congress has already approved most of the rise, raising the budget to $4.4 billion this year, from $3.9 billion last year. And lawmakers of both parties have vowed to provide the science foundation with more money than the president sought.
The budget of the National Endowment for the Arts, once a source of fierce contention, would be increased slightly, to $105.2 million next year, from $104.8 million this year. The agency's budget reached a peak of $176 million in 1992. Arts organizations in New York State received nearly 14 percent of all grants last year, the largest share of any state.
Here are other highlights of the budget:
*Mr. Bush would split the Immigration and Naturalization Service into two agencies, one for law enforcement and one for the delivery of services. The number of Border Patrol agents would be increased by 570 in each of the next two years, reaching a total of 11,000 in 2003.
*States could use some of their federal welfare money to offset the cost of providing new tax credits to people who make contributions to state-designated charities. Such charities would work to alleviate poverty.
*Mr. Bush would create a new federal tax credit to encourage investors to build single-family homes for low-income people.
*The budget for Pell grants, the main form of federal aid to college students, would rise by $1 billion, to $9.8 billion next year. The maximum award would be $3,850, up $100 from the current year.
*Mr. Bush assumes that the federal government will raise $1.2 billion a year, starting in 2004, from oil leases in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska. Some of the money would be dedicated to research on solar energy technology.
Over all, the budget for protecting the environment and conserving natural resources would be reduced by 6.7 percent, to $26.6 billion next year, from $28.5 billion this year, according to budget documents.
The budget outlook depends, to some extent, on assumptions about the economy. But Mr. Daniels said the economic slowdown of recent months would not significantly reduce the surplus expected in the next five or 10 years.
"We're not concerned about the economy tanking," Mr. Daniels said. "We think that the economy is struggling along at the moment with unacceptably low growth, but at least it's still growing." 
Moreover, Mr. Daniels said, "if you look at our revenue projections, you will see we have essentially assumed a slow growth or even recessionary economy over the next few years, just out of a conservative approach."

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET: THE BREAKDOWN; 
Who Gets What Slice of the President's First Federal Budget Pie

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

 BODY:
Housing
 President Bush's proposed $30.4 billion budget for the Department of Housing and Urban Development includes a 6.7 percent increase intended to expand programs for new homeowners and provide better housing for low-income renters. 
 In presenting the budget, Housing Secretary Mel Martinez announced two new programs that he said were intended to enable more members of minorities to become homeowners. 
"The sad fact is only 46 percent of Hispanic and African-American families own their own homes," Mr. Martinez said. "And we must do better."
The first program is a $1.7 billion tax credit over five years to encourage investors to build housing for low-income families. Mr. Martinez said the tax credit could help build 100,000 homes in low-income areas. 
The second program is intended to provide low-income families with money for a down payment. The American Dream Fund would provide $1 billion over five years which, HUD officials said, could help 650,000 low-income families to become homeowners.
In addition, the president's budget would add $3 million to church-based and community programs like Habitat for Humanity that build or repair homes for new homeowners. 
As promised, the budget includes increases of $197 million for 34,000 more housing vouchers and $150 million to help cover higher utility costs in public housing. 
Other proposals include spending $20 million to house 3,700 people living with AIDS and $10 million for a 10-year program to eliminate lead paint hazards in 2.3 million low-income households with children.
The budget discontinues several programs, including the $309 million drug-elimination program for public housing, which had helped pay for policing in public housing compounds. Mr. Martinez said this program duplicated other efforts.
The $25 million rural housing and economic development program was eliminated because officials said it duplicated many Agriculture Department programs. ELIZABETH BECKER

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE REVIEW; 
Architectural Trendsetter Seduces Historic SoHo

BYLINE:  By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
Last week the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission made a decision of breathtaking importance for the future of architecture in New York. The 11-member commission unanimously approved a design by the French architect Jean Nouvel for a new hotel in SoHo, one of the first of the city's historic districts and one of its most preservation-minded neighborhoods.
 The design bears little resemblance to the derivative contextual aesthetic promoted by preservation groups and local community boards in recent decades. Mr. Nouvel's design is good news, but the enthusiastic support it drew from the Landmarks Commission and its commissioner, Jennifer J. Raab, is an even bigger deal. This is the most significant architectural initiative we've seen from city government since -- well, since the landmarks law was passed in 1965. 
 The 180-room hotel, called the Broadway, is being developed by Andre Balazs, owner of the Mercer Hotel (also in SoHo), and the Chateau Marmont and the Standard, citadels of chic in Hollywood. His partner in the project is Hines, a Houston-based development firm. The hotel will be built on a large site, now occupied by a parking lot and flea market, on Grand Street between Broadway and Mercer. Mr. Nouvel's Cartier Foundation for Contemporary Art in Paris, completed in 1994, captured a perfect picture of modern Left Bank life. The Broadway will do the same for downtown Manhattan. 
While the design is as distinctive as any New York has seen in decades, it is sensitive to its surroundings. The building is massed into a six-story tower atop a six-story base. The tower's height is determined by what planners call the sky plane, the variable angle from which the sky remains visible from the street. The base extends the full length of the Grand Street block, with the tower set back to the north by 44 feet. The facades, glass compositions of overlapping rectilinear geometry, reflect the Manhattan street grid and its cosmopolitan life.
Just north of the building, a cut through the block between Mercer and Broadway will reveal a garden set two levels below the street. Lushly planted, with reeds whose frilly tops will reach above the sidewalk, the garden will adjoin a two-story spa. An angled wall enlarges the outdoor space and lets hotel guests peer down from their rooms. Another cut, on the Mercer Street side, reveals a steel mesh fire escape. Other amenities: glass elevator cabs, lobby, shops, luxury, the unending once-over.
Like the LVMH Tower on East 57th Street, designed by Mr. Nouvel's countryman Christian de Portzamparc, the hotel's outstanding feature is its innovative use of glass. This is not coincidence. In France glass has kept its connotations of modernity. It represents openness, lightness, technical innovation and a progressive view. Mr. Nouvel's design, like Mr. Portzamparc's, showcases technical advances in glass production and the expanded range of ideas they make possible. The facades are visually enriched -- ornamented, if you like -- with applied and architectonic features that give the glass uncommon depth and texture. The three street facades have steel grids of mullions and spandrels. Glass fins, used for support as well as for aesthetic effect, are set perpendicular to the walls. These amplify the play of reflections across the surface.
The transparency is further modulated by different types of glass, and by screening and fretting techniques that play against the strict geometry of the steel grid. Applied scrims of gradated color -- red, blue and gray -- also distinguish the design from glass towers of 40 years ago.
Like other contemporary architects, Mr. Nouvel stresses the relationship between inside and outside. Here he defines the relationship with the interaction of art and technology. The building's exterior includes the world immediately around it. The scale of the base and the proportions of the grid mirror those of nearby loft buildings, which would also be reflected in the glass. The transparency draws the outside inside, and vice versa.
The facades' industrial look recalls the origins of SoHo's architecture in cast-iron construction, but the glass is fabricated on a scale impossible a century ago. The steel grid evokes the mass production of SoHo's ornamental facades and the steel mullions of the classic American towers of Mies van der Rohe. Abstract imagery applied to the glass suggests SoHo's transformation from a district of light manufacturing to a center of computer-age design.
It would be obtuse to analyze the design in strictly formal or functional terms. This hotel is made for "Moody's Mood for Love" as performed by King Pleasure, on a rainy weekday afternoon, downtown, in a room surrounded by low-rise buildings. Think Edward Hopper crossed with Pedro Almodovar. Not least, this design is about sex. That is its major departure from the glass office towers of mid-20th-century New York.
In those buildings, glass stood for Reason: economy, technology, prefabricated construction. These meanings still hold in projects like the Rose Center for Earth and Space, by James Stewart Polshek and partners. Elsewhere, but especially in France, new techniques in glass have made possible a range of erotic suggestions. Mr. Nouvel has pursued them in projects including the Cartier Foundation, the Galeries Lafayette in Berlin and the (unbuilt) Victoria Building for Frankfurt. Modulating the visual texture of glass with reflectivity, fretted patterns, screened-on images, blurring, veiling, coloration, support systems and other techniques, these projects summon forth states of narcissism, exhibitionism, voyeurism, veiling, vamping, elusiveness, disconsolation, Hitchcock's blonde.
Novelty holds erotic appeal. Modern architects of the heroic era could not acknowledge this. They let movies say it for them, in sets for mysteries and romantic comedies -- "That Touch of Mink," "The Best of Everything," -- in which the gleam of the new denoted desire. 
Mr. Nouvel's vision has long been cinematic. He has used the New York City fire escape before, most notably in the Arab World Institute in Paris, but in the New York context the image derives more recognizably from the realm of "Rear Window" and "West Side Story." Grace Kelly has discovered that she is a better photographer than Jimmy Stewart, and that romantic intrigues are more photogenically combustible than wars and natural disasters. In an animated dream sequence, she sees the walls shattered by an explosion of high-pressure glamour, and the colored glass shards, transformed by the pressure into precious stones, pave the streets with diamonds, rubies, sapphires. It's that kind of building.
The hotel's northern side, which faces away from the street, is its most explicitly cinematic feature. A screened coating will render the glass gray, rhythmically punctuated by transparent rectangles with blurred edges. These resemble film sprockets or movie stills from an emphatically film noir genre. 
Mr. Nouvel's design is a supreme example of what we mean when we talk about an architecture of ideas. It is an aesthetic of differences that depends on an awareness of similarities, a design that demonstrates the extent to which continuity depends on periodic rupture and separation.
The miracle is that the members of the Landmarks Commission understood it. They got it completely. In fact, they overruled the opinion of the community board's preservation panel. I doubt that we could have counted on the commission's support even as recently as two years ago, certainly not to this degree. Perhaps it took the arrival of the millennium for the city to realize that it had produced almost no buildings of landmark stature in more than 30 years and that a resistance to ideas was to blame.
I suspect the commission's decision will have widespread repercussions, even outside New York, by identifying several fundamental principles. It points up the profound distinction between architecture and architectural history. It helps dispel the confusion between preservation and preservationism. And it demonstrates that the architectural context for great cities like New York is international as well as local. This is called leadership.

HEADLINE: ARTS ABROAD; 
It's a Circus Out There, but Cirque Still Isn't Satisfied

BYLINE:  By James Brooke 

DATELINE: MONTREAL 

 BODY:
In one stockroom, racks rising from the floor to the ceiling hold 700 plaster heads. With seven different shows on four continents, Cirque du Soleil wants to have each head on file in case a performer needs a new mask, wig or headdress.
 To venture behind the scenes at Cirque du Soleil's new international headquarters here is to explore an arts multinational that is booming through a blend of creativity and efficiency. At home, Cirque is seeking to turn this city into the world capital of circus arts. Abroad, Cirque plans to expand its entertainment concepts beyond the big top, into Cirque hotels, restaurants, art galleries and boutiques. 
 "Guy broke the rules with Cirque," Mario D'Amico, Cirque's vice president for marketing, said of Guy Laliberte, a onetime Quebecois accordion player, fire-eater and stilt-walker who formed the company in 1984 with a dozen friends. "Now with hotels and dinner theaters, he wants to build an experience around the customer."
New York area residents got another chance to line up to taste the Cirque experience when the company scheduled its "Dralion" show for an eight-week run in Liberty State Park in Jersey City starting on April 4. Like the six other Cirque shows, "Dralion" is a Felliniesque fusion of music and mime, acrobatics and dance, clowning and theatrical drama. A swirl of multicolored masks, costumes and sets create a world of fantasy and imagination under a traditional circus tent. Aimed at affluent sophisticates -- children and adults alike -- Cirque further breaks with circus tradition by using no animals and by eschewing a star system.
This approach has shaken up the circus industry, prompting Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey to counterattack with its own new-wave circus show, "Kaleidoscape." 
But Cirque officials are not resting on their laurels. Cirque has plans to build a 2,000-seat theater in London at Battersea Power Station, an empty 1930's landmark thought to be the largest brick building in Europe. Planned in a partnership announced in December with a Taiwanese investor, Victor Hwang, the Battersea renovation would include Cirque-inspired restaurants, hotels, art galleries and a spa and movie theater. Over the next 15 years, Cirque says, it plans to build four to six entertainment complexes around the world.
"We want to be in the major entertainment capitals of the world -- London, New York, Singapore, Hong Kong, Tokyo, Sydney," Mr. D'Amico said. "You could see trapeze artists practicing when you check in, or there could be statue acts around the lobby."
Mr. Laliberte, Cirque's 42-year-old founding president, has mused about the possibility of clowns' delivering room service to hotel guests or mimes' climbing out of hidden compartments in elevators.
Moving beyond merchandising souvenirs, Cirque already takes advantage of its branded artistic aesthetic to sell Cirque wallpaper, fabrics, teapots, leather jackets, blown glass and handmade jewelry. It is considering a line of home furnishings, presumably something more innovative than armchairs with built-in whoopee cushions.
At home here, its ambition to establish this North American city, 90 minutes by plane north of New York, into a world center for circus arts. This city, a multilingual greenhouse for entertainers and artists, already has, in addition to Cirque du Soleil, the National Circus School of Canada; Cirque Eloize, a small touring troupe formed by Cirque veterans; En Piste, a Quebec circus association; dozens of street performers and jugglers; and the Canadian chapter of Clowns Without Borders, an aid group that has taken good cheer to war-torn areas like Bosnia and Kosovo.
The next step, Cirque officials say, is to band these groups together to form a world circus capital. Rising around the nucleus here of Cirque du Soleil would be a new center for training, creating and performing the circus arts called the Cite des Arts du Cirque.
"We want to create a critical mass in Montreal," said Chantal Cote, a Cirque spokeswoman. Located on a vast reclaimed landfill that Cirque made its home five years ago, the Cite would include residential housing for performers and would drive economic development in the surrounding St. Michel neighborhood, the third poorest residential area in Canada.
As with every decision by Cirque, a privately held company that reported $300 million in revenue last year, shrewd business calculations are at work in the Cite project. In an era when senses are dulled by a barrage of recorded entertainment, the thinking goes, worldwide demand for live circus entertainment outstrips the supply. 
Thirty million people have attended Cirque shows over the last 17 years, and company officials say that the demand justifies an eighth show, with a debut in the spring of 2002. 
Behind the magic of Cirque is a relentless international recruiting machine that must contend with the 20 percent annual turnover in skilled performers at the company. Beyond the lure of running away to join the circus, Cirque offers second careers to former Olympic athletes and coaches. Last year company talent scouts held auditions in the United States, Belgium, Brazil, Britain, Canada, France, Russia and Ukraine. 
Despite the company's Gallic stamp, only 20 percent of its 530 performers are Quebecois, with the remainder from 40 different countries. Although the working language for performers is English, safety signs in the high wire practice room are posted in English, Russian and Chinese.
On March 12 Cirque inaugurated a new step toward the Cite project, an $11 million workshop with spaces for hundreds of mask makers, dyers, costume seamstresses and artisans who fashion the trapezes and high-wire hardware. Cirque now employs 2,100 people, double its payroll of five years ago.
The Workshop joins the existing Studio, a four-year-old building that includes a three-story indoor space for acrobatic and trapeze training, as well as the traditional clocks on the wall befitting the international headquarters of a company with touring shows in Europe, Asia, Australia and the United States and permanent shows in Las Vegas, Orlando, Fla., and Biloxi, Miss. Unfinished metal and concrete were used to give buildings the air of a permanent work in progress. To recreate the collegial spirit of traveling troupes, a generous number of interior windows allow office workers and trapeze artists to see one another at work throughout the day.
"The theme is transparency," Ms. Cote said as she passed a room in which a Chinese child repeated a juggling act over and over again. "We started as street performers. We wanted something to remind us of our origins."
