HEADLINE: A Single Hour That Can Save the Day 

BYLINE:  By NANCY RUBIN STUART 

 BODY:
The three-martini lunch is dead. So what has replaced it? As it turns out, many office workers are inventive about recharging their batteries during their lunch hour. And often, food has nothing to do with it.
 Andy Lerer, a cash analyst in the accounting department of the Manhattan publisher VNU/USA, delivers meals to house-bound AIDS patients. "It's important to switch gears," Mr. Lerer said. "I enjoy the clients, and it makes them happy to see me at lunchtime. That makes me feel good and gives me perspective." 
 Merna Skinner, a vice president at Exec Comm, a communications consulting firm in Midtown Manhattan, takes a more introspective approach. During her lunch hour, she often turns off the lights, the computer and the cell phone in her office and lights several candles. "My goal is to disconnect from all technology and reconnect with myself," she said.
Other people meditate, go to church, exercise or just wander aimlessly through stores -- anything it takes, it seems, to work off the stress of the morning and prepare them for the frustrations of the afternoon.
True, workplace stress is nothing new. And true, some people have always used their lunch breaks to combat it. But, specialists say, more people are stressed than ever. And since few of them knock back three martinis at lunch anymore, or even indulge in a glass of wine, more workers are devising strategies to lift their spirits at midday.
It is not just sobriety that is driving the trend. So are the hectic pace of the Internet age, Americans' growing health consciousness and now, fears of unemployment. Seventy percent of Americans surveyed last year by Penn, Schoen & Berland for the American Psychological Association reported high or moderate workplace stress, and 57 percent said they worried their heightened anxiety would cause health problems. The study was done in response to anecdotal reports from members of the association that job stress was increasing.
And while the jobless rate remains low, the recent economic slowdown and stock market slump are giving many the jitters.
"Today's rapidly changing economic climate, with its mergers and acquisitions and resultant uncertainty, inevitably has a stressful effect," said Rex Gatto, an industrial and organizational psychologist and author of "Controlling Stress in the Workplace" (Pfeiffer, 1993).
Even the lunch hour itself is being blamed for workplace malaise. "For many people, the lunch hour represents the frightening realization that half the day is over and yet there's lots more work to be done," said Marlin Potash, a clinical psychologist who has written a book about balancing work and personal life.
The information age is a major culprit, she said, because people feel trapped by the very technology that was supposed to set them free from much of their workload. "We have beepers, cell phones and pagers so that people can reach us all day long, even at lunchtime when we're supposed to be taking a break," Dr. Potash said. "Psychologically, that's a dangerous phenomenon because it means we're not in control and our jobs are running us."
Some people seek spiritual solace. Chuck Ughetta goes to Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral. "It gives me a chance to pray, to find peace and have an opportunity to reflect," said Mr. Ughetta, secretary-treasurer of Gerard Klauer Mattison, a securities firm.
Charlie Buck, president of Charles Buck & Associates, an executive recruitment firm, favors a Hindu discipline, practicing hatha yoga once a week for 90 minutes. "It revs me up mentally and physically and gives me more energy than if I'd just had eight hours of sleep," Mr. Buck said.
Vigorous exercise, of course, is a time-honored break from the office grind. Every day, untold thousands of workers troop off to the gym or the indoor swimming pool or just to a nearby park for a quick jog or fast walk. Since 1987, membership in gyms and health clubs has nearly doubled to roughly 33 million from just over 17 million, according to the International Health, Racquet and Sportsclub Association. "After a workout, I feel rejuvenated, and my sense of humor and hopefulness have returned," said Linda Touster, a financial consultant for an oncologist on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.
Window shopping is another standby. Cynthia Reed, a word processor at the Falconwood Corporation in Manhattan, a merchant banking company, likes to browse in Saks Fifth Avenue. "Saks is my respite," she said, "especially when I leave my credit cards at my desk. Then I just wander though the store, looking at the clothes and at the interesting people who come to that store from all over the world."
Behavioral specialists say what you do is less significant than whether you do it. What is important, they say, is to shift gears -- to do something so radically different that you'll put work out of your mind.
"Change the pace, the type of activity and your environment, even if it's only for 15 or 20 minutes," Dr. Potash advised. "If you can't leave your office, leave the room or switch chairs. Put your head down for 10 minutes. You'll get several hours of renewed vigor from that."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Andy Lerer, above, delivers meals to house-bound AIDS patients to escape office stress during his lunch break. Charlie Buck uses a 90-minute yoga session each week. (Above, Ozier Muhammad/The New York Times; Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times) Chart: "Stress Menders"Relaxation tips from workplace experts. Stand up and stretch at least once an hour. Take deep breaths and meditate at your desk. Also do hand and neck exercises. (Ask a physical therapist about which ones to do.) Go outside during your lunch hour, if only for a few minutes. Do not let bad weather deter you. Fight self-pity, anger and other office blahs with mental pep talks.

HEADLINE: Europe's Rate Setters Wary of Slowdown 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, April 10 

 BODY:
If the United States catches a cold, can Europe escape with just a sneeze?
 At least for the last decade, the opposite was true: any mild economic setback in the United States usually led to pronounced problems in Europe. But as the American economy teeters on the edge of a recession, European central bankers are clinging to the hope that the slowdown will be significantly less acute on their side of the Atlantic. 
 On Wednesday, the European Central Bank will meet once again to decide whether to follow the Federal Reserve Board's lead and reduce interest rates. Alone among major central banks, the European Central Bank has so far held the line and refused to ease monetary policy, in part because its leaders were confident that American problems would have only a limited impact on Europe. The Fed, meanwhile, has reduced rates three times this year, the Bank of Japan cut short-term rates essentially to zero last month and the Bank of England made a modest reduction in February and another last week. 
But Europe has grown noticeably more anxious in the last few weeks. Forecasters in government and private industry have trimmed their predictions for 2001, and now expect growth of about 2.5 percent in the 12-nation euro currency area, down from 3 percent before. Germany, which accounts for one-third of the euro zone's output, has slowed even more, and growth there is not expected to exceed 2.1 percent.
That would still be faster growth than is now predicted for the United States, but those European forecasts are based on an assumption that the American economy will start to revive later this year. Without a pickup in America, all bets are off.
Confusion has compounded the anxiety. Three weeks ago, top officials at the European Central Bank hinted that they were ready to ease monetary policy. In a series of public comments, they acknowledged that European growth had slowed more than they had expected, and suggested that inflation worries were fading. But other members of the bank's board, including the president of the Bundesbank of Germany, quickly said they were not so sanguine about inflation and wanted to wait and see.
Cacophony has been a problem since the dawn of the euro as a common currency two years ago. But the central bank's likely next move seems especially hard to read, and analysts are revising their predictions every few days as they ponder the latest comment or scrap of economic data.
"It is true that signals were contradictory at one point," said Elga Bartsch, an economist in London at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "But that very much underlines that the consensus was shifting within the central council."
Three questions are at the heart of current policy battles within Europe. The first is how severe a slowdown Europe is likely to suffer, and what if anything the central bank should do to minimize it. A second question is whether it will directly affect Europe as a whole or be confined mainly to Germany. The third is whether the European Central Bank is responding quickly enough to changing economic conditions.
Officially, the bank is still sticking to a 3 percent growth forecast for the euro zone, though senior bankers concede unofficially that the figure is too high. Today, six institutes that advise the German government revised their own growth forecasts down to 2.6 percent, while the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a research organization financed by industrialized countries around the world, reduced its forecast to 2.7 percent.
The O.E.C.D. and the German institutes both called on the European Central Bank today to reduce interest rates quickly. Those calls follow similar remarks last week by the head of the International Monetary Fund, Horst Kohler.
"The E.C.B. has a tendency to move incrementally, perhaps because of a desire to foster consensus," said Vincent Koen, a senior economist at the O.E.C.D. who wrote the survey on Europe published today. "At the same time, we think the time has come for a small move."
Most economists still predict that Europe will escape a recession. Despite a steady diet of discouraging news, consumer confidence appears to remain strong in most countries. And while exports to North America and Asia are expected to decline, many experts say European investment in technology and new equipment will remain fairly buoyant. 
"We haven't had as much of a bubble in Europe as we had in the United States," Mr. Koen said. Overspending on telecommunications and Internet networks, fueled by the stock market boom for start-up technology companies, was much more acute in the United States, he said. Beyond that, European consumers are not burdened by nearly as much debt as Americans, who have been on a spending spree that lasted through most of the 1990's. Nor have Europeans been affected as much by declining stock markets, because a much smaller percentage had been investing in stocks.
Germany remains one of Europe's biggest uncertainties. Though it is among the largest economies over all and a leading exporter of industrial equipment and automobiles, German economic growth has consistently lagged the European average. 
"At the time when the European Union was forming, everyone thought that Germany would be the standard, and all other countries would have to get their acts together to compete with it," said Stefan Schneider, an economist at Deutsche Bank Research in Frankfurt. "Now Germany is no longer the leader. It is more the laggard."
Germany has always been vulnerable to a global downturn because of its greater reliance exports of heavy machinery, but its problems in recent years have had more to do with lackluster demand for goods and services at home, which most economists attribute to a long series of tax increases.
"Export orders are slowing down big time, but that was expected," said Jose Luis Alzola, an economist at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney in London. "What was not expected was that domestic demand in Germany would not respond to tax cuts."
This year, the German government has passed the first significant tax reduction in years, but it also raised taxes on gasoline just when world oil prices went soaring.
"Germany is indeed the weak core of the euro area," Mr. Koen said. "Germany is slowing down the euro area, while France and the peripheral countries are doing better. Clearly there is a German problem, and maybe in part this has to do with the lack of structural reform."

HEADLINE: Mining Giant Steps Out on Its Own 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, April 10 

 BODY:
Anthony J. Trahar, the new chief executive of the mining giant Anglo American, was asked a few weeks ago to list the changes since he took over the company last July, in what many took as a sea change of generation and corporate style.
 The recurrent theme in his response was speed: "rapid" moves to reassure shareholders that a new strategy was unfolding; "fairly rapid" steps to shed noncore businesses and, most of all, a quicker-than-expected deal last month to disentangle the cross-holdings of Anglo American and De Beers, the diamond colossus that is Anglo's sister company in the Oppenheimer family empire. 
 A couple of days later, Mr. Trahar (pronounced TRAY-er) might have been forced to conclude that his rivals were moving with equal if not greater speed, as the world's mining and metals titans consolidate in face of uncertain commodity prices, seeking to outflank Anglo American as it sheds the final legacies of doing business in apartheid-era South Africa. 
On March 19, taking Anglo American by surprise, BHP of Australia and Billiton of London announced a $28 billion merger that, if completed, would leapfrog over Anglo American into the No. 2 slot of miners, after Alcoa. 
Anglo American maintained a studied silence, but the deal showed that the rough-and-tumble of the mining industry extends far beyond the deep pits where many of Anglo-America's 220,000 employees work to the boardrooms where strategies evolve.
Since its incorporation in 1917, Anglo American has tried to project a patrician visage. Its founder, Ernest Oppenheimer, was knighted. The atmosphere at its longtime headquarters in Johannesburg -- before the company moved its main stock market listing and some of its offices to London in May 1999 -- was more redolent of a gentleman's club than of a dealer in the mucky business of mining.
But Mr. Trahar, a 51-year-old South African, was appointed with a different mission: to implant a leaner style of management and to convince investors that however much the Oppenheimer dynasty has been seen as inbred and manipulative, Anglo American is moving into more open ground, with a keener eye on shareholders.
Unlike his two predecessors, Julian Ogilvie Thompson and Gavin Relly, Mr. Trahar was not a Rhodes scholar and did not get his start as a personal assistant to Harry F. Oppenheimer, the patriarch who died in September. (He is quick to point out, however, that he was once a personal assistant to Mr. Relly.)
Rather, he studied business and accounting in Johannesburg. "I actually wanted to be an architect," he said, "but my father said that if I did that, I'd be poor all my life." His father had a point: last year, with bonuses, Mr. Trahar earned some $975,000, a company spokesman said, a figure that will rise in 2001.
Like his predecessors, he is an Anglo American lifer, projecting the understated diffidence the company has used to cloak corporate aggressiveness. His brief time as an assistant to Mr. Relly helped as he rose to become a director in 1989 as head of the Mondi paper division -- his springboard to the top job. He bridles slightly at the suggestion that accounting is not an appropriate background for a mining boss. Anglo American, he said, "has never been run by miners."
"It's been run by financiers," he said. "This is about running people and people teams -- not about running mines -- and making people teams perform."
There is another, less obvious break with company history. Traditionally, Anglo's chairmen and chief executives were offered directorships of privately held Oppenheimer family companies, often perceived as the true power behind much of South African business. Those directorships blurred the lines of management and ownership. Once Anglo American listed in London in 1999, Mr. Trahar said "it was absolutely clear that those roles had to be separate and independent."
Disentangling the long ties that bind Anglo American, De Beers and the Oppenheimer family has been by far his biggest task. Even before his appointment as chief executive was announced, Mr. Trahar said, he had been thinking about ways to end the cross-holdings through which De Beers and Anglo American own about a third of each other's stock, protecting against swings in the diamond business, but also weighing down Anglo American's share price and unsettling investors.
Shortly before he died, Harry Oppenheimer told associates the arrangement "had outlived its usefulness," Mr. Trahar said.
It was Mr. Oppenheimer's son Nicholas, the head of De Beers, Mr. Trahar said, who came up with the idea of taking De Beers private in a way that will give Anglo a 45 percent stake, but separate the companies -- almost. The Oppenheimer family's stake will be reduced to 7 percent, guaranteeing Mr. Oppenheimer a seat on the Anglo American board. 
Anglo American, he said, is "completely independent of the Oppenheimer family."
Mr. Trahar objects to suggestions that the privatization was an inside job, one that hurt shareholders. But that is not the only message he must get across to investors. While rivals' stocks trade at higher multiples of earnings, Anglo American has lagged because it has been seen as slow to slim down. Yet Mr. Trahar lists several actions culminating in the De Beers' deal, which some analysts say may have distracted executives from developments like the merger of BHP and Billiton.
The slowdown in the American economy has also forced him to pare expectations, but he said he was hoping for a swing back to old- economy investments after the collapse of dot-com stocks. 
"We watched with a wry amusement," he said, "as dot-com turned to dot-bomb."

HEADLINE: Cutbacks by Daimler Leave A Bitter Residue at Chrysler 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 9 

 BODY:
When word emerged a month ago that Chrysler burned through $5 billion in cash last year, the radio talk show host David Newman wondered aloud what had happened. "How can money disappear like that?" he asked on the local powerhouse, WJR-AM. "I simply didn't know, and I still don't know."
 But his callers knew where to lay blame: at Chrysler's German parent, DaimlerChrysler A.G. Speculation flew that management had siphoned away the money to help keep its Japanese partner, Mitsubishi, afloat and to pay for projects at Mercedes-Benz in Stuttgart. 
 As the often xenophobic debate spread to the Internet and in the local media, Chrysler officials said the cash was depleted by declining auto sales, higher-than-expected rebates and an unplanned expense connected with vehicle introductions.
"There was no jumbo jet landing at Detroit Metro with pallets of money being shipped back to Japan and Germany," Chrysler's chief operating officer, Wolfgang Bernhard, said.
The episode illustrates the lingering resentment here over Chrysler's German superiors, who took control after the $39 billion deal that joined the Chrysler Corporation with Daimler-Benz in 1998.
DaimlerChrysler is about to hold its annual meeting in Berlin. The session follows a recent forecast that revenue will fall 13 percent this year and operating profit as much as 75 percent, dragged down by Chrysler.
The anti-German sentiment in and around Auburn Hills, Mich., where Chrysler is based, is complicating efforts by managers there to stem Chrysler's operating losses -- $1.8 billion last year -- and to make the company competitive again. "Being German adds an additional challenge," said Mr. Bernhard, who, along with the Chrysler division's new chief, Dieter Zetsche, had been imported from Stuttgart.
The hostility, which stirs anew with each spate of bad Chrysler news, brings to mind the Japan-bashing of the early 1980's, when Japanese automakers took sales from American rivals. That fervor reached a peak of sorts in 1982, when a Chinese-American, Vincent Chin, was killed by patrons in a local bar who thought he was Japanese.
By contrast, no one has threatened metropolitan Detroit's more than a million people of German descent.
"No violence -- it's been more or less verbalized," said Eugene C. Strobel Jr., founding president of the German-American Heritage Foundation International.
The debate takes place in doughnut shops, on radio shows and on Internet message boards.
"Dump Schrempp Now!" a posting on Yahoo's DaimlerChrysler board said last week, referring to the parent company's chief executive, Jurgen E. Schrempp. "Where's my stockholder value -- from $108 to $45 -- that's real German engineering, ya?" sic The American shares, which began trading in October 1998 around $82, are now a little shy of $50.
It was this sort of resentment that Mr. Schrempp had hoped to prevent with a strategy created ahead of the Chrysler deal. It included two corporate teams, three outside public relations firms, a memorial to World War II slave laborers and gifts to all employees of both companies.
In DaimlerChrysler's first year, more than 1,000 Chrysler employees signed up for company-sponsored German-language lessons or cultural awareness classes. But such enthusiasm soon disappeared, along with virtually all of Chrysler's American senior management, including Robert J. Eaton, the chairman who forged the deal with Mr. Schrempp, and Thomas Stallkamp, the first Chrysler president after the merger. The new managers' rapid move to cut 26,000 jobs, key to the turnaround plan, inflamed a raw wound.
"There are a lot of people who feel Chrysler would have been better off alone," a recently retired manager of a Chrysler parts supplier said. The deepest resentment was aimed at Mr. Schrempp, who, in a November interview in The Financial Times, said he had never intended the deal to be a "merger of equals."
Soon after, DaimlerChrysler ousted the second postmerger president, James P. Holden, and installed Mr. Zetsche and Mr. Bernhard. Though they are the only top managers sent from Germany, the moves generated dismay.
Mr. Newman, the talk show host, said he had been taken aback by the vitriol of his callers. Some even equated the new management with Nazis. "I have a shiver of embarrassment about it," he said. He has encouraged callers to take a more civil tone.
Others have followed suit. The Detroit Free Press columnist Doron Levin has since written a conciliatory column, and he was upbeat about Chrysler in a speech to the Economic Club of Detroit.
The creator of ChryslerTakeover.com says he removes postings with ethnic disparagements from the site. But the man, who works in Chrysler's product-testing operations, and refused to provide his name for fear of losing his job, remains contemptuous of management. "They are really playing right into the stereotype of the arrogant German manager," he said, by laying off workers en masse soon after they took charge.
Mr. Zetsche and Mr. Bernhard say they recognize the need to address such feelings. Among other efforts, they often eat in the employee cafeteria and regularly stroll down to visit managers in the enormous technical center, instead of summoning them to the executive tower.
Lately, support for Chrysler management has come from a perhaps improbable quarter, the United Auto Workers. Two decades ago, the U.A.W. barred Japanese cars from its headquarters parking lot. But last week, the union's president, Stephen P. Yokich, who sits on the DaimlerChrysler supervisory board, said he did not think that Chrysler would have survived its financial troubles as an independent company.
Nate Gooden, the union's vice president for DaimlerChrysler employees, added, "I think the American people had the wrong perception when the Germans came over." Under the U.A.W. contract, workers who are laid off receive virtually full pay and benefits until the pact expires in 2003. And improving sales, Mr. Gooden said, might eliminate the need for some job cuts.
Mr. Bernhard and Mr. Zetsche agree that financial recovery is the antidote to what Mr. Zetsche calls the "German passport issue."
"When we get the first signs of success," Mr. Bernhard said, "this stuff will die."

HEADLINE: Field Getting More Crowded In Japan Premiership Race 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 10 

 BODY:
The contest to determine who will replace Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori grew more heated today, with two more contenders entering the race.
 There are now five potential candidates for the leadership vote by the long-governing Liberal Democratic Party, to be held on April 24. But there is disagreement about whether the expanded field means that the party is becoming more democratic or less cohesive. 
 The new entries in the race are Shizuka Kamei, a former police officer who has risen to become the party's policy chief, and Taro Aso, the minister in charge of economic and fiscal policy, who has only recently taken a starring role in the party and who says he will run if he musters enough support from party members. 
Junichiro Koizumi, a party upstart who has been flirting with running for weeks, today canceled his allegiance to a faction that is unpopular with some members, apparently trying to position himself for a broader role. 
Mitsuo Horiuchi, another heavy hitter in the party, was said to be preparing a speech to announce his candidacy. And Ryutaro Hashimoto, a former prime minister and leader of the party's largest faction, is also in the running.
"The party's becoming more democratic," said Taro Kono, a young legislator. "It's not so different from the selection process that occurs in party primaries in the United States."
But others say the abundance of potential candidates for party leader, and thus prime minister, could be regarded as a sign that the fractious confederation of factions that has governed Japan since World War II with only a 10-month hiatus is closer than ever to disintegration.
"The fact that four or five names are popping up proves there is no one who can carry the party anymore," said Masumi Ishikawa, a professor at Obirin University. "They can't agree among themselves who should be their leader."
The broader field of candidates may be little more than a gimmick. Staging a competition for the top job addresses critics who say the leadership selection process is flawed, but past races have ended predictably.
Indeed, political analysts chalked Mr. Kamei's entry into the race as little more than an effort to play kingmaker. "Kamei basically wants to sell his faction's votes to either Koizumi or Hashimoto in a runoff election," said one party member. 
Mr. Kamei, who heads the party's third-largest faction, may find himself more of a contender than he imagined. Party members said meetings held on Monday by the leaders of Mr. Hashimoto's faction revealed an unexpectedly low level of support for him, and there is speculation that he will decline to run.
The party first forced its leaders to compete for the job in 1996, when Mr. Hashimoto and Mr. Koizumi squared off in a race that was dismissed by outsiders as little more than kabuki theater.
Mr. Hashimoto won, and when he resigned in 1998, three party members competed to replace him. But the winner, Keizo Obuchi, died suddenly a year ago and was replaced by Mr. Mori.
Mr. Mori did not have to run a race. He was elevated by five of the party's leaders in a smoke-filled hotel room, underscoring concerns that Japan has no clearly defined mechanism for replacing its leadership in a crisis. After he repeatedly embarrassed the party with verbal gaffes and protocol faux pas, it decided that it had no choice but to replace him or risk the wrath of voters in the election for the upper house of Parliament scheduled for this summer.
Mr. Hashimoto is unlikely to repair the party's relationship with the electorate, since he is remembered for increasing the sales tax and thus pushing the economy into yet another slide.
Mr. Koizumi scores highest in public opinion polls, bested only by Makiko Tanaka, an outspoken member of Parliament who has said she would support him if he abandoned his factional allegiances and agreed to appoint a cabinet to "reflect the will of the people."
But Mr. Koizumi is disliked by the more conservative elements in the party because he advocates the privatization of the postal savings system, a political sacred cow, and has generally assumed the role of the rabble-rouser in the party.

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD 

BYLINE:  By ABBY GOODNOUGH, KAREN W. ARENSON, KATHLEEN CARROLL and ALLISON FASS 

 BODY:
Recruiting in Caribbean
 The Board of Education is sending recruiters to the Caribbean this month in hopes of luring teachers from Barbados, Trinidad and Jamaica to New York City schools. The board wants to increase the number of Caribbean teachers in Districts 17 and 18 in Brooklyn, which encompass Flatbush and Crown Heights and have many students from Jamaica, Trinidad and Haiti. 

New Humanities Leader
The New York Institute for the Humanities at New York University, which has been looking to reclaim some of its old intellectual momentum, has named LAWRENCE WESCHLER, a staff writer for The New Yorker and the author of 10 books, as its new director. The institute was founded 25 years ago by a group of intellectuals, including Susan Sontag and Joseph Brodsky, and was intended to be a forum for discussion that linked the university with the city's intellectual, cultural and artistic life. It has about 120 members. Mr. Weschler replaces LEONARD BARKAN, who began leading the institute in 1997.

International Affairs
The New School, the adult-education division of the New School University, has created a graduate program in international affairs and named MICHAEL A. COHEN, a former World Bank official and expert on urban policy in developing countries, as director. Dr. Cohen said the program was intended to train practitioners rather than theoreticians. In the fall, he will teach a course on financial bailouts, looking at the experiences of Argentina, Brazil, Russia, Turkey and Indonesia.

Immigrant Scholarships
To encourage more immigrant children to think of attending small liberal arts colleges, Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., will begin offering 20 full-tuition scholarships a year to immigrants and children of immigrants. LEON BOTSTEIN, the president of Bard, said that immigrants tend to prefer large universities like the ones in their native countries and to focus on fields like science, technology and business because they believe careers in those fields will yield the greatest payoff.

Harlem Robot Is Tested
Cross a moving bridge, pick up a large ball and place it on top of an eight-foot structure and drag the structure back across the bridge without dropping the ball. 
That was the challenge faced by robots created by 330 schools across the country at the National First Robotics Competition in Orlando, Fla., last week, and a robot built by 30 students at Rice High School in Harlem, a Roman Catholic school better known for basketball than academics, came in 11th out of 84 schools in its division. In March, the Rice team, helped by engineers from Consolidated Edison, won the New York City regional competition.

Technology Grants Offered
New Visions for Public Schools, a nonprofit education group, is seeking proposals for $1.1 million worth of grants to help New York City schools enhance their use of computers and the Internet. Grants of up to $20,000 will be awarded to 24 public schools over a two-year period, starting in July. New York Life Foundation is awarding the grant money, and New Visions will help choose the winners.

Theater Group Moves
After 14 years at the Bayard Rustin High School for the Humanities on West 18th Street, the Irondale Ensemble Project, an experimental theater group, has moved to the Brooklyn High School of the Arts at 345 Dean Street in Brooklyn. TERRY GREISS, Irondale's executive director, as well as an actor in the group, said the company would help students and teachers at the new location "in conceptualizing and implementing their musical theater program." Irondale will also continue producing its own professional plays. ABBY GOODNOUGH, KAREN W. ARENSON, KATHLEEN CARROLL and ALLISON FASS

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
The Tyranny Of Baseball Contraction

BYLINE:  By GEORGE VECSEY 

 BODY:
THIS wild-eyed, bushy-faced guy pounced on me outside the Metrodome the other day. Well, maybe not literally pounced, but with enough fervor to move me back a step.
He was there for Final Four basketball, but his thumping heart was obsessed with baseball.
 "You know this stuff," he said, displaying obvious derangement. "Are they going to have contraction?" 
 The man was old enough to have cheered Harmon Killebrew's home runs in the long Minnesota summer evenings, and he had surely witnessed Kirby Puckett's heroics in the cacophonous dome.
This zealot had his memories. Now there is talk of lopping off his team like a callus from the aching heel of baseball.
Apparently, there is this Darwinian theory that if baseball can just whack a couple of minor-market franchises with lousy facilities, then everything will be all right.
Clearly, somebody has been spending too much time watching "Survivor." 
The most obvious victims of contraction have already been speculated: Minnesota, Montreal, Oakland, Tampa Bay.
All right, you could scuttle the Rays and nobody would notice, but 29 is such an unwieldy number that teams with real history would be jeopardized.
With such dismal plotting going on, it was surely heartwarming to see the Twins and the Expos at the top of their divisions yesterday.
True, it was early in the season, but in baseball, you take your thrills when you can. The Expos beat the Mets vendredi, samedi et dimanche, but this team would be singled out for contraction if only so Vladimir Guerrero could be shunted to a truly deserving franchise (in New York, no doubt.)
Should teams be cannibalized for their spare parts? 
It has happened before. In November 1954, an early version of the Baltimore Bullets was disbanded 13 games into the National Basketball Association season. The players were absorbed, except for four, including a personal-foul specialist named Al McGuire. You could look it up.
But who would even think of contraction in a sport that prizes tradition? Why, it turns out to be none other than Commissioner Bud Selig.
"I will tell you today that the economic situation is so significant, and I would call it pervasive, that I wouldn't take contraction off the table," Selig said recently. "It's one of the options out there that we are considering. No question about it, I have had a change of heart." 
Selig, who has a new stadium for his family-owned Milwaukee Brewers, may be merely trying to shame taxpayers in Minnesota and Montreal into subsidizing a worthy welfare client like baseball to the tune of a new stadium.
That's what commissioners do. Selig may also be threatening the loss of 50 jobs in order to frighten the union, what with the contract ending after this season. However, the Players Association did not reach the A-Rod level of salary madness by being frightened of Bud.
Some form of salary cap and real revenue-sharing would be far too sensible for both sides. Boys will be boys.
Goodness knows, teams have flown the coop. You can't tell me hockey is any better for the trail of tears left by the Quebec Nordiques and the Winnipeg Jets. Baseball hasn't had a team move since the Washington Senators became the Texas Rangers in 1972. Football may have lost the Portsmouth Spartans after 1933, but it maintained the Green Bay Packers, courtesy of television revenue-sharing. The N.B.A. is bulging with losers, but turnaround is only one good draft pick away, breeding a form of optimism.
Losing teams should be unavoidably spontaneous, which could happen in the wake of all our dot-com geniuses and their bizarre little Ponzi schemes that made them so celebrated and rich for 15 minutes.
Sponsors and fan support could fade in this shaky economy, but baseball's first obligation should be to preserve a facade of calm.
However, instead of talking contraction, baseball could adopt relegation, like the European soccer system, which has sent historic teams like Fiorentina and Napoli to Italy's Serie B after losing seasons. 
Come to think of it, baseball should relegate on a sliding scale, linking performance to salaries. The Baltimore ownership is said to favor contraction. Fine. Under my plan, the Orioles would be in Class AAA right now -- and so would the Dodgers. That might shake them out of their dysfunctional doldrums, but would not terminate them outright.
Contraction is a ghastly signal for baseball fans like my wild-eyed friend out on the steppes of Minnesota. First-place Minnesota, that is.

HEADLINE: U.N. Report Says U.S. Slowdown Is Damaging Other Economies 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 10 

 BODY:
The American slowdown is damaging many other economies around the world, forecasters from more than 60 countries said in a report today. 
 Particularly vulnerable are Asian nations with high-technology industries that had just begun to recover from the 1997 regional crash. Mexico and Canada, however, are also paying the price of being closely linked to the United States in trade and investment, the experts said. 
 The report describes the spreading downturn as "an intended one, at least in its early stage, engineered by policy makers, in the first instance in the United States." The Federal Reserve's aim was to "put on the brakes" to head off inflation, said Lawrence R. Klein, professor emeritus at the University of Pennsylvania and leader of the forecasters' group.
"It looks as though they did it too hard and too long," said Mr. Klein, a Nobel laureate in economics who was an economic adviser to Jimmy Carter. He was speaking at a news conference here today.
Dozens of economists from around the world, meeting here this week, meshed findings from 79 national and economic models to arrive at global predictions. They said world economic growth is expected to slow this year to 2.4 percent from 4 percent in 2002.
Growth in the industrial market economies will slow, the experts said, especially in Japan, which can not be counted on for economic stimulus when other big economies lag. "One would have hoped that we would get some strength from the No. 2 economy in the world in terms of size of production, but Japan has a longstanding recessionary problem," Mr. Klein said. "The help is not coming there."
In the developing countries, already beset by rapid population growth, epidemic diseases and often weak economic bases, output growth is expected to decline to 4.4 percent from 5.7 percent last year. In the "economies in transition" from government control to a free market -- mostly former Communist nations -- the growth rate of 5.9 percent achieved in 2000 is "unsustainable," the report says. The rate will drop to 3.6 percent this year, it predicts.
Only countries rich in oil and gas can avoid serious problems, the experts said. They include Russia, the Middle Eastern petroleum exporters and some African and Latin American nations. 
The report, the latest Global Economic Outlook, was prepared by economic experts working through Project Link, a joint program of the United Nations department of economic and social affairs, led by Josef M. van Brabant, chief of the economic assessment and outlook branch, and a research center at the University of Toronto headed by Peter H. Pauly, dean of the university's Rotman School of Management.
At the news conference, Mr. Pauly echoed Mr. Klein's concern about the loss of Japan as a compensating factor, and expressed concerns about disappointing trends for Europe.
"The European performance, while solid, is not apparently sufficient to counteract the effect of the U.S. slowdown on the world economy," he said, urging what he called decisive monetary policy in both the United States and Western Europe and fundamental structural change in Japan to prevent a longterm slide in growth.
One of the report's central findings is that the expansion of international trade is expected to reverse sharply, falling to 6 percent from the 12 percent recorded last year. That frequently reflects loss of trade with the United States, the experts said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Stocks Gain in Broad Rally; Dow Returns Above 10,000
Stock prices rose broadly as the Dow Jones industrial average closed above 10,000 for the first time since March 15. Technology stocks led the rally as investors picked through the market's battered offerings.
 The Nasdaq composite index jumped 106.32 points, or 6.1 percent, to 1,852.03. The Dow rose 257.59 points, or 2.6 percent, to 10,102.74, while the Standard & Poor's 500 gained 30.79 points, or 2.7 percent, to 1,168.36. Page A1. 

Motorola Posts a Quarterly Loss
Motorola posted a greater-than-expected first-quarter loss as order growth weakened across all sectors of the company because of the slowing economy. Motorola said it lost $206 million, or 9 cents a share, a penny more than Wall Street forecasts. Before the company issued it financial results, its shares closed at $13, up $1.50. C4.

Consumer Backlash Against China
Customers have begun urging companies to stop buying products from China. The outpouring of anger may indicate that the current standoff may have started to shake one of the foundations of the United States-China relationship: the partnership of trade and investment that has grown rapidly. A1.

Anti-German sentiment in and around Auburn Hills, Mich., where Chrysler is based, is complicating efforts by managers there to stem Chrysler's operating losses and to make the company competitive again. C4.

Creators of 'Survivor' Sue Fox
The creators of "Survivor" and the show's network, CBS, have accused Fox and the creators of "Boot Camp" of stealing the concept behind the show from "Survivor." C2.

Prudential of Britain Sues A.I.G.
Beginning a counterattack in the battle for the life insurer American General, Prudential of Britain sued American International Group, seeking to halt negotiations between the two American companies. A.I.G., meanwhile, said that it had signed a confidentiality agreement with American General and had begun discussions on a $23 billion takeover. C4.

Judge Criticizes Napster Effort
Confronted with evidence that thousands of copyrighted works remain on Napster, a federal judge called the efforts to filter music "a disgrace" but did not specify how Napster should comply, saying she would seek counsel with an expert about the process. C5.

Internet Magazines Retrenching
Time Inc. is in talks to buy Business 2.0, with the intention of acquiring its subscriber list and folding the editorial content into eCompany Now, and The Industry Standard said that it was closing its European edition. C2.

Restaurateur Uses the Right Pen
Michelle Garnaut, the owner of M on the Bund, considered the most elegant restaurant in Shanghai, has encountered challenges with the bureaucracy in China. "You can't sign checks, for example, with a felt-tip pen," she said, "you have to sign with a black ballpoint pen." And then there is something called the Price and Commodities Bureau. "They have rules and regulations fixing the markup you're allowed to charge. They also said they were the only ones allowed to print the menus," she said. "In the end, I just told them to fine me and asked how much and how often I'd have to pay. I haven't heard from them since." The Boss. C7.

New President at ABC Television
Walt Disney named Steven M. Bornstein, the former head of its Internet division, as president of ABC Television. C2.

Trouble Still Possible for Travelers
Although Northwest Airlines and American Airlines have made progress on labor issues, business travelers are still anticipating trouble. Labor Disruptions are possible at three airlines, and companies are looking to cut travel costs, which can lead to reduced luxury. Joe Sharkey: Business Travel. C6.

HEADLINE: Looking at China Through Blinders 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "China's Costly Rigidity" (editorial, April 9):
 The incident involving the United States spy plane and the detention of its crew serves for nothing more than stirring up the nationalist fervor of a people so that they will be distracted from the real source of China's problems: its corrupt ruling clique. 
 Beset from within by failures in its economy, growing discontent at its suppression of basic civil and religious rights and greater and more vocal international support for the people of Tibet and East Turkestan, China's Communist regime is, after more than 50 years, coming to the end of its life.
This standoff is about a regime desperately trying to create conditions for its survival.

WILLIAM F. HEWITT
New York, April 9, 2001

HEADLINE: Phoenix Counts Its Many Challenges 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, April 6 

 BODY:
Benito's small backyard has become his workshop, a dirt square filled with cars to repair and parts to fix them. As he takes an afternoon cigarette break, his wife, Carmen, tends to clothes hanging out to dry. Their barefoot 3-year-old daughter, Fernanda, wanders about.
 This is their life here, a tattered two-bedroom home and a thriving business in a poor section southwest of downtown Phoenix. Inside a house across the street, a man is selling crack to walk-in customers. A few blocks away, prostitutes troll Van Buren Street. 
 "In 10 years, maybe Beverly Hills," Benito said wistfully, insisting that this was better than life was in Mexico before he sneaked across the border three years ago. He remains an illegal immigrant, which is why he would not give his surname. 
In record numbers, people like Benito are moving to the American Southwest. Here in Maricopa County, which is larger in area than each of seven states, new census figures show that from 1990 to 2000, the Hispanic population swelled by 108 percent, a rate fueled by a rising flow of illegal immigration as well as higher-than-average birth rates and migration from other states. The county now has 3.07 million people, of whom 763,000 are Hispanic. 
Officials estimate that a third of the 1.3 million Hispanics now living in Arizona, roughly 400,000 people, entered the country illegally. Five years ago, according to the Immigration and Naturalization Service, the number was just 115,000.
The new illegal workers have helped sustain the state's buoyant economy, and economists and demographers acknowledge that without them, that economy and those of many other states could not have grown so fast.
At the same time, their growing numbers -- and their work in a shadow economy that earns them cash income on which they pay no taxes -- have exerted pressures on county agencies. Many schools, hospitals and libraries are struggling to accommodate rising need. 
"It has been a real challenge," said Luis Ibarra, president and chief executive of Friendly House, a community service agency in Phoenix. "All of a sudden agencies are not adequately staffed to deal with the demands of the population they are serving."
Of the four states bordering Mexico, Arizona had the greatest Hispanic population increase, in percentage terms, during the decade: 76.7 percent, compared with 46.1 percent for Texas, 33.4 percent for California and 23.5 percent for New Mexico.
Phoenix has become an especially strong magnet. The local economy remained particularly vibrant through the 1990's, and legal and illegal migrants alike say they were warned before arriving that Los Angeles and other larger cities had grown too expensive and the competition for jobs there too intense. 
"Here," said Ruben Marquez, a legal resident from Colombia who manages a shop selling medicinal herbs, "it's easier to live, and there are greater opportunities to work."
One result has been a regeneration of whole new communities, where rusting manufacturing plants along thoroughfares like McDowell Street and Van Buren are giving way to bustling strip malls. In another measure of change, nine radio stations now broadcast in Spanish, compared with three in 1990.
Hispanics now account for two-thirds of all those attending the city's 13 public high schools, compared with 42.7 percent a decade ago. Two-thirds of the children in the county's Head Start program are Hispanic.
At city and county libraries, officials cannot keep up with the demand for materials in Spanish. Toni Garvey, the city librarian, said her annual budget for Spanish reading and listening material and for Spanish-speaking personnel had increased fivefold, to $250,000, since 1996. Still, she said, "I can't hire Spanish speakers fast enough."
The rising numbers have also strained the county health system, the safety net for uninsured and under-insured residents. Since 1997, the county hospital in Phoenix has required new employees to speak Spanish and has more than tripled, to 10, the number of translators who help doctors talk to their patients. And, said Paul Strauss, vice president for planning and development, the value of uncompensated care to illegal immigrants and other uninsured county residents has been steadily rising, reaching $49 million last year. 
Francisca Montoya, executive director of Stardust House, a center that helps Hispanic families, said many of those newly arrived, fearing immigration officials, were reluctant to obtain municipal services. So, she said, doctors who volunteer at free clinics in neighborhood churches sometimes see as many as 1,500 people a day.
Several new immigrants interviewed here through a translator said their illegal status and a language barrier had left them feeling isolated and often preyed upon, though some were not reluctant to give a full name. 
Pedro Marin, who works for a pool cleaning company, said he hurt his left hand when he worked for a lumber yard last year and yet was told by a doctor to whom his boss sent him that he should go back to work the next day. Mr. Marin said he agreed to work the next two weeks, using only his right hand "because I needed the job." Then, he said, he was dismissed.
"If I was an Anglo," he said, "maybe this doesn't happen."
Damian Guadalupe, a construction worker, saw the difference this way: "If I had papers, I could make $10, $12, maybe $14 an hour. I make $6 or $7, and it's always, 'Hurry up, hurry up.' "
Many illegal immigrants said they were reluctant even to call 911 when they needed help. A friend of Benito said they were afraid that the police would arrive with immigration agents.
"That's why they are still selling crack over there," he said, pointing to the house across from Benito's. "Nobody around here complains."
Still the immigrants come in waves that include people like Maria Camacho, who was a lawyer in Mexico, and Luis Mario Moreno Gomez, who was a dentist in El Salvador. They are attending a class in English, though they know that as illegal immigrants, they will need years to have a chance for legal status. 
Those without legal status have found hope in recent talks between the United States and Mexico about a guest-worker program that would allow Mexicans to register as they cross the border to fill jobs that keep the American economy churning. 
But even if the talks fail and the American economy sputters, government officials and community leaders here say, the flow northward will continue, easing only when wages and living standards in Mexico and other Latin American countries improve.
"There has always been a pattern of economic migration," said Margie Emmermann, Gov. Jane Dee Hull's policy adviser for Mexico and liaison to the Hispanic community. "The only way this is going to slow down is with economic development in their home countries. Meanwhile, there is at least now dialogue at a high enough level for gradual change that would accommodate these things."

HEADLINE: At Title-Happy Companies, It's a Chief Per Bottle Washer 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
Time was, being the chief executive meant one thing: you were the boss, the first among unequals, the person who stopped the buck; you were the "capo di capi," in the words of Geoff Unwin, global chief executive of Cap Gemini Ernst & Young.
 Now, many large companies have several chief executives -- one for each division, perhaps, or maybe one for each continent. 
 Cap Gemini, a consulting firm, actually has not one, not two, but nine chief executives.
Bertelsmann, the German media company that owns, among other things, the Random House publishing company, recently hired Joel Klein, the Clinton administration's chief antitrust lawyer, as one of the 8 to 10 chief executives Bertelsmann says it has in the United States alone. And just last month, Boeing announced that it would create three new chief executive positions as it moves from its longtime headquarters in Seattle. 
Titles apparently come cheap.
The tight labor market of recent years, corporate growth, mergers and acquisitions and the need to retain senior executives have led to more and more cases of so-called title inflation, executive recruiters and compensation advisers say. In decades past, a vice president or perhaps a president might have run a division of a big company; now it is a chief executive -- who actually reports to a superior chief executive.
"The title has really come a long way, certainly in the last 20 to 30 years," said Jay W. Lorsch, who teaches corporate governance at the Harvard Business School.
Today, he said, " 'chief executive' is immensely popular."
Among the reasons for the phenomenon, headhunters say, are ego and thrift. In a tight labor market, companies can make employees feel more important -- and so discourage them from defecting -- by nominally promoting them.
"If you run a company and you need to stroke somebody, you give them a title," said Peter Crist of Korn/Ferry, an executive search firm. "You can call someone anything you want -- C.E.O., C.O.O., vice chair. That's title inflation." 
High-powered titles are not only proliferating at the very top, said Mr. Crist, whose own title is vice chairman. With the rising numbers of baby boomers swelling management ranks -- even as more organizations adopt a flatter, less hierarchical structure -- only a comparative few can actually run the business. As a result, many companies are giving these people titles that make it sound as if they are in control. 
The bigger titles also impress clients, said Brian M. Sullivan, managing partner of the global financial services practice at Heidrick & Struggles, an executive search firm. 
"There's nothing like a client thinking that they're dealing with a vice chairman," Mr. Sullivan said. "There may be 25 vice chairmen, but the client doesn't know that."
The movement is also driven by corporate mergers. People who are used to running companies do not want to accept an apparent demotion -- even if they will tolerate an actual one when they are subsumed by a larger company -- and it makes more sense to give rank-sensitive former chief executives a big title than to make up for the shift solely with money and perquisites, Mr. Crist said.
Given these trends, the result is that a hefty title does not necessarily mean that its holder has supreme corporate power. Mr. Klein is assuming a position created especially for him, as the chief executive of a subsidiary of Bertelsmann, not of the German parent company. (A Bertelsmann executive said that determining the precise number of chief executives within the company's assorted divisions and subsidiaries is difficult because of its complex structure.)
Similarly, there is no question within Cap Gemini who is boss. "We have regional C.E.O.'s who report in to the chief operating officer, and then you have a global C.E.O., which is yours truly," Mr. Unwin said. The company has had that structure for several years, he added.
General Electric also has separate operating units, organized around products, like engines. The heads of G.E.'s overseas businesses have been called chief executives for more than 15 years, so that they can deal with business leaders in other countries on an equal footing. But the leaders of domestic business units were given the title of president and chief executive of their operations more recently, starting in 1992, according to Louise Binns, a spokeswoman for G.E.
"Each of them is running a significant business in its own right," Ms. Binns said. Analysts say that the increasing size of companies' divisions makes them more like stand-alone companies. That is why, they say, the job of running them can more appropriately be described as that of a chief executive.
Boeing made a similar move when it announced that it was promoting the leaders of its three main operating units by giving them the titles of president and chief executive. They were already in charge of their divisions but will now have slightly greater autonomy, said Larry McCracken, a Boeing spokesman.
"It gives them a little more freedom and flexibility," Mr. McCracken said. "With that title, they get greater leeway in setting their business strategies." They will continue to report to Philip M. Condit, Boeing's overall chief executive.
These situations, where the distribution of power is clear even if the distribution of titles is a little loose, is quite different from those of co-chief executives who try to share power. Those power-sharing arrangements rarely work for long, as shown when Sanford I. Weill and John S. Reed both briefly held that title after Citicorp merged with the Travelers Group to form Citigroup. 
Mr. Weill and Mr. Reed clashed almost from the first days of the merger, and the arrival of a former Treasury secretary, Robert E. Rubin -- someone who is certainly considered capable of running a company on his own -- further complicated the dynamic at the top of the company. Ultimately Mr. Weill -- formerly the Travelers chief executive -- took over, Mr. Reed retired, and Mr. Rubin is a member of the board and retains the awkward titles of chairman of the executive committee and member of the office of the chairman. Citigroup has five other chief executives serving under Mr. Weill.
Co-chief executives are a "dysfunctional business model," Mr. Crist said. At the helm of companies whose management has been widely lauded, like General Electric and Cisco Systems, he said, one person holds the wheel. "Look at the companies that have done well over time, and you find the benevolent dictator, the one person," whatever the proliferation of titles.
Several companies were reluctant to discuss why they had multiple chief executives under one roof. Among the few that would, most noted that their structures had not changed much in recent years.
For example, the News Corporation, a holding company that is the parent of media companies like Fox Television, has eight chief executives under the top chief executive, Rupert Murdoch. "There have always been C.E.O.'s," a company official said. "We're a diversified, international media company with lots of different lines of business, operating across a lot of different geographic boundaries, so it's natural that we're going to have separate operational structures."
In that case, the multiple titles probably make sense, argues Chris Dixon, an analyst who follows the News Corporation for PaineWebber. Like G.E.'s businesses, the News Corporation subsidiaries are very large.
Mr. Crist cited another reason for title inflation: executives in other countries need titles of sufficient grandeur to appear on an equal footing with local clients and the heads of local businesses.
"You must be a managing director in Germany to have any impact," he said. Changing a title may seem trivial, but in some cases it matters to people other than the holder.
Yet somehow Microsoft, one of the most valuable companies in the world, has only one chief executive -- and it is not Bill Gates.
Mr. Gates is now the chief software architect; the chief executive is Steven A. Ballmer.

HEADLINE: China's Generals 

 BODY:
The unyielding insistence on an American apology in the spy plane affair provides a revealing and disturbing picture of high-level decision-making in Beijing. China's actions betray not only a profound misreading of American politics, which might be understandable, but also a heavy reliance on the advice of Chinese military commanders, exactly the wrong group to shape the handling of this unfortunate incident. Despite yesterday's formal statement of regret by President Bush, the influence of the military leadership could delay a speedy resolution of the affair and distort the future course of relations between the United States and China. 
 The deliberations of China's leaders remain shielded from view at home and abroad, but the events since the midair collision of an American spy plane and a Chinese fighter jet 10 days ago offer important clues about the formulation of Beijing's response. The stamp of an assertive military seems evident in the rush to assign blame for the collision before the facts are established, the detention of the 24 American crew members and the stubborn effort to extract an apology from Washington when a reasonable diplomatic resolution is within reach. 
 Identifying a clear fault line between political and military leaders in Beijing in this case is impossible, and President Jiang Zemin has himself called for an apology. But China's military commanders in recent years have displayed a more distrustful and even hostile attitude toward the United States than the civilian leadership. 
In the current crisis, top military leaders may have found ready allies in the heads of the internal security agencies and some of the more ideologically conservative civilian party leaders. Public opinion, so far as it can be accurately measured in a totalitarian country, has also taken a strongly nationalist and anti-American tack. 
Defense officials and army newspapers have been uncompromising in their denunciations of Washington and their demands for an American apology. They have also insisted on an end to American reconnaissance flights near China's coasts. Military commanders may have sought to prolong the stalemate to allow time to dismantle and study the sophisticated American spy plane. That now appears to have been accomplished. But some military leaders want to go further, arguing that Washington's statements of regret for the loss of the Chinese airman have been insufficient.
Recent Chinese Communist history has left Beijing's military commanders as powerful political actors. Military leaders helped rescue China from the political and economic chaos of the Cultural Revolution in the late 1960's. In 1989 they were called in again to help crush the Tiananmen Square democracy movement. Partly as a result, the military has remained a significant political force. 
Mr. Jiang, his top diplomat, Qian Qichen, both now traveling in Latin America, and Prime Minister Zhu Rongji all understand that a prolonged impasse with Washington would hinder China's prospects for trade and economic development. Mr. Jiang said yesterday that the two sides needed to "find an adequate solution to this problem." Henry Kissinger, the former secretary of state, told CNN this week that on a visit to China just days before the midair collision he found the top political leaders eager to improve relations with the United States. Those aspirations can be realized if this dispute is quickly brought to a fair conclusion. That is a job for China's diplomats, not its generals.

HEADLINE: Standoff Brings Calls to Boycott Chinese Goods 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 10 

 BODY:
Kmart has received thousands of calls and e-mail messages from customers urging the discount retailer to stop buying so many of its shoes, fishing rods, T-shirts and stereos from China, prompting the company to warn Chinese diplomats that it will seek new suppliers unless the crew of an American surveillance aircraft is released promptly, company executives said today.
 The complaints that have streamed into Kmart's customer service line in Troy, Mich., in recent days were an unprecedented and apparently spontaneous response to the overseas crisis, the executives said. Store managers have also telephoned headquarters to relay concerns that customers were annoyed that the stores stocked so many "made in China" goods when American military personnel were being held in that country against their will, they said. 
 "Our customers are telling us to quit doing business in China -- that they're not going to buy things made there anymore," said Dale Apley, vice president for public policy. "These are just the people taking time out of their schedule to contact us. How many other people out there are thinking the same thing?" 
The outpouring of anger may indicate that the continuing standoff may have started to shake one of the foundations of the United States-China relationship: the partnership of trade and investment that has grown rapidly despite regular disruptions in bilateral ties during the last decade and a half.
Unlike China's bloody crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing in 1989 or its efforts to intimidate Taiwan by lobbing missiles off that island's coast five years ago, the current impasse directly affects United States military personnel. Business leaders said that made this crisis uniquely sensitive because the public put the safety of the crew above abstract notions of geopolitical stability or human rights for Chinese citizens. 
Like Wal-Mart, Target and other discount leaders, Kmart sells billions of dollars of Chinese-manufactured consumer goods each year. Total trade volumes have soared, and often, from month to month, the United States trade deficit with China tops the one with Japan. The most recent Commerce Department statistics showed that the United States trade deficit with China increased 19.3 percent in January, rising to $7.2 billion, while the deficit with Japan narrowed slightly, to $5.9 billion, the lowest in 13 months. 
Mr. Apley said Kmart had no plans to pull Chinese goods off its shelves and would like to continue to do business with factories there. But he said the customer response had prompted executives to put Chinese business contacts on notice that Kmart would have no choice but to "diversify its suppliers" unless the matter was resolved quickly. 
At Target Stores, based in Minneapolis, Patty Morris, a spokeswoman, said the company had decided not to answer media questions about customer complaints or product sourcing policies. She said that the company might have received a few calls related to the China standoff, but that the volume "was not alarming to us and does not warrant getting involved in the dialogue." 
Most corporate executives who have worked for years to cultivate cordial ties with Chinese officials are reluctant to say anything about the crisis in public, hoping that a low-key approach will encourage a speedy resolution that leaves few scars. United States companies accounted for almost half of the $40 billion in foreign investment in China last year, and many of the largest -- Boeing, Motorola and General Motors -- have declined comment or said talks should be left to diplomats.
But some business leaders in Washington share Kmart's alarm. Lobbyists here say they worry that the detention of the crew will make it hard to hold back a tide of anti-China sentiment. "We have been the most vocal advocates of open and expanded trade with China," said Thomas Donohue, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce. "But we are going to support these young men and women being held over there. If this goes on much longer, the economic advances are going to be hard to sustain."
The crisis is so sensitive that some Chinese-American business leaders have expressed rare public opposition to China's diplomatic behavior.
Susan Au Allen, head of the United States Pan-Asian Chamber of Commerce, a group of Asian-American business executives, said she wrote a letter to the Chinese Embassy today saying her group had decided to cancel a May meeting on investment opportunities with Chinese trade officials in Washington.
"There is a glaring difference between this crisis and all the other issues with China because they are holding Americans against their will," said Ms. Allen, who was born in Guangzhou. "China does not need any more excuses. They have to grow up and act like big boys."
Unlike the fight in Congress last year over whether to grant China permanent normal trade relations, when the battle resonated only lightly outside the capital, the current standoff appears to have set off a grass-roots response that could affect the way Washington reacts.
Recent polls have found that a majority of people consider the military detainees to be hostages, though the Bush administration has not used that term. The polls also show that a majority do not want the administration to apologize for the incident.
Mr. Apley of Kmart said the company at first suspected that the volume of complaints indicated that an anti-China group had begun an organized campaign, but company officials found no evidence of that.
Still, some unions that have opposed expanding trade ties with China are using this as an opportunity to drive home their message. 
The United Association of Union Plumbers, Pipefitters and Sprinkler Fitters has devoted $500,000 to buy radio advertisements during baseball games around the country urging a boycott. "The crew of an American plane, forced to make an emergency landing in China, is held hostage by the Chinese government," the commercial says. "Think about that. And vow to buy no Chinese products until the servicemen and women are released."

HEADLINE: Prudential Sues A.I.G. on Merger Meddling 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER 

DATELINE: LONDON, April 10 

 BODY:
Beginning a counterattack in the battle for the American General Corporation, the British insurer Prudential P.L.C. sued American International Group today, seeking to halt negotiations between the two American companies.
 American International Group, meanwhile, said today that it had signed a confidentiality agreement with American General and had begun discussions on a $23 billion takeover. 
 Prudential's suit, filed in state district court in Harris County, Tex., where American General is based, says that A.I.G. violated United States securities law and that it made "false and misleading statements" in offering a competing bid for American General last week, after Prudential had signed an agreement to merge with the company. The American General board voted Monday night to begin negotiations with A.I.G., which is based in New York. 
"Other companies are free to make a bid," said Victor Lewkow, a lawyer with Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton in New York, which is litigating the case for Prudential. "But our point is you have to play by the rules."
A.I.G. declined to comment.
American General shares rose 63 cents, to $42.75, on the New York Stock Exchange, while A.I.G. rose 90 cents, to $77.08. In London, Prudential shares slipped 12 pence, to 775 pence ($11.14). Prudential has no ties to the Prudential Insurance Company of America.
Several analysts and legal experts characterized the suit as more spitfire than heavy artillery since Prudential said last week that it would not increase its bid for American General. That bid is now worth $40.70 a share, less than A.I.G.'s offer of $41.60 a share.
"Prudential needs to show they are making a vigorous defense of their merger," said Roman Cizdyn, an analyst with Merrill Lynch in London. "But I don't think it's a goer."
In making its claims, Prudential is not without precedent. In a landmark 1987 case, a Texas jury ordered Texaco to pay Penzoil $10.5 billion for interfering in Penzoil's plans to merge with Getty Oil. Though the remuneration was reduced to $3 billion, the judgment eventually forced Texaco to file for bankruptcy. The Texas courts have since refined the notion of "tortious interference," an ambiguous concept that generally means wrongful meddling and was Penzoil's chief legal argument against Texaco. A Texas Supreme Court ruling last month in Wal-Mart v. Sturges now requires plaintiffs to prove that a third party, in addition to meddling, has broken the law in its attempt to gate-crash.
"You can no longer automatically associate Texas with a verdict like Texaco v. Penzoil," said Henry Hu, a corporate law professor at the University of Texas School of Law in Austin. "The Wal-Mart case introduces a burden on plaintiffs that wasn't there before."
Prudential, which seeks both undisclosed financial damages and a restraining order against A.I.G., says it meets those new requirements, contending that in failing to file certain documents with the Securities and Exchange Commission, like a transcript of a conference call with analysts, A.I.G. broke the law. A preliminary hearing is scheduled next Tuesday.
Regardless of the merits of the case, most legal experts say the suit will make little difference beyond insuring that Prudential pockets its $600 million in breakup fees. "The market forces and economics will dictate who ends up owning American General," said John Cambria, co-chairman of litigation for the international law firm Salans. "This lawsuit is very unlikely to affect the outcome." 

CORRECTION-DATE: April 16, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Wednesday about bids for American General, the life insurance company, misstated the value of an offer from American International Group. Based on its recent stock price, A.I.G.'s offer is worth about $46 a share, not $41.60.
