HEADLINE: Motorola Reports Weakness In the Growth of Its Orders 

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
Investors hoping that the slumping economy is about to turn the corner did not get any encouragement from Motorola, which reported late yesterday that order growth had weakened across all sectors of the company in the first quarter. Motorola said it lost $206 million, or 9 cents a share, excluding special charges, in the three-month period.
 Motorola shares had risen $1.50, to $13 in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange before the earnings were released in anticipation that the company would at least meet Wall Street's expectations of a loss no worse than 8 cents a share. 
 Revenues also came in lower than Wall Street expected at $7.75 billion, down 11 percent from the $8.75 billion Motorola reported in the quarter a year ago. In after-hours trading, the stock retreated 7.3 percent, to $12.05. 
Motorola, which is based in Schaumburg, Ill., has historically been a bellwether stock because its telecommunications products and electronic components are used in so many industries and it is among the first large companies to report each quarter. In addition, weaknesses at Motorola have turned out to be early warnings of broader problems in several technology sectors in recent quarters.
"We see a continuing downturn in the U.S. economy beginning to spill over to the rest of the world," Christopher B. Galvin, Motorola's chairman and chief executive, said.
Analysts said last night that it would be difficult to assess the full effect of yesterday's report until Motorola's conference call, scheduled for this morning.
"The question is whether they will say anything to alter our overall impression that there is no visibility going forward and that business is bad," said Barbara G. Marcin, manager of the Gabelli Blue Chip Value Fund, a mutual fund with 110,000 Motorola shares.
Motorola's biggest unit, its cellular phone business, had sales of $2.3 billion, down 29 percent from a year ago. New orders were $2.8 billion, a milder drop of 10 percent, offering a faint hope that the worst was over, some analysts said. But the business lost $402 million, in contrast to a $53 million operating profit in the first quarter of 2000.
Semiconductors were the other hard-hit segment, with sales off 22 percent from last year, to $1.5 billion, and new orders plunging 47 percent, to $1.1 billion. The $131 million operating loss for the business was in contrast to an operating profit of $128 million in the period a year ago.
Motorola's phone network equipment business also suffered declining sales and orders, but it managed to stay profitable with earnings of $54 million. The radio systems segment managed to book increased sales and orders, but profits fell to $56 million from $96 million a year ago as more of the business was in low-margin products and services.
The smallest unit, broadband communications, was the only group to report increases in sales, orders and profits, but the growth was well below some analysts expectations.
Motorola had earned $481 million, or 21 cents a share, in the first quarter of 2000. The recent three months were the first quarter since 1985 that Motorola had lost money on operations.
The report would have been even bleaker if Motorola had not switched to a new accounting method widely used to dress up technology company earnings. For the first time, Motorola is joining the technology industry trend of issuing its earnings on a "pro forma" basis. The new accounting approach allows Motorola to exclude charges related to the difference between the book value of acquired companies and the higher price Motorola paid for them. If Motorola had stayed with its traditional accounting system, it would have reported a loss of $533 million, or 24 cents a share, for the quarter.
The bad news was scarcely a surprise. Motorola had warned Wall Street in February that the quarter was unfolding in disappointing fashion, with both the cellular phone business and semiconductor operations posting poorer-than-expected results.
Robert L. Growney, president and chief operating officer, said at the time that Motorola's problems were also afflicting its rivals and that the company was not losing market share, a claim that many analysts disagree with.
Motorola was once the clear leader in the cellular phone market but it was late to make the transition from analog to digital phones and subsequently bet too heavily on expensive, full-featured phones at a time when consumers wanted cheaper models. Nokia grabbed the market lead in the late 1990's and, by most analysts' reckoning, has been widening its advantage ever since.
Some analysts had projected otherwise a year ago when Motorola reported strong earnings growth as worldwide demand for cellular products surged. They said that the company had hot new products and had finally become a savvy enough marketer to fight back effectively.
"But they had execution problems," said Brian T. Modoff, who follows the company from San Francisco for Deutsche Banc Alex Brown. "The question is still, 'Can they get the phones into the market?' "
The weakness in the cellular phone business hurts Motorola twice since the phone units are major customers of the company's semiconductor group.
Concerns about Motorola reached a new peak late last week on reports that business had weakened to the point that the company faced a liquidity squeeze. After shares tumbled to a 52-week low of $10.50 on Friday, Motorola responded by strongly denying that any such crisis was in the offing. As of that day, Motorola said, it had more than $4.5 billion in cash and cash equivalents and short-term debts of $3.1 billion.
Mr. Growney stressed in releasing the financial results today that the company had increased its cash reserves during the quarter through a combination of revenues from operations and asset sales.
The company also stressed that it had been taking a number of steps to bolster its cash reserves, including cutbacks in capital spending and work force reductions. Since December, Motorola has announced a series of cutbacks and sales of operations that are set to eliminate 22,000 positions from a global work force of 147,000.

HEADLINE: Moody's Earnings to Beat Estimates 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
The bond-rating agency and financial firm Moody's Corporation said yesterday that it expected first-quarter earnings to exceed analysts' consensus estimates, driven by revenue growth in all its business lines and recent cuts in interest rates.
 Moody's, which also announced a management shakeout and whose investor unit admitted guilt in an obstruction of justice case, said it expected earnings per share for the quarter to top analysts' estimates of 24 cents a share. 
 Moody's -- whose investor service unit yesterday admitted guilt to a criminal charge arising from the destruction of documents in a 1996 antitrust inquiry -- said it expected first-quarter revenue to be 25 to 30 percent higher from a year ago. 
The president and chief executive of Moody's, John Rutherfurd Jr., told investors in a conference call the company had agreed to pay a fine of $195,000 to settle the case with the Justice Department and described the incident as "isolated."
A Moody's employee had destroyed documents related to a civil subpoena issued by the Justice Department in connection with its investigation of suspected anticompetitive practices in the bond rating services industry in 1996.
"This settlement is in the best interest of the company and our shareholders," Mr. Rutherfurd said.
He said the matter did not relate to Moody's credit ratings, analyses, risk management or any other services the company markets to customers throughout the world.
The New York-based company expected diluted earnings per share in the range of 29 to 30 cents and pro forma diluted earnings per share in the range of 28 to 29 cents.
In the quarter to March 31, 2000, Moody's had posted diluted earnings per share of 22 cents and pro forma diluted earnings per share of 20 cents.
Mr. Rutherfurd added that Moody's did not expect any regulatory action from regulatory authorities that could affect the company's business after the case. The Department of Justice's antitrust unit rested its investigation in 1999 without taking any legal action.
Mr. Rutherfurd also said he would assume responsibility of Moody's global corporate finance business and the U.S. public finance business after the resignation of three senior executives, effective May 15.
Those who resigned were Donald Noe, senior vice president global ratings and research; Kenneth Pinkes, senior vice president and credit officer; and Douglas Watson, group managing director public finance.
Mr. Rutherfurd said none of the three had been involved in the destruction of documents case.
But he added that "issues arose regarding the timeliness of the executives' reporting of information relating to the conduct by another employee underlying the government's charges."
Moody's is scheduled to report its first-quarter results on April 18. Its shares closed up 87 cents, or 3.09 percent, at $29.05.

HEADLINE: A Step Backward on Nuclear Cooperation 

BYLINE:  By Michael McFaul; Michael McFaul is a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and an assistant professor at Stanford University.

DATELINE: CHICAGO 

 BODY:
President Bush and his new foreign policy team have announced that they plan to undertake a full review of all aspects of American policy toward Russia on matters like economic assistance, NATO expansion and missile defense. There must be a new agenda, we are told, because the old approach of cooperation and engagement pursued by the Clinton administration has been ineffective. In hinting at the tone of their new policy, Bush administration officials have promised a realist approach, which would presumably include greater attention to Russia's international conduct and less to reforms within Russia.
 Reviews are necessary and rethinking of policies prudent. But why, before the review is completed, has the administration already announced plans to cut cooperative nonproliferation programs between the United States and Russia? Perhaps, after a thorough reassessment, the Bush team could make the case that the cooperative programs that we now sponsor in Russia and other former Soviet republics do not serve American national security interests. Until such a case can be made, however, the proposal to cut these programs by $100 million, or more than 10 percent, from current financing levels is bad policy and worse as symbolism. True realism on the part of the Bush foreign policy team would mean increasing, not decreasing, the size of these efforts. 
 Even two decades ago, it would have been unthinkable for Country A to pay Country B to destroy its weapons. But that is precisely what American-Russian nonproliferation programs have achieved in the past several years. With the end of the cold war, Russian leaders -- committed to greater cooperation with the West -- allowed the United States to pursue our national security interests by new, nontraditional means. In 1991, the idea that we could pay the Russians to deactivate nuclear delivery systems, enhance the storage and security of nuclear materials and keep their nuclear scientists employed was radical. It showed real leadership that George H. W. Bush, who was then the president, embraced this new approach as part of a national security strategy. 
A decade later, cooperative threat reduction is widely accepted. A bipartisan review commission headed by former Senator Howard Baker fully endorses the idea, and Democrats and Republicans vote year after year to finance these programs. And President Vladimir Putin and the Russian army continue to participate willingly in them. Indeed, Mr. Putin's recent firing of the conservative head of the Ministry of Atomic Energy suggests that he might be prepared to go even further to restructure the Russian nuclear complex.
Promoting nonproliferation programs in Russia, of course, directly benefits American national security. The fewer delivery systems of nuclear weapons there are in Russia, the better; the more securely and safely stored are those nuclear materials, the better. If the Bush administration is prepared to spend tens of billions of dollars on missile defense systems to protect Americans against potential threats in the future, it cannot justify cutting the already modest budget for nonproliferation programs that help diminish a real threat in existence today.
These programs are also crucial to maintaining open channels between the United States and Russia at a time when other opportunities for cooperation are disappearing. Without question, Mr. Putin's negative activities in other areas -- whether stifling the independent press or trading weapons with Iran -- will make it more difficult to have meaningful and positive relations. In fact, cuts in some assistance programs to the Russian state (though not to Russian civil society, as in programs that support the development of an independent press) may be appropriate. But reducing nonproliferation programs as a reaction to objectionable Russian behavior in other areas makes no sense and is contrary to American security interests.
Ten years after the Soviet Union's collapse, it is remarkable that the decaying Russian state has not allowed more weapons of mass destruction out of Russia and that there have not been more accidents with nuclear materials. Yet, these threats to American security must not be underestimated. We should in fact be accelerating aid to dismantle this threat, not reversing course. At a time when there appear to be growing strategic conflicts between the United States and Russia, we cannot afford to undercut the one area where there is agreement and cooperation.

HEADLINE: Bush Seeking To Modify Pact on Trade With Jordan 

BYLINE:  By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 10 

 BODY:
President Bush told King Abdullah II of Jordan today that enacting a free trade agreement between the United States and Jordan was one of the White House's top trade priorities. But he indicated that provisions negotiated by the Clinton administration to safeguard workers' rights and the environment might require readjustment.
 During a meeting in the Oval Office, the two leaders devoted much of their discussion to the swelling violence between the Israelis and Palestinians. A senior administration official said Mr. Bush and King Abdullah had agreed that both sides needed to scale down the cycle of violence. 
 Still, the king was visiting in part to urge the United States to remain involved in Middle East peace negotiations and to convince Israel that a military response would not lead the Palestinians to the negotiating table. 
"I look forward to working with you, sir, and with your administration to try and bring peace and stability to the Middle East," the king told the president.
Jordan, which borders Israel and the West Bank, has a population that is roughly half Palestinian. The country has long played a major role in promoting Middle East peace efforts, and American officials see the trade agreement as an important step in jump-starting the struggling economy of the region.
Trade between the two countries is tiny, in relative terms. The United States sells Jordan less than $300 million in goods each year. But the trade deal reached between Jordan and the Clinton administration, which would eliminate all tariffs on trade, is significant beyond the numbers. 
It is the first American trade initiative that included labor and environmental standards as part of the main text, putting the rights of workers and the duty of companies not to pollute on the same plane with tariffs.
King Abdullah signed the agreement at a White House ceremony last October, as the Clinton administration was coming to a close. During the presidential campaign, Al Gore praised the labor and environmental agreements in the Jordan deal, but Mr. Bush expressed reservations.
It is not without precedent for a new administration to reopen a trade agreement signed by a predecessor.
Mr. Bush's father signed the North American Free Trade Agreement, or Nafta, with Canada and Mexico in the closing weeks of his administration. But his successor, Bill Clinton, pursued side agreements to address concerns of labor unions and environmental groups.
In a meeting much like the one that Mr. Bush held today with King Abdullah, Mr. Clinton reassured President Carlos Salinas of Mexico in 1993 that the United States would pursue Nafta, but only after additional negotiations.
In a brief appearance with reporters today, Mr. Bush did not detail his reservations about the deal reached by Mr. Clinton. But officials indicated that the White House was concerned about the precedent that the labor and environmental agreements might have on future trade agreements. 
The officials said Robert Zoellick, Mr. Bush's trade representative, was pursuing a compromise that he hoped would get the pact through the closely divided House and Senate.
Not everybody believes that the deal struck by Mr. Clinton requires change. "This agreement is good, as is," said Mike Siegel, a spokesman for Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana. "There may be some who have expressed concern, but they don't have much traction right now."
In his meeting today, the president reassured the king that he intended to reach a deal. It was the king's father, King Hussein, who died in 1999, who first pressed for more open trade with the United States.
"We look forward to working to get an agreement, one way or the other, out of our Congress, that encourages free trade with Jordan," the president said at the start of the meeting. "We will be discussing strategies as how best to achieve that objective."
In a television interview on Monday night, the king described his country's economic woes as critical. 
"For our country the priority is the economy -- getting, as I've said from day one, food on the table," the king said on PBS. "We have problems with poverty. We have problems with unemployment. If we are going to progress, if we are going to move forward on political reforms and economic reforms, we have to make the economy of paramount importance."

HEADLINE: Freezing Government 

 BODY:
President Bush described the budget he unveiled Monday as a "new way of doing business in Washington" that faithfully reflected the "compassionate conservatism" he espoused during his campaign. The budget was compassionate in one sense. It did not contain the harsh language that earlier Republican administrations and the Newt Gingrich crowd used to describe the federal role. The Bush team has obviously learned the virtues of speaking softly. Basic services will survive and no departments will be eliminated. Yet a careful reading of the fine print does little to dispel the impression that on the whole the budget's conservatism outweighs its compassion, even though there are some surprising cuts in corporate welfare in the form of budget reductions for the Export-Import Bank and for shipbuilding subsidies. But in general this is a business-friendly budget with a lean, carefully targeted approach to spending on social programs. 
 The compassion component comes in the form of increases for a few of Mr. Bush's favorite programs, including education and biomedical research. The White House asserts that over all, the education budget jumped 11 percent, the health budget 5 percent. The education budget would contain modest increases for poor children and for upgrading reading skills. The health budget provides a large boost for the National Institutes of Health, more money for community health centers and a new prescription drug benefit for the elderly. But the $153 billion over 10 years planned for prescription drugs is only about a half to a third of what most experts believe the program will ultimately require. 
 The conservatism of this budget is largely defined by the $1.6 trillion tax cut that lies at its heart -- a cut so large that little money is left over for significant new spending on discretionary social programs. These programs will total $660 billion in the next fiscal year, a rise of only 4 percent compared with an 8.6 percent increase in President Clinton's last budget year. Given inflation, this essentially freezes government at its present level.
The budget is not without some political daring. There were cuts in various farming programs that may make sense in budgetary terms but will not sit well with Midwestern Republicans. There was also a big cut in the transportation budget that may not sit well with Eastern Republicans who favor subsidies for urban mass transit. Yet the biggest and potentially most controversial cuts were in energy, natural resources and the environment.
Environmentalists will detect no compassion in the approach to their issues. A series of budget cuts reflect the administration's hostility to the land conservation programs pursued by the Clinton administration as well as its pro-business attitudes toward environmental and other regulations. They also reflect Mr. Bush's willfully one-sided approach to the nation's energy needs, which relies almost exclusively on drilling for oil and gas while ignoring conservation. Energy Department funds for research into alternative fuel sources and more efficient vehicles would drop by nearly half. Meanwhile, funding for Interior Department programs for oil, gas and coal exploration would increase by nearly 20 percent. Perversely, the budget says that some of the money for alternative-fuel research will be restored by 2004 -- but only with money earned by the government from oil leases in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.
Other environmental programs take comparable hits. Mr. Bush proposes to save $162 million by eliminating one of the Agriculture Department's most useful conservation initiatives, the Wetlands Reserve program. The president made good on his campaign pledge to fully fund the Land and Water Conservation program at $900 million, but the $100 million he promised to spend on saving the world's tropical forests has shrunk to $13 million.
Congress, of course, will have much to say about the ultimate shape of the budget, and votes in the Senate last week have already indicated a desire to devote considerably less to tax reduction and considerably more to social programs. But as a guide to the new administration's core approach -- moderate in tone, conservative in substance -- the new budget is revelatory.

HEADLINE: On-Site Service: Lots of Talk to Get Some Action 

BYLINE:  By CATHERINE GREENMAN 

 BODY:
AS an owner of several Gateway computers, Phil Kirschner had been pleased with the company's technical support. Mr. Kirschner, a New Yorker who does public relations work out of his home, found that when he had problems, they were usually related to software, and that he was able to get the help he needed over the phone. 
 But when he bought a new Gateway Select 950 computer last October and heard what he described as churning and clicking noises the first time he turned it on, he called technical support right away. He had purchased a three-year on-site warranty for $99, so he assumed that someone would come to his house to fix the problem. 
 Instead, Mr. Kirschner spent several hours over five days on the phone with tech support representatives. Each time he called, he said, he was instructed to test and reformat his hard drive and reinstall the drivers. 
"I had to call like eight times," Mr. Kirschner said. "All of the problems I was having were in part related to the hard drive, but they weren't willing to go on site. The tech guy would say, Go to safe mode, do this, do that, but nothing worked."
At one point, Mr. Kirschner held the phone up to the back of the computer so the technician could hear the churning sounds emanating from the hard drive. It was an absurd moment, but it paid off because it persuaded the technician to send someone. Three days later a repair person arrived at Mr. Kirschner's house with a new hard drive. 
But Mr. Kirschner said the process had taken too long. "I felt ripped off in the sense that I paid $99 for a promise of immediate repair," he said, "and I got a long wait and a lot of down time." 
On-site service agreements, which are offered by computer stores and by manufacturers that sell directly to consumers, like Dell, Gateway and Micron, offer peace of mind to computer users who worry about something going wrong. Sold for about $79 and up depending on length (generally from one to five years), the agreements promise that a support technician will come to the customer's home or office by the next business day to fix the problem. 
But even though many consumers get the quick help they need, others, like Mr. Kirschner, say that actually getting a repair person to travel to the computer can be difficult, involving hours on the phone (much of it on hold) and poorly trained technicians. The service delays can extend well beyond the next-business-day promise. 
"Next-business-day, on-site service really isn't that in most instances," said Tim Duffy, a consumer advocate in Los Angeles who publishes consumer information on his Web site (www.timduffy.com). "You have to convince them that you need the part, which can take hours on the phone. And many things, like software -- and in some cases, keyboards, monitors and mice -- are not covered in the on-site agreement at all." For example, Mr. Duffy noted, Hewlett-Packard's on-site agreement covers peripherals like keyboards, while Micron's agreement does not.
For many people, the first hurdle is diagnosing the problem with a technician over the phone. As someone who has logged many hours with technical support representatives on behalf of her clients, Sarah Williams, a computer consultant in Santa Fe, N.M., said the process had gotten much more frustrating in the last year because of what seems to be a lack of experience on the part of technicians.
"Lately, the people I'm talking to seem to be fresh out of school with no experience at all," she said. "I spend an hour going through things they read off of some script before they pass me on to a supervisor." 
PC manufacturers say troubleshooting over the phone is a necessary step in determining whether a technician needs to make a house call. In its agreement for at-home service, Dell says a technician will be dispatched if necessary after troubleshooting is done via phone.
"In order to effect a fix when we do dispatch someone on site, we have to accurately diagnose the problem on the front end," said Dan Allen, Dell's director of client-services marketing for homes and small businesses. "That's got to involve interactions with the customer." 
Jim Hobby, vice president for client care at Gateway, said the diagnostic questions asked over the phone also helped rule out problems with software or peripherals that were not installed on the system when it was sold. "Sometimes customers would like us to support things that should really be supported by another manufacturer," he said. "Often it's like looking for a needle in a haystack, but we're using tools to greatly narrow it down." 
To expedite solutions to computer problems and to reduce the time customers and technicians spend on the phone, computer companies like Gateway, Dell and Micron have designed Web-based programs that let users log on and have their problems diagnosed by the software before they call technical representatives. 
Micron's Connected Support program, for example, which has been available to consumers for the last year and a half, performs an "asset profile" on a system and automatically alerts the user about any driver updates or patches for hardware and software conflicts. Paul Desmond, a product reviews manager at Micron, said the program had reduced the number of calls to Micron's tech support staff.
Dell's Resolution Assistant, which the company started including with all its systems in August 2000, lets customers connect online with a Dell technician who can remotely discern whether the problem is a hardware failure or a conflict between the operating system and software. "Seventy to ninety percent of the time, customers should be able to go online and fix the problem themselves," Mr. Allen said. "It gets them up and running much more quickly than if we dispatched someone to the house." 
In many cases, however, these Internet- and phone-based diagnostic tools succeed only in annoying many customers with on-site agreements. Dave Gill, who worked as a tech support specialist with Gateway for five years, until last September, said he had often fielded complaints about people's expectations for on-site service. "We ran into a lot of situations where a client would call and demand on-site service," he said, "but they didn't want to do any troubleshooting first because sales had said that that's the way it would work." 
Service delays are common when a PC manufacturer hires another company to provide technical support. That was the problem encountered by Noreen Norris, a bookkeeper in San Diego, when her computer's motherboard failed in January. She first worked with Dell over the phone, trying to determine why Windows would not start on her new desktop. Ms. Norris said that Dell then arranged for a technician from BancTec, a local service center, to replace her motherboard, but that he had arrived with the wrong part. Getting the right part took several more days. "Every time I'd call," Ms. Norris said, "the guy at BancTec would complain that they were low on technicians and that they'd have to fly someone in. They'd make appointments and not keep them." 
Mr. Allen, of Dell, said that service delays usually happened because a part was not available. "If your system has a hard drive which is not available in the market, sending an on-site technician is not productive," he said. "That the technician can't come is generally not an issue for us."
Another common misunderstanding among people with on-site service agreements is that if a technician does arrive to fix a hardware problem, it is up to the customer to replace any lost data or files.
"If they repair your hard disk, your data still needs to be restored," said Christopher Muto, an independent computer consultant in New York. "I have had people who have had service calls, and they're sitting there scratching their heads wondering what to do next." 
Complaints about on-site service have surfaced on manufacturers' Web sites and at consumer complaint sites like eComplaints.com. In July 1998, Gateway paid the Federal Trade Commission $290,000 to settle a case after the agency accused Gateway of misrepresenting its refund policy and on-site warranty service in its advertisements. Gateway was prohibited from promising on-site service without disclosing the service's limitations. 
Wayne Harris, director of research investigations at the New York State Consumer Protection Board, said he did not see a lot of complaints about on-site service agreements, which made him think that PC owners were eventually getting the help they needed. "Generally the complaints we get are from consumers who have been promised something that they're not getting," he said. "In this case, they're probably getting the service but having to argue for it on the phone first, so it's probably slower than they thought it would be." 
After waiting nearly three weeks to have her motherboard replaced through her on-site agreement, Ms. Norris said she would buy her next computer from a local dealer so she could pack it up and take it in if something went wrong. "There might be pluses to having on-site warranties," she said, "but you have to have a ton of time on your hands if you want service." 

Service Tips
Before You Call: Things to Know About Guarantees
WHEN you call a manufacturer's technical support department for troubleshooting, ask a few questions to find out how much the person you are talking to knows about computers. 
"You don't want to be talking to someone who's using a book and just looking things up," said Tim Duffy, a consumer advocate in Los Angeles. If you are not satisfied that the person helping you has the necessary expertise, ask to speak with someone else. 
Here are some tips for getting the most out of a service agreement:
* Write down the names of every technician you speak with, as well as the dates and times of each call. Ask for an incident report number before you hang up because that will speed up things the next time you call. 
* If the technician tries to fix the problem over the phone, record the conversation (to insure compliance with any federal or state laws, inform the person that you are doing so). Then you can refer to the tape rather than having to call back if you forget a step.
* Be flexible in the hours you can be present for a technician to make a house call. Jim Hobby, vice president for client care at Gateway, says it is crucial that the person who uses the computer is present. 
* When you first start your computer, leave it on for 72 hours because heat is one of the biggest causes of problems with electronic equipment and you usually have full return privileges if a problem arises this early. 
* Most gold and platinum credit cards will double the warranty offered by a manufacturer for something bought with this kind of card, for a maximum extra coverage period of one year. That makes it more economical to sign up for one year of on-site service for a computer or other gadget and to double the warranty by buying it with a gold or platinum credit card, rather than signing up for two or more years of on-site service. 
 CATHERINE GREENMAN

HEADLINE: Argentina May Peg Peso To Euro as Well as Dollar 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, April 11 

 BODY:
Argentina will overhaul a main pillar of its economic structure, the peg of the peso to the United States dollar, and bring euros into the equation, according to the economy minister, Domingo Cavallo.
 In a speech today in Paris and in several others recently, Mr. Cavallo, the architect of the "currency board" system that has kept the peso equal to $1 since April 1991, has outlined a plan to switch to a half-dollar and half-euro peg in two to three years. Eventually, the Japanese yen may be added as well. 
 "Our economic relations, commercial and financial, with Europe have more relevance each day," Mr. Cavallo said today. "For that reason the incorporation of the euro into our financial system is appropriate."
The exchange rate system is at the heart of a debate over how to revive an economy that has been mired in recession for three years. Some economists say fixed peso-dollar parity locks in high prices and wages and makes exports noncompetitive. Others say scrapping it would ignite inflation and make the national debt, most of it owed in dollars and other foreign currency, ruinously difficult to repay.
Mr. Cavallo proposed shifting away from a dollar-only peg while he was in opposition. But when he was appointed to the cabinet three weeks ago and given extraordinary powers to attack economic problems, he was at pains to say there was no question of abandoning the peg.
Some investors worry that the dollar-euro peg plan is a devaluation in disguise. At present exchange rates, linking the peso in equal parts to the two currencies would reduce its value 5.8 percent, to 94.2 American cents. 
But Mr. Cavallo has said in recent speeches that the peso would not be shifted to a new formula if doing so would devalue it and that the euro would first have to gain value.
"I hope Cavallo isn't holding his breath," said Russell Jones, chief currency strategist at Lehman Brothers in London. 
Mr. Cavallo's push for a mixed dollar-euro peg may be meant to head off a campaign led by a former president, Carlos Saul Menem, in whose cabinet Mr. Cavallo served a decade ago, to scrap the peso entirely and adopt the dollar instead, eliminating all risk of devaluation.
As preliminary steps, Mr. Cavallo's plan calls for allowing Argentines to open euro-denominated bank accounts and carry out financial transactions in euros.

HEADLINE: In a Surprise, Central Bank Sees No Need To Cut Rates 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, April 11 

 BODY:
In a surprising display of defiance, the European Central Bank declined to reduce interest rates today and suggested that it might not do so any time soon.
 The decision caught many investors and economists by surprise because the central bank was widely expected to reduce rates by at least a quarter-point. It came despite calls for the bank to cut rates to help fend off a global economic downturn. 
 Today's announcement reinforces the solitary position of the European Central Bank as the only major central bank that has not eased monetary policy, and it represents a calculated gamble that Europe's prospects will remain much healthier than those of the United States. 
Even more striking than the decision itself was the tough language in the announcement by the bank's president, Wim Duisenberg. 
Mr. Duisenberg said the consensus was so strong on the bank's central council that members did not bother taking a vote. He also predicted that European inflation would not decline below the bank's target of 2 percent a year for at least another 18 months.
"Upward risks to price stability have diminished, but they have not disappeared," Mr. Duisenberg said at a news conference after the bank's board meeting. "The disappearance of medium-term inflation doesn't mean the European Central Bank needs to cut interest rates now."
In declining to nudge economic growth with an injection of easier money, Mr. Duisenberg brushed aside pleas from a range of European economists and political leaders as well as the head of the International Monetary Fund.
Adolf Rosenstock, an economist in London at the investment bank Nomura International, said, "The E.C.B. is taking a big gamble, and the gamble is that they are entirely wrong with respect to their expectations for growth and inflation in the euro area." 
"If they are wrong," Mr. Rosenstock said, "they will be rightly blamed for having missed the opportunity to steer the European economy to safer waters."
Other experts, though also surprised, said the economic climate in Europe was ambiguous enough to justify a hard-line approach.
Phillipe D'Arvisenet, chief economist with BNP Paribas in Paris, said that the 12-nation euro zone was still expanding by more than 2 percent a year, not much below what economists consider the region's long-term potential growth rate. And the most recent inflation data suggested that inflation was still running at 2.6 percent a year.
"Core inflation has been creeping up, gently, but creeping up nonetheless," Mr. D'Arvisenet said today.
Stefan Schneider, an economist with Deutsche Bank Research in Frankfurt, had been expecting a fairly big reduction in interest rates, to 4.25 percent from 4.75 percent.
"To some extent, they want to avoid the impression that they bowed to external pressure," Mr. Schneider said today. "They want to build a reputation that they are really tough cookies."
Today's decision suggested that hard-liners, led by Mr. Duisenberg and the Bundesbank in Germany, had consolidated their position on the central bank's board.
Three weeks ago, several central bankers surprised investors by hinting at a new and softer economic policy. Jean-Claude Trichet, president of the Bank of France and a member of the central bank board, announced that the bank was much less concerned than before about inflation and more worried about an economic slowdown.
But Mr. Duisenberg and other board members quickly began to dampen hopes of easier money, insisting that the central bank was still worried about inflation and would pursue its wait-and-see policy.
In what looked remarkably like a public chastisement, Mr. Trichet was ordered to read a statement from Mr. Duisenberg on March 30, in which the more hard-line views were reaffirmed.
Today, Mr. Duisenberg made it clear that he was not ready to reduce rates any time soon. He told reporters that the bank had "no bias" toward either raising or lowering rates, which contradicted the assumptions of most economists and central bank watchers.
"Upward risks to price stability have diminished, but they have not disappeared," Mr. Duisenberg said at today's news conference. Disputing analysts who worry that an American slowdown could drag Europe with it, Mr. Duisenberg said that growth here remained solid.

HEADLINE: DESIGN NOTEBOOK: FURNITURE FAIR; 
In Milan, Form Follows Fashion

BYLINE:  By JULIE V. IOVINE 

DATELINE: MILAN 

 BODY:
LAST week, at the 40th annual International Milan Furniture Fair, the world's premier modern furniture exhibition, design and fashion paired off in a flamboyant tango. The trends flew like so many sparks from clicking heels -- passion shades of pink on orange, glossy metals and lean curves. Worn by a supermodel or by a divan -- it no longer matters.
 "Designers and architects have a lot to learn from fashion," said John Pawson, the London architect, who is designing a new Calvin Klein shop in Paris. "They shouldn't be so blinkered. Haven't they cottoned on that things have changed? It isn't just about making designs to last a thousand years." 
 Nowhere was fashion's pumped-up energy more evident than at an architecture exhibition by Prada, showing off projects in the works by Rem Koolhaas and Herzog & de Meuron. Visitors milled around architectural models and tables as long as Olympic pools piled with unusually treated building materials like latticed resin walls and foam shelving. Meanwhile, house music throbbed and videos of Prada's shoe collection flashed above a concrete catwalk. 
"This is the year fashion swallowed design whole," said Deyan Sudjic, editor of Domus, the Italian design magazine. "And after wanting fashion's attention for ages, design is already starting to regret it."
Even as design and fashion cozied up, the spectacle of Pucci-clad swivel chairs, rhinestone sofas and ceramic vases zippered in leather left some wondering whether the pair made a good match at all. "It's a total disaster from an intellectual point of view," said Vico Magistretti, a patriarch of Italian design. "In the 60's, we tried to design concepts because they did something that needed to be done. Now it's all styling."
The style spree has apparently not been stalled by looming economic setbacks. Financial worries were not in evidence at the six-day fair, which ended on Monday and was attended by 175,000 people, 6 percent more than last year. And Americans seem more entranced than ever with Italian contemporary design: Italian furniture imports to the United States rose 21.9 percent in 2000, with Americans spending more than $920 million, second only to Germany.
Milan saw more flash than form-making. The mood was giddy and more preoccupied than ever with the next big thing, even if it was a no-show.
But while slick surface decorations and stylized silhouettes grabbed the public's eye, the designers themselves were trying to decide how best to harness new technologies and unconventional materials like polyester films that shift between transparency and opacity, according to the angle of view, and quartz surfaces in intensely luminous colors.
One season of fabulousness will probably be the shelf life of some fashion-sensitive offerings. Pink and orange stretch plaids and blowsy pink and red roses dressed up last year's prim low-backed sofas from Edra. Massimo Morozzi, Edra's art director and blithe spirit, said the prints, new from the Op Art fabric master Ken Scott, express a "desire for ecstasy and optical illusions in order to compensate for the emotional poverty of minimalist design." Splash your living room in Edra's pinks -- just don't put them next to Cappellini's mod armchairs in vintage Emilio Pucci floral psychedelics. Suggested attire? Sunglasses.
Practicality dashed off with flair was the hallmark of furnishings by the newcomers. Jeffrey Bernett, a New York-based designer, introduced an orange felt chaise as spare as a semaphore. A white leather pillow with an inner magnet attaches to its backrest at any angle ($3,200 at B&B Italia). At the exhibition hall devoted to emerging talent looking for the big break, Tron Design of Germany adapted car seat technology to a two-person rocking cocoon equipped with a computer on a steel extension arm.
At Milan's sprawling fairgrounds, some 1,650 exhibitors showed off their latest works. But breakthroughs are usually found at the 200-odd impromptu furniture showcases scattered among palace courtyards, garages and former steelworks around the city. This year, however, that traffic-jamming citywide happening failed to produce much in the way of truly provocative design.
If the year belonged to anyone, it was Cappellini. The company, known for tapping new trends and far-flung talents, outdid itself with some 40 introductions, including sofas, kitchen sinks, shelving and light fixtures displayed in an industrial hangar far from the gold-plated shopping district along the Via Monte Napoleone. It was a tutti-frutti affair, with minimalism offered up alongside pop fashion, computer tech and amoebic forms.
The Cappellini collection included works by Erwan and Ronan Bouroullec, brothers from Brittany, who recently designed a new shop for Issey Miyake in Paris. As with their tree-house bedroom last year, the Bouroullecs are still experimenting with ideas about poetic practicality. "We don't want to make only functional pieces," said Erwan Bouroullec, pointing to a table sprouting a bowl molded from a single piece of heat-welded Corian. "This is not just a table, and we don't want to tell anyone whether it functions as sculpture in the middle of a room or as a place to toss your keys by the front door. Put it anywhere and use it your own way."
In the show's most pronounced case of fashion cross-over, Fabien Baron, a former art director of Harper's Bazaar, eagerly presented his first collection of furniture, rugs and limited-edition cast-acrylic block sculptures commissioned by Cappellini.
Graphically severe, with legs as skinny as a Vogue intern and done up in optional gray-flecked felt and anthracite leather, these furnishings would appeal to the image-conscious. Paola Antonelli, a design curator at the Museum of Modern Art, summed up the general reaction when she called the collection boring but said, "It will probably sell like hot cakes."
Buyers, manufacturers and journalists combed the city in vain for the next hot designer and must-have chair. The real stunners were raw materials up for adoption from other fields, most of which have not yet reached the production line. The Prada Foundation, a vast, vaulted space, contained, among other curiosities, a two-story section of the diamond-shape glass and steel facade bound for Herzog & de Meuron's Prada store in Tokyo. On the wall, a map outlined Prada's plans to dominate the world with boutiques.
Prada wasn't the only advocate of a new design aesthetic based on textures and transparencies. The display by Material Connexion, a New York-based clearinghouse for experimental products, was thronged with people taking notes and squeezing the gel samples. Two glass manufacturers from Barcelona, Spain, shook their heads in dismay as they read a label describing a stack of gem-toned acrylic sheets as 50 percent lighter than glass, with three times the impact resistance of safety glass. Caressing the satiny two-toned green sheets, Erika Zangger, a restaurant designer from Austria, said, "These are ideal room dividers, better than glass in every way."
There was a surprising lack of technological derring-do in the furniture design, however. (With one exception: Ron Arad's long-awaited prototype of a dining chair that folds and slides like a drawer into a table. Sheer engineering bravado, though it remains to be seen if Cassina can figure out how to produce it.)
Instead, there was a renewed appreciation for the artistry of craft, even the machine-made variety. Fernando and Humberto Campana, an architect and a lawyer from Brazil who are now designers, chose to hand-weave industrial trash -- in this case, garden-hose tubing in fluorescent pinks and purples wrapped around an O-shaped steel frame, for Edra. "I work with my hands to learn the limits of the material," said Humberto Campana, "but the shapes themselves come from my dreams."
In a bit of riveting theater, at a 16th-century church, 19 well-known designers were invited to create machine-made designs on the spot with an acrylic extruder, normally used to mix color combinations for plastics. The event was conceived by Domus and Tom Dixon, the design director at Habitat, who sees a future in instant crafts. "People love to watch other people making things," Mr. Dixon said. "It's like taking a Polaroid of the maker's ideas about design."
It was even suspenseful as Karim Rashid, a New York designer, tried to control the dribble of hot-pink acrylic noodles looping over a cardboard and wood chair mold. He also cast his own custom-made Puma sneaker, as a memorial to one stolen (or collected by a rabid fan) at a party the night before.
Even if there were no star turns, there was no shortage of creative potential. Sputnik -- a casual consortium of designers from the Americas, Japan, the Netherlands and England -- struck the pitch-perfect note when it showed prototypes not for chairs but for what the designers call "verbs about sitting." One was a large rattan floor piece resembling a lima bean with a dent. People lined up to test its gentle rock, and one bystander suggested its ideal function: to allow one to hold the lotus position while reading fashion magazines.

HEADLINE: Leaving Colombia 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Your April 10 front-page account of Colombians fleeing to the United States and elsewhere as a result of increased instability did not mention a primary cause of that instability: United States drug prohibition. 
 Failed prohibitionist policies at home aimed at reducing cocaine consumption and increased financial assistance to the Colombian military to fight coca production exacerbate the conditions of the decades-old civil war in Colombia. Peace and prosperity will continue to elude the Colombian people until the United States abandons its misguided and unwinnable war on drugs.

DAVID WEINBERG
New York, April 10, 2001

HEADLINE: Holding Onto Harlem 

BYLINE:  By Angela Glover Blackwell; Angela Glover Blackwell is founder and president of PolicyLink, a nonprofit organization focusing on community building.

 BODY:
The story is familiar. An inner-city neighborhood, long besieged by poverty and economic abandonment, suddenly becomes fashionable because of a combination of economic growth and public investment. As more affluent, usually white, families move in, property values and rents rise. Lower-income working families, often African-American or Hispanic, are forced to leave just when their dream of a more livable neighborhood is about to become reality. Now this story is moving to Harlem, a neighborhood with unique importance to African-Americans nationwide. And this time, New York should rewrite the ending. 
 In past decades, government action drove money away from low-income neighborhoods: a sewage treatment plant on 145th Street, for example, was harmful to Harlem. Now government action should be used to channel investment in ways that let longtime residents stay and thrive. Simply auctioning off city-owned property to the highest private bidder is not enough. 
 New York doesn't have to look far for ideas that preserve economic diversity. New York City, as well as regions from the entire state of New Jersey (under court order) to several Washington, D. C., suburbs to Santa Fe, N. M., have had success with something called inclusionary zoning -- setting aside a portion of new housing, usually 15 percent to 20 percent -- for lower-income families. Developers can be required either to build affordable housing themselves or to contribute to a fund for it. Or they can be given incentives like density bonuses or looser height restrictions.
New York has also helped establish co-op buildings that limit the maximum price at which members' shares can be sold, so prices stay affordable over the years. And it could encourage cooperative leasing, with residents banding together to lease whole buildings, perhaps with options to buy.
A new idea that I believe holds enormous promise is using a community-building trust. This would be a publicly accountable entity that would acquire property in the gentrifying neighborhood by buying it, receiving it from donors or getting it from public agencies through eminent domain or tax foreclosure. Some of this real estate could be sold or leased for higher-end commercial or residential real estate development, to bring money into the neighborhood. The profit could be used to help make the new Harlem a mixed-income, diverse neighborhood.
The trust could subsidize affordable housing, offer employment training, help develop employee-owned businesses or match families' savings for home purchases, education and business financing.
A model is at work in San Diego's Market Creek Plaza, a 20-acre mixed-use commercial and cultural real estate development project. Not only will residents there have an opportunity to be owners of the development, but profits from it are being channeled into a community foundation to help train local residents for managing and running their own businesses.
With imagination and the cooperation of city and neighborhood leaders, ideas like these can change the story of gentrification not only for Harlem, but around the country.

HEADLINE: Joseph Weintraub, 79, Economics Professor 

 BODY:
Joseph Weintraub, who helped make the teaching of economics mandatory for high school students in New York State, died on April 2 in the Bronx. He was 79. 
 The cause was pancreatic cancer, said his daughter, Meryl Hechtman, of East Meadow, N.Y. 
 He had a 53-year teaching career, ending as an economics professor at Nassau Community College. He helped develop a mandatory economics course to be given to every high school student in the state, beginning this fall. On April 25, he was to have received the first Lifetime Achievement Award in Economics Education from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. 
Mr. Weintraub was born in Queens and was a graduate of Queens College. He was in the Army Air Corps during World War II, leaving the service in 1946. He began teaching social studies in 1948, served as principal of Newtown High School in Queens for 11 years, and retired in 1982.
In 1963, he became an adjunct economics professor at Nassau Community College and remained there until last August.
His wife, Beatrice Kass Weintraub, a teacher, died in 1993. In addition to his daughter, he is survived by a son, David Weintraub, of Wantagh, N.Y.; and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: In Radio Feud, a Higher Kind of Superpower Irks Italy 

BYLINE:  By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: ROME, April 11 

 BODY:
Italians have rarely displayed much faith in institutions, whether the post office, the tax police or health inspectors. Now the country is experiencing an epidemic of mistrust, and its epicenter is in Cesano, a small north Rome suburb where many residents say that radiation from the Vatican's nearby radio transmitters causes cancer.
 "People find it hard to believe that the pope would allow something that could be harmful to people," Assunta, 25, a Cesano native who declined to give her last name, said as she pushed her toddler's stroller into a local grocery store. "Maybe the Vatican believes that the emissions are not harmful, but I think that it is convenient for the Vatican not to believe it." 
 That kind of cynicism is widespread -- which is one reason the Vatican is seeking to end the dispute over the antennas of Vatican Radio, which transmits Roman Catholic programming to five continents in 35 languages. Although the Vatican considers itself a sovereign state and not subject to Italian law, it announced on Tuesday that it would begin reducing electromagnetic emissions from the antennas in order to meet stringent Italian limits.
But the minister of the environment for Italy, Willer Bordon, set a deadline of next Tuesday for a drastic reduction in emissions from the antennas -- a forest of red-and-white towers on a stretch of Vatican property a few miles from Cesano -- by which time he would cut electricity to Vatican transmitters. Today, Prime Minister Giuliano Amato overrode Mr. Bordon, effectively extending the deadline.
The radio standoff is only the latest in a series of health scares that have traumatized Italians and prodded public officials, who are mired in a bitter election campaign, to respond even when scientific evidence is divided or inconclusive.
Italy was one of the first countries to complain officially to NATO about unusually high cancer rates among military troops who served in Bosnia. An Italian medical commission later concluded that there was no evidence linking incidents of cancer to NATO's use of depleted uranium in war zones.
Italy to date has reported 11 confirmed cases of mad cow disease, and public fears remain so high -- despite government assurances that beef is being tested carefully -- that sales and prices have plummeted, as they have across much of Western Europe.
Italians, like most Europeans, have banned imports of genetically modified foods and the use of modified grains. On Tuesday, the police seized 88 tons of soy seed at a Monsanto warehouse in northern Italy to test the seeds for genetically modified content. After 112 tons of Monsanto corn were seized from the same warehouse last month, also to be checked for genetic modification, vandals set a grain store on fire, and sent an anonymous letter to the Italian news agency accusing an American biotechnology company of "poisoning the planet."
Such battles are common in Europe, and are usually framed as a test between the traditional way of life and American economic hegemony -- globalization versus McDonalds.
Italians, however, occasionally see themselves as victimized by another kind of superpower, the Vatican. Cesano residents have long seen electromagnetic radiation from Vatican transmitters as contributing to what they say are increasing leukemia rates, though most studies do not support their accusation. 
Their fears have found a voice in Mr. Bordon, the environment minister, who issued the threat to cut off the radio's power if electromagnetic emissions were not reduced to meet Italian limits -- which are almost three times lower than most other European countries. 
Seeking to head off a collision, the Vatican's spokesman, Joaquin Navarro-Valls, said in a statement Tuesday night -- on Vatican Radio -- that it had decided to reduce the emissions. Mr. Bordon, who held a press conference minutes later, stood firm, saying that he needed to know how soon the Vatican would do so, or else he would cut off the electricity.
But his brinkmanship was tempered by the prime minister, who let it be known today that his government would continue to seek a negotiated settlement with the Vatican through a bilateral commission set up to resolve the issue.
And Foreign Minister Lamberto Dini, who has overseen the bilateral commission, complained that Mr. Bordon's threats were "inopportune" and "delegitimized" the government's negotiations. Umberto Veronesi, an oncologist who is now Italy's health minister, added his own doubts, noting that there was little evidence of a link between electromagnetic fields and cancer. He urged Italians to worry more about more proven risks, like skin cancer caused by the sun, which many worship on beaches in summer and ski slopes in winter.
The Vatican's resistance to Mr. Bordon's demands irk many Cesano residents. "The church used to torture people to make them convert to Christianity during the Inquisition, and this is a new form of inquisition," Fulvia Mari, 51, a resident, said angrily. She complained that Vatican Radio waves are so powerful that she hears broadcasts when her apartment intercom rings. "I hear broadcasts in German, English and even Latin," she said. "Who speaks Latin anymore?"
The Vatican, worried by what Dr. Navarro-Valls called "unjustified alarmism," is seeking ways to placate public fears. On Monday it announced that it would stop medium-wave broadcasts for seven hours a day, an initial concession that would not significantly dent its mission because most of the world receives Vatican Radio by shortwave radio.
"It was a gesture of good will," explained Eugenio Pacelli, an Italian lawyer who frequently represents the Vatican and is the grandnephew and namesake of Pope Pius XII. He said the Vatican's gesture was not an admission of error and likened it to the standoff between the United States and China over an American spy plane. "Even President Bush told the Chinese he 'regretted the incident,' " Mr. Pacelli said wryly. "Even though he didn't agree with their view."

HEADLINE: Biggest Drop In Prices Of Imports Since1992 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11 

 BODY:
Prices of goods imported into the United States fell more in March than in any month since December 1992 as the cost of petroleum, steel and paper declined, government figures showed today.
 The import price index dropped 1.6 percent last month after a 0.6 percent slide in February, the Labor Department said. March's decline was the third consecutive drop; import costs have not risen since September. Prices excluding oil fell 0.9 percent after a 0.8 percent decline. 
 Cheaper imports and a dollar that has risen more than 5 percent since the middle of last year have made it difficult for American companies to raise prices. That is a green light for Federal Reserve policy makers to reduce interest rates to bolster the economy.
"This is encouraging," said Richard Yamarone, senior economist at the Argus Research Corporation in New York. "It'll permit the Fed to cut rates as aggressively as they see fit. Inflation isn't even on the Fed's radar screen." 
The March decline was the largest since a 1.7 percent drop in December 1992. It pushed the import price index to its lowest level since January 2000.
Import prices were 1.5 percent lower for the 12 months ended in March, compared with a 9.2 percent increase in the 12 months ended in March 2000. Excluding petroleum, import prices were unchanged in March compared with those in the month a year earlier. For the 12 months ended in March 2000, import prices excluding petroleum were 1 percent higher.
The March decrease in the import price index was led by a 5.9 percent fall in the cost of petroleum products. The price of crude oil, which has more than doubled over the last two years, fell 5.1 percent in March after a 2.5 percent increase in February.
The import prices report is the first of three measures of inflation for March. On Thursday, the government will issue a report on prices at the wholesale level and it is expected to show tame inflation. A report on consumer prices will come next week.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
NasdaqExtends Gains, but Dow and S.& P. Give Ground

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The Nasdaq composite index rose for the third consecutive session yesterday as investors bought shares of market-leading technology companies on hopes their prospects will soon start to brighten.
 Semiconductor stocks, widely seen as the leading indicator of a recovery in the broader technology market, led the advance yesterday. The shares rallied after an analyst from Salomon Smith Barney issued a report recommending the group, saying business is likely to pick up later this year. 
 Paced by gains in companies like Applied Micro Circuits, Applied Materials and Intel, the Nasdaq composite index gained 46.92 points, or 2.5 percent, to 1,898.95. Since last Thursday, the Nasdaq index has risen 16 percent. Even with the gain, it remains 62 percent below the peak reached in March 2000. 
"I am not sure this is the beginning of a straight move to the upside," said Philip S. Dow, managing director of equity research at Dain Rauscher Wessels in Minneapolis. "My guess is we are in a backing and filling, grinding mode. The watchword I am looking for from my analysts is that things are not getting worse." 
The Dow Jones industrial average fell even as the Nasdaq moved higher, pulled down by oil and drug company stocks. The Dow fell 89.27 points, or 0.9 percent, to 10,013.47. Declines in Exxon Mobil, Johnson & Johnson and Merck more than offset gains in Intel, J. P. Morgan Chase and Citigroup.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was little changed, declining 2.49 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,165.89.
Analysts said they were encouraged to see some softness in prices after the big gains recorded on Tuesday.
"I am loving today's action, because I don't want to see huge gains piled on top of one another," said William J. Meehan, chief market analyst at Cantor Fitzgerald. Mr. Meehan said strength in technology and financial stocks was a sign that the market's long slide is probably over.
"We have been telling clients to avoid safe, defensive-type stocks, because we think the market has bottomed," he said. "We are seeing real buying here, not people covering their short positions."
Six stocks rose for every five that fell on the Nasdaq stock market. Losers outnumbered gainers on the New York Stock Exchange by three to two. Nearly 1.3 billion shares changed hands on the Big Board. 
The Salomon Smith Barney upgrade of the semiconductor stocks sent the Philadelphia Stock Exchange semiconductor index soaring. The index gained 44.17, or 8.5 percent, to 564.29. 
Intel rose $2.75, to $27.52. Texas Instruments was up $4.40, to $34. Applied Materials climbed $3.28, to $46.03. And Applied Micro jumped $3.01, to $19.39.
Cisco Systems was the most actively traded stock. The shares gained $1.54, to $17.40.
Bank and brokerage stocks participated in yesterday's rally, even though William Poole, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, made it plain Tuesday that the Fed was highly unlikely to cut short-term interest rates before mid-May, when its policy-making Federal Open Market Committee is scheduled to hold its next meeting.
"A month ago Mr. Poole's comments would have sent financials reeling," Mr. Meehan said. "They are rallying."
Morgan Stanley gained $3.01, to $57.65. Citigroup advanced 94 cents, to $46.34. J. P. Morgan Chase rose $1.44, to $44.74. And Goldman Sachs closed at $91.30, up $3.49.
Health, energy and retail stocks, which were highly sought during the meltdown in technology, were mostly lower. Johnson & Johnson fell $1.19, to $90.84. Merck slipped $1.24, to $77.15. And Pfizer declined $1, to $40.

 (By Bloomberg News) -- Treasury bond prices were mixed yesterday.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 9/32, to a price of 99 4/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.11 percent from 5.08 percent. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 6/32, to 96 19/32. The bond's yield fell to 5.61 percent from 5.62 percent on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
Al Davis: A Shameless, Selfish Rebel

BYLINE:  By HARVEY ARATON 

 BODY:
THE big court trial dragging on like an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease 20 miles down the freeway in Los Angeles is of no interest to Patricio Miranda. Let the big-city taxpayers pay the five-weeks-and-counting freight for Al Davis versus the National Football League, he says. Let others worry about the bloodsucker in silver and black, to whom Miranda's little town once handed $10 million for the privilege of being played.
 "If anything, it was a good lesson that we're too small to get involved with people like that," said Miranda, the city councilman and former mayor of Irwindale, Calif. (population: 1,100). 
 Fourteen years ago, Irwindale, a town of mostly Mexican-Americans best known for its gravel pits, gained sudden national exposure by striking a deal with the Raiders, then in Los Angeles. Davis, the self-styled James Dean of sports owners, wanted out of the aged and parking-challenged Los Angeles Coliseum. Irwindale had a plan, Davis had a price, and Patricio Miranda, then the mayor, had a problem.
"Davis wanted a $10 million good-faith payment and I called it risk money," Miranda said yesterday from his Irwindale home. "I told my city managers: 'It should be like buying a house. Put it in an escrow account and if the deal passes, he gets it. If it doesn't pass, we get it back.' "
The four councilmen didn't listen to Miranda, who voted against the payment despite being threatened with a mayoral recall. The Raiders deal eventually ran into political resistance from Los Angeles and the state capital in Sacramento and died. Irwindale was out the $10 million plus interest, in addition to several million in related costs. Not that Davis cared what became of the small town's economy. He stuffed the money deep into his pocket, put the Raiders back in the free agent market and eventually secured $64 million in upfront benefits from Oakland, the team's original home.
"I'm glad I'm on record as having voted against that payment," said Miranda, the only remaining government member from the town's Raiders fling. "But, still, losing that money hurt bad."
In 1995 Davis returned the Raiders to Oakland, where they were welcomed back like war heroes and where the old Oakland Alameda Coliseum, shared with baseball's Athletics, was remodeled for football. Less than a decade later, he is in Los Angeles County Superior Court, arguing under cross-examination yesterday that he left L.A. only because the N.F.L. undercut a sweetheart deal for a privately financed stadium in Inglewood.
He wants $1 billion in damages. He also accuses Oakland of not living up to its agreement. He wants to establish the Raiders as still holding the territorial rights to the megamarket that lost both the Raiders and the Rams. Then Davis could pursue the invalidation of his lease in Oakland, the long-troubled city from which he has apparently bled all he can.
It sounds arrogant and greed-driven almost to the point of being delusional. Then again, Davis has a pretty good track record in court against the N.F.L., which failed to block his early 1980's slithering from Oakland to L.A. He was back then a regular news media icon, the tough-talking thorn in the derriere of the clubby old rich men. He even once flirted with New York City, after Leon Hess moved his Jets to New Jersey. Hess was called a carpetbagger. Davis was encouraged to come bless us with charisma.
Questioned under oath earlier this week by his trusty lawyer, Joseph M. Alioto, it didn't take Davis long to remind the jury of the Raiders' motto, "Commitment to Excellence." Now all he needs to develop is a commitment to commitment, as a substitute for a conscience. At 71, Davis may still be a rebel but, as usual, he is fighting for a selfish and shameful cause.
Oakland must about now feel as good as Irwindale once did upon hearing Davis testify this week: "I do believe in tradition. I do believe in history. I do believe in loyalty." Mostly, he believes that his football team is no different from a hot quarterback at the end of his contract.
He thinks Los Angeles, which has not closed down without pro football, can't wait to start the bidding. Maybe he's right. Maybe there is no end to this sports team madness and extortion of taxpayers. Even Patricio Miranda wouldn't definitively rule Irwindale out of any future deal.
"I can't speak for the other council members," he said. "As for me, sure, I'd take the Raiders. But I wouldn't spend a penny on them. Let Davis pay. In the end, he gets all the profit."
