HEADLINE: Raising Funds After the Fall; 
Venture Capital Exists For Realistic Prospects

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN; Daniel Altman is a staff writer for The Economist.

 BODY:
At first glance, it looks like a terrible time to start a company.
 Both the public and private markets for new equity have shrunk. Margin calls on debt-financed portfolios have chased away many badly burned investors who were still riding the high-tech bandwagon when it exploded. 
 "I would not want to be a company today raising capital, counting on the markets in the next year or so," said Jeffrey Walker, head of J. P. Morgan Chase's private equity fund.
So are most potential backers of new ventures simply holding onto their money? If that happens, after all, even lower interest rates from the Federal Reserve and a tax cut emerging from Congress may have little power to stimulate investment. The economy could be in for a long dry spell. 
But while investment in business is clearly on the wane, the fear that Washington is lacking effective tools to restart the economic engine appears to be exaggerated. There are several reasons for that.
First of all, the decline in funds for new companies largely represents a return to normalcy. In the public equity market, for instance, initial and secondary offerings, which together topped $45 billion on the Nasdaq and New York Stock Exchange in both November 1999 and February 2000, have retreated to under $10 billion over the last few months. Yet that level would have been fairly ordinary as recently as 1998.
Second, a drop in initial public offerings does not necessarily imply significantly less future growth. A substantial portion of the money raised in the dot-com boom was thrown away on ventures that did not make money. "We thought it was nuts that two people just out of college were getting $20 million to 30 million valuations on a business plan," said James Geshwiler, who leads a private team of wealthy investors called CommonAngels.
Renewed attention to companies with more realistic prospects is likely to channel capital to more effective uses.
Finally, much of the private venture financing that helped inflate the dot-com bubble had merely migrated from other parts of the equity market. Now that most of the opportunists who rushed into venture capital are gone, experts say, the market appears to be not only smaller, but also in some ways healthier.
"We saw over the past few years a huge amount of money switching out of the more mundane area of buyout into venture," said Ray Maxwell, managing director of Invesco's London-based private equity business. Hedge funds, buyout firms and new corporate incubators with little experience in venture capital were trying to take young companies public as soon as possible, hoping for huge proceeds from initial public offerings.
Their retreat has handed the market back to veterans like Mr. Maxwell and Mr. Walker, who still have capital to invest. And "there's still a lot of money in the hands of the old-line venture firms," like Kleiner Perkins Caulfield & Byers and New Enterprise Associates, Mr. Walker said.
Wealthy "angel" investors also continue to participate in venture financing. "Our deal flow is up 30 percent over last year," Mr. Geshwiler of CommonAngels said. "We've had more companies in due diligence, considering investments, than we've ever had before."
And as long as the funds and ideas keep flowing, monetary and fiscal policy can still influence the economy.
"Most of the Fed's influence is over the short term," said Mark Gertler, a professor of economics at New York University who is an expert on how monetary policy affects the economy. But "to the extent the Fed can credibly stabilize the real economy, that's going to raise asset values and make it easier for firms to raise cash."
"The Fed can't perfectly control the economy," he said, "but it still has a strong ability to influence markets."
Fiscal policy has retained its ability to influence the economy as well. "Observers seem to be getting confused between what's happening in the stock market and what's happening in the economy," said Alan J. Auerbach, director of the Burch Center for Tax Policy and Public Finance at the University of California at Berkeley. "I'm old enough to remember some very serious recessions we've had in the past. So far, there's no indication that we're heading in that direction."
Professor Auerbach said that targeted tax cuts and credits could help to enhance investment, but he warned that the Bush administration's current plan would do little to advance that goal. "This is a tax cut that is going toward households, not toward businesses," he said. "That in itself is not going to have an impact on demand for investment goods."
Yet in the longer term, other factors will determine the health of the economy even more than the level of taxes and interest rates.
The flow of new ideas will be crucial. Groundbreaking technologies and profitable new business models raise living standards by improving workers' productivity. The markets' tumble has helped to refocus investment on companies with truly trailblazing ideas rather than boilerplate start-ups.
"The fair-weather entrepreneurs are out of the market," Mr. Geshwiler said. "But there's still lots of room for innovation."
Matchmaking between investors and entrepreneurs is also becoming more precise and productive, as would-be backers are examining new companies more closely than ever.
Russ Henry experienced that first-hand while trying to raise money recently for Trigo, the third technology company he has helped to found. He said investors were "definitely more finicky, but definitely much more committed."
He was surprised by demands from potential investors for up-to-the-minute progress reports on pending contracts, but he found the extra scrutiny refreshing.
"The diligence process took 60 days, which was about 30 days longer than my expectation," Mr. Henry said. "We actually liked it," he added, because it got his investors "much more engaged in what we're doing."
Not all the developments on the innovation front are so positive. Mr. Geshwiler worries that the crash has scared some talented people away from the private sector. "One thing I have noticed is fewer technology people being willing to go in the market," he said.
Mr. Walker, however, does not share his trepidation. "I'm not convinced the spirit of innovation has been impaired," he said. "The spirit of copying has."
He does not miss the days of being besieged by companies seeking instant capital for, say, the Internet's 12th Web site devoted to selling pet food. "Companies came in and gave a presentation and wanted an answer in two or three hours," Mr. Walker said. "These were followers, and not great ideas."
The other factor that will determine the long-term health of the economy is saving.
The overall rate of personal saving fell to zero or even lower between July 2000 and February 2001. Now, it may be starting to move back up again. No longer able to count on gains in the stock market to generate easy wealth, millions of households are probably starting to put aside more savings that should soon show up in the official statistics.
Whether those savings will reach new businesses soon is tougher to predict. Middle-income savers will have to pay off home equity loans, auto loans and credit cards before they can start investing again. "The impact of household debt is one of the big unknowns," Professor Gertler said.
It is clear, however, that both monetary and fiscal policy could play a role in ensuring robust saving and capital accumulation in the long run.
Professor Gertler says that the Fed's best approach to ensuring a healthy outlook for economic growth is to maintain its commitment to keeping inflation low. That agenda could limit the Fed's ability to provide a short-term economic stimulus, but it would minimize long-term risks to businesses and consumers.
On the fiscal side, Professor Auerbach hoped the federal government would continue to pay off its own debt to help produce permanently lower interest rates. "It's been a very beneficial policy, and I think it would continue to be so," he said.
Ensuring lasting, favorable conditions for investment will be particularly important, since the private market's focus is returning to long-term growth opportunities rather than get-rich-quick schemes.
Mr. Walker of JPMorgan Chase said that institutional investors "are back to a more normal style of structuring and pricing of deals, similar to what we saw in the early 1990's."
Mr. Geshwiler of CommonAngels has seen the same trend in his corner of the private-equity world. "Building a company used to be a long-term proposition, and now it's a really long-term proposition," he said. "The people who we're meeting with these days are far more serious about building their business than the people we were meeting with a year ago."

HEADLINE: Tax Cut Announced for Jersey City 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY, April 11 

 BODY:
Mayor Bret D. Schundler held a news conference today at City Hall to announce a tax cut for city property owners for which his opponent for governor can take some credit. 
 In announcing an amendment to the $333.7 million municipal budget that took effect last July, Mr. 
Schundler took responsibility for increasing spending by less than $1 million from the previous year, despite inflation and mandatory salary increases. He said the tax cut would amount to about 60 cents per $1,000 of assessed value. The current municipal tax rate, officials said, is $20.33 per $1,000 of assessed value. 
 "I'm happy to report that my administration has a solid plan to cut property taxes for Jersey City homeowners this year," he said. 
But the budget amendment that set up the tax cut was to incorporate $4.15 million in additional aid allocated to the city by the state under the Aid to Distressed Cities Program. The money was authorized by Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco, Mr. Schundler and the City Council were told in an April 6 letter from the state's director of local government services. Mr. DiFrancesco is Mr. Schundler's opponent in the Republican primary. (The city had already been allocated $7.34 million in distressed cities aid.)
Despite the letter, Mr. Schundler said, the state had initially decided to cut its aid to Jersey City this year by about $10 million, so even with the $4.15 million, the city is getting less this year from the state. "If the state had just kept its revenue flat, we would have been able to cut taxes further," Mr. Schundler said.

HEADLINE: A New Editor Named at Wired Magazine 

 BODY:
Chris Anderson, the United States business editor of The Economist, has been named the editor of Wired magazine, which is published by Conde Nast. 
 Mr. 
Anderson will succeed Katrina Heron, Wired's editor of the last three years, on June 4. 
 At The Economist, Mr. Anderson, 39, covered technology and the economy as both a writer and an editor. Mr. Anderson said that he would probably bring more of a business approach to Wired, which has covered the Internet and technology from broad business and cultural perspectives.
"We're in the midst of a slump right now, but I believe that the underlying technology revolution will emerge from this period," he said. "But the hype of a year ago is diminished. The magazine will be a more sober, more level-headed, perhaps more pragmatic review of where the revolution is going."
Conde Nast, a unit of Advance Publications Inc., bought Wired magazine in 1998. The magazine's circulation has increased 8.3 percent in the last year, to 507,816, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations. But advertising has dropped, as it has throughout the technology and Internet magazine sector. Wired's ad pages for March declined 41 percent, to 103 pages from 178. Revenue dropped 26 percent, to $3.7 million in the March issue from a reported $5.1 million in March 2000, according to the Publishers Information Bureau.

HEADLINE: A New Approach: Slow and Steady 

BYLINE:  By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 11 

 BODY:
Among the junkyards, crushed cars and broken glass in this city's warehouse district, Walt Morton spends his days hunting for deals on computer hardware from failed dot-com companies. 
 The auctioning off of the infrastructure of the not-so-new economy is one sign that Silicon Valley is plunging into a financial abyss unparalleled for decades in this high-technology region. 
 At the same time, Mr. Morton and others like him are evidence that the entrepreneurial fervor that led to the boom is still very much alive, and that sprouts seem to be emerging from the rubble.
As he examined a pizza-box-size server computer and an auctioneer barked out prices, Mr. Morton reflected that he might well be the first sign of a new era rather than an observer of the final moments of the old one. 
"All the people I know who lost their jobs are trying to start new companies," he said. But he added that their approach this time was radically different from the gold-rush mentality of the quickly fading dot-com era: "We're part of a whole new wave of cheap start-ups." 
A former executive at America Online who is now chief executive of an Internet start-up in San Francisco, Sawhorse Partners, Mr. Morton explores several auctions each week.
"If these are cheap, enough I might buy a couple of them," he said, eyeing a stack of computers sitting in a corner of a warehouse. He estimated that the infrastructure he built for his last start-up at a cost of $200,000 would now be less than $18,000.
The shift in the market has created an unfamiliar paralysis among Silicon Valley's venture capitalists, many of whom have a dazed look as they watch previous bad investments crumble and try to figure out what the next hot investment will be. As a result, the area's venture-capital-to-entrepreneur ecosystem has abruptly stalled, at least temporarily.
While some analysts have worried about the impact that such dot-com fire sales are having on equipment makers like Cisco, Dell and Sun Microsystems, the most visible beneficiaries of the boom, many economists noted that the recycling of equipment has always been a part of the high-technology life cycle, in which most start-up companies either fail or are acquired. Employment, at this point, remains surprisingly strong.
"I think the whole dot-com layoff thing has been blown out of perspective," said Steven Levy, an economist at the Center for the Continuing Study of the California Economy, in Palo Alto, noting that in the last three months, the San Francisco Bay area has recorded historically low unemployment rates.
The California Employment Development Department reported this month that the state's unemployment rate dropped to 4.5 percent in February, a 32-year low. (It was 4.4 percent in December 1969.) The unemployment rate last month in Santa Clara County, which largely defines Silicon Valley, was 1.7 percent, indicating that only 17,600 people were jobless in a work force of 1,004,900. 
Even in San Francisco, which has been more dependent on e-commerce start-ups, unemployment was 3.2 percent, up from 2.6 last year. 
Mr. Morton is one sign that while the dot-com bubble has burst and expectations have been "reset" -- in the current jargon of the e-commerce neighborhood known as South of Market Street -- the start-up culture here is now deeply ingrained.
Big Storage, a South-of-Market start-up with 30 employees that largely missed the dot-com boom, turned profitable in March, two months ahead of schedule. The company, which sells Linux-based disk arrays to companies that need large data storage systems, once felt embarrassed that it was not on the public offering bandwagon but was now finding it easier to expand.
"Last year, each month I would apologize to my board of directors for not finding more business," said Big Storage's chief executive, Sam Bogach. Now, he says, missing the boom was a blessing.
Many Silicon Valley executives said the shift was away from the era of easy-money dot-com start-ups and back to a climate that more closely resembled the original Silicon Valley up-from-the-garage ethos. 
"You're no longer viewed as a loser if you have a cheap office space; you're perceived as smart," said Paul Kocher, chief executive of Cryptography Research, who is financing a small start-up to develop an e-commerce application. 
Indeed, it may be that venture capitalists, who until recently were among the biggest beneficiaries of the boom, are now the biggest victims of the downturn.
"The V.C.'s are hiding under their desks right now," said Anthony Perkins, co-author of "The Internet Bubble," a 1999 book that predicted the dot-com shake-out. 
"Most of them," Mr. Perkins said, "are facing up to the fact of whatever percentage of their deals that were stupid. They're shooting all the lame horses." 
Mr. Perkins's company, Red Herring Communications, which publishes the business and technology magazine Red Herring, had a round of layoffs not long ago, but Mr. Perkins said that when he checked recently, he discovered that all but one of the former employees had found a job -- and that the one person was not looking. 
Of 742 venture capital firms in Silicon Valley, he said, 192 were created within the last 18 months, a situation that will inevitably lead to a pruning of the venture community in the months ahead. That, in turn, will lead to a consolidation in the power and influence of venture firms like Sequoia and Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers.
And if the venture capital industry is in shock, that has created a domino effect among start-up companies. 
"These guys are schizo right now," said David House, chief executive of Allegro Networks, a start-up router company in San Jose, Calif. "They've just raised their billion-dollar funds and they're scared. Now everyone wants to be the second guy to invest, not the first." 
From the point of view of the venture capitalists, the entrepreneurs have also grown more cautious. 
"We think it's a wonderful time to be a bold entrepreneur," said Jim Breyer, managing partner of Accel Partners in Palo Alto, Calif. "But unfortunately we're not seeing a lot of people with those ideas. It's too bad."
The current period, Mr. Breyer said, was similar to the one venture capitalists went through in the late 1980's and early 1990's, when most people thought Microsoft had won the PC platform wars and they were only interested in incremental ideas.
Today, most executives here remain convinced that the Internet is not a fad and that it has only begun to transform the economy. But they are now grasping for specific trends, with profit potential, to seize upon. 
"There are no fads right now," said Sheldon Breiner, a longtime Silicon Valley inventor who is now an independent investor. "Six months ago it was optical switching and a year ago it was business-to-business, but now I don't know of a fad."
There are those who said that the absence of fads was a good thing and that the economy in Silicon Valley was being led back to its fundamentals in technology, where it has always excelled. 
"Two years ago you couldn't recruit anyone into the semiconductor industry," said Andrew Rappaport, a partner at August Capital, a venture firm in Menlo Park, Calif. "They all wanted to go to a dot-com. Now they're all coming back and the talent pool is growing." 
And some venture capitalists remain enthusiastic, certain that they are only one company away from the Next Big Thing. 
"We've gone from irrational exuberance to irrational pessimism," said Greg Galanos, a partner at Softbank Venture Capital in Mountain View, Calif., adding: "Have I told you about Danger Research? Wait until you see what they're doing!"

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
A history lesson: Don't count on stocks to lead the way out of a downturn.

BYLINE:  By Jeff Madrick; This column appears here every Thursday. Jeff Madrick is the editor of Challenge Magazine and a new collection of essays, "Unconventional Wisdom: Alternative Perspectives on the New Economy." E-mail: challenge@mesharpe.com

 BODY:
NOTHING bothered me more as a viewer of the finance programs on cable TV in the 1990's than the professional analysts who said that stocks were always a good investment as long as you planned to hold them for at least five years. Stocks always rose over the long run, they argued.
 But in truth, stock prices over the last century were sometimes flat for 10 or 15 years, and occasionally even longer. In the heady 1990's, though, any Tom-Dick-or-Harry prognosticator could say that five years was the long run and get away with it. 
 The recent downturn has not yet weaned the financial markets from such overoptimism. The widespread view today is that once stocks find a bottom, they will start back on their inexorable upward march fairly quickly. Analysts now acknowledge that the gains of 25 percent a year or more won't return any time soon, but recapturing the long-term average of 7 percent a year, after inflation, is not only reasonable but even likely. At such a pace, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index would again be setting records in about three years. 
A serious look at stock market history, however, suggests that this is far from a sure thing. And because the health of the economy depends so much more on high stock prices than it once did, we should be particularly concerned about the economy's ability to fend off recession without further stimulus.
The powerful consumer spending of the late 1990's was especially dependent on high stock prices -- the famed wealth effect. But the United States may be entering the reverse, a vicious circle in which falling stock prices further weaken consumer spending, and the resulting weaker economy, in turn, further weakens the stock market. 
What, then, does history truly tell us? Here is one stark fact to keep in mind. Stock prices plummeted in 1969 after the long and optimistic economic expansion of the 1960's that was similar to the 1990's in some respects. And the market did not exceed its 1969 high again, discounted for inflation, until 1992.
In other words, if you had your investments in the S.& P. 500 in 1969, it took 23 years to earn a positive real return from the movement of stocks. The "long run" can be very long indeed. 
Now, the above calculation does not include dividends. But one of the additional disturbing differences in now and 1969 is that dividend payments are on average so low today as to be almost nonexistent. The dividend yield for the S.& P. 500 at the end of 1968, when stock prices were near their highs for that run-up, was nearly 3 percent. Thus, even if stock prices fell, the average investor was at least receiving a handsome dividend. Today's average dividend yield is only about 1.2 percent, so the big gains in the future will have to come from the rising stock price itself.
The current low level of dividends, in fact, throws all historical analyses of future stock returns into doubt. But even if we set the dividend issue aside, the stock market's history is not comforting.
First, stocks on average today are still trading at relatively high multiples of their earnings. The price-earnings ratio of the S.& P. 500, based on the preceding 12 months' earnings, is currently 22.
From 1947 to 1990, the average multiple was 14. If market enthusiasm wanes further and multiples fall to the average the next five years, the earnings of the S.& P. 500 would have to rise by an unusually rapid 10 percent a year to justify current prices.
In bear markets, multiples often return to levels below their former averages. Jeremy J. Siegel, the author of "Stocks for the Long Run" (McGraw-Hill, 1997), has found that stocks, even with dividends reinvested, can make no gain after inflation for as long as 17 years. As for that so-called safe five-year period for investing in stocks, stocks have occasionally done so poorly that bonds outperformed them one of three times over that time span.
And for those who do not adequately diversify their stock portfolios, the long run provides little refuge at all.
Many investors mostly owned high-technology stocks, for example. From where it is now, the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index has to increase by approximately 25 percent a year over the next five years simply to compensate for the sharp fall of the last 12 months. Anything could happen, of course. The Nasdaq rose that fast in just two years from 1998 to 2000. But even the most optimistic analysts doubt such a frenzy will be repeated.
Mr. Siegel's basic finding was that over every 30-year period since 1871, stocks produced a handsome return that was invariably greater than the return earned by investing in bonds, and over 20-year periods, stocks outperformed bonds better than 9 of 10 times.
But the Yale economist Robert Shiller, who wrote "Irrational Exuberance" (Princeton, 2000) even warns that a 20- or 30-year holding period is not necessarily risk free.
"This was the most economically successful century for the most economically successful nation of all time," he says. "It will not necessarily repeat itself."
Some argue that now is precisely the time to invest again. But if such analysis depends on faith in history alone, there is clearly good reason to be cautious.
Nothing can replace solid analysis about the future earnings prospects of individual companies as a guide to investing. A little cautious buying might make sense now, but an investor should have plenty of patience and the financial flexibility to absorb further losses.
Our policy makers should also certainly read their history more carefully. The wealth effect has become integral to the nation's economic strength. Some investors might be able to wait 5, 10 or 20 years to make up their losses, but a falling stock market these days means the economy needs some serious stoking right away.

HEADLINE: Runoff Set for Los Angeles Mayor 

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 11 

 BODY:
For years political experts have talked about the day when this city's surging Latino population would shape the outcome of local elections. In Los Angeles this morning, there was an unavoidable feeling that that moment had arrived.
 In a crowded mayorial primary election on Tuesday, Antonio Villaraigosa, a high school dropout who went on to become speaker of the California Assembly, pieced together a multi-ethnic coalition to finish first, positioning himself for a runoff that could make him the city's first Hispanic mayor since 1872. 
 Because no candidate got a majority of the vote, Mr. Villaraigosa, who won 30 percent in a field of six major contenders, will now face City Attorney James K. Hahn, the son of a beloved local political family who is white but rode his strong support among blacks to take 25 percent of the vote. 
Steve Soboroff, a Republican businessman making his political debut, finished third with 21 percent, but he narrowly carried white neighborhoods in the traditionally conservative San Fernando Valley and the city's politically eclectic Westside. Those areas will be decisive in the nonpartisan runoff on June 5.
Mr. Villaraigosa's first-place showing reflected not only the growing power of Hispanic voters -- who made up one-fifth of the electorate, two and a half times their share just eight years ago -- but his early success in styling himself as a worthy heir to Tom Bradley, who was elected the first black mayor in 1973. Mr. Bradley built a path-breaking coalition of his own with black voters and white liberals, before the Hispanic population exploded. 
For a year, Mr. Hahn, a Democrat, as is Mr. Villaraigosa, had led in virtually all the polls. But his support stalled several weeks ago while Mr. Villaraigosa surged from the low double digits with endorsements from the state's Democratic Governor, Gray Davis, the local party organization, the city's main labor union umbrella group and a handful of local billionaires, many of them sensing that the time had come for a Hispanic mayor and that he had the best chance to win.
"This candidacy represents an opening up of this city to more people," Mr. Villaraigosa (pronounced VEE-yah-ray-GO-suh) said today at news conference in the Valley, which he called "ground zero" in the coming campaign. At the same time, Mr. Villaraigosa took pains to say, as he has throughout his campaign: "I'm not running to be first. I want to be mayor for the whole city."
The election was a remarkable turnabout for a city that only eight years ago, reeling from the 1992 riots and a punishing recession, chose Mayor Richard J. Riordan, a maverick multimillionaire Republican making his first run for public office, and then re-elected him overwhelmingly four years ago against token opposition. 
This year, Mr. Riordan's campaign team was split, with most of his political advisers backing Mr. Hahn, with whom the mayor has often tangled, and a group his wealthiest supporters, including Eli Broad, the city's richest citizen, supporting Mr. Villaraigosa.
Mr. Riordan's own chosen successor was Mr. Soboroff, and the two runoff candidates must now compete for his voters, as well as those of Joel Wachs, a veteran city councilman who has represented neighborhoods on the Westside and in the Valley and who finished fourth, with 11 percent of the vote. 
"The real battleground is going to be over those voters who were neither black nor Latino, especially white Jewish voters," said Raphael Sonsenshine, a political scientist at the California State University. "While Villaraigosa led among Jewish voters, he by no means has a majority yet."
For Mr. Hahn, 50, the challenge is to stop Mr. Villaraigosa's momentum and build beyond his base with black voters in South-Central Los Angeles, who fondly remember his father, the longtime County Supervisor Kenneth Hahn. A familiar, if often phlegmatic figure in the city's political world, Mr. Hahn must appeal to moderates and conservatives in the suburban Valley and Westside neighborhoods where he has run well in citywide campaigns since he was elected city controller in 1981 and city attorney in 1985. 
"I have experience where it counts, right here in my hometown," Mr. Hahn said today, in a preview of a campaign that seems certain to try to portray Mr. Villaraigosa, 48, as lacking local government experience and too liberal for a city with a long tradition of middle-of-the-road nonpartisanship in municipal politics. 
"I think most people consider themselves moderates," Mr. Hahn added. "They don't like labels like liberal or conservative. They look past labels and want ideas."
State and local term limits drove the dynamic of this year's contests. Mr. Riordan was barred form seeking a third term, and Mr. Hahn was barred from seeking re-election to his current job as the city's chief lawyer. Mr. Villaraigosa had to give up his seat in the State Assembly just two years after becoming speaker.
At the same time, demographic changes left whites a smaller share of the electorate, and black and Asian voters roughly stagnant, compared to eight years ago, while the Hispanic share of the electorate rose to about 21 percent from 8 percent in 1993, an all-time high, according to surveys of voters leaving the polls by The Los Angeles Times. Four years ago, Hispanic voters made up about 15 percent of the electorate, and most backed Mr. Riordan.
Jaime Regalado, executive director of the Pat Brown Institute of Public Affairs at California State University's Los Angeles campus, said that Mr. Villaraigosa's candidacy "is really ushering in the new era of politics in Los Angeles."
"People have talked for a long time about the political potential of the Latino community, but it's only been in the last four to five years that we've really seen that taking place," Mr. Regalado added. "And yet it wasn't really a base for Antonio. He ran as a coalition candidate, and he spent a lot of time for the past two years reaching out to other communities and I think he knew he had to because he wasn't even a household name in the Latino community."
while Mr. Villaraigosa won a clear majority of the overall Hispanic vote, he split it with another candidate, Representative Xavier Becerra, who took just under 20 percent of the Hispanic vote to more than 60 percent for Mr. Villaraigosa, according to voter surveys. Mr. Becerra came in fifth. State Controller Kathleen Connell finished last.

HEADLINE: COLLISION WITH CHINA: BEIJING; 
Chinese Claim a Moral Victory, Describing a Much Bigger Battle

BYLINE:  By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, April 11 

 BODY:
The Chinese government, claiming a moral victory, told its people today that the United States had offered "a form of apology" for the collision of an American spy plane and a Chinese fighter jet that cost the life of the Chinese pilot and led to the detention of the American crew.
 After more than a week of demanding that the United States offer an official apology and admit full responsibility for the incident, Chinese leaders settled for less. They accepted a letter, negotiated in English only, in which the United States told the Chinese people and the family of the lost Chinese pilot that it was "very sorry," and also said that it was "very sorry" that the crippled American aircraft had landed in China without permission. 
 But even as Beijing announced that the 24 American crew members would be released, Chinese officials implied that they had gained an apology and emphasized that "the battle is not over." They restated demands that the United States end its spy flights and explain its actions -- apparently a topic to be taken up in future talks. They also vowed to keep "investigating" the damaged aircraft, laden with advanced eavesdropping equipment, as long as necessary. 
A Foreign Ministry spokesman, Sun Yuxi, made it clear that the plane would not be returned quickly and stressed China's position that it had a legal right to conduct a full investigation of the American spy plane and the mid-air collision, which China says the American pilot caused with a sudden swerve.
Hoping to head off a possible backlash from a Chinese public that has grown increasingly angry, officials presented today's deal as a victory for Chinese dignity and world stability, sometimes stretching words in the process. In meetings today with Communist Party organizations and newspaper, radio and television editors -- intended to shape the public discussion -- party leaders said that the United States had agreed to "a form of apology," without providing the exact language.
In those meetings and in an editorial in Thursday's People's Daily, the leaders betrayed their domestic uneasiness by exhorting citizens to "turn patriotic zeal into energy for a strong country" -- that is, to rally around President Jiang Zemin's leadership and work hard at their job or studies, rather than second-guessing the deal. 
Just how the agreement will play may not be evident for days as the specific terms become more widely known among the public. Initial reactions ranged from happiness at what some understood to be an American flinch -- one university professor excitedly called a friend to say "The Americans have apologized!" -- to deep skepticism about the leadership's resolve.
"This will add to the people's existing image of Jiang Zemin -- that he talks big but is inconsistent," said an editor of a party magazine.
Random interviews offered diverse views, with a significant group still angry at the United States and disappointed in China's leaders.
"This government is so weak," said a 20-year-old bartender, who gave only his surname, Jiao. "The United States thinks it can do anything it wants to us." A 38-year-old delivery man surnamed Wu said: "Saying you're sorry isn't good enough. Americans need to know we aren't afraid of their bullying." 
Supporting the government's decision to release the crew, a 28-year-old software developer, Mr. Zhang, said: "We want to continue developing and working together with other countries in a stable environment. Our relations with America are extremely complex." 
One party official said that the real test would come in the next few months as the United States decides what kinds of weapons to sell to Taiwan despite Chinese objections, and as Beijing's bid to play host for the 2008 Summer Olympics is decided. "That's when people will look back and either say, 'They were right,' to make this compromise, or 'That shows why they can't lead,' " she said. 
Throughout the standoff, China's leaders emphasized their desire not to destroy Chinese-American relations, which they see as vital to China's economic future. In contrast to the aftermath of the 1999 bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, officials never gave permission to students who asked to demonstrate at the American Embassy. Tonight, though extra guards were at the embassy, there was no sign of protests. 
Tonight, the Chinese news media described as a victory the short English-language letter, which had been written in days of intensive talks in Beijing and Washington and was hand-delivered by Admiral Prueher to the Chinese foreign minister, Tang Jiaxuan. In the agreed English version released by the American Embassy, Mr. Preuher conveyed "sincere regret" over the missing pilot and aircraft and said "we are very sorry" about the loss of the pilot.
In a nod to China's extreme sensitivity about territorial infringements -- a product of its much-resented history of invasions by colonial powers -- the ambassador's letter also said "we are very sorry" that "the entering of China's airspace and the landing did not have verbal clearance." The point had been especially important for China -- and a fairly easy one to concede by the United States because it was technically true. 
There was no official Chinese version of the letter, a deliberate tactic that allowed for politically necessary imprecision in China's domestic presentation. The embassy provided its own translation into Chinese of the letter, which revealed the complexity of precisely translating terms of contrition. 
The letter's first, general expression of "sincere regret" over the missing pilot is rendered in the embassy's Chinese version as "chengzhi de yihan," a close equivalent of the English. Then the letter asks the foreign minister to "please convey to the Chinese people and to the family of Pilot Wang Wei that we are very sorry for their loss." This time, "very sorry" is translated as "feichang wanxi," an expression of sorrowful condolences, but not one implying culpability.
The "very sorry" expressed in the letter for the unauthorized entry into Chinese airspace during the emergency landing is translated by the Americans as "feichang baoqian," which is a strong way to say "very sorry," but stops short of the acceptance of responsibility that China had demanded. 
Nowhere did the word for a full-fledged "apology" -- daoqian in Chinese -- appear, in the English version of the letter or in the Chinese translation released by the United States, apparently on its own. But in their public descriptions of the deal and letter tonight, Chinese officials and news writers tonight used other Chinese terms for "sorry" and "regret" without providing an entire, official translation of the letter, clearly hoping to emphasize how much the United States had backed down.
While there were no published claims that the United States had actually used the term "daoqian," an account of the letter by the New China News Agency translated "very sorry" twice, using another term that can imply some culpability as well as regret: "shen biao qianyi." This literally means to deeply express regrets or an apology. 
That particular usage is not used by the embassy in its own Chinese text of the letter. But in the official news agency's largely indirect account it is put in quotation marks, as though directly from the letter, and the Foreign Ministry spokesman repeatedly used this term when describing the American letter at a news conference tonight.

CONFUSION ON POTATO BAN

BYLINE:  By Anthony DePalma 

 BODY:
 Canada accused the United States of reneging at the last minute on a decision to relax a ban on imports of potatoes from Prince Edward Island, where potato wart, a rare fungus, was found in one field last fall.

At issue is a washing requirement that Canada says is too costly. Anthony DePalma

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
EMC Joins Motorola in Earnings Shortfall

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
The EMC Corporation, the leading vendor of data storage products for business, added its influential voice yesterday morning to the chorus of companies reporting that the economy both at home and in Europe has weakened further and more rapidly than anticipated this year.
 As a result of the slowdown, EMC said, it will report earnings and revenue slightly below Wall Street's expectations when it issues its quarterly figures next Thursday. The shortfall occurred despite an all-out effort at the end of the quarter by the company's famously aggressive sales force to "defy the economy" and meet projections, said Michael C. Ruettgers, EMC's chairman. 
 At the same time EMC was issuing its warning, Motorola was telling analysts in a conference call that it would lose even more money in the second quarter than the $206 million operating loss it reported Tuesday night for the first three months of the year. 
Motorola also increased by 4,000, to 26,000, the number of jobs it plans to eliminate as part of cost-cutting efforts that began late last year. It said that investments in new factories and machinery, which topped $4.1 billion last year, had been sliced to $1.4 billion this year and that a third of that had already been spent.
In an interview after the conference call, Robert L. Growney, Motorola's president and chief operating officer, said the Federal Reserve Bank should immediately cut interest rates by 1 percent to stimulate the economy. He also urged Congress to approve the Bush administration's tax-cut proposals.
When asked whether the Democratic alternative of immediate "rebates" to poor and middle-class citizens would not be a more potent lift, Mr. Growney said Motorola supported anything "that gives consumers some dollars."
The two technology bellwethers were not entirely downbeat. Motorola predicted that it would return to profitability in its cellular phone and semiconductor businesses in the second half of the year. It projected that overall demand for cell phones would climb to 425 million to 475 million units this year, an increase from the total of 410 million last year.
And EMC said that major customers were telling it that they had finished the task of reducing technology budgets to reflect the slowdown. Based on such research, EMC told Wall Street it was confident that its revenue growth would top 20 percent this year and that earnings per share would end up modestly higher than in 2000.
Investors appeared more upset with EMC's announcement. The company, which is the clear market leader in its fast-growing segment of the technology universe, said earnings per share would be 18 cents, 10 percent lower than Wall Street's consensus projections as monitored by Thomson Financial/First Call. EMC said revenue would climb 29 percent, to $2.35 billion. EMC's shares tumbled $2.19, to $32.21, on the Big Board.
The reduced expectations for the rest of the year -- EMC had been aiming for 25 percent to 35 percent revenue growth and sharply higher profits -- were welcomed by some analysts as a bullish development. "With lower guidance, they now have the leeway to attack competitors and increase market share," said James Berlino at Merrill Lynch.
But others said they feared that the company's attempt to meet the first-quarter targets had pulled forward sales that would have occurred in the current quarter, that the company was underestimating how much it would have to cut costs to fend off competitors or that it was simply too optimistic.
"You can't count on budgets staying put in this environment," said Laura Conigliaro of Goldman, Sachs, referring to EMC's confidence that its customers had settled their spending plans for the rest of the year.
Investors in Motorola appeared to have feared that the company's outlook would be even gloomier than it turned out to be. Motorola's shares held on to most of their gains from Tuesday's trading, ending yesterday down 10 cents at $12.90.
Motorola is three times the size of EMC by sales and is far more diversified. A far greater share of its business is dependent on consumer confidence, either directly, as in the cell phone segment, or indirectly, as in the case of its sales of microchips to automakers. Analysts said that Motorola's "visibility" -- Wall Street jargon for ability to project market conditions -- was especially poor and many questioned the company's projection yesterday that it would end up with modest profits for the year.
"If you are buying for the long run, Motorola's O.K.," said Edward Snyder, who follows the company for J. P. Morgan. "But the news will probably get worse before it gets better."

HEADLINE: Judge Deals Blow to Plans For Casinos 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
A New York State judge dealt a major setback yesterday to a plan by the St. Regis Mohawk tribe to build a $500 million Las Vegas-style casino in the Catskills.
 The judge, Justice Joseph C. Teresi of State Supreme Court in Albany, ruled that Gov. George E. Pataki does not have the authority to sign gambling compacts with Indian tribes without first seeking approval from the State Legislature. 
 Governor Pataki, who had contended that he could unilaterally permit gambling operations by American Indian tribes, has long supported the development of Indian casinos in depressed former resort areas like the Catskills. The Mohawks and their partners, Park Place Entertainment, are seeking to develop their resort casino near Monticello, a town in Sullivan County that has fallen on hard times.
Despite the governor's support, proponents of gambling have long feared that casino projects will almost certainly fail in the Legislature, where Joseph L. Bruno, the majority leader in the Senate, and many upstate Republicans have long been opposed to gambling.
The decision also undermines proposed casinos in Greene County and Niagara Falls, where political leaders had hoped that gambling would revive the local economies. But it does not affect the operations of the two American Indian casinos currently operating in the state, the Oneida tribe's Turning Stone casino in Verona, about 20 miles west of Utica, and the smaller Mohawk casino on the Akwesasne reservation near the Canadian border. 
Governor Pataki's office vowed to fight the ruling.
"We're reviewing the decision," said Michael McKeon, a spokesman for the governor, "and we expect to appeal immediately."
Justice Teresi ruled that Mr. Pataki and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo before him had "crossed the line of executive power and entered into the domain of the Legislature without proper mandate or authority." He said the governor would have to obtain legislative approval before signing a gambling compact with a tribe. 
Although Indian land is considered sovereign territory and therefore is not subject to New York's prohibition of casino gambling, Justice Teresi also permanently prohibited the state from spending money to expand the Turning Stone and Akwesasne operations.
He noted that tribal gambling compacts in Kansas, Michigan, Rhode Island and New Mexico were invalidated by the highest court in each state because they lacked legislative approval.
The opponents of gambling who brought the lawsuit -- a mix of horse racing interests, Atlantic City casino operators and people who say they have moral objections to gambling -- declared victory.
"It seems to put an end to Sullivan County gambling for the near future," said Jay Goldberg, a lawyer for the antigambling groups. "The ruling affirms the power of the Legislature to speak for the people."
Donald J. Trump, for one, was jubilant. He predicted that the Legislature would be nowhere near as sympathetic to Indian casinos as the governor had been. Mr. Trump has spent hundreds of thousands of dollars lobbying against Indian casinos in New York, which might siphon patrons from his three casinos in Atlantic City.
"I think it'll be very tough to get this through the Legislature," Mr. Trump said.
Bradley S. Waterman, a lawyer for the St. Regis Mohawks, said the ruling was both "a setback and a disappointment." 
"We have some significant hurdles to negotiate," Mr. Waterman said. "Now we have one more."
Park Place executives did not immediately return phone calls seeking comment yesterday.
Only 16 days ago, the tribe had announced that it had made significant progress on its plans for a large casino and 750-room hotel at Kutsher's Resort and Country Club in Monticello, about 80 miles from New York City. The Mohawks and Park Place, the largest casino company in the world, had formally filed an application with the Bureau of Indian Affairs to transfer land to the tribe and build the casino. Governor Pataki and the federal government had not approved the new application before the justice's ruling. 
Under federal law, tribes can appeal to the Secretary of the Interior if a state refuses to permit a casino. But it is a lengthy process and the Mohawk tribal chiefs and Park Place also face lawsuits by both dissident Mohawks and the tribe's former casino partners. 
The Mohawk chiefs had rejected their longtime partners, Catskill Development, shortly after they obtained initial federal approval for a casino in Monticello a year ago. Park Place filed a new application last month for the Kutsher's location near Monticello.
The Monticello project would be the third American Indian casino in New York. Governor Cuomo approved the Oneida tribe's Turning Stone casino in the mid-1990's and signed a gambling compact with the Mohawks in 1993. Governor Pataki amended the Mohawk compact two years ago to allow video gambling machines at the reservation's casino in exchange for a state share of revenues.
But gambling opponents mounted new efforts to stop the spread of casinos, as the Mohawks' project in Monticello was nearing federal approval.
Thirteen months ago, Justice Teresi threw out two lawsuits brought by antigambling groups that accused the governor of violating the state's constitution by allowing the St. Regis Mohawks to operate a casino. Without addressing the constitutional issues, the justice ruled at that time that the suits were deficient because they did not name the Mohawks as defendants.
But last August, the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court ruled that Justice Teresi's decision to throw out the case was "harsh" and that he had abused his discretion. The court also ruled that the various antigambling groups had standing to challenge the gambling compacts.

HEADLINE: COLLISION WITH CHINA: MIDWESTERNERS; 
A Readiness to Let Bygones Be Bygones

BYLINE:  By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 11 

 BODY:
What a difference a day makes.
 On Tuesday, before China and the United States reached an agreement to allow the release of the crew of an American spy plane, people interviewed here were angry and frustrated. 
Though few were prepared to advocate a military solution to solve the crisis, many threatened to take personal economic action by boycotting Kmart and other retailers that sell Chinese-made goods. 
Yet by breakfast this morning, among Republicans and Democrats, blue- and white-collar workers and retirees, Kansas City is letting bygones be bygones. 
"I don't think the Chinese man in the street is a warmonger," said Leonard Gorter, 69, a retired insurance agent. 
Edward Story, 75, a veteran of World War II, was equally positive, and equally willing to move on. 
"I was just numb" worrying about how the dispute would be resolved, said Mr. Story, a Republican who lives in the overwhelmingly Republican suburb of Overland Park, Kan.. 
"But one thing Bush has done is surround himself with a lot of brilliant men, and ladies. We handled it correctly.
The Chinese handled it well, too, he said. "I thought they would stall a month or two," he said. "As for the plane, you can scratch that off. The Chinese will take it apart, and we won't get anything back but the hubcaps." If it had been a Chinese plane in American territory, he said, "we'd be all over it too, like a bunch of ants."
Outside a Kmart on the north side of the Missouri River, Dave Saunders, 57, a self-employed appliance repairman, welcomed the return of the crew. Though he did not vote for George W. Bush, he praised the president. 
"I think Bush handled it as well as could be expected," he said. "I think we should get the plane back, but I don't think we should go to war over it."
He added that he would probably avoid purchasing Chinese-made goods from the Kmart behind him -- but not because of this month's dispute. 
Buying American products protects American jobs, he said. There was also the question of quality: "If it's for permanent use, I buy American made."
Around Kansas City, the nature of the American apology was a subject of debate. 
"You can't just say, 'Sorry the accident happened,' " said Pam St. Thomas, 44, of Olathe, Kan., a Kansas City suburb, who was having lunch at a mall.
At another table Margaret Fancher, 53, whose son was wounded in Desert Storm, disagreed. "To say 'I won't apologize' is ridiculous," she said before the wording of the American statement was published. "I would hope we would be more humble."
But with peace and commerce at stake, people found they could be flexible. 
On Tuesday, after President Bush expanded his expressions of regret to encompass the plane's unauthorized landing on Chinese soil, Jim Gilmore, owner of a State Farm insurance office in Overland Park, and his daughter, Lori Emerick, the office manager, had mixed feelings about apologizing.
By this morning, however, both felt Mr. Bush and China had settled on a suitable compromise. 
"We didn't apologize," Mr. Gilmore said. "It was like bumping into each other in the elevator. You say 'Sorry' or 'Excuse me.' That's basically all we did. In my view, Bush handled it just perfectly."
Ms. Emerick, 34 and an Air Force veteran, said that on Tuesday, she was prepared to join the boycott. "But no, not now," she said. 
Besides, her own household economy today is bound up with China's. "If American goods are available," she said, "I will still buy them. But half the time they're not there."

GRAPHIC: Photos: In and around Kansas City, Mo., anger at China seemed to evaporate quickly yesterday after an agreement to release the 24 Americans. From left, three residents: Dave Saunders, Lori Emerick and Edward Story. (Photographs by Roy Inman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COLLISION WITH CHINA: NEWS ANALYSIS; 
Taiwan Arms Sales and China's W.T.O. Application Will Test a Relationship

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11 

 BODY:
Now that the Bush administration has resolved its first diplomatic test with China, an important question remains about what the episode says about the administration's still-evolving China policy and the relationship between the countries. 
 Within the next few weeks, the relationship faces two tests as the Bush administration must decide which weapons systems to sell to Taiwan and how to reignite China's stalled drive to join the World Trade Organization. 
 The release of the spy plane's crew almost certainly means that the incident will not create a permanent rift in Sino-American relations, and might even serve a positive end by reminding both sides that they stand to lose a great deal unless they begin a major push to find common ground, several American diplomats and China experts said today.
"There is no way to get away from this without some residue, mainly the public attitudes toward us in China and our public's attitude toward China," said Samuel R. Berger, who served as national security adviser under President Clinton. "But the people who believe in relations between these two countries prevailed over those who see it only in nationalistic terms, and I think that's a positive sign." 
James R. Lilley, a former United States ambassador to China, said that every recent American president, whether by accident or miscalculation, "gets himself in a terrible mess with China to start things off." 
The silver lining, he said, is that a sharp slide in relations usually prompts a frantic scramble to consult each other more, to open lines of communications and to consider each other's strategic interests. President Reagan, President Bush and President Clinton each began terms with a China crisis, and each left saying he had built a much closer relationship than the one he had at the start of their terms. 
"I think you're going to see this administration reaching out to China on North Korea, on the W.T.O., and on a range of strategic and economic issues," Mr. Lilley said. "China badly needs to be included in these efforts, and we badly need to have a strategic dialogue with China." 
The broader question for Sino-American relations is whether incidents like the spy plane episode and the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, as well as disagreements over Taiwan and human rights, are manageable rifts that distract from an otherwise solid relationship. If not, the almost seemingly endless succession of crises is likely to have a cumulative impact, like a roller coaster on which the uphill climb keeps getting longer and the downhill plunge steeper. 
"I think we should view this mainly as a diplomatic management problem," said Stapleton Roy, a longtime State Department Asia expert and former China ambassador. It is a "period in which all kinds of episodes need to be handled, and the question is whether they will be handled skillfully." 
Other experts said the latest episode is unlikely to be forgotten quickly. The involvement of American military personnel brings the strains in relations home to average American more vividly than any crisis since Tiananmen Square, which received weeks of saturation coverage by network television and made China's political instability a household concern. The tone of the relationship, at least for a time, should reflect American concerns about China's direction, these people said.
"I think our response going forward has to be quite cool," said Winston Lord, a former China ambassador and State Department official who oversaw East Asia policy during the earlier Clinton administration. "We need to make it clear to the Chinese that there's a residue of annoyance over their performance." 
Mr. Lord said the two sides should try to restore a full dialogue on international strategic issues, including nuclear issues in South Asia and stability in the Persian Gulf, but that the Bush team should not give China the impression that the two sides are back to business as usual.
In some ways, President Bush had already put China on notice that it could not expect the same sort of attentive diplomacy it received at the end of Mr. Clinton's term. Mr. Bush came to office saying he had abandoned the Clinton administration's aspiration to make China a "strategic partner." Instead, he called the nation a "strategic competitor," a term that translates harshly in Chinese. 
The change in tone was similar to vows by President Reagan and President Clinton to change the terms of the relationship with China. Mr. Reagan told the Chinese that he intended to stand firmly behind America's old friends in Taiwan, China's rival, which prompted diplomatic warring that ended only after Mr. Reagan signed the Shanghai Communique in 1982, a document in which the United States promised to phase out arms sales to the island.
Mr. Clinton came to office promising to challenge China on human rights and to link China's treatment of its own people to the extension of its trading privileges. That approach quickly backfired when the Chinese jailed several dissidents and effectively challenged the United States to withdraw its trading rights. Mr. Clinton ended up abandoning the link.
Wordplay did not cause the accident over the South China Sea. But some experts said it showed how even subtle changes in approach could strain ties.
Jiang Zemin, the Chinese president, had to corral growing anti-American sentiment in his own leadership ranks, a task made harder by the perception that the United States had downgraded China ties and taken a tougher line on a range of diplomatic issues. "The Bush administration in its early comments may have been talking to the American right, but that hardened some positions in China," Mr. Berger said.
Many other experts gave high marks to Mr. Bush and his top aides for their handling of the incident. "Judicious, careful, firm," was Mr. Lilley's review. Mr. Roy said he thought Mr. Bush managed this episode better than Mr. Clinton handled the Belgrade embassy bombing.
But the next few weeks will bring fresh tests. The most sensitive is how to handle Taiwan's annual request to buy arms. Taiwan has long hoped to purchase the Aegis missile defense system, while China has said it will consider that sale an egregious affront to its sovereignty. A decision is expected later this month.
Most China watchers had been expecting Mr. Bush to sell Taiwan several items on its weapons wish list, but not the Aegis. But one former Clinton administration official who has studied the question said the administration may now decide to sell the Aegis system as a way of demonstrating that there was no quid pro quo for the release of the American military personnel.
"I think this incident could and perhaps should up the ante on Taiwan," the official said.
Mr. Lilley said that the arms sales question threatened to send the two nations into a fresh round of crisis management. But he said the Bush administration should find a way to delay the decision until tempers cool and the new administration has a chance to study options in depth.
The Bush team had been working to restore momentum in another area of common interest: China's bid to join the World Trade Organization. Negotiations in Geneva stalled over a variety of issues, including agricultural subsidies, and some experts feel China has delayed its final accession to the trade group because it is not ready to carry out the concessions it has made to gain entry.

HEADLINE: COLLISION WITH CHINA: NEWS ANALYSIS; 
China's Bonus: Attention, and Respect

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, April 11 

 BODY:
As the American crew members head home, the Chinese must be satisfied with the spoils of their latest run-in with the United States. The Chinese government acquired secrets from the downed spy plane, of course, but also something far more coveted: attention from the new Bush administration, and a bit of respect. 
 Ever since George W. Bush took office in January, with the promise to downgrade China's standing in America's Asia policy, Chinese ranging from ministry officials to street vendors had felt diminished and insulted. 
 Chinese consider their country an emerging power, and were pleased that the Clinton administration treated it as such. 
But the Bush administration had paid so little heed to China that it has no high-level China experts in its ranks -- a handicap last week, when the 24 Americans abruptly found themselves detained on Chinese soil. The administration lacked familiarity with Chinese politics and senior staff members experienced in negotiating with Beijing.
Now, with the spy plane incident resolved and President Bush himself calling for a "fruitful and productive relationship," many Chinese believe that the new American president is coming around.
"I think people are becoming happier with President Bush," said Xiao Gongqin, a professor of history and a social commentator at Shanghai Normal University. "He is shifting from his initial stance about China as he has learned more about our country and had more experience with it -- just as President Clinton did."
Mr. Clinton was also elected on a promise to get tough with China, but by his second term was touting a "strategic partnership," cultivating closer diplomatic and economic ties.
Dali Yang, a political scientist at the University of Chicago said, "Before, from President Bush, it was just 'they're competitors,' and they deliberately excluded China people from the administration. Now channels are open and they are learning that this relationship requires a lot of attention and adaptation."
The Chinese have good reason to feel offended, many scholars say.
Most of the highest-ranking Bush foreign policy appointments are cold war veterans, more familiar with the former Soviet Union. The senior Asia advisers are specialists in Japan, Indonesia or Taiwan.
The appointee with the most China experience is Adm. Joseph W. Prueher, the American ambassador, who came to Beijing as a neophyte two years ago. While he has won high marks for his work since then, he is a holdover from the Clinton administration with just a few weeks left on the job.
"The current U.S. regime hasn't taken China seriously -- they haven't even regarded it as a player," said Anthony J. Saich, a China specialist at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government.
That dismissive attitude was confirmed for many Chinese by Mr. Bush's brusque initial remarks after the collision between the American spy plane and a Chinese fighter jet, in which a Chinese pilot was lost. He demanded a prompt return of the American plane and crew and later insisted there would be no apology. 
"The Americans are so willful to demand that we release the crew and return the plane," said Wu Shenyi, a driver for a Beijing company, last week. "They think we are soft persimmons. But we are not!
"I hope this time President Jiang will stiffen his spine," he said, referring to China's president, Jiang Zemin.
But Chinese analysts said the public anger was both predictable and avoidable. And that Mr. Bush's initially harsh public statements undercut President Jiang, who has promoted closer ties with the United States, and narrowed the Chinese leader's room to negotiate.
"They don't really understand China, so they don't know how to deal with it" said Xiong Zhiyong, dean of China's Foreign Affairs College. Private discussions, he said, would probably have been more effective than public accusations. "Hopefully they have learned from this -- hopefully both sides have."
But this incident has provided the Bush administration with a crash course in Chinese sensibilities.
Lesson One involved China's heightened sense of national pride and grievance, nurtured by its modern history of foreign domination.
"China has a long history of occupation by foreign powers and so nationalism is a very big force here," Professor Xiao said. "So when a foreign plane is skirting around our borders, we're sensitive -- some might say too sensitive -- about that."
Nationalism has only intensified with the waning of Communist ideology. "The Americans should know that the life of the Chinese pilot is as precious as their crew members, and he'll be forever remembered as our national hero," Zhang Wei, an office worker at Capital Normal University, said this past weekend. "I'm not calling for blood debts to be paid in blood, but the U.S. government must act in ways that cool this indignation."
Another lesson is that diplomatic solutions must allow China to maintain face, both before the outside world and its own people. American planes were spying along China's border, a Chinese pilot was dead. And many Chinese were offended that Mr. Bush had not even picked up his hotline, set up by Presidents Jiang and Clinton in 1998, to try to work things out.
They noted that after NATO warplanes bombed the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade in 1999, Mr. Clinton called Mr. Jiang on the hotline -- although the latter refused to take the call.
When negotiations seemed at a standstill, many Chinese said it was obvious how to break the impasse.
"President Bush needs to send a special envoy -- someone important -- to China to deal with the crisis," a liberal foreign policy writer said. "This is not about an airplane, it's about face, and China needs a signal that it is taken seriously." 
In the last few days, with the round-the-clock negotiations and expressions of regret, Mr. Bush was giving the Chinese a bit more of what they wanted. China mattered.
"The Americans might have felt there's not reason to apologize since they feel there's been no error," said Wang Su, a university student, while acknowledging that culpability might be difficult to sort out.
"But we feel this incident occurred and we suffered a loss. So why not give the government some face with an apology?"

HEADLINE: Green Calls for Efforts to Make Brooklyn a Hub of City Business 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Mark Green called yesterday for economic incentives, including changes in zoning and tax laws, to transform downtown Brooklyn into an economic hub in New York. One of four Democrats hoping to succeed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in the fall election, Mr. Green said Mr. Giuliani's economic policies had favored Manhattan and had failed to prepare the city for the emerging digital economy. 
 Mr. Green, the city's public advocate, delivered his address in Manhattan, where he lives, but he devoted much of it to ways to help Brooklyn, the city's most populous borough, saying it was best situated to become the third center of business activity in the city. 
 The 29-minute speech, which his aides described as a major economic policy address, was delivered to a small audience of students and supporters in a lecture room at Baruch College, and was largely low-key except for its attacks on Mr. Giuliani's economic policies. Mr. Green said that, New York's recent economic boom notwithstanding, City Hall had done "next to nothing" to compete for what Mr. Green called "I.T.," or information technology.
"When is a cogent, innovative, future-oriented strategy and vision for our city and region coming from City Hall?" Mr. Green asked. "There is none. Other cities are planning to attract digital firms and biofirms while we are fiddling around with stadiums and skyboxes."
He said Brooklyn could be transformed into a major business district if the city changed zoning regulations that strictly separate residential and manufacturing districts.
Mr. Green's remarks drew a rebuke from Mr. Giuliani's press secretary, Sunny Mindel. Pointing out that Mr. Green was a part of the Dinkins administration, when the city lost 340,000 jobs, Ms. Mindel said, "It's somewhat odd and unseemly that Mark Green would criticize the Giuliani administration, during which growth in New York has been consistent and outpaced the rest of the country." 
The other Democratic candidates for mayor -- Peter F. Vallone, Fernando Ferrer and Alan G. Hevesi -- also drew attention to their candidacies yesterday. Mr. Vallone, the City Council speaker, introduced legislation to require the police to disclose monthly statistics on stop-and-frisks, traffic stops, police misconduct and other activities, broken down by race and gender. 
Campaign aides to Mr. Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, criticized Bruce J. Teitelbaum, a senior political adviser to Mr. Giuliani and a supporter of Mr. Hevesi, for telling The Jewish Week, a New York newspaper, that Jewish voters should be concerned that so many Dinkins supporters were now backing Mr. Ferrer. He added that if Jewish community leaders are asked how they were treated during the Dinkins administration, "They will say, 'Not well.' "
John Del Cecato, a spokesman for Mr. Ferrer, described the remarks as "shamefully divisive and polarizing" and called on Mr. Hevesi to repudiate them. Mr. Hevesi said he "disagreed very strongly" with Mr. Teitelbaum, adding: "I think these are very unhelpful and divisive remarks and he should not have said them."

HEADLINE: Is This the Budget We Want? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Freezing Government" (editorial, April 11): 
 I fail to see how President Bush's budget request limiting growth in spending for discretionary social programs to "only 4 percent" is such a problem. 
You seem to criticize the fact that under Mr. Bush's plan, the rate of growth in government spending does not outstrip inflation.
I see a problem with the fact that government spending has grown faster than the rate of economic growth and the rate of inflation during the Clinton years. Income taxes as a proportion of gross domestic product are higher now than ever. Americans are paying nearly as high a percentage of the G.D.P. in all federal taxes now as they did in 1944 at the height of World War II.
Given that situation, it seems bizarre to criticize a budget that "only" increases discretionary spending by the approximate rate of inflation.

HOWARD DEUTSCH
Princeton, N.J., April 11, 2001
